\lx Ambaya
\mr ambaya
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd people
\sd tribe and language
\lt name of people whose country is to west of Waanyi country and name of their language
\ge Wambaya
\re
\so RS
\xv Badbarini, Kudanji-anyi, Ambaya-anyi.
\xe Badbarini (rockhole) belongs to the Kudanji and Wambaya.
\rf rs2004-05
\xv Junuu, mudumbanyi, budangkun lajibi, yanyi yalungi, Kudanji, banga Ambaya. Budangku ngamba lajibi nana yanyi yalungi. Mudumbanyi ngamba.
\xe Don't know, ignorant, can't understand their language, Kudanji and Wambaya. We don't understand that language of theirs. We don't know it.
\rf rs2004-05
\xv Jingili burrurri. Ambaya burrurri.
\xe Jingili man. Wambaya man.
\rf rs2002-06
\xv Midiba nana Ambaya-anyi.
\xe That Midiba (place name) belongs to Wambaya (people).
\rf rs2002-04
\va
\sy
\cf
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt 30/Oct/2006


\lx -anyi
\mr -anyi
\hm 1
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun suffix
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt Dative case
\ge belonging to
\ge for
\ge of
\ge to
\ge till
\ge until
\re
\so EF, RS, GB, EK
\xv
\xe
\rf
\xv Danyalamba ngawu ninya balungka-anyi, jukulii.
\xe I bashed you till you bled, with a boomerang.
\rf rs2002-03
\xv Yakujbu! Yingka-anyi, burrurri-anyi.
\xe Leave it! It belongs to another man.
\rf rs2000-08
\xv Budangku ngawu wanami-anyi.
\xe I don't have any water.
\rf rs
\xv Budangku yalu windijbi nurriyanya namirra-anyi.
\xe They don't give us any money.
\rf rs2003-01
\xv Kunyba nayi kundan nangkanyi ngalya-anyi.
\xe This bush is good for this sickness.
\rf RS
\va -kanyi
\va -nyi
\va -wanyi
\va -yanyi
\sy
\cf -wurru
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt 04/Sep/2006

\lx -anyi
\mr
\hm
\sv
\sf
\sn
\ps verb suffix
\pc
\sd grammar
\la
\lt Irrealis mood
\ge could
\ge might
\ge should
\ge want to
\ge will
\re
\so
\xv Budangku nyulu, baba-anyi, kananganja.
\xe Emus can't fly.
\rf IS_GB
\xv Nanganja-anyi ngawu kunda, dajkanyi ngawu nan dara.
\xe I'll get a stick to hit this dog.
\rf MF_GB76
\xv Nayi wululuku, jungku-anyi nyulu nayi bayungu.
\xe This old man, he's got to stay in the west.
\rf rs2005-08a
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\va -kanyi
\sy
\cf ja-
\an
\nt In a clause negated by {budangku} the irrealis form of the main verb is mostly used in speech of earliest sources, recorded in the 1960s and 1970s. In later recordings the realis verb form is mostly used.
\cp
\nq
\dt
\lf


\lx baba
\mr baba
\sf baba.wav
\sf babaa.wav
\ps verb
\pc baba.jpg
\sn 1
\sd motion
\lt move through air quickly
\ge fly
\re
\so RS, EK, GB
\xv Babaa nyulu.
\xe It flies.
\rf EK2008
\xv Babaa nyulu julaki. Baba-wurru, lajibi ngawu.
\xe The plane is flying. I can hear it flying.
\rf rs2005-05
\xv Babaa nurri kingkarri jujuu.
\xe We flew way up high.
\rf rs2005-06
\xv Babaa nurri kajalaba kingkarri. Bala-wurru.
\xe We fly up towards the sky.
\rf rs2005-06
\xv Baba-kanyi nyulu.
\xe He'll fly.
\rf rs2004-04
\xv Babana nyulu jilaba. Burrbijbi nyulu.
\xe It's flying past. It's moving fast.
\rf rs2004-04
\xv Budangku nyulu, baba-anyi, kananganja.
\xe Emus can't fly.
\rf GB
\va
\sy
\cf babararra
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt 18/Sep/2006
\lf babaa
\lf baba-anyi
\lf babana
\lf baba-wurru

\lx babakana
\mr babakana
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd artifact
\lt stone knife
\ge stone knife
\re
\so RS, GB, JD
\xv Mirramba yalu babakana. Daba yalu karaa. Ramijbi yalu. Ngukujaba yalu yamarrina barri.
\xe They used to make stone knives. They would strike them with a rock and break them (in two). They would sharpen it on a flat rock.
\rf rs2002-04
\va
\sy
\cf KALIKALI
\cf kangkarinya
\nt Dymock (1993) specifies as 'white stone knife' (probably made of white chert)
\cp
\nq
\dt 12/Sep/2006



\lx badada
\mr bardada ~ bardarda
\sf badada.wav
\ps noun
\pc newborn_baby.jpg
\sd people
\lt new baby
\ge baby
\re
\so EF, GB, RS, JD, MF_SK
\xv Badada nyulu kudijbi.
\sfx badada-nyulu-kudiijbi.wav
\xe The baby is sleeping.
\rf EF
\xv Winjakanyi na lakija? Nanangkanyi badada-yudu-kanyi.
\xe Whose is this coolimon? (It) belongs to that one (woman) with the baby.
\rf GB
\xv Wikijbi nyulu miya, badada-yangka.
\xe A snake is crawling near the baby.
\rf GB
\xv Mularri nana badadan!
\xe Pick up that baby!
\rf GB
\xv Wanyinkanyi ninji badadan ngindingindijbi?
\sfx
\xe Why did you make the baby cry?
\rf GB
\xv Badada-yangkurru.
\xe Deceased child.
\rf GB
\xv Balyanga ngindimi, badada!
\xe Don't cry, baby!
\rf GB
\xv Ngaraba nyulu badadaa.
\sfx
\xe The baby is suckling (drinking).
\rf EF_EMR299A1
\va
\sy bulumirri
\cf bulungu
\cf wawurra
\nt Also used for young of animals, e.g., kid, lamb
\cp
\nq
\dt
\lf badada-yudu

\lx badakalinya
\mr bardakalinya
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc 
\sd animal
\sd mammal
\sd marsupial
\la Osphranter antilopinus
\la Osphranter rufus
\lt 
\ge Plains Kangaroo
\ge Red Kangaroo
\ge Antelopine Kangaroo
\re 
\so RS, GB, JD, GW
\xv
\xe
\rf
\va
\sy maraji
\sy marraji
\cf bidirrika
\cf junabu
\cf nangurrbuwarra
\nt Dymock (1993) records as 'Red Kangaroo'
\nt Described by Ivy George as "big long-legged one"
\nt Breen records as "sandhill kangaroo" possibly same as {maraji}
\cp Ganggalida {bardagalinya} Macropus rufus or robustus; Garrwa
\nq
\dt 28/Oct/2006

\lx badawamba
\mr badawa-mba
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd
\lt
\ge bore hole in
\ge cut through
\ge perforate
\ge pierce through
\ge wound
\ge open (up)
\re bore hole
\re perforate
\re pierce
\so RS
\xv Mayi nyulu karrbijbi ninya nukami, malangkarrii. Badawamba kalarrangi, badawamba nukamin.
\xe The sheet of iron might cut into your feet. It might pierce a hole right through the feet. 
\rf rs2005-06

\lx badibadi
\mr badibadi
\sf badibadi_RS.wav
\sf badibadi_CO.wav
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd PEOPLE
\lt old person
\ge old woman
\ge old man
\ge elderly
\re old
\re elderly
\so GB, RS, EK, CO, JD
\xv Durrajba nyulu, mayi nyulu burrurru, ngaki ngada-nganja. Durrajba nyulu badibadi, ngaki ngada-nganja.
\xe She's frightened she might fall, my mother is. The old woman is frightened, my mother that is.
\rf rs2005-01
\xv Ngaki kangku wululuku, badibadi. 
\xe My old grandfather is elderly.
\rf rs2005-02
\xv Ngabama ninji waliji nayi, maman. Nanangkurru badibadi-wurru. ngandaarra-wurru. Balikajba nyulu. 
\xe You take this meat and tucker over to that old person. To that old woman. She's hungry.
\rf rs2000-09
\xv Kudajba nyulu wululuku, badibadi. Slim Dusty. Budangku barri nyulu birajba nana badibadi wululuku.
\xe He died that old fellow, the old man, Slim Dusty. That old man, he doesn't sing any more.
\rf rs2002-02
\xv Ngaki mungkuji, Karrwa, nana-waan badibadi, wululuku.
\xe My relations are Garrwa, those old women and old men.
\rf rs2004-05
\xv Ngabama ninji walijin, nanangkurru. Badibadi, windijbi ninji badibadi.
\xe Take the meat over to that one. The old woman, you give it to the old woman.
\rf rs09
\va
\sy wululuku
\cf malbu
\cf ngandaarra
\nt
\cp Wambaya {bardibardi}
\nq  
\dt 29/Sep/2006

\lx bajalijbi
\mr bajali-j-bi
\sf bajalijbi.wav
\sf bajalijbi02.wav
\ps verb
\pc 
\sd perception
\lt Xerg draw in air through nose to perceive odour of Y
\ge smell
\ge sniff
\re 
\so EF, RS, EK, GB
\xv Bajalijbi nyulu nukami daraa.
\xe The dog is smelling  (his) tracks.
\rf rs2005-01
\xv Wanami nyulu bajalijbi, muluu.
\xe He was sniffing petrol through his nose.
\rf rs2005-08a
\xv Bajalijbi nyulu warrki jila-kurru.
\xe He smells a dingo coming.
\rf rs2002-04
\xv Bajalijbi ngaka manin.
\xe I can smell my hands.
\rf rs2000-09
\xv Bajalijbi nurri nayi yilaka. Kunyba nayi kundan nangkanyi ngalya-anyi.
\xe We sniff these leaves as this bush is good for this sickness.
\rf RS
\xv Bajaliwa nan walijin.
\xe Smell this meat.
\rf GB
\xv Bajalijbi ngayu waliji. Dabarraba nayi walijin. Ngurrburr waliji nayi.
\xe I can smell meat. The meat is cooking here. This meat smells bad.
\rf EK (ML notes)
\xv Bajalijbi nyulu warrkii mulu-yudii.
\xe The dingo smells it with his nose.
\rf EK (ML notes)
\va
\sy
\cf bajba
\nt
\cp
\nq 
\dt 30/Apr/2009
\lf bajaliwa

\lx bajangu
\mr bajangu
\sf bajangu-dog.wav
\sf bajangu02-dog.wav
\ps noun
\pc dog.jpg
\sd animal
\lt dog
\ge dog
\re
\so EF, RS, GB, JD
\xv Winjikanyi nana bajangun? Budangku ngamba jirringkijbi.
\xe Who does that dog belong to? We don't recognize it.
\rf rs2005-06
\xv Mama nyulu jarrba balikajini, bajanguu.
\xe The dog is hungrily eating the food.
\rf rs2005-06
\va
\sy burawa
\sy dara
\cf kujukuju
\cf warrki
\nt Garrwa word for dog, image also for burawa
\cp Garrwa; possibly derived from Warluwarra *bajangu 'biter'
\nq 
\dt 24/Oct/2006


\lx bajawaja
\mr bajawaja
\sf bajawajaa.wav
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd contact (impact and violence)
\lt
\ge thrash around
\ge kick around
\ge flap about
\ge throw a fit
\ge lash out at
\re thrash around
\so RS
\xv Duka-nanja nyulu marijbi. Bajawaja nyulu, wadaban. Kudumanjaa nyulu marijbi.
\xe It (dog) grabbed it (goanna) by the neck. The goanna thrashed around, but it (the dog) kept hold of it.  
\rf rs2005-01
\xv Kudumanjaa nyulu bijbi, bajawaja-wurru.
\xe He kept a grip on it with his mouth (i.e., biting) while it thrashed around.
\rf rs2005-01
\xv Mayi ninya burra-daba, wanuu. Mayi ninji bajawajaa.
\sfx mayi ninya burra-daba#wanuu.wav
\sfx mayi ninji bajawajaa.wav
\xe The tobacco, it might knock you out. You might throw a fit.
\rf rs2005-04
\xv Bajawaja nyulu ngindini.
\xe He was thrashing around crying.
\rf rs2004-03
\xv Najba nungka bajawaja-wurru. Bajawaja nyulu nana kaku.
\xe You and I can see it thrashing about. That fish is thrashing about.
\rf rs2004-04
\xv Bajawajana nyulu ngindii wanaminin, ngada-nganja-anyi.
\xe He's crying and kicking around in the water, wanting his mother.
\rf rs2004-05
\xv Bajawaja, ninji wululuku.
\sfx bajawajaa ninji wululuku.aif
\xe You'll be thrashing around, old man.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Kudumanja nyulu marrijbi, ngala nyulu bajawaja.
\xe He kept a grip on it while it thrashed around (trying to get away).
\rf RS
\va bajiwaji [GB]
\sy
\cf jayajayajba
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt 17/Oct/2006
\lf bajawajana
\lf bajawaja-wurru

\lx -baji
\mr -baji
\sf
\sn 1
\ps suffix
\pc
\sd grammar (derivational)
\lt characterised by behaviour associated with N
\ge noted for
\ge having
\re characterised by 
\so RS, EF, GB, CO
\xv Kiji-baji.
\sfx
\xe Trouble-maker.
\rf rs, EF, CO
\xv Bijbi nyulu ngaan kijibajii. 
\xe The cheeky one (ant) bit me.
\rf rs2004-04
\xv Wadaba-baji.
\sfx wardaba_bajiF.wav
\xe Goanna-hunter.
\rf EF_R299AE2
\xv Ngaki dara, wadaba-baji.
\xe My dog is a (good) goanna-hunter.
\rf EF_R299AE2
\xv Waku-baji.
\xe Fast mover
\xe smart
\xe clever
\xe quick minded.
\rf RS
\xv Kaku-baji.
\xe Fisherman.
\rf CO
\xv Jumbuuna-baji.
\xe Good goanna hunter.
\rf GB
\va
\sy
\cf -yudu
\nt Limited use, mostly only found in fixed expressions.
\cp Wambaya {-baji} 'privative'
\nq

\lx bakamba
\mr baka-mba
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd contact (impact and violence)
\sd effect
\lt Xerg forces way through Y
\ge bust through
\ge bust out of
\ge break out of
\ge emerge
\ge escape from
\re bust out of
\re emerge
\re escape
\re
\so RS
\xv Bakamba nyulu, wadabaa, nangangini kuwii. Lalujbu nyulu, jilaba barri nyulu.
\xe The goanna busts through (from its burrow) using its head. It comes out and it walks around.
\rf rs2002-14
\va
\sy
\cf kalarrangi
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt 12/Sep/2006

\hm

\lx bakarrijbi
\mr bakarri-j-bi
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd ELEMENTS
\sd fire
\lt Xerg cause Y to burn
\ge burn
\ge light (fire)
\ge set fire to
\ge ignite
\re burn
\so RS, GB
\xv Jangu barri yalu bakarrijbi. 
\xe They then light a fire.
\rf rs2005-01
\xv Kudumanjaa yalu bakarrijbi nana kanba, kunburrkii.
\xe They keep on setting fire to that grass using a firestick.
\rf rs2005-01
\xv Budangku yalu kannga mukura-yudu. Yakujbu yalu. Ramiramba yalu, ramiramba mukuran. Bakarrijbi yalu, bakarrijbi yalu jangunu.
\xe They didn't go back with the spears (after a revenge party). They would leave them there. They would smash them up, smash up the spears. They would burn them, burn them in the fire.
\rf rs2002-03
\xv Janguu ngaan bakarrijbi nukamin, danyali. Nijbijbi ngawu. Budangku ngawu najba. Bakarrijbi nyulu ngaan.
\xe The hot coals burned me on the foot. I stood on it, I didn't see it. It burned me.
\rf rs2003-05
\xv Bakarrijbi ngawu ninya kunburrkii.
\xe I'll burn you with a fire-stick.
\rf rs2003-05
\xv Bakarrijbi ngawu ninya jungkinya.
\xe I'll burn your back.
\rf rs2003-05
\xv Bakarrijbi niyangka kunburrkii janguu.
\xe We'll burn each other with burning sticks
\rf rs2003-05
\xv Janguu nyulu bakarrijbi karila.
\sfx
\xe He brands it (on) the hip with a hot (iron).
\rf RS
\va
\sy karrijbi
\cf jangkaranyi
\cf jangu
\cf rajba
\cf wukarrijbi
\nt Breen records as Garrwa word
\cp
\nq
\dt 17/Oct/2006

\sn 2

\pc

\lt tool made from forked piece of wood or other substance
\ge hook
\ge forked stick
\re hook
\so RS
\xv Nanganja yalu nguli bala wadaba-wunyi.
\xe They used to get a hooked bone from a goanna (to use to catch fish).
\rf rs2005-03
\xv Barrawu-wurru nyulu kannga bala-anyi, kaku-anyi.
\xe She's gone back to town to get hooks (to catch) fish with.
\rf rs2005-06
\xv Jariyamba nyulu bala. Kakuu nyulu jariyamba janyini.
\xe It took the hook away. The fish took it away in its mouth.
\rf rs2005-06
\xv Kiinyba nyulu janyini, nana bala.
\xe That hook is stuck in its mouth.
\rf rs2005-08b
\xv Nijbi yalu walijin balana. Balana yalu nijbi, kaku-anyi.

\lx balikaajba
\mr balikaa-j-ba
\sf balikajba.wav
\sf balikajba02.wav
\sf balikajini.wav
\ps verb
\pc
\sd bodily function
\lt X be hungry
\ge be hungry
\so RS, GB, EF, EK, MB_LH13
\xv Balikaajba ngawu.
\sfx balikajba_ngawu-I'm_hungry.wav

\xe I'm hungry.
\rf RS-RG1999
\xv Balikaajba nyulu, nayi kadimirra. Juka nyulu balikaajba waliji-anyi, mama-anyi.
\xe He's hungry, this little boy. The little lad is hungry for meat and vegetables.
\rf rs2005-03
\xv Balikaajba nyulu muwa, wada-anyi.
\xe His stomach is hungry for food.
\rf rs2005-02
\xv Darrandarra, dakalijbi nyulu balikaajini. Dakalijbi nyulu kaku-anyi, kuujini kaku-anyi.
\xe The Diver Duck, it ducks down (under the water) when it's hungry. It dives down to get fish, looking for fish.
\rf rs2005-02
\xv Jilaba nimba nangkurru. Mukunjana-anyi. Ngila-wiya, balikaajba nimba.
\xe You two go to him, for lunch. You two girls are hungry.
\rf rs2002-03
\xv Ngindii nyulu, kuujbu nyulu ngada-nganja-anyi, balikaajba nyulu ngabulu-anyi.
\xe He's crying, he's looking for his mother, (as) he's hungry for milk.
\rf rs2000-10
\xv Ngaki waliji ngawu jarrba balikaajini.
\sfx
\xe I'll eat my meat as I'm hungry.
\rf EF_R299AE2
\xv Ninya, kiya ngawu ninya windijbi walijii balikaajkurru.
\sfx ninya_kiyangawuninyawindijbF.wav
\xe You, I would have given you meat when you were hungry.
\rf EF_R299AE2
\xv Windijbi ngawu ninya waliji-yanyi balikaajkurru.
\xe I gave you meat as you were hungry.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Ngaki walijin, ngawu jarrba, balikaajini.
\sfx
\xe My meat, I'm eating it as I'm hungry.
\rf EF_R299EA3
\va balikajba
\va balikayajba

\lx balungka

\sn

\pc

\lt
\ge blood
\re

\xe I bashed you till you bled, with a boomerang.

\xe You've got blood pouring down (on you).
\rf rs2002-03
\xv Balungkana nangka nijbi.
\xe He sticks it (feather down) on himself with blood.
\rf GB
\xv Kunjunu balungka nanganginbunu.
\xe He has blood on his body. (Lit. On body (is) blood on him.)

\xv Daba ngawu balungka-anyi.
\xe I hit him and made him bleed.
\rf GB

\sfx
\xe His nose is bleeding.

\lf balungka-anyi

\lf balungka-yudu

\lx balyanga
\mr balyanga
\sf
\sn 1
\ps particle
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt particle used with imperative verb to make a negative command
\ge don't
\ge not
\re
\so EF, GB, RS, MB_LH14
\xv Balyanga jakajba. Jungku nyulu nayi.
\xe Don't hunt him away. He's staying here.
\rf rs2000-10
\xv Balyanga nanganja. Yakujbu. Yingka-anyi, burrurri-anyi.
\xe Don't take it. Leave it. It belongs to another man.
\rf rs2000-08
\xv Balyanga nana lalumbu.
\xe Don't wake that one up.
\rf rs-2000-09
\xv Balyanga ninji lalumbu. Kudijbi nyulu.
\xe You are not to wake (him). He's sleeping.
\rf rs-2000-09
\xv Balyanga karrinjama.
\xe Don't stand up.
\rf GB
\xv Balyanga jila jangunu.
\sfx
\xe Don't go near the fire.
\rf IS_GB
\xv Balyanga jadimbi, ngaki nana, jangu. Balyanga jadimbi, dabarraba ngawu maman.
\sfx
\xe Don't put out the fire, it's for me. Don't put it out, (as) I'm cooking damper.
\rf
\va
\sy
\cf budangku
\cf -kana
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt

\xv Jundubu nyulu mama-anyi. Walijii, walijii banga mamaa. 
\xe He feeds the old man with bread. With meat, with both meat and bread.

\xe I frightened them both, the woman and the man.

\xe You didn't forget (and leave behind) the bread or the meat.

\lf


\lx banka
\mr barnka
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd PEOPLE
\sd kin
\lt mother's father
\lt mother's brother's child
\lt father's sister's child
\ge cross-cousin
\ge maternal grandfather
\ge mother's father's brother
\ge mother's father's sister
\so RS
\xv Nangkujarra, ngila-wiya. Bankanya-wiya. Maku-nganja-wiya. Nangkujarraa ngila-wuyaa, nijbi bulangka mimi-kula.
\xe These two girls, they are two cousins, two cross cousins. These two girls, they call themselves cousins.
\rf rs2004-01
\xv Winja nganyi kawaja, banka? Winja nganyi kawaja, ngaki ngada-nganja.
\xe Cousin, where's your aunt? Where's your aunt, (who is) my mother?
\rf RS
\xv Mimi-nganja, kangku-nganja, banka-nganja, ja nanganyjaa.
\xe (The deceased's) mother's father, his father's father, and his cousin will inherit.
\rf RS
\va
\sy mimi
\sy maku-nganja
\cf
\nt This is a widespread term for 'cousin' in languages across the Barkly and Victoria River district.
\cp Wambaya {barnka} 'cross-cousin'; Warlpiri
\nq ? MF
\dt 27/Oct/2006
\lf bankanya


\lx bankala
\mr barnkala
\hm
\sv
\sf
\sn
\ps noun
\pc sit_legs_crossed.jpg
\sd body related
\lt seated (of person) with legs crossed
\ge cross-legged
\re leg (cross-legged)
\re cross-legged
\so GB
\xv Burrurri-wayan nyulu jungku, bankala.
\xe He's sitting like an Aborigine, with his legs crossed.
\rf IS_GB78

\lx bankanya
\mr barnka-nya
\sf barnkanya-MinlawM.wav
\sf bankanyaRS.wav
\ps noun
\pc
\sd PEOPLE
\sd kin
\lt mother's father
\lt mother's brother's child
\lt father's sister's child
\ge cross-cousin
\ge maternal grandfather
\ge mother's father's brother
\ge mother's father's sister
\re
\so RS
\xv Nangkujarra, ngila-wiya. Bankanya-wiya. Maku-nganja-wiya. Nangkujarraa ngila-wuyaa, nijbi bulangka mimi-kula.
\xe These two girls, they are two cousins, two cross cousins. These two girls, they call each other 'cousin'.
\rf rs2004-01
\xv Ngunyarri-anyi ngada-nganja, bankanya.
\xe The mother of one's mother-in-law is (called) cousin.
\rf RS
\va
\sy mimi
\sy maku
\cf banka
\nt Man is referring to relationship between his son's child and his daughter's child.
\cp Binbinka and Gudanji
\nq mother or ngunyarri
\dt 30/Sep/2006
\lf banka
\lf banka-kula


\lx banmarra
\mr barnmarra
\sf
\sn
\ps noun
\pc headband.jpg
\sd manufacture
\lt ceremonial headdress made of plaited grass tied around with hairstring or a headband into which feathers are put
\ge headband
\ge headdress
\re 
\so RS, GB, JD
\xv Ngadarru yalu nijbi, banmarrana. Jarrkarra yalu, banmarrana. 
\xe They put the plumage made of bird feathers in the headdress. They stand them up straight in the headdress.
\rf rs2005-03
\va
\sy
\cf
\nt This headdress is made of plaited grass, spun possum fur used to cover front of head. Feathers are stuck into it as decoration for ceremonial rituals. Used by women for ceremonies.
\nt Dymock (1993) 'white headband' and 'lily stalk headdress'
\cp Garrwa {barnmarra}
\nq
\dt 26/Oct/2006

\lx barimbi
\mr bari-mbi
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc buggered_up.jpg
\sd
\lt Xerg cause Y to become bad
\ge make bad
\ge spoil
\ge ruin
\ge destroy
\ge wreck
\ge damage
\ge hurt
\re
\so GB, RS, EK
\xv Wanamiin, kamukamuu, barimbi naan. Barimbi naan lungkarra.
\xe The beer, grog, it has ruined this (fellow). The strong (stuff) has wrecked him.
\rf rs2005-01
\xv Barimbi-yanyi.
\sfx barimbiyanyi_CO.wav
\xe To make it worse.
\rf OSBORNE_C02-000165B.TMP
\xv Barimbi nyulu ngaan nanangkani ramii, nanangkani jalwaa ramii.
\xe Those glasses hurt my eyes, those strong glasses.
\rf rs2005-08a
\xv Barimbi niyangka, wanamii.
\xe We'll get wasted with grog. 
\rf rs2004-01
\xv Barimbi nyulu ninya kudulu.
\xe It damages your heart.
\rf rs2004-04
\xv Mayi yalu ngambalangi {car}, barimbi ngambalangi narrunguja.
\xe They might wreck our car, wreck out vehicle.
\rf rs
\xv Wanamii, barimbi nyulu yubal. Wanamiin, dumularraa.
\xe The rain, it wrecked the road. The water, the flowing water (did).
\rf rs
\xv Barimbi nana yubal ngambalangi, narrunguja-anyi.
\xe It ruined that road for us, for vehicles (to travel on).
\rf rs2004-06
\va bariyimbi
\sy
\cf 
\nt
\cp Garrwa {barimba}

\xe You missed it. Pelt it with a stick!

\xe I saw him miss it with (my own) eyes.
\rf RS2004-04
\xv Barimbi ngawu.
\sfx barimbi ngawu.wav
\xe I can't (see) it.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Burrbijbi nyulu. Rirrajba ngawu kajalaa daba bari-barimbi.
\xe It ran off. I chased it down and tried to hit it with my yamstick but kept missing it.
\rf RS

\xe He was sneaking up on the animal, then he missed that animal (with his shot).

\sfx
\xe He threw it at him but missed.
\rf RS2000-05a

\lx barrawal
\mr barrawal

\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc Sulphur_Crested_Cocky.jpg
\sn 1
\sd animal
\sd birds
\la Cacatua galerita
\lt 
\ge Sulphur-crested Cockatoo
\re 
\so RS, EK, JD, MS_SK, GW
\xv Najba nyulu winyarrki. Nayi barrawal, durrajba nyulu barrawal. Durrajba nyulu burrurri-anyi. Kayi nyulu. Nganyarrukiijbi nyulu nyungkana.
\xe It sees a wild man. This white cockatoo, it gets frightened. It gets frightened of the man. It screeches out. Its crest stands up and opens out on its head.

\va barrawaa (GB)
\sy
\cf
\nt
\cp Garrwa, Gunindirri {barral}; Yanyuwa {barral}
\nq GB barrawa
\dt 26/Oct/2006


\lx barrawu
\mr barrawu
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd manufacture
\lt building or room inside building
\ge building
\ge house
\ge room
\re
\so RS, EK, GB
\xv Budangku yalu nana wanba, barrawu kanjijbi. Karrinja nyulu.
\xe They haven't finished that house. It has stopped (being built).
\rf RS
\xv Mayi nyulu janybijbi ngambalangi barrawu, jalwaa wurrarraa.
\xe The strong wind might blow our house down.
\rf rs2005-02
\xv Wilijirri yalu kalawunyi. Barrawunu ja yalu nijbi naan.
\xe They are dragging (him) inside. They will put this (fellow) down inside the house.
\rf rs2005-08a
\xv Wanka nyulu bujubu, kalawunyi, barrawunu.
\xe He's lying there alive, inside, in the clinic.
\rf rs2005-08a
\xv Kudumbu nyulu barrawunu, kalawunyi.
\xe He locked him inside the house.
\rf RS2005-09
\xv Jungku ninji wuja nawunu. Kudijbi kalawunyi barrawunu.
\xe You stay put here, lie down inside the house.
\rf RS2003-03
\va
\sy wanba
\cf raji
\nt 
\cp Wambaya; Yanyula
\nq house/town/settlement, Yanyula word; Possibly borrowed from Yanyula language.
\dt 02/Nov/2006

\sn 2
\ps noun
\pc
\sd
\lt
\ge cell
\ge jail
\ge
\re
\so RS
\xv Yurru-kadi nyulu kala-wunyi barrawunu lungkajii kijibajii.
\xe The cheeky policeman took him from his place and put him into a jail cell.
\rf RS
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\va
\sy wanba
\cf
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt

\sn 3
\ps noun
\pc town.jpg
\sd
\lt place where there is a building or collection of buildings
\ge settlement
\ge town
\ge station
\ge village
\re
\so RS, GB
\xv Barrawu-wurru nyulu kannga bala-anyi kaku-anyi.
\xe She's gone back to town to get fishing hooks.
\rf rs2005-06
\xv Najba-nurri. Yirrkuu barri nana wanba, barrawu.
\xe We can see it. That town, settlement, is close now.
\rf rs2005-06
\xv Kannga-yirrimbi nyulu ngaan mudunama, wululukuu, barrawu-wurru.
\xe The old man will take me back to the station tomorrow.
\rf RS
\xv Jilaba nyulu nangkurru yanyi-anyi. Ngala ngawu, ngawu, jujuu ngawu jungku karurri, jujuu, kajana barrawunu. 
\xe He come here for some meeting, while I was far away to the east, away in the big town (among many buildings).
\rf RS
\xv Ngada-nganja nangangi, jungku nyulu nanawunu. Kayawanana, barrawunu.
\xe Her mother is living there at Kiana station.
\rf RS
\xv Kudarrijbi nana barrawu.
\sfx
\xe That station is very quiet.
\rf RS
\va
\sy wanba
\cf raji
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt

\lx barrba (?)
\mr
\hm
\sv
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd heat
\la
\lt
\ge boil
\re
\so CO
\xv Wanami barrba, yilaka niya.
\sfx
\xe Boil the water, put in the tea leaves.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\va
\sy
\cf dabarraba
\cf rajba
\an
\nt Possibly imperative verb form
\cp
\nq
\dt
\lf


\lx barrbarrarra
\mr barrbarrarra
\hm
\sf
\sn
\ps verb
\pc
\sd spatial
\lt in stance whereby head is at lowest position
\ge head down
\ge upside down
\re
\so GB, RS
\xv Langanba nyulu barrbarrarra. 
\sfx
\xe It's hanging head down.
\rf IS_GB78
\xv Barrbarrarra nyulu wajka-kulaji.
\xe It (flying-fox) hangs head down.
\rf rs2003-01
\xv Barrbarrarra nyulu, balarrka, walijin. Barrbarrarra nyulu, kingkarri-nukami.
\xe The flying fox hangs (there), it is (good) meat. It hangs with its feet upwards.
\rf rs2003-04
\va 
\sy
\cf langanba
\cf wajka-kulaji
\cf wajkali-kuwi
\an
\nt Pronounced [badbarrarra].
\cp
\nq
\dt


\lx barri
\mr barri
\sf barri.wav
\sn 1
\ps enclitic
\pc
\sd time
\lt indicates a changed situation: into state or location designated by the word or phrase preceding {barri}
\ge then
\ge now
\ge yet
\re
\so GB, RS, EF, CO
\xv Burra-daba nyulu. Daraa barri bijbi nana wadaba kudanba.
\xe He knocked him down. Then the dog bit that goanna (and) killed (it).
\rf rs2005-01
\xv Najba nurri. Yirrkuu barri nana wanba, barrawu.
\xe We can see it. That town is close up now, the settlement.
\rf rs2005-06
\xv Jilaba nyulu nukamin barri. 
\xe He's now walking (of child previously only able to crawl).
\rf rs2005-01
\xv Wayi barri nimba kawa-najba nukami?
\xe Have you (two) found his tracks yet?
\rf rs2005-01
\xv Dawurrumbu nungka nayi yanyin. Budangku barri nayi yanyi-anyi.
\xe We've finished this language (work). There's no more words left.
\rf rs2005-01
\xv Winja ninji jila barri?
\xe Where have you been?
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Winja ninji barri jungku?
\xe Where are you now sitting?
\rf MF+EM_CO
\va 
\sy
\cf
\nt {barri} encliticises to previous word.
\nt Following a verb ending in {ba} this word is reduced to {arri} or {rri} especially in rapid speech.
\cp Garrwa
\nq
\dt 29/Aug/2006

\sn 2
\ps particle
\pc
\sd time
\la
\lt
\ge already
\re
\so CO
\xv Barri ngawu nanganja.
\sfx
\xe I've already got it.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\va
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt
\cp Garrwa
\nq
\dt
\lf

\lx barriyi
\mr 
\hm
\sf Barrii-earlymorning.wav
\sf barrii-early.wav
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd time
\lt early morning before first light
\ge early morning
\ge predawn
\ge before dawn
\re 
\so GB, RS, EF
\xv Barriyi nyulu kalijbi, barriyin.
\sfx barriyi nyulu kalijbi #barriin.wav
\xe She speared it (fish) before dawn.
\rf RS2005-04
\va
\sy
\cf dururruru
\cf mungamba
\nt 
\cp
\nq Also used to translate 'last night' in GB notes.
\dt

\sn 2
\ps noun
\pc
\sd
\la
\lt during night before time of speaking
\ge last ^night
\re
\so EF, GB
\xv Budangku ngawiji balangarra najkanyi barriyi.
\xe I didn't see the moon last night.
\rf GB
\xv Barriyi ngawu buwarajba.
\xe Last night I had a dream.
\rf GB
\xv Barriyi nyulu ngaba mungamba.
\xe She gave birth last night.
\rf GB
\xv Daran ngaki kudajba barriyi.
\sfx
\xe My dog died last night.
\rf EF_R299A3
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\va
\sy
\cf mudunama
\cf
\an
\nt
\cp
\nq

\lx barrku
\mr barrku
\sf barrku-nullanulla.wav
\sf barrku02-nullanulla.wav
\ps noun
\pc fightingstick.jpg
\sd manufacture
\lt long wooden fighting stick typically used by men
\ge nullanulla
\ge wooden ^club
\ge fighting ^club
\re
\so RS, EK, JD, JP_TT, GB
\xv Budangku ninji kannga nangkurru. Dajaya ngawu ninya, jadiyadiyimbi barrkuu.
\xe Don't you come back here, or I'll beat you up, give you a good hiding with a nullanulla.
\rf rs2005-01
\xv Nanganja yalu mukura, banga jukulin, barrku, ngalika.
\xe They gather up (their) spears and boomerangs, nullanullas, woomeras.
\rf rs2005-03
\xv Daba nyulu ngaan burra-daba, barrkuu.
\xe He hit me and knocked me down with a nullanulla.
\rf rs2004-03
\va
\sy kuyarriji
\cf kajala
\nt
\cp Garrwa; Wambaya
\nq
\dt 19/Sep/2006

\lx barrulki
\mr barrulki
\sf barrulki.wav
\sf barrulki_RS.wav
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc oil.jpg
\sd body
\lt
\ge butter
\ge fat
\ge grease
\ge oil
\re 
\so EF, RS, GB, EK, JD93, MB_LH17
\xv Walijin kunyba. Barrulki-yudu.
\xe It is good meat. It's fatty.
\rf rs2003-01
\xv Jarrkanyi ngawu, jaluki. Barrulki.
\xe I want to eat the intestines, the fat.
\rf rs2002-02
\xv Budangku barrulki-anyi. Barijbi nyulu.
\xe It doesn't have any fat. It's no good.
\rf rs2002-02
\xv Binanyba nyulu. Kalijkanyi nyulu ngambalanya, mukuraa. Kuku-najba nyulu ngambalanya. Jarrkanyi nyulu ngambalanya -- barrulki.
\xe He's creeping up. He's going to spear us. He's peering at us. He's going to eat us, eat our fat.
\rf rs2005-05
\va 
\sy kungu
\cf
\nt 
\cp Garrwa {wurralki}
\nq Mary had barrulki in 2002-2; also GB barrulki; Also recorded as {barulki}.
\nq GB has barrulki, and barulki
\dt 19/Sep/2006
\lf barrulkijbi

\lx barrulkijbi
\mr barrulki-j-bi

\sn

\lt oily

\xe You're getting fat now.

\lf barrulkijini

\lx barrulkijini
\mr barrulki-j-ini
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd
\lt body of X be/come to be with fat
\ge fatten
\ge fatty
\ge oily
\re 
\so RS
\xv Wuluku kananganja waliji barrulkijini.
\xe The meat of the big emu is fatty.
\rf rs2004-01
\xv Kaku kunyba walijin. Barrulkijini.
\xe The fish is good meat. It's oily.
\rf rs2003-01
\xv Balikajba ngawu. Kunyba nayi waliji. Barrulkijini. Barrulkijini waliji nayi.
\xe I'm hungry. This meat is good. It's fatty. This meat is fatty.
\rf rs2002-02
\xv Makarraba nangka, wadabaa. Barrulkijini.
\xe The goanna, he buries himself (under the ground) and gets fat.
\rf rs2003-03
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\va
\sy
\cf
\nt
\cp
\nq

\lx barulajba
\mr barula-j-ba
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd spatial
\sd motion
\lt
\ge go another place
\ge go past
\ge pass by
\ge go elsewhere
\ge go another way
\re 
\so RS, GB
\xv Barulajba nyulu burrbijbi.
\xe He raced past.
\rf rs2005-03
\xv Najba ngawu ramii, barulajkurru.
\xe I saw him go past.
\rf rs2005-03
\xv Ja-ninji baba barulajba. Kingkarri-nanja, walajba ninji nurriyanya, jungku-wurru.
\xe You will fly over us. From up there, you'll look down on us sitting (here).
\rf rs2005-08
\xv Kannga ngawu kulana, barulajba. Langkurri.
\xe I'm going back from the south, passing by here heading north.
\rf rs2002-04
\xv Budangku nyulu nanajba ngambalangi. Burrbijbi nyulu, barulajba.
\xe He couldn't stop for us. He raced straight past.
\rf RS
\xv Jila nyulu barulajba ngakinbiyangka.
\xe He walked straight past me.
\rf GB
\xv Barulajba yalu, ngajangaja.
\xe They sped past.
\rf RS
\va bawulajba
\sy wabudala
\cf banyajba
\nt
\cp Wambaya {barulajbi}
\nq bawula in 2002
\dt 18/Oct/2006

\lx bawa
\mr bawa
\sf bawa-eB.wav
\ps noun
\pc
\sd people
\sd kin
\lt elder son of one's father or son of father's elder brother
\ge elder brother
\ge big brother
\re elder brother
\so EF, RS, GB, EK, JD
\xv Bawa, ngaki? Budangku ngawu bawa-nganjanyi.
\xe An elder brother, for me? I don't have an elder brother.
\rf rs2000-10
\xv Ngakinkanyi bawa-nganja-anyi. Budangku ngaki, nangangi.
\xe That belongs to my big brother. It's not mine, it's his.
\rf rs2000-10, RS2002-14
\xv Jukulii nyulu rangkijbi bawayi.
\sfx
\xe Brother killed it with a boomerang.
\rf IS_GB
\xv Bawa-nganjana ngawu jila.
\sfx
\xe I went with my brother.
\rf IS_GB
\xv Bawanyi.
\sfx
\xe My brother.
\rf IS_GB
\va
\sy
\cf balala
\cf dawirri
\cf kakulu
\cf kawija
\cf maju
\nt
\cp Garrwa {baba}
\nq
\dt 30/Oct/2006

\lf bawa

\lx bawa-nganja
\mr bawa-nganyja
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd kin
\lt one's elder brother
\ge one's big brother
\re
\so RS
\xv Nganyi bawa-nganja.
\xe Your elder brother.
\rf rs2005-02
\xv Bawa-nganja, mamanumbu nyulu kakulu-nganjaa.
\sfx
\xe His elder brother, the younger brother lost him.
\rf rs2002-14
\xv Ninji, nanangkanyi bawa-nganyja-anyi, ja-ninji nanganja.
\xe You, you will marry that (woman) who belonged (=was married) to your elder brother.
\rf rs2002-14
\xv Ngakinkanyi bawa-nganjanyi.
\xe (It) belongs to my elder brother.
\rf rs2000-10
\xv Najba ngawu nganyi bawa-nganja.
\sfx
\xe I saw your brother.
\rf IS_GB
\xv Najba ngawu nan, bawa-nganja.
\sfx
\xe I saw his brother.
\rf IS_GB
\xv Nganyi bawa-nganja nyulu daba.
\sfx
\xe He hit your brother.
\rf IS_GB

\re

\lx bayibu
\mr 
\sf

\lx bayungu
\mr bayungu
\sf bayungu-west.wav
\sf bayungu02-west.wav
\sf bayungu03-west.wav
\ps noun
\pc
\sd space
\sd direction
\sd compass points
\lt towards where sun sets
\ge west
\re
\so EF, GB, RS, EK, JD93
\xv Jilaba nyulu jujuu, bayungu.
\xe It's moving a long way away, to the west.
\rf rs2005-08a
\xv Karrinja nyulu najini bayungu.
\xe He's standing looking west.
\rf GB
\xv Nayi wululuku, jungku-anyi nyulu nayi bayungu.
\xe This old man, he's got to stay in the west.
\rf rs2005-08a
\xv Jujuu nyulu jungku bayungu, yingkana barruwunu.
\xe He's living far away to the west, in another town.
\rf rs2003-02
\xv Bayungunu ngawu jilaba.
\xe I came from the west.
\rf rs2005-06
\xv Jangayarrijbi nyulu nayi ngila ngambalangi bayungu. Kuujbu nyulu ngada-nganja-anyi.
\xe This little girl is sneaking away from us (going) west. She's looking for her mother.
\rf rs2005-06
\xv Bayungunu nurri babaa karurri.
\xe From the west we flew east.
\rf rs2005-06
\xv Winja-bunyi nana julaki? Bayungunubinyi.
\xe Where's that plane from? From the west.
\rf rs2005-06
\va
\sy
\cf
\nt
\cp Wambaya; Garrwa
\nq 2005-05 bayangarrinyi ; {check if (bayungunubinyi) is correct, I suspect bayungunanbinyi }

\lx bidirrika
\mr birdirrika
\sf birdirrika-red_kangarooFR299D2.wav
\sf birdirrika02-red_kangarooFR299D2.wav
\sf birdirrika03-red_kangarooFR299D2.wav
\sf birdirrika04-kangarooF.wav
\sf bidirrika_CO.wav
\sn
\ps noun
\pc kangaroo.jpg
\sd animal
\sd mammal
\sd marsupial
\la Osphranter rufus
\lt
\ge Red ^Kangaroo
\re
\so RS, EF, GB, PK_SK, MS_SK, GW
\xv Budangku ngawu najkanyi bidirrika.
\sfx
\xe I couldn't see any kangaroos (there).
\rf GB
\xv Budangku nyulu kalijbi. Barimbi nyulu bidirrika. 
\sfx
\xe He didn't spear it. He missed the kangaroo.
\rf RS2000-08a
\xv Kunyba waliji, bidirrika. Barrulki-yudu.
\sfx
\xe The kangaroo meat is good (to eat). It's fatty.
\rf RS2000-08a
\va
\sy maraji (?)
\sy marraji
\cf badakalinya
\cf junabu
\cf warraji
\nt Possibly also 'wallaroo'
\nt Breen also suggests it might be Antelopine Kangaroo
\nt Also identified as "mountain kangaroo" (EF_R299C2); and "rock wallaby" (PK_SK)
\nt Identified as same as Ganggalida {bardakalinya} by Alice Gilbert (EF_R299C2)
\nt Identified by Roy Seccin as "big red kangaroo belong in the hills" and "old man kangaroo" (RS2000-08)

\lf bijali


\lx bijbi
\mr bi-j-bi
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd body related
\lt Xerg make contact with Y by means of mouth
\ge bite
\re
\so EF, RS, GB
\xv Bijbi nyulu.
\sfx biijbi-nyulu_it bites.aif
\xe It bites.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Bijbi nyulu janyii, mayii.
\xe He's biting (it) with his mouth, with his teeth.
\rf 2005-01
\xv Bijbi nyulu, kudanba.
\xe He bit him to death.
\rf rs2005-01
\xv Kudumanjaa nyulu bijbi.
\xe He kept on biting him.
\rf rs2005-01
\xv Bijbi nyulu ngaan kijibajii. 
\xe The cheeky one (ant) bit me.
\rf rs2004-04
\xv Kudanba nyulu bijbi ngambalanya, miyaa kijibajii.
\xe He will bit us and kill us, that dangerous snake.
\rf rs2005-04
\xv Bijbi nyulu ninya kudanba.
\sfx biijbi nyulu ninya kudanba.aif
\xe It can bite you and kill you.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Biyaa ninya nanangkani. 
\xe That one is likely to bite you.
\rf GB
\xv Miyaa bijbi dara.
\sfx
\xe The snake bit the dog.
\rf IS_CG
\xv Biyaa nyulu daran, nanangkani miyaa, biyaa nyulu dara.
\sfx
\xe That snake, it might bite the dog. It might bite the dog.
\rf IS_GB
\xv Budangku nyulu nga wawurranyini daraa bijkanyi; mandaki-yanyini daraa nga bijbi.
\xe The child's dog didn't bite me; the whitefella's dog bit me.
\rf IS_GB
\xv Miyana nana. Biyanyi.
\sfx
\xe She's near the snake there. It might bite her.
\rf EF_R299EB1
\xv Daraa ngaan bijbi mani.
\sfx
\xe A dog bit my hand.
\rf EF_R299EB1
\va
\sy
\cf
\nt Undesired possibility form {biyaa} may derive from {bi.ya-ya}
\nt The realis and irrealis forms are pronounced with a long initial vowel: {biijbi} and {biijkanyi}
\cp Garrwa {bijba}
\nq
\dt 25/Oct/2006

\sv

\ge shoulder

\lf 

\sn 2
\ps verb
\pc carry_logs.jpg
\sd hold (holding and transfer)
\sd transfer
\lt Xerg cause Y to move along same path as X
\ge carry
\ge take
\ge shoulder
\ge transport
\ge give a lift to
\re shoulder (carry on)
\re carry 
\so EF, RS, GB, LM, CO
\xv Jangu nyulu bikali, ngaba, manii.
\xe He's carrying that firestick, carrying (it in his) hand.
\rf rs2005-01
\xv Yimbira nyulu bikalii, wanamii, dumularraa.
\sfx Yimbirra-nyulu-bikali wanamii dumularraa-RS2003-12T03.wav
\xe The floodwaters carry the refuse along with them.
\rf rs2005-02
\xv Nganyi nana maman. Bikalii ninji. Manii ninji bikalii
\xe That's your tucker. You're carrying it. You're carrying it in your hand.
\rf rs2005-05
\xv Wawurra yalu bikali ngabana, kirriyaa, banga burrurrii, bulungu bulangi.
\xe The man and the woman carried (their) children on their shoulders, the little ones belongs to both of them.
\rf rs2005-05
\xv Langan-daba yalu waliji, jukuli, wadaba, bikali barri yalu.
\xe They used to hang the animals (they had caught), boomerangs, goannas (in their waistbelt) and they then carried them (that way).
\rf rs2005-05
\xv Budangku nana wululuku. Wakijbi nyulu wululuku. Bikalini.
\xe That's not the old man. The old man's still away taking (them back home).
\xv Wawurra-darra nyulu burra-daba. Wawurra-darra, bikali nyulu narrungujaa. Burra-daba.
\xe He's dropping off the kids. He's taking the kids with the truck. Dropping them off.
\rf rs2005-05
\xv Manini nyulu bikali, kijibajii ngarrangarraa.
\xe The wild, angry man is carrying them (spears) in this hand.
\rf rs2005-8b
\xv Mularrijbi yalu jamba-wunyi, janki-wurru barri. Janki-wurru yalu mularrijbi bikali yalu jankini.
\xe They pick them up from the ground and put them on their shoulders (around their neck). They lift them onto their shoulders and carry them on their shoulders (astride their neck).
\rf rs2004-03
\xv Wandu-wandujbu yalu bikalini.
\xe They walk around carrying them.
\rf rs2004-03.
\xv Mimi-nganjaa, kangku-nganjaa, bikali yalu.
\xe It's their cousins, mother's father and father's father who carry them.
\rf rs2004-03.
\xv Najba ngawu bikali-wurru, maman.
\xe I saw him bringing the food.
\rf rs2004-04
\xv Jarrba kiya ngawu, daraa barri ngaki bikalii wakuu.
\xe I was about to eat it, when the dog quickly took it from me.
\rf GB
\xv Bikalimi!
\xe Carry (it) on the shoulder!
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Bikali ngaba.
\sfx
\xe Carry it on the shoulder.
\rf EF_R299B2
\va
\sy ngaba
\cf birrinbirri
\nt Includes carrying on body, transporting in vehicle.
\cp Wambaya {bikilanyi}
\nq can be used with daba
\dt 09/Oct/2006

\lx bilikija
\mr 
\sf bilikijaa.wav
\ps verb
\pc
\sd elements
\sd water
\sd motion
\lt X move in, on or through water
\ge swim
\ge sail
\ge float
\ge paddle
\ge wade
\re
\so EF, RS, GB, EK, CO
\xv Bilikija ngawu wanamini.
\xe I'm swimming in the water.
\rf rs2000-10
\xv Budangku nyulu bilikijaa, kadimirra wawurra. Wurrujbu nyulu, wanamini.
\xe That little boy can't swim. He's drowning, in the water.
\rf rs2005-01
\xv Muwadana yalu burrbijbi, bilikija. Bilikija yalu.
\xe They are travelling in a boat, moving through the water. They are moving along in the water.
\rf rs2004-03
\xv Jilaba yalu nambunyi. Bilikija yalu.
\xe They are going from here. They are going through the water.
\rf rs2003-03
\xv Budangku yalu durrajba, bilikija yalu karurri.
\xe They are not frightened, they are sailing eastward.
\rf rs2003-03
\xv Kaku ngawu najba bilikija-wurru.
\xe I can see the fish swimming.
\rf rs2004-04
\xv Bilikijana nyulu burrbijbi.
\xe It's swimming fast.
\rf rs2004-04
\xv Bilikijama!
\xe Swim!
\rf MF+EM_CO
\va bilyikija
\sy banjarrba
\sy baru
\cf bulwa
\nt 
\cp
\nq bilikajba in 2003-01a is a typo should be bilikija
\dt 18/Oct/2006
\lf bilikijaa
\lf bilikija-anyi
\lf bilikijama
\lf bilikijana
\lf bilikija-wurru

\lx binanyba
\mr binany-ba
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc hunt.jpg
\sd contact (impact and violence)
\lt Xerg move slowly towards Y keeping hidden, in order to attack Y
\ge hunt
\ge stalk
\ge sneak up on
\re
\so RS, EK, JD93
\xv Binanyba nyulu. Kalijkanyi nyulu ngambalanya, mukuraa.
\xe He's sneaking up so he can spear us.
\rf RS
\xv Kudijbi nyulu nana bungkina. Mayi nyulu binanyba burrurrii. Binanyba nyulu mukura-yudu.
\xe That wallaby is lying asleep. The man might sneak up on it. He might sneak up on it with his spear.
\rf rs2004-04
\xv Mirramba nyulu nangangi nana mukura. Binany-kanyi nyulu walijin bungkina.
\xe He's making himself that spear. He wants to hunt that wallaby.
\rf rs2004-04
\xv Bajalijbi nyulu warrki jila-kurru. "Jilaba nyulu warrki. Binanyba nyulu ngaan. Binanyba. Warrkii."
\xe He (wallaby) smells a dingo coming. "There's a dingo coming. He is hunting me. The dingo is after me."
\rf rs2002-01
\xv Jilaba ngawu binanjini barri, waliji-anyi. Mukura-yudu barri.
\xe I'm going along hunting for game. With the spears (I've just made).
\rf rs2002-01
\xv Jilaba-nyulu nyubana, waliji-anyi. Binanyba nyulu, kudijkurru, walijin. Nangurrbuwala. Wululuku.
\xe He's going along alone looking for game. He's sneaking up on an animal that's asleep. It's a big old man kangaroo.
\rf rs2002-13
\va
\sy marrkajba
\cf jangajba
\cf jakajba
\cf namburri
\nt
\cp Garrwa
\nq 
\dt 21/Sep/2006
\lf binanjini
\lf binanykanyi

\lt

\re 
\so RS, JD, GW

\xe He boils the paperbark leaves and pours the water on himself.

\nt

\nq GB glosses as type of Ti-tree.
\nq Identified by GW

\lx birajba
\mr bira-j-ba
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd ceremony
\sd bodily function
\lt Xerg sing Y
\ge chant
\ge sing
\so RS, EF, CO, EK, JD, MF+EM_CO
\xv Birajba ninji.
\sfx birajba-ninji.wav
\xe You are singing.
\rf EF
\xv Budangku nyulu birajba barri.
\xe He doesn't sing anymore.
\rf rs2004-01
\xv Budangku barri nyulu birajba nana badibadi wululuku.
\xe That old man can't sing anymore.
\rf rs2004-01
\xv Birajba yaluwangka yurrul. Jungku yalu birajini yurrulini nana-waan burrurri-darra.
\xe They're singing (themselves) a corroboree. Those men are sitting singing a corroboree song.
\rf rs2004-01
\xv Birajba yalu junba.
\xe They are singing a song.
\rf rs2004-01
\xv Birajini nyulu jungku. Manku nurri nana wululuku. Jukulini nangka birajba wululukuu, kuyii buka-yuduu [buka-aduu].
\xe He's sitting singing. We are listening to that old man. The old man with his grey hair is singing himself (clapping) a boomerang.
\rf rs2004-05
\xv Birajba yalu, kujikaa, nana-waan jukajuka.
\xe They are singing those boys with Kujika songs.
\rf rs2004-07
\xv Jukulii, dirribirrili yalu birajba junba.
\xe They sing the song with boomerangs and clapsticks.
\rf rs2003-02
\xv Lajibi ngawu ninya birajkurru.
\xe I heard you sing.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Birayi!
\xe Sing!
\rf MF+EM_CO
\va burajba
\sy
\cf kayi
\cf junba
\nt
\cp
\nq GB birijba
\dt 21/Sep/2006
\lf birayi (?)
\lf birajini
\lf birajkurru

\lx biraki
\mr biraki
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc ant.jpg
\sd animal
\sd insects (and spiders)
\lt
\ge ant
\re ant
\so RS, EK, DJ93, GB
\xv Kijibaji biraki.
\xe Cheeky ant.
\rf rs2005-06
\xv Kadimirraa birakii ngaan bijbi nukamin kadimirraa.
\xe Little ants are biting me on the foot. Tiny ones.
\rf rs2005-06
\xv Kurrijbi nyulu maniin jamba waliji-anyi biraki-anyi. Kuujbu nyulu biraki-anyi. Jarrba nyulu.
\xe It (echidna) digs the earth with its front legs (lit. hands) to find ants to eat. It searches for ants. It eats (them).
\rf rs2003-01
\xv Bijbi ngaan birakii nganmarraa, kadimirraa. Kurrijbi ngaka biraki-wunyi. Barijbi ngawu.
\xe Small red ants bit me. I scratched myself, from the ants. I was hurting.
\rf rs2003-05
\xv Biraki ngujuruka.
\xe Black ants.
\rf rs2002-09
\va buraki
\sy
\cf dinmanja
\cf munku
\cf minyiri
\nt
\cp
\nq buraki in 2003-02a
\dt 30/Oct/2006

\lx birrirri
\mr birrirri
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc cold.jpg
\sd motion
\lt X shake as result of excessive cold
\ge shake
\ge shiver
\re
\so EF, RS, EK, JD93, GB
\xv Najba ngawu nana burrurri birrirri-wurru.
\xe I saw that man shivering.
\rf rs2004-04
\xv Jungku nyulu birrirrini.
\xe He's sitting shivering.
\rf rs2004-04
\xv Durraja ngawu, birrirri ngawu.
\xe I'm frightened, I'm shaking (with fear).
\rf rs2004
\xv Wanyingkanyi ninji birrirrin?
\xe What are you shivering for?
\rf GB
\xv Ngajirrijbi ngawu birrirri.
\xe I'm shivering from the cold.
\rf EF_REB1
\xv Ja-ngamba, kuujbu, jangu-anyi barri. Birrirri nurri.
\xe We need to look for firewood now (as) we others are shivering (from cold).
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf jayayaya
\nt
\cp Wambaya; Warlpiri {pirriya} 'cold wind, cold weather'
\nq 
\dt 21/Sep/2006
\lf birrirrini
\lf birrirri-wurru

\lx birrki-marrijbi

\pc

\ge hold tightly to
\ge not let go of
\ge take a firm hold of
\re hold tightly
\so RS2004-01
\xv Marrijbi nyulu. Birrki-marrijbi nyulu, manii.
\xe He's holding it. He's holding on to it tightly with his hand.
\rf rs2004-03
\xv Birrki-marrijbi nyulu.
\xe It's holding on to it tightly (of Wedgetail Eagle holding its prey in its talons).
\rf rs2004-01
\xv Birrki-marrijbi nyulu, nyungka. Nyungka-nanja, wilijirri nyulu, nyungka-nanja.
\xe She grabbed hold of his hair. She dragged him by the hair.
\rf rs2002-04
\xv Baba nyulu, nayi nyulu, wanbiya nyulu, birrki-marrijbi nyulu. Duka nyulu marrijbi.
\xe It flies and then this (eagle), it descends, it grabs hold of it. It grabs its neck.

\lx budangku
\mr burdangku
\sf budangku-nothingF.wav
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd quantity
\lt absence of
\ge absent
\ge no
\ge not
\ge nothing
\ge none
\ge never
\ge without
\ge don't
\ge can't
\re
\so RS, GB, EF, EK, JD93, AP+AF_PS
\xv Budangku ngawu mankuu Yanyula.
\sfx budangku_ngawu_mankuu_yanyula_RS.wav
\xe I don't understand Yanyula.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku ngawu yanyba.
\sfx budangku ngawu yanyba_RS.wav
\xe I can't speak.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku ngamba jarrba.
\sfx budangku_ngamba_jadba.wav
\xe We didn't eat it.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku nayi jangkaranyi. Wingki nayi, wingki walijin.
\sfx budangku nayi jangkaranyi_RS.wav
\xe This is not cooked. It's no good, the meat tastes bad.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku kunuma-anyi.
\xe There are no bees.
\rf rs2003-01
\xv Budangku ninji jadimbi-kanyi jangu.
\sfx budangku_ninyji_jardimbikanF.wav
\xe Don't start a fire.
\rf EF
\xv Budangku nyulu ngaan najba.
\sfx budangku=nyulu=ngan_najba.aif
\xe He didn't see me.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Budangku ngawu jungku, maninyin.
\sfx budangku ngawu jungku maninyin.wav
\xe I don't have any, nothing in hand.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Dawurrumbu nungka nayi yanyin. Budangku barri nayi yanyi-anyi.
\xe We've finished this language (work). There are no more words left.
\rf rs2005-01
\xv Budangku ngawu jarrkanyi barri, dumbululujbu ngawu muwa.
\xe I don't want to eat any more, my belly is full up.
\rf RS2004-07
\xv Bakarrijbi nungka jangun, yukal-yudu. Budangkun barri jindal-anyi.
\xe We made a smoky fire to chase away the mosquitoes. So there would be no more mosquitoes.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku yalungi nayi, budangkun. Kannga ngamba.
\xe There's nobody here. Noone. Let's go back.
\rf 2003-03
\xv Budangku nayi, budangku nurri jarrba. Wingki. Bijbi nyulu ngaan janyi wingkii.
\xe Not this one, we don't eat it. It's green. When it's not ripe it stings my mouth. 
\rf rs2003-01
\xv Budangku yalu ngaan daba.
\xe They didn't hit me. (or Nobody hit me.)
\rf rs2003-01
\xv Budangku nurri najba nana-waan, narrunguju-yudu. Budangku yalu jilaba nangkurru.
\xe We didn't see anyone with a car. Nobody came here.
\rf rs2003-01
\xv Budangku yalu najba, nurriyanya, jungku-wurru. Budangku yalu najba, nurriyanya, jungku yalu nawunu, yanjini barri.
\xe They didn't see us sitting (here). They didn't see us, they were sitting here talking.
\rf rs2003-01
\xv Ngurrubu nurri nana-waan wawurra, budangku yalu jirringkijbi nurriyanya.
\xe We tell those kids, (but) they take no notice of us.
\rf rs2003-01
\xv Wayi barri ninji ngaba ngaki danya? Budangku ngawu, budangku ngawu ngaba nganyi. Mamanumbu ngawu.
\xe Did you bring me (any) clothes? I didn't. I didn't bring you any. I forgot.
\rf rs2003-01
\xv Jungku ninji, kujarrana? Budangkun. Murrku-darrana.
\xe Are you staying for two (nights)? No, for four.
\rf rs2003-01
\xv Budangku yalu windijbi nurriyanya, namirra-anyi.
\xe They don't give us any money.
\rf rs2003-01
\xv Kuujbu ngawu nanangkanyi ngila-anyi. Budangku ngawu najba.
\xe I am looking for that little girl. I can't find her.
\rf rs2003-01
\xv Budangku nyulu lalumbu ngaan. 
\xe He didn't wake me up.
\rf rs2003-01
\xv Budangku bula ngurrubu ngaan, nangkanyi wanami-yanyi. Jangayarrijbi bula wanami-yudu.
\xe They didn't ask me for this drink. They sneaked away with the drink (without telling me).
\rf RS
\xv Budangku ngawu, namirra-nyi. Budangku ngawu windijbi ninya. Maninyi ngawu, maninyi.
\xe I don't have any money. I can't give you (any). I'm empty-handed, empty-handed.
\rf rs2003-03
\va
\sy
\cf balyanga
\cf maninyi
\cf miku
\cf -kana
\nt Used with {barri} it has the meaning of 'no more' or 'no longer' as well as 'not now (unlike before)'.
\cp
\nq

\xv Ramin ngawu bujubu.
\xe I'm lying awake.
\rf rs2000-09
\xv Bujubu nyulu ngunyi, ngurruwijbi.
\xe He's lying fast asleep snoring.
\rf rs2005-08b
\xv Bujubu nyulu dara-yudu.
\xe He’s sleeping with a dog
\rf rs2000-09
\xv Buju-kanyi ngawu.
\xe I'm going to lie down.
\rf rs2005-08b
\xv Nayi nyulu bujubu jambana. Kurrijbi ngawu. Kajalaa.
\xe Here it (goanna) is lying in the earth. I'll dig it out, with (my) digging stick.
\rf rs2002-01
\xv Bujubu nyulu nana wawurra.
\sfx
\xe That child is sleeping.
\rf MB_LH12
\xv Kannga ngawu raji-yurru, bujukanyi ngawu.
\sfx
\xe I'm going back home so I can sleep.
\rf MB_LH13
\va
\sy kudijbi
\cf ngunyijbi
\nt
\cp
\nq 
\dt

\lf bujukanyi

\lx bula
\mr bula
\sf bula.wav
\ps pronoun
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt Third person dual subject pronoun
\ge they both
\ge them two
\so RS, GB, EF, EM_SK
\xv Nayi bula kujarra.
\sfx nayi_bula_kujarra.wav
\xe There are two of them.
\rf RS-RG1999
\xv Nayi bula.
\sfx nayi_bula.wav
\xe Here they are both.
\rf RS-RG1999
\xv Jungku bula nanawunu.
\xe They are living there.
\rf rs2005-09
\xv Wajarrijbi bula.
\xe They are both fishing.
\rf rs2005-01
\xv Maninyin bula, bulungu-anyi.
\xe They don't have any children.
\rf rs2005-02
\xv Kannga bula maninyi. Budangkun kaku-anyi. Ngada-kula.
\xe They've come back empty-handed. No fish. Mother and daughter.
\rf rs2005-03
\xv Jilaba bula kaku-anyi, wawurra-wiya.
\xe The two kids have gone for fish.
\rf rs2005-03
\xv Mudumbanyi bula nangkujarra, ngila-wuya, ngakinkanyi yanyi-anyi.
\xe These two girls don't know my language.
\rf rs2005-06
\xv Budangku bula yanyba. Mudumbanyi bula yanyi-anyi.
\xe They don't speak (it). They don't know the language
\rf rs2005-06
\xv Jila bula kujarra kirriya.
\sfx
\xe Two girls come.
\rf EM_SK
\va
\sy
\cf kujarra
\cf -kuya
\cf -wuya
\cf yalu
\nt {bula} is typically used as a subject enclitic which comes after the first word or phrase in a sentence.
\cp
\nq

\sfx yakujbu nana wanu.wav
\sfx mayi ninji warrawarraa.wav
\sfx mayi ninya burra-daba.wav
\xe Don't smoke, old man! Leave that tobacco alone. You might have a fit. It might knock you out.

\xv Bulinjaa nayi, nayi larrwa.
\xe Smoke this, this pipe.
\rf RS2005-09
\xv Jungku nungka bulinja barri nayi, larrwa-yudu nayi. Wanu-yudu.

\lx bulubarrba
\mr bulubarr-ba
\sf bulubadba.wav
\ps verb
\pc
\sd motion
\lt x move rapidly
\ge jump
\ge dive
\ge leap
\ge twitch
\so RS, GB, CO, EF, JD93, MB_LH15
\xv Ngawu bulubarrba.
\xe I used to jump.
\rf GB
\xv Bulubarrba nyulu kaku wanami-wunyi.
\xe The fish jumped up out of the water.
\rf RS
\xv Bulubarr-kurru nyulu najba julakii kaku, ramii.
\xe The bird is watching the fish jump, with its eyes.
\rf RS
\xv Bulubarrba nyulu ngunyi-wunyi. Najba nyulu buwarajini. Bulubarrba nyulu.
\xe He jumped up from his sleep. He had been dreaming (and) he jumped up (startled).
\rf RS
\xv Bulubarrba nyulu, bulubarrba durrajini. 
\xe He leapt (to his feet), leapt up in fear.
\rf RS
\xv Bulubarrba nyulu narrunguja, barijbi nyulu nana yubal.
\xe The vehicle is jumping about (because) that road is bad.
\rf RS
\xv Bulubarrba yalu wanami-yurru barri.
\xe They are now jumping into the water.
\rf RS
\xv Bulubarrba nyulu rami.
\xe His eye twitched.
\rf JD93
\xv Bulubarrbama!
\xe Jump!
\rf MF+EM_CO
\va 
\sy
\cf WARARRBU
\nt Pronounced [bulubadba]
\nt Used of muscle twitch warning of approaching kin (JD93)
\cp
\nq   bulu + balba
\dt 24/Oct/2006
\lf bulubarrbama
\lf bulubarrkanyi
\lf bulubarrkurru

\lx buludu
\mr buludu
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd motion
\lt Xerg apply pressure to Y
\ge apply pressure to
\ge press on
\ge roll out
\ge squeeze
\re
\so RS, JD93
\xv Buludu yalu manii.
\xe They roll it (dough) out with their hands.
\rf RS
\xv Buludu nyulu jaluki.
\xe He squeezes the intestines (to get out the contents).
\rf RS
\xv Buludu ngawu, jidimbi duka.
\xe I press down on it, squeeze its throat.
\rf RS
\va 
\sy

\pc cows.jpg

\lt
\ge cattle
\re cattle
\so RS
\xv Jilaba nurri, buluka-adu, yarraman-adu. Barulajba. Kalana barri, Kalkudungu-yanyi-wurru raji-wurru.
\xe We used to go with cattle and horses following along the river down to the Kalkudungu people's country.
\rf RS
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\va BULUKI
\sy
\cf wakada-wakada
\an
\nt

\nq

\lx bulungu
\mr burlungu
\sf bulungu_CO.wav
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc newborn_baby.jpg
\sd people
\lt small offspring of person, animal or plant
\ge baby
\ge chick
\ge infant
\ge joey
\ge pup
\ge puppy
\re
\so EF, RS, GB, EK, JD, SC_BB, AP+AF_PS
\xv Muwana kuyuwarrunu, kudijbi ngawu, kadimirra bulungu.
\xe Inside a coolimon is where I slept when I was a little baby.
\rf rs2000-05
\xv Junabu, bulungu-yudu muwana. 
\xe The female kangaroo has a joey in (her) pouch.
\rf 2000-08
\xv Warrki bulungu.
\xe Dingo pup.
\rf rs2005-03
\xv Wandarrku nana kundan; bulungu-yudu.
\sfx wandarrku nana kundan#bulungu-yudu.wav
\xe That tree has a lump (on it); it's got a 'baby'.
\rf rs-2005-04
\xv Wawurra yalu bikali ngabana, kirriyaa, nga burrurrii, bulungu bulangi.
\xe They carried children on their shoulders, the woman and the man, their children.
\xv Bulungu-yudu.
\sfx bulungu-yudu.wav
\xe Pregnant. (lit. with child)
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Ngakin bulungu wuluku barri, banyajba barri nyulu ngaa.
\xe My child is big now, he's now bigger than me.
\rf GB
\xv Maninin bula, bulungu-anyi.
\xe They don't have any children.
\rf rs2005-02
\xv Barijbi nyulu nana janba. Budangku nyulu bulungu-anyi kadimirra-anyi, julaki-anyi, makulu-anyi.
\xe That nest is no good. It doesn't have any baby birds in it, or any bird eggs.
\rf RS2004-06
\xv Wilijirri nyulu bulanya, kadimirra, bulungu-wiya. 
\xe He's pushing two little children (in a pram).
\rf 2005-06
\xv Bulungu kadimirra yalu mundukaa.
\xe They carry little babies in coolamons.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf badada
\cf bulumirri
\cf wawurra
\cf wandarrku
\nt
\cp Wambaya {bulyungu} 'little'
\nq nephew in 2002-14, suspect it is 'baby'? check this one. Glossed as baby in 2002-3
\dt 30/Oct/2006

\lx bungkana

\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc

\ge yesterday
\ge previous day
\re yesterday
\so RS, EK, GB, CO, JP_TT
\xv Jawikajba nyulu ngaan bungkana, jila-kanyi nungka mudunama.
\xe He asked me yesterday if we two would go the next day.

\xv Bungkana nyulu jangayarrijbi wanami-anyi.
\xe Yesterday he sneaked off to get beer.
\rf RS
\xv Bungkana ngawu kawa-najba, dirrbu, kundana.
\xe Yesterday I found some sugarbag, in a tree.
\rf RS
\xv Jilaba bula bayunguna. Burrbijbi bula. Bungkana.
\xe They came from the west. They both drove (here), yesterday.
\rf RS, EK
\xv Bungkana, jilaba ngawu nangkurru, windijbi nyulu ngan waliji-anyi. 
\xe Yesterday, I came here, and he gave me some meat. 
\rf RS2000-10
\xv Jawikajba nyulu ngaan bungkana, jila-kanyi nungka mudunama.
\xe He asked me yesterday if we two would go the next day.
\rf RS
\xv Wambu ngawiji bungkana.
\xe I was sick yesterday.
\rf GB
\xv Kuujbu ngawu nganyi bungkana.
\xe I was looking for you yesterday.
\rf RS
\xv Winja ninji bungkana jila?
\xe Where did you go yesterday?
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Bungkana ngawu nganyi kujbu.
\sfx
\xe Yesterday I looked for you.
\rf EF_R299EB1

\cf mudunama
\nt Also recorded as {bungkaana} GB, JP_TT

\lx bunija

\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd plant
\lt tobacco mixed with white ashes and ground into a ball or wad to be chewed
\ge chewing tobacco
\re wad (tobacco)
\so RS, JD, AP+AF_PS
\xv Kuujbu ngawu, nanganja ngawu, wuliwuli. Wiyala ngawu, wanu, nangkanyi bunija-anyi. Bunija, julwu-yudu. Nangkani barri wuliwulii, wiyala ngawu.
\xe I look for and find a round stone. I grind the tobacco to make it into this wad. (I) mix it with ashes. Then with this round stone, I grind it up.
\rf RS
\xv Ngawu, kirriya ngawu. Jarrba ngawu wanu, bunija. Julwu-yudu.
\xe As for me, I'm a woman. I chew tobacco, a wad, mixed with ash.

\xe Chew the wad of tobacco in (your) mouth.

\ps verb

\xe You're pouring water.
\rf RS
\xv Makirra, kurrijbi yalu kajalaa, manii. Bunyarrijbi yalu bindawarrana manii.
\xe The white ochre, they dig it out with their digging stick and their hands. They pour it into a bag with their hands.
\rf rs2004-01
\xv Bunyarrijbi dirrbu. Jawaranyana. Bujilini barri.
\xe Pour honey into a pannikin. Into a billycan.
\rf rs2002-03
\xv Bunyarrijbi nyulu kumbulungkana, mandakii. 
\xe The white man, he pours (it) into bottles.
\rf RS2005-08b
\xv Nganyi nana. Bunyarri nana! 
\xe That's for you. Pour it!
\rf RS2005-09
\xv Bunyarri!
\xe Pour (it)!
\rf MF+EM_CO
\va
\sy
\cf
\nt
\cp
\nq 
\dt 29/Sep/2006

\mr -bunyi
\lx
\sf
\sn 1
\ps suffix
\pc
\sd 
\lt Ablative suffix
\ge from
\re
\so RS, GB
\xv Winja-bunyi ninji? Kala-wunyi ninji?
\xe Where are you from? What place are you from?
\rf RS
\xv Jilaba yalu nambunyi. 
\xe They are going from here. 
\rf rs2003-03
\xv Winja-bunyi nana julaki? Bayungunubinyi.
\xe Where's that plane from? From the west.
\rf rs2005-06
\xv Kujbu yalu nangangi. Jangayarrijbi nyulu nanambunyi wanba-wunyi.
\xe They were looking for him. He had sneaked away from that station.
\rf rs2004-06
\xv Winja-bunyi nimba jilaa?
\xe Where have you two come from?
\rf GB
\xv Wakadaba ngaka nanganbunyi waliji-wunyi karrbajinyi.
\xe I washed my hands after cutting up this meat.
\rf GB
\va -wunyi
\sy
\cf -nanja
\nt Form used after consonant and on certain words such as {winja} 'where' and some compass direction terms following vowel.
\cp
\nq

\lx burradaba
\mr burra-da-ba
\sf burradaba-knockout.wav
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd CONTACT
\sd movement
\lt Xerg cause Y to move downwards or outwards from some location
\ge drop
\ge drop off
\ge knock down
\ge knock over
\ge make collapse
\ge pour down on
\re 
\so RS, GB, EK
\xv Ninji ngan burradaba.
\xe You made me fall over.
\rf GB
\xv Burradaba ngawiji.
\xe I dropped it.
\rf GB
\xv Burradaba ninji, balungka.
\xe You've got blood pouring down (on you).
\rf rs2002-03
\xv Mayi ninya burradaba.
\sfx mayi ninya burradaba.wav
\xe It might knock you down.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Wawurra-darra nyulu burra-daba. Wawurra-darra, bikali nyulu narrungujaa. Burradaba.
\xe He's dropping off the kids. He's taking the kids with the truck. Dropping them off.
\rf rs2005-05
\xv Burradaba nyulu. Daraa barri bijbi nana wadaba kudanba.
\xe He knocked him down. Then the dog bit that goanna (and) killed (it).
\rf rs2005-01
\xv Bulinja-kana wululuku! Yakujbu nana wanu. Mayi ninji warrawarraa. Mayi ninya burradaba.
\sfx bulinja-kana wululuku.wav
\sfx yakujbu nana wanu.wav
\sfx mayi ninji warrawarraa.wav
\sfx mayi ninya burra-daba.wav
\xe Don't smoke, old man! Leave that tobacco alone. You might have a fit. It might knock you out.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Durrajba nyulu ngambalangi. Dabaya ngamba, burradaba kundaa, jadiyadiyimbii.
\xe He's frightened of us, thinking that we might hit him, knock him down with a stick, give him a hiding.
\rf RS2005-01
\xv Bungkana ngawu kawa-najba, dirrbu. Kundana. Dayi ngawu, burradaba.
\xe Yesterday I found honey, in a tree. I chopped it down.
\rf RS2003-02
\xv Winjuraba ngambalanya. Burradaba wanami ngambalangi. Mirramba nyulu dumularra. 
\xe It's raining on us. The rain is pouring down on us. It's forming a fast running current.
\rf RS
\xv Jayajayamba nyulu burradaba nana mama wajka jamba-wurru. Jalwaa wurrarraa.
\xe That strong wind shakes it (the tree) and makes that fruit fall down to the ground.
\rf RS
\xv Burradaba yalungka wanamini.
\xe They are pushing each other into the water.
\rf RS
\xv Yingkaa burradaba jamba-wurru.
\sfx
\xe One forced (the other) down to the ground.
\rf IS_GB
\va
\sy
\cf 
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt
\lf burrajba

\sn 2
\ps verb
\pc
\sd movement
\lt Xerg be in process of falling (with reflexive pronoun)
\ge fall down
\ge topple over
\ge collapse
\re
\so RS
\xv Lalujbu nyulu, burra-daba nangka.
\sfx
\xe He would get up and then fall down (again).
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt When this verb is used with reflexive pronoun it may refer to repeated or continuous 'falling' action not caused by external agent, but due to some internal source.
\cp
\nq

\lx burrbijbi
\mr burrbi-j-bi
\sf budbijbi.wav
\sf burrbijbi.wav
\ps verb
\pc budbijbi.jpg
\pc fly.jpg
\sn 1
\sd motion
\lt X move rapidly
\ge blow (of wind)
\ge run
\ge flow (of water)
\ge fly
\ge race
\ge speed
\re
\so EF, RS, GB, EK, MF_EM_CO
\xv Babana nyulu jilaba. Burrbijbi nyulu.
\xe It's flying past. It's moving fast.
\rf rs2004-04
\xv Burrbijbi nyulu. Rirrajba ngawu kajalaa daba bari-barimbi.
\xe It ran off. I chased it down and tried to hit it with my yamstick but kept missing it.
\rf RS
\xv Barulajba nyulu burrbijbi.
\xe He raced past.
\rf rs2005-03
\xv Jilaba bula bayunguna. Burrbijbi bula. Bungkana.
\xe They came from the west. They both drove (here), yesterday.
\rf rs2000-01, EK
\xv Bidangku, langkurri nyulu burrbijbi, Mungkubayi-yurri.
\xe The Gregory River runs north towards Burketown. 
\rf rs2005-09
\xv Muwadana yalu burrbijbi, bilikija. 
\xe They are travelling in a boat, moving through the water. 
\rf rs2004-03
\xv Bilikijana nyulu burrbijbi.
\xe It's swimming fast.
\rf rs2004-04
\xv Mayi nungka daba, kundaa. Burrbijbi nyulu jayi.
\xe Because we might hit it with a stick, he's running off.
\rf RS03-01
\xv Burrbijbi nyulu wurrarra jalwa.
\xe There's a stong wind blowing.
\rf RS
\xv Ngajangaja-wurru burrbijkurru ngawu najba.
\xe I saw him running away fast.
\rf RS
\xv Wabudala nyulu burrbijbi. Budangku nyulu karrinjaa.
\xe He ran across and he didn't stop.
\rf RS
\xv Wanbiya nyulu, burrbijbi nyulu jambana barri.
\xe It (aeroplane) lands and then runs along the ground.
\rf RS
\xv Burrbijbi nana jayi yala barri durrajini.
\xe He ran away for good, feeling scared.
\rf GB
\xv Burrbijbi yalu niyangi.
\xe They ran away from us.
\rf EK
\xv Ngurrubu ngawu nan burrbijudu.
\xe I told him to run.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Burrbingi!
\xe Run!
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Burrbijbi nyulu mandaki-mukunu.
\sfx
\xe He's running away from the whitefella.
\rf IS_GB
\xv Dumularra burrbijbi wajka wanamin, kalana.
\xe The flood waters are flowing down in the river.
\rf MF_GB76
\xv Wuluku wurrarran burrbijbi.
\xe A big wind is blowing.
\rf MF_GB76
\va 
\sy
\cf jayi
\cf ngajangaja
\cf waku
\nt Pronounced {budbiijbi}
\cp
\nq

\lx -burru
\mr -burru
\sf
\sn 1
\ps suffix
\pc
\sd Grammar
\lt form of allative suffix on restricted set of words including pronouns with stem ending in [n]
\ge to
\ge towards
\ge than
\re
\so RS, GB
\xv Ngaki juka yaja nganyinburru.
\xe My boy is older than yours.
\rf GB
\xv Nanganginburru.
\xe Towards him.
\rf GB
\xv Kannga ninji nganyinburru jamba-wurru, kala-wurru, jungku-anyi ninji jambana nganyinbunu. Nayi nganyin jamban, budangku yalungi. 
\xe You have returned to your land, to your country, to live on your land. This is your land. It doesn't belong to other people.
\rf RS2004-05
\xv Kannga yalu, kaku-yudu. Jangkaranyi, ngabaa ngakinburru.
\xe They come back with fish. They bring cooked (fish) to me.
\rf RS2002-10
\xv Mayi bula janybijbi kara ngakinburru.
\xe They might throw a stone at me.
\rf RS
\va -kurru
\va -wurru
\sy
\cf
\nt Possibly derived from historical {b}+{(w)urru}.
\cp
\nq
\dt 30/Sep/2006

\lx burrurri
\mr burrurri
\sf burrurri-man.wav
\sf burrurri02-man.wav
\ps noun
\pc man.jpg
\sd PEOPLE
\lt
\ge man
\ge Aboriginal man
\re 
\re 
\so RS, GB, EF, MF_CO, EK, JD, SC_BB, MF_SK, MS_SK, RC+MF_SK, AP+AF_PS, JP_TT
\xv burrurri-darra
\sfx burrurri-darra.wav
\xe men
\rf EF
\xv Kuna-najba ngawu nana burrurrin.
\xa kuna-najba ngawu nana burrurrin.mp3
\xe I watched that man.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Burrurri nana bari.
\xe That man is no good.
\rf GB
\xv Najba ngawu burrurri, dara-wurru, dajkurru.
\xe I saw a man hitting a dog.
\rf GB
\xv Burrurri-wayan nyulu jungku, bankala.
\xe He's sitting like an Aboriginal man, cross-legged.
\rf GB
\xv Jakajba na burrurri
\xe Hunt this man away.
\rf GB
\xv Nanangkani burrurrii ngambalanya najba.
\xe That man is looking at us.
\rf GB
\xv Winjika burrurrin jila?
\sfx winyjika_burrurrin_jilaF.wav
\xe Which man is going?
\rf EF_R299EA1
\xv Wululukuu, burrurrii, kunymamba nyulu mukura.
\xe The old Aboriginal man, he's making a spear.
\rf RS2004-04
\xv Nginngirri ngawu bulanya -- kirriya, burrurrin.
\xe I'm watching them (both), a woman and a man.
\rf rs
\xv Jingili burrurri.
\xe A Jingili man.
\rf RS
\xv Winjika nana burrurri?
\sfx
\xe Who is that man?
\rf MF_SK
\xv Burrurrini nyulu jila.
\xe He's going with the man.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Burrirri-yudu.
\xe Married woman (lit. man-with).
rf MF_SK
\va burrurru
\sy
\cf kaburru
\cf wadubaku
\cf wululuku
\cf yarrbanji
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt 12/Sep/2006

\lx burrurru
\mr burrurru
\sf
\hm 2
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd MOTION
\lt X fall
\ge fall
\re fall
\so RS, JD93, MB_LH
\xv Durrajba nyulu. Mayi nyulu burrurru, ngaki ngada-nganja.
\xe She's frightened she might fall, my mother.
\rf RS
\xv Kalika, najba nungka ramiin. Burrurru nyulu.
\xe The light rain, we can see it. It's falling
\rf RS
\xv Kajalaba ninji kundana. Najba-najba nganyingka. Mayi ninji burrurru. 
\xe You climb up the tree. Watch out for yourself. You might fall.
\rf rs2000-09
\xv Burrurru nyulu kingkarrini. Namanyba nyulu niyanya, mangkanyii, kudanba.
\xe He may fall on top (of us) and he would pin us down with his body, and kill us.
\rf RS2005-08a
\va burruma
\va burumanijbi [GB]
\sy yirrbinkijbi
\cf
\nt
\cp
\nq check if not bururru ~ burruru
\dt 24/Oct/2006

\lx daba
\mr da(j)-ba
\sf daba.wav
\sf daba03.wav
\ps verb
\pc
\sd contact (impact and violence)
\lt Xerg come into contact with Y by means of body part or body of instrument
\ge beat
\ge fight
\ge hit
\ge kick
\ge slap
\ge strike
\re
\so EF, RS, MF+EM_CO
\xv Daba nyulu ninya kudanba jadiyadiyimbi, kundaa, wululukuu. Daba nyulu ninya kijibajii wululukuu.
\xe The old man, he will beat you to death, give you a really good hiding with a stick. The fierce old man will thrash you.
\rf RS2004-03
\xv Mirramba yalu babakana. Daba yalu karaa. Ramijbi yalu. Ngukujaba yalu yamarrina barri.
\xe They used to make stone knives. They would strike them with a rock and break them (in two). They would sharpen it on a flat rock.
\rf rs2002-04
\xv Yarraman, barrkidikidi. Daba nyulu ngambalanya, yarramana, kudanba.
\xe The horse, it's dangerous. The horse can kick us to death.
\rf rs2005-08a
\xv Daba nyulu ngaan burru-daba, barrkuu.
\xe He hit me and knocked me down with a nullanulla club.
\rf rs2004-03
\xv Daba bulangka, yulurrii muwaa.
\xe They had a fight because they were very angry with each other.
\rf rs2002-03
\xv Budangku yalu ngaan daba.
\xe They didn't hit me. (or Nobody hit me.)
\rf rs2003-01
\xv Mayi nungka daba, kundaa. Burrbijbi nyulu jayi.
\xe We might hit it with a stick. (So) he's taking off.
\rf RS03-01
\xv Dajini ngawu najba nana burrurrin.
\sfx dajini_ngawu_najba.mp3
\xe I saw that man (as I) hit him.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Ngurrubu ngawu nan dajudu.
\sfx
\xe I told him to hit her.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Daja!
\xe Hit (him)!
\rf MF+EM_CO
\va
\sy
\cf danyalamba
\cf dayi
\cf diba
\cf jadiyadiyimbi
\cf jurrbuwali
\cf kalijbi
\cf rangkijbi
\nt {Daba} is used with preverbal words to create some transitive verbs which do not necessarily contain a 'hit' meaning, e.g., {bikali-daba} 'lift', {burra-daba} 'knock down', {langan-daba} 'hang something'.
\cp
\nq
\dt 07/Oct/2006
\lf dababa
\lf dabawarr
\lf dabaya
\lf daja
\lf dajaya
\lf dajini
\lf dajkana
\lf dajkanyi
\lf dajkurru
\lf dajudu

\sn 1

\xe He kept on hitting him with a nullanulla, gave him a real hiding.

\lf daba

\lx dabarraba
\mr dabarra-ba
\sf dabarraba-cook.wav
\sf dabarraba-cookFR2999C1.wav
\ps verb
\pc
\sd FOOD
\lt Xerg produce the effect of heat on Y
\ge burn
\ge cook
\ge heat
\re
\so EF, RS, GB, EK, JD93, MF+EM_CO, MB_LH14
\xv Dabarraba ngawu.
\sfx
\xe I can cook.
\rf EF_R299C1
\xv Dabarraba nyulu niyanya duka nangkani nanyaluu ngabangabaa. Mayi nyulu barimbi niyanya dabarraba. 
\xe That hot tea can burn our throats. It might scald us and do us damage.
\rf rs2004-04
\xv Dabarraba nyulu nanyalu ngambalangi.
\xe He's making (=cooking) tea for us.
\rf RS2005-01
\xv Dabarraba ngamba nawunu jangunu.
\xe We are cooking it here on the fire.
\rf RS2004-01
\xv Dabarra-kanyi yalu walijin wingki.
\xe They will cook the raw meat.
\rf RS2004-06
\xv Kuku-najba nungka nayi wululuku, dabarra-kurru.
\xe We are watching this old man cooking.
\rf RS2004-04
\xv Dabarraba nyulu ngan, duruu. 
\xe The sun is burning me.
\rf RS2004-04
\xv Jamba nyulu dabarraba, ngadaraa jalwaa. Dabarraba nurriyanya jambaa, nukami.
\xe The strong sun is heating the ground. The ground is burning our feet.
\rf RS2004-04
\xv Ja-nyulu dabarraba walijin, wululukuu. Waliji-anyi, nanajba ngawu. Nanajba nungka, ngala nyulu dabarraba walijin.
\xe The old man, he will cook the meat. I'm waiting for that meat (to be cooked). Let's wait while he cooks the meat.
\rf rs 2004-04
\xv Dabarra-kana! Ngaki nana. Yakujbu! Yakujbuma!
\xe Don't cook (it). That's mine. Leave (it)! Leave it alone I say!
\rf RS2005-05
\xv Walijin yalu dabarraba. Dabarrajini yalu jungku.
\xe They are cooking meat. They are sitting cooking (it).
\rf RS2005-08b
\xv Ngurruju ngawu nan dabarrajudu.
\xe I told him to cook it.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Dabarraba ngawu waliji nganyi, dandini.
\xe I'm cooking meat for you, in an earth oven.
\rf EF_R299EB1
\va
\sy
\cf rajba
\cf ngarrangarra
\nt
\cp
\nq dabara glossed as burn in 2002-2
\dt 19/Sep/2006
\lf dabarrajini
\lf dabarrajudu
\lf dabarra-kana
\lf dabarra-kanyi
\lf dabarra-kurru

\lx dabawarr
\mr daba-warr
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd IMPACT
\lt something liable to strike and cause damage
\ge hitter
\ge killer
\ge kicker
\ge striker
\re killer
\so RS
\xv Dabawarr yarraman. Daba nyulu niyanya kudanba.
\xe The horse is a killer. It can give us a deadly blow.
\rf RS2005-08a
\va
\sy
\cf 
\cf kijibaji
\cf barrkidikidi
\nt
\cp
\nq

\lf daba

\lx dabaya
\mr da-ba-ya
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd IMPACT
\lt lest Xerg hit Y
\ge hit
\ge beat
\ge thrash
\re
\so RS
\xv Durrajba nyulu ngambalangi. Dabaya ngamba. Burra-daba kundaa, jadiyadiyimbii.
\xe He's frightened of us, thinking that we might hit him. Knock him down with a stick, give him a hiding.
\rf RS2005-01
\va dajaya
\sy
\cf 
\nt Seems to be used in same way as {dajaya}, a negative potential or avoidance form of {daba}.
\cp
\nq

\lx dadarrba
\mr dadarr-ba
\sf dadarrba.wav
\sf dadarrba02.wav
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd body
\sd bodily function
\lt X feel pain
\ge ache
\ge be sore
\ge hurt
\ge pain
\re
\so EF, GB, RS, CO, JD93
\xv Dadarrba barri ngawu nukamin.
\xe My foot is now hurting.
\rf RS2002-3
\xv Dadarrba ngawu, banyi.
\xe My body is paining.
\rf RS2004-05
\xv Dadarrba nyulu, kadimirra wawurra.
\sfx dadarrba-nyulu.wav
\xe The little child is hurting (all over).
\rf RS2004-05
\xv Jilana nurri dadarrba nukami.
\xe As we walk along our feet hurt.
\rf RS2002-10
\xv Dadarrba ngawu kuyi. Barrku-wunyi ngawu dadarrba, danyalamba-wunyi.
\xe My head is hurting. It's paining from being bashed by a nullanulla.
\rf RS2002-03
\xv Winja ninji dadarrba?
\xe Where are you hurting?
\rf GB
\xv Dadarrba ngawu. Mundirri ngawu bariyijbi, nayi mularrijbi kundan.
\xe I'm in pain. I hurt my back (when) I lifted this log.
\rf GB
\xv Dadarrba ngawu ramin.
\xe I have sore eyes.
\rf JD93
\xv Jungku ngawu nawunu dadarrkini.
\xe I'm staying here as I'm sore.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\va dadajba
\sy makuujbu
\cf kulawarrijbi
\cf mirriimbi
\nt Pronounced [dadadba]

\nq GB dadajba and dadadba; Flint clearly dadarrba ; RS also dadarrba [dadadba]; CO dadajba and [dadadgini]

\lx dajaya
\mr da-j-a-ya
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd IMPACT
\lt negative potential form of {daba}
\ge lest someone/something hit
\re 
\so RS
\xv Budangku ninji kannga nangkurru. Dajaya ngawu ninya, jadiyadiyimbi barrkuu.
\xe Don't you come back here, or I'll beat you up, give you a good hiding with a nullanulla.
\rf rs2005-01
\xv Dajaya nyulu ngaan, barrkuu, kudanba. Jadiyadiyimbi.
\sfx
\xe So he can't give me a severe beating with a nullanulla, a real hiding.
\rf RS2004-03
\xv Dajaya yalu ngambalanya.
\sfx dajaya yalu ngambalanya.wav
\xe They might kill us.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Dajaya yalu ngambalanya nana-waani burrurri-darraa, Kalkudunguu. Dajaya yalu ngambalanya, jungku ngamba nawunu, Kanmangini, Waanyi-darra.
\xe Lest those Kalkudungu men beat us up, lest they fight us, we'll stay here at Kanmangi as we are Waanyi.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Dajaya yalu ninya. Maninja.
\xe They might beat you up. Leave it alone!
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf
\nt The {dajaya} form of the verb {daba} is used when there is a possibility of something happening which is better avoided.
\cp
\nq
\dt
\lf daba
\lf daja
\lf dajini
\lf dajkana
\lf dajkanyi
\lf dajkurru

\lx dajkanyi
\mr daj-kanyi
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc hit_stick.jpg
\sd IMPACT
\lt Purposive form of {daba} 'hit'
\ge hit
\re
\so RS, GB
\xv Dajkanyi nyulu kundaa, burra-daba.
\xe He's got to hit it with a stick and knock it down.
\rf 2005-01
\xv Dajkanyi ngawu nan jungkinya, barrkuu.
\xe I'll hit him back with a nullanulla.
\rf RS
\xv Dajkanyi nangka, warrakujini.
\sfx
\xe He'll kill himself in a fit of madness.
\rf RS
\xv Budangu ngawiji ninya dajkanyi.
\xe I didn't mean to hit you.
\rf GB
\xv Nanganja-anyi ngawu kunda, dajkanyi ngawu nan dara.
\xe I'll get a stick to hit this dog.
\rf MF_GB76
\va
\sy
\cf
\nt

\lx dakalijbi
\mr dakali-j-bi
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd motion
\lt X rapidly move downwards
\ge dive down 
\ge duck
\re
\so 2004-04
\xv Darrandarra, dakalijbi nyulu balikaajini. Dakalijbi nyulu kaku-anyi, kuujini kaku-anyi.
\xe The Diver Duck, it ducks down (under the water) when hungry. It dives down to get fish, looking for fish.
\rf rs2005-02
\xv Dakalijbi nyulu kunda-wunyi jambana wajka. Buluburrbi nyulu wajka  jamba-wurru.
\xe He quickly got down from the tree onto the ground. He jumped down to the ground.
\rf RS2005-02
\xv Mudi nyulu. Dakalijbi nyulu, dakalijbi. Budangku ngawu naan najba. Ngadijbi nangka burrurrii, durrajini.
\xe He's low down. He's has ducked down. I can't see him. The man is hiding himself as he's afraid.
\rf RS2004-04
\va
\sy
\cf buluburrbi
\cf burrurru 
\cf kulijibi
\cf mudi
\cf wajka
\cf wanbiya 
\nt
\cp Garrwa {dakalijba}

\sfx
\xe He quickly got down from the tree. He jumped down to the ground. You made him drop down from the tree to the ground. He's down in the grass. He's hiding.
\rf RS2004-06

\re shady tree
\re shelter

\xe She's sitting in the shade.
\rf RS2004-08a
\xv Budangku nayi dalu-anyi. Jungku nurri durunu. Rajba nurriyanya duruu. Ngarrangarrajba nurri.
\xe There's no shade here. We are sitting in the sun. The sun is baking us. We are getting hot.
\rf RS2002-10
\xv Yakujbu nyulu niyanya daluu, nganduu.
\xe The shade is leaving us, the shadow. (We are no longer in the shade.)
\rf RS2005-01
\xv Karrinja nganyi yajangu, nganyinbuyangka dalu. Jungku ngamba, wakalinyi.
\xe It's standing in front of you, the shady tree is near you. We are sitting under it.
\rf RS2000-11
\xv Dalunu langanba, nana waliji.
\xe That meat, it is hanging in the shade.

\lx dangajba
\mr danga-j-ba
\sf 
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd motion
\lt X move closer to some entity (Ydat) so that presence of X is not known
\ge sneak up
\ge stalk
\ge creep up
\re
\so RS
\xv Jangajba nyulu burrurrin, mukura-yudu.
\sfx dangajba nyulu burrurrin mukura-yudu.wav
\xe The man snuck up on it with his spear.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Jarrkurru nyulu jangajba.
\sfx
\xe He's sneaking up (on it) while it's eating.
\rf RS
\xv Jangajba nyulu wululuku -- waliji-anyi, kalijkanyi nyulu mukuraa.
\sfx
\xe The old man is sneaking up on the animal, so he can spear it.
\rf RS
\xv Binanyba nyulu walijin. Kudijbi nyulu. Jangajba.
\xe He stalked the animal. It was sleeping. (He) snuck up (on it).
\rf RS2002-12
\xv Jangajba nyulu ngaki. Jangajba. Bijkanyi nyulu ngaan, kudijkurru.
\xe He's sneaking up on me. Sneaking up. He intends to attack me while I'm asleep.
\rf RS2002-01
\xv Jangajba nyulu ngambalangi.
\sfx
\xe He's sneaking up on us.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku nyulu mankuu nana burrurrin Jangajkurru.
\sfx
\xe He can't hear that fella sneaking up (on him).
\rf RS2005-04

\re
