\xe He hit him with a boomerang, knocked him down. Smashed it against the back of his neck.
\rf RS2002-03
\xv Daba ngawu kundaa. Dangalbangi.
\xe I hit him with a stick. Smashed him (with it).
\rf RS2000-03
\xv Wadaba, marijbi ngawu, bambularra-nanja. Wilirrjirri ngawu. Dangalbangi. Daba ngawu kajalaa. Dangalbangi.
\xe The goanna, I grabbed hold of it by the tail. I dragged it out (of its burrow). Dealt it a killing blow. I hit it with my digging stick, knocked it out.
\rf RS2000-03
\xv Dangalbangi ngawu, kudanbarri.
\xe I hit and killed it.
\rf RS2002-01

\xe They struck him with a rock and they killed him stone dead.

\sd animal
\lt pair of emus
\ge pair of emus
\ge two emus
\re emu (pair of)
\so RS, GB
\xv Dangkarr-wuya, kujarra.
\sfx jangkarr-wuya_kujarra_RS.wav
\xe A pair of emus, two (of them).
\rf RS2004-05
\xv Dangkarr-wuya, kananganja kujarra.
\sfx
\xe 'Dangkarr-wuya' means two emus.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf kananganja
\cf ngaribundu
\cf nujungunyi
\nt
\cp
\nq GB recorded as <dangkarr-wiya>
\dt

\ge charcoal

\rf rs2003-05
\xv Nijbi ninji danyalina barri. Dabarraba nungka nayi walijin, wadaba.

\lx dara
\mr dara
\sf dara.wav
\sf dara02.wav
\sf dara03.wav
\sf daraa.wav
\sf daran.wav
\sf dara-02_CO.wav
\ps noun
\pc dara.jpg
\sn 1
\sd animal (introduced)
\la Canis familiaris 
\lt
\ge dog
\re
\so RS, EF, GB, EK, JD, SC_BB, PK_SK, LP_SK, AP+AF_PS, JP_TT
\xv dara-yudu
\sfx dara-yurdu.wav
\xe with a dog
\rf EF
\xv Dara nayi barri kudajba.
\sfx dara-nayi-barri-kudajba.wav
\xe This dog has died.
\rf EF
\xv Ngaki daran, kunyba wadaba-anyi.
\sfx
\xe My dog, it's good at hunting goannas.
\rf EF_299AE2
\xv Bajalijbi nyulu nukami daraa.
\xe The dog is smelling (his) tracks.
\rf rs2005-01
\xv Bujubu nyulu dara-yudu.
\xe He’s sleeping with a dog
\rf rs2000-09
\xv Kawa-najba nyulu, daraa, kudijkurru.
\xe The dog found it (kangaroo) lying down.
\rf RS2005-01
\xv Nyulu-kiya bijbi ngaa nangkani daraa.
\sfx
\xe This dog would have bitten me.
\rf rs2000-10
\xv Jilaba yalu karriya nana, marrkajini, kaja-yudu dara-yudu.
\xe They go on the east side hunting with a big mob of dogs.
\rf RS2005-08b
\xv Daba ngawu nayi daran wandura-kurru.
\xe I hit this dog that was barking.
\rf RS2000-10
\xv Janybijbi nyulu dara-wurru.
\xe He's throwing (it) to the dog.
\rf RS2005-02
\xv Windijbi nungka dara jalukii.
\xe We give the dogs the guts.
\rf RS2004-03
\xv Lalumbu nyulu ngaan, daraa, wanduraba nyulu.
\xe The dog wakes me up, he barks.
\rf RS2000-09
\xv Nana nyulu jungku dara.
\sfx
\xe A dog is sitting there.
\rf LP_SK
\va
\sy bajangu
\sy burawa
\cf kujukuju
\cf warrki
\nt In fluent speech {dara-yudu} 'with a dog' is pronounced [daraadu].
\cp
\nq
\dt 18/Sep/2006

\lf darana
\lf dara-wurru

\pc

\ge Yellow Plum
\re
\so RS, GB, JD
\xv Windijbi nyulu ngalyaa, nanangkani mamaa. Lungkarraa. Darimaa. Budangku ngamba jarrba. Wingki nyulu. Duruu, rajba barri nana maman, darima. Nanganja ngamba. Jarrba barri ngamba, jangkaranyi.
\xe That bitter unripe plum makes (us) sick. We can't eat it when it’s raw. When the sun has ripened the plum fruit, we pick it and then we eat it, ripe.

\lf darrajba

\lx -darra
\mr -darra
\sf
\sn 1
\ps suffix
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt plural suffix: indicates the noun it attaches to refers to more than two entities of the type denoted by its host word
\ge some
\ge many
\ge more than two of
\re some
\re several
\so RS2002-13
\xv Bayungunanbinyi nanawaan burrurri kirriya-darra.
\xe Those men and women are from the west.
\rf rs2005-08a
\xv Jungku ninji, kujarrana? Budangkun. Murrku-darrana.
\xe Are you staying for two (nights)? No. For four.
\rf rs2003-01
\xv Burrurri-darra
\sfx burrurri-darra.wav
\xe Men
\rf EF
\xv Kirriya-darra nana-waa.
\xe Those women.
\rf GB
\xv Dajaya yalu ngambalanya nana-waani burrurri-darraa, Kalkudunguu. Dajaya yalu ngambalanya, jungku ngamba nawunu, Kanmangini, Waanyi-darra.
\xe Lest those Kalkudungu men beat us up, lest they fight us, we Waanyi people will stop here at Kanmangi.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Ja nyulu jariyamba nana-murrku kadimirra-darra wawurra-darra.
\xe He will carry off those little boys.
\rf rs2004-08a
\xv Jungku yalu birajini yurrulini nana-waan burrurri-darra.
\xe Those men are sitting singing a corroboree song.
\rf rs2004-01
\xv Jungkumu narri kaja-darra.
\xe Sit down, you lot!
\rf GB
\va
\sy
\cf -kuya
\cf -waa(n)
\cf -wiya 
\cf -wuya
\nt
\cp Barkly languages
\nq
\dt 12/Sep/2006

\lx dawurrumbu
\mr dawurru-mbu
\sf dawurrumbu.wav
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd motion
\lt completely do something
\ge
\ge complete
\ge do to the end
\ge exhaust
\ge finish
\re complete
\re finish
\re use up
\so RS, GB, CO
\xv Dawurrumbu nungka nayi yanyin. Budangku barri nayi yanyi-anyi.
\xe We've finished this language (work). There's no more words left.
\rf rs2005-01
\xv Ngaraba ngawu dawurrumbu, wanamin, ngajirrin.
\xe I've finished drinking up all the cold water.
\rf rs2005-01
\xv Ngulumirri, dabarraba nyulu. Jarrba yalu dawurrumbu. Budangku yalu yakujbu, nana-waan-kanyi.
\sfx jarrba yalu dawurrumbu-they ate all.wav
\sfx budangku yalu yakujbu nana-waan-kanyi.wav
\xe The barramundi, she cooked it. They ate it all up. They didn't leave anything for others.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Bungkana, jilaba ngawu nangkurru, windijbi nyulu ngan waliji-anyi. Budangku nurri waliji-anyi. Dawurrumbu nurri.
\xe Yesterday, I came here, and he gave me some meat. We don't have any meat, we finished it all up.
\rf RS2000-10
\xv Dawurrumbu ngaka, makarraba ngaka bulinyaa dawurrumbu. Budangku yalu ngaan najba.
\xe I did it to myself completely, I covered myself all over with weeds, so they couldn't see me.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Jarrkana ninji! Jarrkana nana maman, dawurrumbu ninji.
\xe Don't you eat (it)! Don't eat that food, you're eating it all up.
\rf RS2005-05
\xv Dawurrumbu nyulu, wululukuu, burrurriin. Budangku nyulu maninyi barri.
\xe The old man has finished it all. He has nothing more left now.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Dawurrumbu yalu jarrba.
\sfx Dawurrumbu yalu jarrba.wav
\xe They ate it all.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Dawurrumbu-yanyi ngamba nawunu -- yanjini.
\sfx dawurrumbu-yanyi-ngamba-nawunu_CO.wav
\xe So we will finish it (language recording) here.
\rf OSBORNE_C02-000165B.TMP
\xv Dawurrumu!
\xe Finish (it)!
\rf MF+EM_CO
\va
\sy
\cf
\nt {dawurrumbu} typically combines with another verb to express completeness of effect of act denoted by other verb.
\cp
\nq
\dt 24/Oct/2006
\lf dawurru
\lf dawurrumu


\lx dayi
\mr dayi
\sf dayi.wav
\sf dayi02.wav
\ps verb
\pc
\sd contact (impact and violence)
\lt Xerg cause axe to come into contact with Y in order to damage integrity of Y
\ge cut with axe
\ge chop
\ge cut off
\re
\so RS, EF, GB, CO
\xv Dayi jangu.
\sfx dayi-jangu.wav
\xe Chop firewood.
\rf EF
\xv Dayi mani.
\sfx
\xe Chop off a finger.
\rf EF_R299B3
\xv Dirrbu-anyi nana jila dayini.
\sfx dirrbu-anyi-nana-jila-dayini.wav
\xe That one's going chopping (the tree) for honey.
\rf EF
\xv Dayi nyulu wamulun, durukii.
\xe He chop out that coolimon (from bark of tree) with an axe.
\rf RS2005-03
\xv Bungkana ngawu kawa-najba, dirrbu. Kundana. Dayi ngawu, burra-daba.
\xe Yesterday I found honey, in a tree. I chopped it down.
\rf RS2003-02
\xv Dayi, kurrijbi nyulu kundan. Dayi nyulu kundan dirrbu-anyi.
\xe He chopped open the tree (around the hive). He chopped the tree to get the honey.
\rf RS2000-11
\xv Dayi ngawu nanangkanyi jangun, windijbi nyulu walijii niyanya.
\xe I chopped firewood for that man (who) gives us meat.
\rf GB
\va
\sy
\cf daba
\cf diba
\cf karrbijbi
\cf kurrijbi
\nt Also recorded by Breen (W-G vocab) as 'hatch' (from egg)
\cp
\nq ? not sure?
\dt 21/Sep/2006
\lf dayini

\lx diba
\mr diba
\hm
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd contact
\sd impact
\lt Xerg come into contact with surface of Y, by moving through air
\ge strike (of missile)
\ge hit
\ge pelt
\ge pound
\re
\so EF, GB, RS, CO, JD93
\xv Diba ngan nukami karaa. Yirrbinkijbi ngawu karana.
\sfx
\xe A stone struck my foot. I tripped on the stone.
\rf GB
\xv Mama nan diba-diba kunda-nanja. Yirrbinkijbi kunda-wunyi, langankini, jamba-wurru.
\xe This fruit was struck down from the tree. It fell from the tree where it was hanging, to the ground.
\rf GB
\xv Diba ngaa nanangkani burrurrii, karaa.
\xe That man struck me with a stone.
\rf GB
\xv Dibama!
\xe Hit (him)!
\rf GB ; MF+EM_CO
\xv Diba mayi.
\xe Knock out a tooth.
\rf JD93
\xv Diba ngawu karayudinyi.
\xe I hit him with a stone.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\va
\sy rangkijbi
\sy rangkimbi
\cf daba
\cf dayi
\an
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt
\lf dibarriba

\lx dibarriba
\mr diba-diba
\hm
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd CONTACT & IMPACT
\lt Xerg repeatedly come into contact with Y by means of part of X or entity manipulated by X
\ge hit repeatedly
\ge tap on
\ge bang on
\ge rap on
\re tap
\so GB, JD93
\xv Dibarriba manii!
\sfx
\xe Bang on it with (your) hand!
\rf GB
\xv Mama nan dibarriba kunda-nanja. Yirrbinkijbi kunda-wunyi, langankini, jamba-wurru.
\xe This fruit was struck down from the tree. It fell from the tree where it was hanging, to the ground.
\rf GB
\va
\sy
\cf diladilarraba
\an
\nt This reduplicated verb pronounced [dibarriba] with lenition of /d/ between vowels
\nt Dymock (1993) records as 'hit, smash'
\cp
\nq
\dt

\lx diindi
\mr diindi
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd spatial
\lt uninterrupted path
\ge straight 
\ge right through 
\ge straight through
\ge without stopping
\re straight
\so RS
\xv Diindi nyulu jilaba.
\sfx diindi_nyulu_jilaba_RS.wav
\xe He went straight.
\rf RS2005-01
\xv Budangku ngamba yunngurrijbi. Diindi nurri jilaba. Budangku nurri jungku, jilaba nurri, diindi nurri jilaba, kaku-anyi.
\xe We won't stay. We'll keep going. We won't stop, we'll keep going, we'll go straight (there) to catch fish.
\rf RS2003-03
\xv Yakujbu nyulu ngambalanya. Diindi nyulu burrbijbi.
\xe He left us. He ran off without stopping.
\rf RS2004-07
\xv Budangku nyulu jilaba diindi. Warrawarra nyulu. Yirrbinkijbi nyulu. Lalujbu nyulu, burra-daba nangka.
\xe He couldn't walk straight. He was all over the place. He was staggering and falling about. He would get up and then fall down again.
\rf rs2002-13
\va
\sy
\cf kajikaji [GB]
\cf maka-nijbi
\nt
\cp Wambaya {dirndija} 'straight'
\nq dandi in 2002, only one example of each!
\dt 29/Sep/2006
\sn 2
\ps noun
\pc
\sd evaluative
\lt
\ge correct
\ge right
\ge true
\re
\so
\xv Manku-anyi ngawu ninya yanykurru, diindi ninji yanyba.
\xe I've got to listen to you talking (to see if) you're talking straight (i.e. correctly).
\rf RS2003-03
\xv Diindi ngawu yanyba, diindi. Budangku ngawu jijamba.
\sfx
\xe I spoke straight, the truth. I didn't lie.
\rf RS2003-03
\xv Budangku nyulu niyanya ngurrubu, winja-kurru nyulu jilaba. Wunjuku ninji jilaba, wululuku? Ngurrubu ninji ngaan. Diindi ngaan ngurrubu.
\xe He doesn't tell us where he's going. Where are you going old man? You tell me. Tell me straight.
\rf RS2003-02
\xv Diindi ninji ngurrubu nayi lungkaji.
\xe You tell this policeman the truth.
\rf RS2004
\va dindi [MB_LH]
\sy durrka
\cf
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt

\lx dirrbu
\mr dirrbu
\sf didbu-sugarbag.wav
\ps noun
\pc sugarbag.jpg
\sd animal related
\sd food
\la Hymenoptera; Apoidea; Trigona spp., Austroplebeia spp.
\lt honey of native bees from tree hive
\ge bee hive
\ge honey
\ge sugarbag
\re 
\so RS, EF, EK, JD93, GW
\xv Jarrkanyi barri ngawu nayi dirrbun.
\xe I now want to eat this honey.
\rf RS2002-02
\xv Dayi nyulu kundan dirrbu-anyi.
\xe He's chopping the tree to get the honey.
\rf RS2000-11
\xv Dirrbu-anyi nana jila dayini.
\sfx dirrbu-anyi-nana-jila-dayini.wav
\xe That one's going chopping (the tree) for honey.
\rf EF
\xv Wungkurru nyulu kunuma. Manku ngawu, kuwadaa. Dirrbu, najba ngawu rami.
\xe The bees are humming. I can hear them with my ears. The honey hive, I can see its opening.
\rf RS2003-02
\xv Budangku ngawu kawa-najba dirrbu.
\xe I didn't find any honey.
\rf RS2003-02
\xv Dirrbu ngawu kawa-najba. Kawa-najba ngawu, kunuma, baba-wurru. Rami ngawu najba.
\xe I've found a bee hive. I've found the forager bees flying around. I can see the hole (entrance to nest inside tree trunk).
\rf RS2003-02
\va dirrbi [GB, CO]
\sy marrji
\sy mungi
\sy ngiri
\cf kambalarri
\cf kunuma
\cf wajili
\cf KURUDA (JD93)
\nt Pronounced [didbu].
\nt Dymock (1993) records for 'all sweet food', 'all sugarbag'
\cp
\nq

\lx duka
\mr duka
\sf duka.wav
\sf duka-throat.wav
\ps noun
\pc
\sd body
\lt
\ge neck
\ge throat
\re throat
\re neck (front of)
\so EF, RS, GB, CO, EK, LM, JD93, SC_BB, MS_SK
\xv Marijbi nyulu duka-nanja.
\xe He grabbed him by the throat.
\rf RS2005-01, GB
\xv Buduramba ngawu ninya, duka.
\xe I'll wring your neck.
\rf RS2002-03
\xv Namanyba ngawu ninya nukamii, duka.
\xe I'll press down on your throat with my foot (and choke you).
\rf RS2002-03
\xv Kirijbi nyulu dukaa, nana walijin.
\xe He's swallowing that meat down his throat.
\rf RS2004-05
\xv Mayi ninya nanganja kaburrukajaa, nanganja-anyi ninya, marijbi manii. Bijbi ninya. Jidimbi ninya duka.
\xe A crocodile might get you. It's going to get you, grab you with its claws, bite you, and squeeze you by the throat.
\rf RS2004-07
\xv Mudamudajibi nangka duka. Duka-nanja nangka langandaba.
\xe He tied (the rope) around his throat. He hanged himself by the neck.
\rf RS2005-08b
\xv Duka yalu ngaan bijbi daraa kijibajii.
\xe Wild dogs might grab me by the throat.
\rf RS2004-untaped
\xv Nganmarrkijbi ngawu duka, yanyjini.
\sfx nganmarrkijbi ngawu dukan yanjini.wav
\xe My throat is getting dry from talking.
\rf RS
\xv Dabarraba nyulu niyanya duka, nangkani nanyaluu ngabangabaa.
\xe This hot tea is burning our throats.
\rf RS2004-04
\va
\sy
\cf janki
\cf ngundungundu
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt 19/Sep/2006

\lx dumularra
\mr dumularra
\sf dumularra.wav
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc 
\sd ELEMENTS
\sd water
\lt body of surface water
\ge flowing water
\ge flood water
\ge running water
\re
\so RS, GB, EK, JD93
\xv Wanamii, barimbi nyulu yubal. Wanamiin, dumularraa.
\xe The rain, it wrecked the road. The water, the flowing water (did).
\rf rs
\xv Yimbirra nyulu bikalii, dumularraa. 
\xe The floodwaters carry the refuse along with them.
\rf rs2005-02
\xv Langkurri nyulu wanami dumularra burrbijbi.
\xe The flood water is flowing to the north.
\rf RS2002-09
\xv Nana kundan, wanamii jayajayamba dumularraa.
\xe That tree, it is being tossed around by the flood waters.
\rf RS2004-04
\xv Dumularra wuluku.
\xe Big flood waters.
\rf RS
\xv Winjuraba ngambalanya. Burra-daba wanami ngambalangi. Mirramba nyulu dumularra. 
\xe It's raining on us. The rain is pouring down on us. It's forming a fast running current.
\rf RS
\xv Raji ngaki wajka kalana. Dumularraa ngan jakajba kala-wunyi.
\xe My camp was down near the river. The flood waters chased me away from the river.
\rf GB
\xv Dumularra wajka barri nayi.
\xe The water (in the river) is now low.
\rf EK (ML notes)
\va
\sy
\cf jakuli
\cf kala
\cf mali
\cf manangka
\cf wanami
\nt Dymock (1993) also records NGAYULU 'running water'
\cp
\nq flood water in RS2002-1
\dt 19/Sep/2006

\ge rock

\re

\rf RS2002-02
\xv Karrbijbi nurri. Jaluki, janybijbi nurri. Nijbi nurri dungalan.
\xe We cut it (open). The intestines we toss aside. We put in hot stones.
\rf RS2003-03
\xv Daba yalu dungalaa.
\xe They bashed him with a rock.
\rf RS2003-09
\xv Daba nyulu mangkarri-nganyjaa dungalaa. Kuyi nyulu daba, dungalaa, nana wululuku, kijibajii kirriyaa.
\xe His wife hit him with a rock. The wild woman hit that old man on the head with a rock.
\rf RS2003-03
\xv Dungala wuluku. Budangku nurri kajalaba. Jujuu kingkarri.
\xe It's a big hill. We can't climb it. It's too high.
\rf RS2002-06
\va
\sy kara
\cf dandi
\cf dadara
\nt Noted as Garrwa by GB.
\cp
\nq I have frequently transcribed as {dungkala}. CHECK

\lx durrajba
\mr durra-j-ba
\sf durrajba.wav
\sf durrajba02.wav
\sf durrajba03.wav
\ps verb
\pc
\sd mind
\lt X have fear (of Ydat)
\ge fear
\ge afraid (of)
\ge scared (of)
\re
\so EF, RS, GB, JD, MF+EM_CO
\xv Miya-anyi ninji wayi durrajba?
\sfx miyaanyi-ninyji-wayi-durrajb.wav
\xe Are you frightened of snakes?
\rf EF
\xv Miya-anyi ngawu durrajba.
\sfx miyaanyi-ngawu-durrajba.wav
\xe I'm frightened of snakes.
\rf EF
\xv Nayi barrawal, durrajba nyulu barrawal. Durrajba nyulu burrurri-anyi. 
\xe This white cockatoo, it gets frightened. It gets frightened of the man.
\rf rs2003-03
\xv Durraja ngawu, birrirri ngawu.
\xe I'm frightened, I'm shaking (with fear).
\rf rs2004
\va
\xv Durrajba nyulu ngambalangi. Dabaya ngamba, burra-daba kundaa, jadiyadiyimbii.
\xe He's frightened of us, thinking that we might hit him, knock him down with a stick, give him a hiding.
\rf RS2005-01
\xv Ngadijbi nangka burrurrii, durrajini.
\xe The man is hiding as he's afraid.
\rf RS2004-04
\xv Durrajba ngawu nangangi. Mayi nyulu ngaan kalijbi, mukuraa.
\xe I'm scared of him. He might spear me.
\rf RS
\xv Durrajba nyulu, dajaya ngamba.
\xe He's afraid we might hit him.
\rf RS
\xv Durrajba ngawu. Nana nyulu jila.
\xe I'm frightened. He's coming.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Durrajba ngawu nanangkanyi.
\xe I'm afraid of that one.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Wanyingkanyi ninji durrajba?
\sfx
\xe What are you frightened of?
\rf IS_GB
\sy
\cf
\nt
\cp Wambaya {durra} 'fear'
\nq 
\dt 05/Sep/2006

\lx duru

\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc duru.jpg
\pc sun.jpg
\sn 1
\sd ELEMENTS
\sd sky
\lt sun
\ge sun
\ge sunlight
\re
\so RS, GB, EF, JD93, RC_SK, RC+MF_SK, JP_TT, MB_LH12

\xe This sun is now high up above us.

\xe The sun is now going down on us.
\rf RS2004-08a

\xe Hot sun.
\rf RS
\xv Najba barri ngamba duru. Lalujbu ninji.
\xe We can now see the sun. You get up.
\rf RS
\xv Dabarraba nyulu ngan, duruu. 
\xe The sun is burning me.
\rf RS2004-04
\xv Jambaa nurriyanya rajba nukami, kijibajii nangkani duruu.
\xe The hot ground is burning our feet, (because of) this fierce sun.
\rf RS
\xv Duruu, rajba barri nana maman, darima. Nanganja ngamba.
\xe When the sun has ripened the plum fruit, we pick it.
\rf RS2002-11
\xv Kindiba ngamba jungku, jalanya, durunu barri.
\xe We are now sitting here sweating, now that we are in the sun.
\rf RS2004-04
\xv Rajba ngaan. Duruu. Rajba niyanya jalwaa janguu.
\xe It's burning me, the sun (is). The strong heat is burning us.
\rf rs2005-09
\xv Jungku nurri durunu. Rajba nurriyanya duruu. Ngarrangarrajba nurri. Kindiba nurri.
\xe We are sitting in the sun. The sun is cooking us. We are getting hot. We're sweating.
\rf RS2002-10
\xv Jilaba nyulu budangku warikiki-anyi, maniinyi. Mayi nyulu kulawarrijbi, duru-wunyi. Kuyi-mandaja!
\xe He goes without a hat, with nothing. He's likely to get a headache from the sun. His poor head!
\rf RS2004-05
\xv
\xe
\rf
\va
\sy ngadara
\cf ngabu-ngabu
\cf ngarrangarra
\nt 
\cp Nhanta {turi} ‘sun’; Tharrkari & Warriyangka {juru} ‘sun; daytime’; Wajarri {thuri} ‘sunlight, daytime’
\nq duruu? duru-wu in careful speech 2003-03 {add synonym ngadara}; {ngadara} is Garrwa
\dt 12/Sep/2006
\lf duru-anyi
\lf durunu
\lf dururruru
\lf duruu

\sn 2
\ps noun
\pc
\sd time
\lt period of time during which sun is visible
\ge day
\ge daylight hours
\ge light
\re
\so RS, JD, RC_SK, RC+MF_SK
\xv Jungku nurri yingkanyini durunu, kannga nurri yababalana.
\xe We'll stay away during the day and return in the evening.
\rf RS
\xv Kankulu nurri durunu barri.
\xe We are having a feed now it's light.
\rf RS
\xv Jilaba ngawu kujarrana, durunu.
\xe I'm going for two days.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf ngunyi
\cf mudunama
\an mungamba
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt


\lx duruki
\mr duruki
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc stone_axe.jpg
\sd artifact
\lt small axe
\ge tommyhawk
\ge axe
\re
\so RS, EK, JD
\xv Dayi nyulu wamulun, durukii.
\xe He cut out that coolimon (from bark of tree) with a tommyhawk.
\rf RS2005-03
\xv Dayi ngawu, durukii, nayi kundan, dirrbu-wanyi. Burra-daba ngawu, durukii.
\xe I chop this tree with a tommyhawk to get the honey. I chop it down with a tommyhawk.
\rf RS
\xv Karrba nayi jangu durukii.
\xe Cut this firewood with an axe.
\rf EK (ML notes)

\sy

\lx dururruru
\mr dururruru {< *duru-duru}
\sf durururu.wav
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc dawn.jpg
\sd ELEMENTS
\sd sky (sky, moon, star, sun)
\sd time
\lt
\ge dawn
\ge first light
\ge sunrise
\ge sun-up
\re
\so RS, GB, JD93
\xv Laluyu barri ninji, laluyu. Dururruru.
\xe Get up now, get up. The sun's coming up.
\rf RS
\xv Wanbiya ngawu dururruru.
\sfx
\xe I arrived at dawn.
\rf rs2005-08b
\xv Yakujbu ngawu narriyanya, dururruru, mudunama.
\xe I leave you tomorrow morning at first light.
\rf RS
\xv Dururruru. Lalujbu nyulu ngunyi-wunyi.
\xe At first light, he woke up and got out of bed.
\rf RS
\xv Jilaba nurri dururrurunu.
\xe We are going at first light.
\rf RS
\va
\sy WURRBANDA
\cf barriyi
\nt Recorded by Dymock (1993) as 'piccaniny dawn'

\nq

\dt



\lx ja
\mr ja
\sf
\sn 1
\ps particle
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt indicates a possible future event or obligation to be fulfilled
\ge will
\ge must
\re
\so RS, EF, GB, EK
\xv Ja ngaka durramba.
\sfx ja-ngaka-durramba.wav
\xe I'll get frightened.
\rf EF
\xv Ja ngawu nganyi kirajba.
\xe I'll send (it) to you.
\rf RS
\xv Ja ninji baba barulajba. Kingkarri-nanja, walajba ninji nurriyanya, jungku-wurru.
\xe You will fly over us. From up high, you'll look down on us sitting (here).
\rf rs2005-08
\xv Ja ngawu jilaba jalanya, kudijkanyi ngawu.
\xe I've got to go now, I want to lie down.
\rf RS2005-08a
\xv Windijbi ja nyulu ngaan kara-anyi.
\xe He will give me money.
\rf RS2002-07
\xv Ja nyulu dabarraba walijin, wululukuu. Waliji-anyi, nanajba ngawu. Nanajba nungka, ngala nyulu dabarraba walijin.
\xe The old man, he will cook the meat. I'm waiting for that meat (to be cooked). Let's wait while he cooks the meat.
\rf rs 2004-04
\xv Ja nyulu jariyamba nana-murrku kadimirra-darra wawurra-darra.
\xe He will carry off those little boys.
\rf rs2004-08a
\xv Ja ngamba kannga-yirrimbi, raji-wurru.
\xe So we can take it back home.
\rf RS 2004-03
\xv Ngawu, ja ngawu nanganja ngaki maku-nganja.
\sfx ja-ngawu_nanganja_ngaki_maku-nganjaRS.wav
\xe As for me, I'm going to get my cousin (as my wife).
\rf RS2002-15
\xv Nawan ngilangila, kirriya-darra, ja yalu mindikirri.
\xe These young girls, and women, they must dance.
\rf RS
\xv Jawikajba ngawu ninya, ja ninji mirramba jukuli ngaki?
\xe I'm asking you, will you make me a boomerang?
\rf RS
\xv Ja nyulu mulaarri.
\xe He will lift it up.
\rf GB
\xv Jangu ja nungka nanganja daandii.
\xe Let's get hot coals (from the fireplace).
\rf EK (ML notes)
\xv Windijbi ngan kuluu-yudungi, dayi-ja ngawu jangun.
\xe Give me an axe, I'll chop firewood.
\rf MF_GB76
\va
\sy
\cf
\nt {Ja} is usually first or second word in sentence or clause and is followed by the subject pronoun so that it sounds like a single word with main stress on {ja}.
\nt This particle is also found in Garrwa, and was considered by some Waanyi speakers consulted by Breen as a non-Waanyi feature borrowed from Garrwa. 
\cp
\nq
\dt 04/Sep/2006

\xe Put out the fire with water.

\sfx
\xe Put out the fire last night.

\lf jadimbi-kanyi

\lf jadijbi


\lx jadiyadiyimbi
\mr jardiyardi-yi-mbi
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd contact (impact and violence)
\lt Xerg beat Y severely
\ge give good hiding
\ge give a good beating
\ge bash
\ge beat up
\ge thrash
\re bash
\re beat up
\re punish
\re beating
\re hiding
\so RS, EK
\xv Daba nyulu ninya kundaa, jadiyadi-yimbi.
\xe He hit you with a stick, gave you a hiding.
\rf RS
\xv Dajaya nyulu ngaan barrkuu, jadiyadiyimbi.
\xe So that he doesn't hit me, beat me up.
\rf RS
\xv Kudumanja nyulu, jadiyadi-yimbi daba, wawurra kuwada-yaan.
\xe He kept on severely hitting that senseless child.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku ninji kannga nangkurru. Dajaya ngawu ninya, jadiyadiyimbi barrkuu.
\xe Don't you come back here, or I'll beat you up, give you a good hiding with a nullanulla.
\rf rs2005-01
\xv Ngindi-ngindijbi kadimirra ngila, ngada-nganjaa naan daba kundaa. Jadiyadiyimbi.
\xe The little girl is crying (because) her mother is hitting her with a stick.
\rf RS
\va jadiyadimbi [EK]
\sy
\sy
\cf burra-daba
\cf daba
\cf minamina-ngumbu
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt 21/Sep/2006


\lx jakajba
\mr jaka-j-ba
\sf jakajba.wav
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc 
\sd MOTION
\lt Xerg cause Y to move away from some place
\ge chase away
\ge hunt away
\ge send away
\ge expel
\re
\so RS, GB
\xv Jakajba ngawu kaburrukaja. Kudijbi nyulu.
\xe I chased away the crocodile. He was lying asleep.
\rf RS
\xv Jakajba nyulu ngaan. "Kuuni jilanji! Kuuni jilanji ninji!"
\xe He hunted me away. "Go away! You go away!"
\rf RS
\xv Mayi yalu ninya jakajba nanambunyi jamba-wunyi.
\xe They might hunt you away from that place.
\rf RS
\xv Bakarrijbi nungka jangun, yukal-yudu. Budangkun barri jindal-anyi.
\xe We made a smoky fire to chase away the mosquitoes. So there would be no more mosquitoes.
\rf RS
\xv Wanamii ngambalanya jakajba.
\xe The rain chased us away.
\rf RS
\xv Jakajba ninji kundaa. Daba ninji kundaa. Jakajba nana bajangun.
\xe You hunt (him) away with a stick. You hit (him) with a stick. Chase that dog away.
\rf RS
\xv Balyanga jakajba. Jungku nyulu nayi.
\xe Don't hunt him away. He's staying here.
\rf rs2000-10
\xv Liwii ngaan jakajba.
\xe The mosquitoes chased me away.
\rf RS
\xv Kurnngarra nyulu jakajba jindal.
\xe The smoke chases away the mosquitoes.
\rf RS
\xv Raji ngaki wajka kalana. Dumularraa ngaan jakajba kala-wunyi.
\xe My camp was down near the river. The floodwaters chased me from the river.
\rf RS, PC_GB76
\va
\sy
\cf rirrajba
\nt
\cp
\nq 
\dt 17/Oct/2006

\lf


\lx jaki
\mr jaki
\hm
\sf
\sn
\ps particle
\pc
\sd quantifier
\lt no more than
\ge just
\ge merely
\re
\so GB, MB_LH13
\xv Jaki ngawu jila najini.
\sfx
\xe I'm just looking around.

\sfx
\xe I'm just looking at you lot.
\rf IS_GB
\xv Jaki ngawu jila, jungku naji narriyanya.
\sfx
\xe I've just come to see you (all).

\lx jalwa
\mr jarlwa
\sf jarlwa-heavyF.wav
\sf jarlwa02-heavyF.wav
\sf jarlwa04-heavyF.wav
\sf jalwa-strong.wav
\ps noun
\pc
\sd descriptive
\lt something which exerts or resists a strong force
\ge tough
\ge strong
\ge heavy
\ge weighty
\ge fierce
\ge hard
\ge powerful
\ge solid
\ge resistant
\ge forceful
\ge difficult
\re
\so RS; EF_R299D2; GB; JD; JP_TT, MB_LH13
\xv Jalwa nayi walijin. Ramijbi nyulu ngaan mayi.
\sfx
\xe This meat is tough. It broke my tooth.
\rf RS2002-04-14
\xv Jalwa, waduku.
\xe The fishing line is strong.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Yimbirra nyulu bikalii, dumularraa. Janybijbi nyulu, janybijbi, jalwaa dumularraa.
\xe The floodwaters carried the stuff along with it. It discarded it along the way, the strong current did.
\rf RS2005-02
\xv Mayi nyulu janybijbi ngambalangi barrawu, jalwaa wurrarraa.
\xe The fierce wind, it might blow our house down.
\rf RS2005-02
\xv Budangku nyulu jalwa. Barijbi nyulu wululukun. Mayamayada nyulu.
\xe He's not strong enough, that old man is no good. He's weak.
\rf RS2005-08a
\xv Rajba ngaan. Duruu. Rajba niyanya jalwaa janguu.
\xe It's burning me, the sun (is). The strong heat is burning us.
\rf rs2005-09
\xv Jalwa nana yanyi yalungi. Budangku ngawu mankuu. 
\xe That language of theirs is hard (to learn). I can't understand it.
\rf RS2004-05
\xv Jalwa nana.
\sfx jalwa_nana_RS.wav
\xe That's hard (of language).
\rf RS2004-05
\xv Jalwa nana balungka, ngulya.
\xe That blood will come out strong.
\rf RS
\xv Jayajayamba nyulu wurrarraa kunda nayi karrinja-wurru. Jalwaa wurrarraa.
\xe The wind is shaking this tree standing (here). The strong wind is.
\rf RS
\xv Barijbi nyulu. Budangku nyulu jalwa. Kadimirra.
\xe It's no good. It's not strong. It's too small.
\rf RS
\xv Nayi, jalwa nayi wulukun.
\xe This one, this big one is strong.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku nangka mularrijbi jamba-wunyi. Namanyba naan. Namanyba nukami jambaa kalabirri, jalwaa jambaa kalabirrii.
\xe It (motorcar) couldn't lift itself out from the sand. It was stuck. Its wheels were held in place by the sandy earth, that strong sandy soil.
\rf RS2004-08
\xv Jalwa rami.
\xe Strong eyes. (i.e., can stay awake)
\rf RS
\xv Budangku yalu ngunyijbi, jalwa rami. Budangku yaluwangka kudumbu ramin.
\xe They don't nod off as their eyes are strong (i.e., they can stay awake). They don't close their eyes.
\rf RS2004-08
\xv Jamba nyulu dabarraba ngadaraa jalwaa.
\ve The strong sun is baking the earth.
\rf RS2004-04
\xv Budangku nyulu jalwa, barijbi nyulu wululukun.
\xe He's not strong (enough), the old man can't do it.
\rf RS2005-08
\xv Nanangkani ramii, bariimbi nyulu ngaan nanangkani ramii, nanangkani jalwaa ramii.
\xe Those glasses, those strong eye-glasses are hurting my eyes.
\rf RS2005-08
\xv Jalwa nana wanu, jalwa.
\sfx jalwa nana wanu jalwa.aif
\xe That tobacco is strong. (It's) strong.
\rf RS2005-04

\lx jamba
\mr jamba
\sf jamba.wav
\sf jambaFlint02.wav
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc country.jpg
\sd elements
\sd land
\lt
\ge country
\ge earth
\ge ground
\ge land
\ge place
\ge soil
\ge dust
\re
\so RS, GB, EF, EK, JD, SC_BB, MS_SK, RC+MF_SK, JP_TT, CO
\xv Jambana.
\sfx jambana.wav
\sfx jambana_RS.wav
\xe In/on/at/along the ground
\rf EF
\xv Kurrijbi nyulu maniin jamba waliji-anyi biraki-anyi.
\xe It (echidna) digs the earth with its front legs (=hands) to get ants to eat. 
\rf rs2003-01
\xv Mularrijbi yalu jamba-wunyi, janki-wurru barri. 
\xe They pick them up from the ground and put them on their shoulders (around their neck). 
\rf rs2004-03
\xv Nayi nyulu bujubu jambana. Kurrijbi ngawu. Kajalaa.
\xe Here it (goanna) is lying in the earth. I'll dig it out with (my) digging stick.
\rf rs2002-01
\xv Mayi bulangka burru-daba, wajka jamba-wurru.
\xe They might knock each other down to the ground.
\rf rs2004-05
\xv Jambaa nangka makarraba, bambularraa, burrkaa.
\xe It covers itself over with dirt, using its tail.
\rf rs2004-07
\xv Jamba nyulu dabarraba, ngadaraa jalwaa. Dabarraba nurriyanya jambaa, nukami.
\xe The strong sun is heating the ground hot. The ground is burning our feet.
\rf RS2004-04
\xv Mayi yalu ninya jakajba nanambunyi jamba-wunyi.
\xe They might hunt you away from that place.
\rf RS
\xv Wanyi nyulu najba jambana?
\xe What did he see on the ground?
\rf RS2005-01
\xv Budangku nayi jamba nganyi; yalungi nayi jamban. 
\xe This land is not yours, this land is theirs.
\rf RS2004-05
\xv Kannga ninji nganyinburru jamba-wurru, kala-wurru, jungku-anyi ninji jambana nganyinbunu. Nayi nganyin jamban, budangku yalungi. 
\xe You have returned to your land, to your country, to live on your land. This is your land. It doesn't belong to other people.
\rf RS2004-05
\xv Nayi wululuku, jungku-anyi nyulu nayi bayungu.
\xe This old man, he's got to stay in the west.
\rf rs2005-08a
\xv Kudumanja nyulu kurrijbi jamban. Ngadijkanyi nangka, kalawunyi jambana.
\xe He kept on digging into the ground so he could hide himself down under the earth.
\rf RS
\xv Jungku narri nawunu jambana.
\xe You lot sit down here on the ground.
\rf PC_GB76
\va
\sy
\cf kala
\cf kalabirr
\cf jundurr
\nt Dymock (1993) records DALULU(N) 'bare ground'
\cp Garrwa; Wambaya
\nq

\xe We caught a plane for the meeting about the land.

\dt
\lf jangkurr-yudu

\lx jangu
\mr jangu
\sf jangu-fire.wav
\sf jangu02-fire.wav
\sf jangu-fireF.wav
\sf jangu_CO.wav
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc fire.jpg
\sd ELEMENTS
\sd fire
\lt fire and fire related
\ge fire
\re
\so RS, EF, GB, EK, CO, JD93, SC_BB, MS_SK, AP+AF_PS
\xv Jangu barri yalu bakarrijbi. 
\xe They light a fire.
\rf rs2005-01
\xv Janguu ngaan bakarrijbi nukamin, danyali. Nijbijbi ngawu. Budangku ngawu najba. Bakarrijbi nyulu ngaan.
\xe The hot coals burned me on the foot. I stood on it, I didn't see it. It burned me.
\rf rs2003-05
\xv Budangku ninji jadimbi-kanyi jangu.
\sfx budangku_ninyji_jardimbikanF.wav
\xe Don't put out the fire.
\rf EF
\xv Dabarraba ngamba nawunu jangunu.
\xe We are cooking it here on the fire.
\rf RS2004-01
\xv Jungku ngawu jangunu.
\xe I’m sitting near the fire.
\rf RS
\xv Burrandi ngawu kudijbi, kujarrana jangunu.
\xe I sleep between two fires.
\rf RS
\xv Mirramba nurri, jangu. Nijbi nurri jangunu, makarraba jibaa, dandini. 
\xe We make a fire. We put it (meat to cook) in the hot (earth), cover it with paperbark, in the earth oven.
\rf RS2002-10
\xv Wilijirri ngawu jangu-nanja.
\xe I pulled it out of the fire.
\rf RS2002-02
\xv Kawa jangu-wunyi! Rajba ninya.
\xe Come away from the fire! It can burn you.
\rf EF
\xv Bakarrijbi nungka jangun, yukal-yudu. Budangkun barri jindal-anyi.
\xe We made a smoky fire to chase away the mosquitoes. So there would be no more mosquitoes.
\rf RS
\xv Jala-wanyi nayi jangun. Banjana yalu jilaba ngambalangi.
\xe This is a recent fire. They are ahead of us.
\rf RS2002-13
\xv Walimi barri nurri jangu-wunyi malumalu.
\xe We then take the mussels out of the fire.
\xv RS
\xv Ramiramba yalu mukuran, bakirrijbi, jangunu barri. Janybijbi yalu jangu-wurru.
\xe They smashed the spears and then burned them in the fire. They threw them into the fire.
\rf RS2003-02
\xv Karrinja ngawu yilkuu jangunu.
\xe I was standing close to the fire.
\rf RS
\xv Ngarrangarramba wanamin jangunu. Nanyalu-anyi.
\xe Heat the water on the fire. For tea.
\rf RS
\xv Kuuni ninji jilanji kuuni! Mayi ninya rajba janguu, nukamin.
\xe You move away, away! The fire might burn your feet.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf jawula
\cf kunburrki
\cf mabibarr
\cf ngarrangarra
\nt
\cp Warlpiri {jangunyu} 'firestick, torch'; P-L {jangi} 'firestick'
\nq

\xe We strike goannas on the neck.

\ge
\re

\xe Throw (it)!

\sfx

\lx janybijbi
\mr janybi-j-bi
\sf janybijbi.wav
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd hold (holding and transfer)
\lt Xerg cause Y to move through air away from X
\ge throw
\ge drop off
\ge chuck
\ge discard
\ge toss
\ge cast
\re
\so EF, RS, GB, EK, CO, MB_LH12, MB_LH14

\xv Kara janybijbi.
\sfx kara_janybijbi_R299b2.wav
\xe Throw a stone.
\rf EF_R299b2
\xv Janybijbi nyulu.
\sfx janybijbi=nyulu.wav
\xe He threw it (spear).
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Mayi nyulu janybijbi ngambalangi barrawu, jalwaa wurrarraa.
\xe The strong wind might blow our house down.
\rf rs2005-02
\xv Yimbirra nyulu bikalii, dumularraa. Janybijbi nyulu, janybijbi, jalwaa dumularraa.
\xe The floodwaters carried the stuff along with it. The strong current discarded it along the way.
\rf 2005-02
\xv Kurrijbi nyulu, janybijbi nyulu jamba barri, manii, nukamii.
\sfx
\xe It (goanna) digs (a burrow) and it tosses up the earth with its forelegs (=hands) and hind legs (=feet).
\rf RS2002-04
\xv Mayi bula janybijbi kara ngakinburru.
\xe They might throw a stone at me.
\rf RS
\xv Janybijbi ngawu nana wingki. Budangku ngawu jarrba. Bijbi nyulu ngaan janyin.
\xe I throw that green (fruit) away. I don't eat it. It stings my mouth.
\rf RS
\xv Janybijbi ngawu, rangkijbi ngawu.
\sfx janybijbi ngawu rangkijbi ngawu.wav
\xe I throw it, I hit him (with the boomerang).
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Budangku ngawu jarrba, lungkarra. Janybijbi! Mayi nyulu windijbi niyanya ngalyaa.
\xe I can't eat this (because) it's too bitter. Throw it away. It might make us sick.
\rf RS
\xv Janybijbi ngawu jamba-wurru.
\xe I threw it down on the ground.
\rf GB
\xv Janyii ngawu janybijbi jabula.
\xe I'm spitting with my mouth.
\rf RS2005-02
\xv Janybijbi ngawu, kurrkulu ngawu. Janybijbi ngawu ngalurr, mulu-nanja.
\xe I cast it out, I cough and I blow out the mucous, from my nose.
\rf RS
\xv Kara ninji janybijbi ngakinburru.
\xe You threw a stone at me.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Kanybijbi dara-wurru.
\sfx
\xe Throw it to the dog!
\rf MB_LH12
\xv Janybijbi mukura ngalikaduni.
\xe Throw a spear with a woomera.
\rf EF_R299B3
\va
\sy
\cf birrimi
\cf duwarrijbi
\nt Also used to refer to expulsion of saliva from mouth (spit) and mucous from nose (blow nose).
\cp
\nq
\dt 18/Sep/2006
\lf janyba

\xv Jariyamba-kurru, najba ngawu naan, manini. Jariyamba nyulu maman.

\lf jariyamba-kurru

\sn 2
\ps
\pc
\sd

\lx jarrba
\mr jarr-ba
\sf jadba.wav
\sf jadba02.wav
\sf jadba03.wav
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc eat.jpg
\sd behaviour
\lt Xerg eat Y 
\ge eat
\re
\so EF, RS, GB, EK, JD93, JP_TT, MF+EM_CO
\xv Jarrba nungka waliji.
\sfx jadba_nungka_waliji.wav
\xe We eat meat.
\rf rs-rg1999
\xv Maman jarrba.
\sfx
\xe Eat food.
\rf JP_TT
\xv Budangku ngamba jarrba.
\sfx budangku_ngamba_jadba.wav
\xe We didn't eat it.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku nurri jarrba nana jarrbikala. Bari.
\xe We don't eat that Wedgetail Eagle. It's no good (to eat).
\rf RS
\xv Jarrkurru nyulu jangajba. 
\xe He was sneaking up on it while it was eating.
\rf RS2004-04
\xv Nana walijin, kankulu nyulu jarrbana kanba. Binanyba nyulu burrurrii. 
\xe That animal, he was eating his fill of grass as the man was sneaking up on him.
\rf RS2004-04
\xv Mama, ngabaa ninji, walijin. Jarrkanyi ngamba, balikajini.
\xe Bring the bread and the meat so we can eat it when we get hungry.
\rf RS
\xv Ja ngamba dabarraba, jarr-kanyi kamu.
\xe We'll cook it to eat this evening.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku ngawu jarrkanyi barri. Dumbu-lulujbu ngawu, muwa.
\xe I can't eat anymore. My stomach is full up.
\rf RS2004-07
\xv Jarrkana ninji. Jarr-kana nana maman, dawurrumbu ninji. Jarrkana yakujbu ngambalangi.
\xe Don't eat. Don't eat that food, you're eating it all up. Don't eat it (all) and leave some for all of us.
\rf RS2005-05
\xv Kudarrijbi nyulu jungku, jarrjini walijini, mamana.
\xe He sat quietly eating meat and vegetables.
\rf RS2004-05
\xv Jarra!
\xe Eat (it)!
\rf RS
\xv Jarra ninji maman! Jarra!
\xe You eat the food! Eat it!
\rf RS
\xv Jarrkanyi ninji nayi mama.
\xe You'll eat this food.
\rf RS2005-09
\xv Jarrba kiya ngawiji, ngala nyuluji ngabaa nana. 
\xe I was going to eat it, but he (dog) took it.
\rf GB78
\xv Ngurrubu ngawu nyulu jarrkanyi.
\xe I told him to eat it.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Ngurrubu ngawuji nan jajudu.
\xe I told him to eat it.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Najba ninji ngaan jarrkurru.
\xe You watch me eating.
\rf RS2005-09
\va
\sy
\cf junujbu
\cf kankulu
\cf wadamba
\cf ngaraba
\nt Pronounced [jadba]
\cp
\nq The 'rr' before a consonant like 'b' or 'k' is pronounced like a 'd': [jadba], [jadkanyi], [jadkurru]
\dt 03/Sep/2006

\sfx
\xe (They) come back, scatter, return, move away.

\xe The wheel sank into the sand.

\lx jawayawa

\ps verb
\pc

\ge chew

\ge have in mouth

\xe We chew it (=tobacco) in our mouths.

\xe He's chewing that meat. He's sitting there chewing the meat.
\rf RS
\xv Kudarrijbi nyulu jawayawana, walijini.
\xe He's sitting there in silence chewing on the meat. 
\xv Jawayawaa nyulu janyii.
\xe He's chewing it with his mouth.
\rf RS
\xv Jarrba nyulu bangkijbi, mayii. Janyii nyulu jawayawa nana walijin.
\xe He ate it, pulled the skin off with (his) teeth. He chewed that meat in his mouth.
\rf rs2004-05
\wa Yurrukadi janyini, nayi wanu. Jawayawa nayi wanu.
\xe He put the tobacco into his mouth. He chewed on the tobacco.
\rf RS
\xv Jawayawama!
\xe Carry it in your mouth!
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Jawayawa janyini nayi wanu.
\sfx
\xe Chew this tobacco in your mouth.
\rf RS2005-09

\sfx
\xe The dog carries it in its mouth, digs up the ground and buries it.

\dt 29/Sep/2006

\lx jawikajba
\mr jawika-j-ba
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd behavioural
\lt Xerg speak to Y in order to obtain something (information, entity) from Y 
\ge ask
\ge question
\re 
\re 
\so RS, MF+EM_CO, GB, MB_LH13
\xv Jawikajba ninji ngaan.
\sfx jawikajba ninji ngaan.wav
\xe You asked me...
\rf RS2004-05
\xv Jawikajba nurri ngarrawanyi. Budangkun ngarrawanyi. Kudulumbu ngawu banja rajini.
\sfx
\xe We asked him for salt. There is no salt. I forgot it (and left it) back at home.
\rf rs2002-10
\xv Jawikajba nyulu ngaan bungkana, jila-kanyi nungka mudunama.
\xe He asked me yesterday if we two would go the next day.
\rf RS
\xv Jawikajba ninji ngaan jangkurr-anyi.
\xe You're asking me about the language.
\rf RS2003-01
\xv Janyii ngawu ninya jawikajba.
\xe I'm asking you in person (lit. by mouth).
\rf RS
\xv Wayi-kiya ninji jawikajba ngaliyanya mama-anyi?
\xe Couldn't you have asked us for food.
\rf RS2004-04
\xv Jawikajba ngawu ninya wanyi ninji nini.
\xe I'm asking you what your skin is.
\rf RS
\xv Ngiraa yalu burrurrii yarrbanjii. Budangku yalu jawikajba ngaan.
\xe The young men stole it. They didn't ask me (for it).
\rf RS
\xv Jawikajba yalu ngambalanya, nangkanyi kala-anyi.
\xe They ask us about this land.
\rf RS
\xv Jawikajba yalu, ngada-nganja, ngaki. Kuujbu yalu ngaki.
\xe They are asking their mother about me. They are looking for me.
\rf RS
\xv Jawikajba ninji ngaan, wanyi nana yanyi.
\xe You're asking me what that language is.
\rf RS
\xv Jawikajba yalu ngaan wanu-anyi bulinja-anyi.
\xe They are asking me for tobacco to smoke.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku ninji ngaan jawikajba, mama-anyi.
\xe You didn't ask me for food.
\rf RS
\xv Jawikajkanyi yalu, ngaan. yanyi-anyi, mandaki-darraa.
\xe The white men will ask me for stories (information).
\rf RS
\xv Jawikajba ngawu nan yawanba nangka.
\xe I asked him what he was doing.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Jawika!
\xe Ask!
\rf MF+EM_CO
\va jawukajba [GB]
\sy
\cf
\nt
\cp Garrwa {yilikajba}
\nq

\lx jawula
\mr jawula
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd ELEMENTS
\sd fire
\lt
\ge charcoal
\ge dead fire
\ge remains of fire
\ge extinguished fire
\re
\so RS2002-3, JD93, JP_TT
\xv Kanjijbi barri nyulu. Kanjijbi nyulu, jawulan.
\xe It's extinguished now. There's only coals left. 
\rf RS
\va
\sy 
\cf danyal
\cf jangu
\nt Recorded by Dymock (1993) as 'fire' and 'camp fire'
\nt Recorded as 'light' in JP_TT

\lf jayajayamba

\lx jayajayamba
\mr jayajaya-mba
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd motion
\lt exert pressure on and cause to move
\ge move
\ge shake
\ge toss around
\ge buffet
\re
\so RS, GB
\xv Jayajayamba nayi kundan, wurrarraa.
\xe The wind is shaking (the branches of) this tree.
\rf rs-2004-07
\xv Jayajayama!
\xe Shake it!
\rf GB
\xv Balyanga jayajayama!
\xe Don't shake it!
\rf IS_GB78
\xv Nana kundan, wanamii jayajayamba dumularraa.
\xe That tree, it is being tossed around by the flood waters.
\rf RS2004-04
\xv Jayajayamba nyulu burra-daba nana mama wajka jamba-wurru. Jalwaa wurrarraa.
\xe That strong wind shakes it (the tree) and makes that fruit fall down to the ground.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf
\nt
\cp
\nq

\lx jayi
\mr jayi
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd spatial
\sd direction
\lt
\ge move away
\ge run away
\ge take off
\re away
\so RS, GB
\xv Mayi nungka daba, kundaa. Burrbijbi nyulu jayi.
\xe Because we might hit it with a stick, he's running off.
\rf RS03-01
\xv Burrbijbi nana jayi yala barri durrajini.
\xe He ran away for good feeling scared.
\rf GB
\xv Baba nyulu jayi.
\xe He flies away.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf barranyi
\nt {Jayi} is used with a verb that refers to the type of movement.

\dt 29/Sep/2006



\lx jiba
\mr jiba
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd plant related
\la Melaleuca spp. 
\lt
\ge paperbark
\ge Ti-tree bark
\re
\so RS, GB, CO
\xv Jibaa mundukaa.
\sfx jibaa-mundukaa_CO.wav
\xe Carrying in bark coolamon.
\rf OSBORNE_C02-000165B.TMP
\xv Bangkijbi nurri nayi, nayi jiba.
\xe We remove the bark, this paperbark.
\rf rs2003-02
\xv Juka! Nanganja! Jiba ninji nanganja.
\xe Little boy! Pick it up! Pick up the paperbark.
\rf RS2002-03
\xv Mirramba nurri, jangu. Nijbi nurri jangunu, makarraba jibaa,  dandini. 
\xe We make a fire. We put it (meat to cook) in the hot (earth), cover it with paperbark, in the earth oven.
\rf RS2002-10
\xv Mudamudajibi yalu jibana. Windijbi nyulu nanangkanyi kundaanyi, diwurrurru-anyi. Windijbi nyulu manii.
\xe They wrapped it in paperbark. That piece of wood, that message stick was given to someone, handed it to him.
\rf RS2005-03
\xv Mudamudajibi nurri kalawa. Yakujbu nurri, kumayangunu. Mudamudajibi yalu jibana.
\sfx
\xe We tied up the bones (of the dead person) and we left them in a cave. They used to wrap them up in sheets of paperbark.
\rf RS2002-09
\xv Mayika ngawu kularrijbi, manii. Nijbi nurri, jibana nurri kularrijbi. 
\xe I scoop out the top part of honey hive with (my) hands. We put (the honey), we scoop it out onto a sheet of paperbark.
\rf RS200304-02
\xv 
\xe
\rf
\va
\sy najaa
\sy najarr
\cf
\nt
\cp
\nq

\lx jidimbi
\mr jidi-mbi
\hm 1
\sf jidimbi.wav
\ps verb
\pc
\sd contact (impact and violence)
\lt Xerg apply downward or inward pressure on Y 
\ge squeeze
\ge choke
\ge wring
\ge pinch
\ge knead
\re
\so EF, RS, GB, CO
\xv Marijbi nyulu duka, jidimbi duka. 
\xe It grabs hold of its neck and chokes it around the neck.  
\rf rs2002-14
\xv Buludu ngawu, jidimbi duka.
\xe I press down on it, squeeze its throat.
\rf RS
\xv Mayi ninya nanganja kaburrukajaa, nanganja-anyi ninya, marijbi manii. Bijbi ninya. Jidimbi ninya duka.
\xe A crocodile might get you. It's going to get you, grab you with its claws, bite you, and squeeze you by the throat.
\rf RS2004-07
\xv Marijbi ngawu duka jidimbi. Kudanyu. Kudanyu ngawu jidimbi duka.
\xe I'll grab his neck and wring it. Without letting go. I'll keep on wringing his neck.
\rf RS2002-04
\xv Jidimbi ninji, kudanba.
\xe You choked it to death.
\rf RS
\xv Manii ngawu jidimbi.
\xe I squeezed it with my hands.
\rf RS
\xv Jidimi!
\xe Squeeze ()it)!
\rf MF+EM_CO
\va jidiyimbi [GB] [EF]
\sy
\cf
\nt
\cp
\nq possibly jidiyimbi
\dt 21/Sep/2006

\lx jijajba
\mr jija-j-ba
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd sound
\lt
\ge tell lies
\ge pretend
\ge deceive
\ge make mistake
\ge play trick on
\ge lie to
\ge make out (to be true)
\re
\so EF, RS, GB
\xv Jijajba ninji.
\xe You made a mistake.
\rf RS
\xv Jijajba nyulu.
\sfx
\xe He's telling a lie.
\rf EF_R299C1
\xv Jijajba ngawu nangangi. Ngadijbi ngawu maman.
\xe I played a trick on him. I hid the bread (from him).
\rf RS
\xv Jijajba nyulu, budangku mama-anyi.
\xe He made out that there was no food.
\rf RS
\xv Jijamba ninji ngaan. Ngurubu ninji jijajini.
\xe You tricked me. You lied.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku ngawu jijajba; diindi ngawu yanyba narriyangi.
\xe I'm not lying, I'm speaking the truth to you.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku ngawu, jijajba, nganyi.
\xe I'm not lying to you.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku nyulu kudijbi. Jijajba nyulu. 
\xe He’s not sleeping, he’s (only) pretending.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku nurri jijajba.
\xe We are not telling lies.
\rf
\va
\sy
\cf 
\nt
\cp
\nq

\dt 29/Sep/2006


\lx jila
\mr jila
\sf jila.wav
\ps verb
\pc
\sd motion
\lt
\ge go
\re
\so EF, RS, EK, JD93, JP_TT, MF_CO, GB
\xv Jila nungka.
\sfx jila-nungka02.wav
\xe Let's go.
\rf EF
\xv Jila nurri.
\sfx jila-nurri_we-go.wav
\xe Let us go.
\rf RS-RG1999
\xv Wajkali jila ngawu wanami-wujbu.
\xe I'm going down to get water.
\rf EF_R299EB1
\xv Kannga nurri jilana.
\sfx Kannga-nurri_jilana-RS2002T09a.wav
\xe We are going back.
\rf RS
\xv Jila ngawu raji-wurru.
\sfx
\xe I'm going home.
\rf JP_TT
\xv Daran jila kundanu burrandi.
\sfx
\xe The dog is on its way to the tree.
\rf MF_CO
\xv Ngurrubu ngawu ninya jilajudu.
\xe I told you to go.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Jilanji!
\xe Go!
\rf MF+EM_CO
\sy
\cf 
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt
\lf jilaba
\lf jilajini
\lf jilajudu
\lf jilakanyi
\lf jilakurru
\lf jilanji

\lx jilaba
\mr jila-ba
\sf jilaba.wav
\sf jilaba02.wav
\sf jilaba-go.wav
\ps verb
\pc
\sd motion
\lt
\ge go
\ge come
\ge walk
\ge move
\ge travel
\re
\so RS, EF, GB, SC_BB, MF_CO
\xv Jilaba nyulu.
\sfx jilaba_nyulu_RS.wav
\xe He's walking.
\rf RS2005-01
\xv Jilaba nurri.
\sfx jilaba-nurri-RS2002T09a.wav
\xe We went.
\rf RS
\xv Jilaba nyulu naniwii.
\sfx jilaba-nyulu-naniwii.wav
\xe He's going that way.
\rf EF
\xv Jilaba barri ngali.
\sfx jilaba_barri_ngali-we-go.wav
\xe We two are going now.
\rf RS-RG1999
\xv Jilaba bula.
\sfx jilaba_bula-come_both.wav
\xe They are both going.
\rf RS-RG1999
\xv Jilaba ninji ngaki banjana. Jilaba ngawu yajanga.
\xe You come behind me. I'll go ahead.
\rf RS
\xv Barranyi ninji jilaba, yunngumu ninji. Budangka ninji kannga.
\xe You go away and stay away for good. Don't you return.
\rf rs2002-07
\xv Jilaba yalu barralaala, budangku yalu ngunyi-ngunyijbi. 
\xe They walk around all night, they don't sleep.
\rf rs2005-02
\xv Jilaba nyulu nukamin barri. 
\xe He's now walking (of child previously only able to crawl).
\rf rs2005-01
\xv Bayangarrinyi, jilaba yalu nana-waan kaku-anyi.
\xe Those ones have gone over to the west side (of the river) to fish.
\rf rs2005-05
\xv Bayungunu ngawu jilaba.
\xe I came from the west.
\rf rs2005-06
\xv Jila-kanyi ngawu karurri Burketown-wurru.
\xe I'll go east to Burketown.
\rf EF
\xv Ninji jila barranyi.
\xe You go away!
\rf EF
\xv Bajalijbi nyulu warrki jilakurru.
\xe He smells a dingo coming.
\rf rs2002-04
\xv Budangku nyulu karrinjaa ngambalangi. Banyajba nyulu ngambalanya jilajini.
\xe He didn't stop for us. He went straight past us.
\rf rs2004-04
\xv Jungku ninji wuja. Jilakana wunjuku.
\xe You are staying put. Don't go anywhere.
\rf RS
\xv Jila-kana. Jungku ninji wuja nawunu ngakinbunu.
\xe Don't go. You stay here with me.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf burrbijbi
\cf kannga
\nt
\cp
\nq jila possibly hortative form, seems to express deontic modality here. The -kanyi ending seems to be a type of purposive (glossed as IRR by GB). It is in opposition with -ba (IND/REALIS) form, the base form {jila}. (GB 41, 2000). Note {jila-kurru} and not {jila-wurru} (as though hidden j in {jila(j)} is responsible for the initial k in allative (true vowel final stems form allative as {-wurru}. Cf. Garrwa {jilaj-}.
\dt 04/Sep/2006
\lf jila
\lf jilaa
\lf jilajini
\lf jila-kana
\lf jilakanyi
\lf jilakurru
\lf jilalaba
\lf jilana
\lf jilanji

\lx jilakanyi
\mr jila-kanyi
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd 
\lt irrealis form of verb {jila}
\ge go
\ge come
\re go
\re come
\so EF, RS, GB, MB_LH02
\xv Jilakanyi barri ngamba.
\sfx jilakanyi-barri-ngamba.wav
\xe We've got to go now.
\rf RS2005-05
\xv Jilakanyi ngamba.
\sfx jilakanyi-ngamba.wav
\xe We've got to go.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku ngawu jilakanyi.
\sfx budangku-ngawu-jilakanyi_CO.wav
\xe I'm not going yet.
\rf GB
\xv Marrkajini ngawu jilakanyi.
\xe I'll go hunting.
\rf GB
\xv Budangku barri ngawiji jilakanyi.
\xe I won't be able to go today.
\rf GB
\xv Jilakanyi ngawu Ngumarri-wurru.
\xe I'm going to Lawn Hill.
\rf GB
\xv Jawikajba nyulu ngaan bungkana, jilakanyi nungka mudunama.
\xe He asked me yesterday if we two would go the next day.
\rf RS
\xv Jila-kanyi ngamba raji-wurru, jalanya.
\xe We'll go home now.
\rf RS2004-04
\xv Lajikanyi ninji, jilakanyi ngamba.
\xe You have to recall (where) we have to go.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku ngawu wanu-anyi. Jilakanyi ngawu mudunama, kularra, wanu-anyi. 
\xe I don't have any tobacco. Tomorrow I have to go south to get tobacco.
\rf RS
\xv Jilakanyi yalu nanangkurruna.
\xe They will all go there.
\rf MB_LH02
\va
\sy
\cf
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt
\lf jila
\lf jilaba
\lf jilanji
\lf jilajini

\lx jilalaba
\mr jila-la-ba
\hm
\sf
\sn
\ps verb
\pc
\sd
\lt x move continually
\ge walk around
\ge travel
\ge move constantly
\ge come and go
\re
\so
\xv Budangku yalu jungku nawunu wuja. Jilalaba yalu.
\sfx
\xe They don't stay put here. They walk around all the time.
\rf RS
\xv Yanjini nyulu jilalaba.
\xe He goes around talking.
\rf RS
\xv Jilalajini nyulu yanyba.
\xe He talks as he travels around.
\rf rs
\xv Jilalaba nyulu ngambalangi nana wululuku, najini kalana.
\xe That old man always comes for us and looks around on (our) country.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku nyulu jilalaba; jungku nyulu jambana.
\xe He can't walk around; he stays sitting on the ground.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt note partial reduplication
\lf jila
\lf jilaba
\lf jilalajini


\lx jilanji
\mr jila-nji
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd
\lt imperative form of verb {jila}
\ge go
\ge move
\re go
\so RS, GB, CO
\xv Kuunii jilanji! Kuunii jilanji ninji!
\sfx kuunii-jilanyji.wav
\xe Go away! You go away!
\rf RS2005-01
\xv Jilanji ninji.
\sfx jilanji-ninji.wav
\sfx jilanji ninji-move.aif
\xe You go away!
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Jilanji ninji, kuuni.
\sfx jilanji ninji kuuni-move away.aif
\xe You move, away.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Kuuni ninji jilanji kuuni! Mayi ninya rajba janguu, nukamin.
\xe You move away, away! The fire might burn your feet.
\rf RS
\xv Ninji jilanji nanganjana wanamini.
\xe You go and get water yourself.
\rf GB
\xv Ninji nukami-yudi jilanji yiniyini nanganjana.
\xe You've got feet (so) go and get it yourself.
\rf GB
\xv Waku jilanji!
\xe Come quick!
\rf GB
\xv Jilanji wajkali! 
\sfx jilanji-wajkali_CO.wav
\xe Go down!
\rf OSBORNE_C02-000165B.TMP
\xv Jilanji walimi!
\sfx jilanji-walimi_CO.wav
\xe Move out!
\rf OSBORNE_C02-000165B.TMP
\va
\sy
\cf
\nt
\cp
\nq

\lx jiringkijbi
\mr jiringki-j-bi
\sf jiringkijbi-knowF.wav
\sf jiringkijbi02-knowF.wav
\ps verb
\pc
\sd mind
\lt Xerg have knowledge of Y
\ge learn
\ge know
\ge recognize
\re
\so RS, EF_R299C1, GB, JD93, CO
\xv Ja ninji, jiringkijbi, yanyi nurriyangi.
\xe You've got to learn our language.
\rf RS
\xv Jiringkijbi ninji nana?
\xe Do you know that one?
\rf GB
\xv Winjikanyi nana bajangun? Budangku ngamba jiringkijbi.
\xe Who does that dog belong to? We don't recognize it.
\rf rs2005-06
\xv Budangku ngawu jiringkijbi nana. Mayi ngaki, nangangi.
\xe I don't recognize that one, whether it's mine, or his.
\rf rs2004-01
\xv Miyarrkana ninji jungku nawunu. Miyarrka nana-waan burrurri-darra. Budangku ninji jiringkijbi nana-waan burrurri-darra. Budangku ninji lajibi yanyin yalungi.
\sfx
\xe You are here as a stranger. You don't know about those men. You don't know those men. You can't understand their language.
\rf RS
\xv Jingili-anyi, yinini yanyi, budangku ngawu jiringkijbi.
\xe The Jingili people's language is different, I can't understand it.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku ngawu ninya jiringkijbi.
\xe I don't know you.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku ngawu jiringkijbi nayi kala. Miyarrka ngawu.
\xe I don't know this country. I'm a stranger (here).
\rf RS
\xv Najba yalu, jiringkijbi yalu.
\xe They look at it and they recognize it.
\rf RS
\xv Jiringka!
\xe Learn!
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Budangku nayi jiringkijkanyi. Budangku jiringkijbi.
\sfx
\xe This one can't know. Doesn't know.
\rf EF_R299C1 
\xv Jiringkijbi nyulu barri?
\sfx
\xe Does he understand now?
\rf EF_R299C1
\va 
\sy
\cf lajibi
\cf manku
\cf milidimbi
\nt
\cp
\nq check quality of /r/ ~ /rr/
\dt 18/Oct/2006

\xv Jiwarrana bula jungku jiwarrana, nanangkujarra makulu-wuya.
\xe Those two 'eggs' (Magellanic Clouds) sit near the Milky Way.
\rf RS
\va yiwarra
\sy yubal
\cf
\nt Dymock (1993) also records JUNDURUMAJBALI and WALINDIRIMA 'Milky Way'
\cp
\nq

\lx jujuu
\mr jujuu
\sf
\sn
\ps noun
\pc
\sd size
\sd spatial
\lt
\ge long way
\ge far away
\re distant
\re far
\re long way
\so RS, EK
\xv Jujuu ngawu jilaba.
\xe I went a long way.
\rf RS
\xv Yakujbu ngamba. Jilaba ngamba jujuu.
\xe We leave (it). We go far away.
\rf RS2002-14
\xv Babaa nurri kingkarri jujuu.
\xe We flew way up high.
\rf rs2005-06
\xv Jujuu nyulu jungku bayungu, yingkana barruwunu.
\xe He's living far away to the west, in another town.
\rf rs2003-02
\xv Ngamuyu-kiya ninji jungku nawunu. Budangku. Budangkun. Jungku ninji jujuu kularra.
\xe It was thought you would be here, but no. You were not. You were far away down south.
\rf RS2003-12-01
\xv Yurrwalijbi nyulu ngakinburrinyi-anyi, budangku nyulu yanyba nangangi. Budangku nyulu jilaba. Jujuu nyulu wandajba nangangi.
\xe She feels shame towards her son-in-law, she doesn't speak to him. She doesn't go (close to him), she keeps her distance from him.
\rf RS2004-08b
\xv Dungala wuluku. Budangku nurri kajalaba. Jujuu kingkarri.
\xe It's a big hill. We can't climb it. It's too high (=far up).
\rf RS2002-06
\xv Jilaba nyulu wanami jujuu barri ngambalangi, bayungu.
\xe The rain has now moved away from us, towards the west.
\rf RS2005-08a
\xv Wunanba nana, kala yalungi, jujuu, karurri.
\xe That place of theirs is far away, a long way to the east.
\rf RS
\xv Jujuu nayi ngaki jamba. Jujuu nayi bayungu. Burrandi nungka jungku.
\xe My country is a long way. It's a long way west of here. We'll stop halfway.
\rf EK (ML notes)
\va 
\sy barranyi
\sy junii
\sy wunanba
\cf
\nt Possibly {juju}
\cp
\nq
\dt 25/Oct/2006

\ge ashes
\re ash

\xe I look for and find a round stone. I grind the tobacco to make it into a wad. (I) mix it with ashes. Then with this round stone, I grind it up.
\rf RS
\xv Jarrba ngawu wanu, bunija, julwu-yudu.

\nt JP_TT records as "red kangaroo"; JP also gave {bijilba}
\nt Dymock (1993) records as "rat - red eyed kangaroo" and also as "wallaby - paddy mellon" synonym of {linjilinji}

\sd animal
\sd reptile
\la Varanus panoptes (?)
\lt big yellow goanna sp.
\ge Yellow-spotted Goanna
\re
\so RS, EK, GB, SC_BB, JP_TT
\xv Najba ngawu jumbuuna, daba ngawu. Dangalbangi. Kundaa. Kajarlaa.
\xe I saw the goanna and I hit it. Killed it with a stick, with a yamstick.
\rf RS2000-09
\xv Kujarra jumbuuna-wuya, wululuku-wuya, wandaba bulangka, kunju bulangi. Wandaba bulangka, jumbuunaa, warrakuujini. 
\xe The two goannas, who were two old men, they turned themselves into stone, their bodies. They turned into stone, those goanna men, after they got lost (in other people's country).
\rf rs2005-09
\xv Jumbuuna, kujarra, nukami bula jilaba karurri. Kanmangi-wurru bula jilaba, nukamin.
\xe Two goannas, their tracks went east. They both travelled on foot to Kanmangi (Highland Plain).
\rf RS
\xv Jumbuunaa ngan bijbi.
\xe The yellow-spotted goanna bit me.
\rf IS_GB
\xv Wadaba yiniyini; jumbuuna yiniyini.
\xe A {wadaba} goanna is distinct from a {jumbuuna} goanna.
\rf IS-GB
\va jumbuwuna
\sy 
\cf warrnguna
\cf wadaba
\cf jamarawu
\nt A {jumbuuna} man is the ancestor for people from the Murrunmurrula area of South Nicholson River.
\nt The {jumbuuna} is described by Roy Seccin as "big yellow desert goanna"
\cp
\nq Check if warrnguna and jumbuuna are really the same.
\dt 30/Oct/2006

\xv Jundu-kanyi ninji kaku, kamu, mungamba. Jundu-kanyi ninji, jalwamba ninya muwan.
\xe You'll have a good feed of fish this evening, come nightfall. You'll eat up, so that your stomach will feel tight.

\xe The big truck stirred up the dirt, the dust.

\lx jungku
\mr jungku
\sf jungku.wav
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc sit_legs_crossed.jpg
\sd spatial
\lt X be at some location or in some state
\ge be
\ge sit
\ge live
\re
\so EF, GB, RS, EK, JD93, SC_BB, CO
\xv Jungkumu ngandunu, jangkurrini. Jungkunu nyulu yanyba ngambalangi.
\xe Sit in the shade and talk! He sits and talks to us.
\rf RS
\xv Jungku nyulu kundana, balarrka. Baba-rarra nyulu wajka-kulaji.
\xe The flying fox lives in trees. It hangs head down.
\rf rs2003-01
\xv Banyajba ninji nurriyanya, jungku-wurru. Wajka.
\xe You will pass over us, sitting (here) below.
\rf rs2005-08a
\xv Jungku nyulu banjana kundana, kuku-najini ngambalyanya.
\sfx
\xe He is sitting behind the tree observing us.
\xe rs11
\xv Birajini nyulu jungku. 
\xe He's sitting singing.
\rf RS
\xv Bujiji nyulu jungku. Budangku barri, budangku jawaji-nganja-anyi.
\xe She is a bereaved mother. She doesn't have her child any more.
\rf rs2004-14
\xv Kannga ninji nganyinburru jamba-wurru, kala-wurru, jungku-anyi ninji jambana nganyinbunu.
\xe You have returned to your land, to your country, to live on your land. This is your land.
\rf RS2004-05
\xv Yanyba ninji ngakinbunu, jungkunu.
\xe You're sitting talking with me.
\rf GB
\xv Nyubana ninji jungku.
\xe You are alone.
\rf GB
\xv Jungku narri, nawunu jambana.
\xe You all sit down here on the ground!
\rf GB
\xv Wangkulan jungku kundana.
\xe The crow is sitting in the tree.
\rf RS
\xv Bawanyi ngakin Ngumarrini jungku.
\xe My brother is at Lawn Hill.
\rf GB
\xv Ngurrubu ngawu nan nyulu jungku-wanyi [jungkuanyi].
\xe I told him that he should sit down.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Ngurrubu ngawu jungku-wudu [jungkuudu].
\xe I told him to sit down.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Jungkumu!
\xe Sit down!
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Budangku ngawu jungku-wanyi.
\sfx
\xe I won't sit down.
\rf IS_GB
\va
\sy
\cf
\nt {jungku-wanyi} is sometimes heard as [jungkuanyi] or [jungkuranyi]
\cp
\nq

\lx junuu

\hm 2
\sf
\sn 1
\ps particle
\pc
\sd mind
\lt not have knowledge of
\ge don't know
\ge ignorant of
\ge not know
\re
\so RS, GB

\sfx junuu nungka.wav
\xe We don't know it.
\rf RS2004-05
\xv Junuu, mudumbanyi. Budangkun lajibi  yanyi yalungi, Kudanji, banga Ambaya. 
\xe Don't know. Don't understand. (I) don't understand their language, Kudanji or Wambaya.
\rf RS
\xv Junuu yalu yanyba, junuu ngawu manku nana.
\xe I don't know what they are saying. I don't understand that (language).
\rf RS
\xv Junuu, kudinyi ngawu, nanangkanyi burrurri-anyi.
\xe Don't know, I don't know about that man (where he comes from).
\rf RS
\xv Junuu ngamba jilaba mudunama.
\xe Don't know where we are going tomorrow.
\rf RS
\xv Junuu wunjuku ngamba jilaba mudunama.
\xe We don't know where we're going tomorrow.
\rf RS
\xv Nijbi nyulu junuu. Mamanumba nyulu. 
\xe He put it he doesn't know where. He's forgotten (where he put it).
\rf RS
\xv Junuu yalu jilaba.
\xe We don't know where they've gone.
\rf RS
\xv Winjika nana jila? Junuu barri, junuu.
\xe Who's that coming? I don't know, don't know.
\rf GB
\xv Junuu-barri jala nyulu wunjuku-barri nyulu jila.
\sfx
\xe I don't know where he's gone now.
\rf GB_IS
\va

\an
\nt Recorded by Dymock (1993) as "downs goanna"
\nt Not found in Waanyi country (IV_GB) but plentiful further south around Camooweal; described as "piebald goanna"
\cp Wambaya {jurrkubarri}
\nq
\dt
\lf

\xe They roll it in their hand. They make it into a small (ball) like an egg.
\rf RS
\xv Buju-kadi nyulu nayi bulungu kadimirra, jabakana. 
\xe She lays the little baby down on the bed.
\rf RS
\xv Ngamuyu jukuli-waya balangarra kadimirra.
\xe That little moon looks like a boomerang.
\rf RS
\xv Jangu ninji, mirramba, kadimirraa ngilaa wadukarraa.
\xe Make a fire, little girl.
\rf RS
\xv Jakajba nana, kadimirraa, jukajukaa.
\xe Chase that, little boy.
\rf RS
\xv Kadimirraa birakii ngaan bijbi nukamin, kadimirraa.
\xe Little ants are biting me on the foot, tiny ones.
\rf RS
\xv Kadimirra, kundan ngawu najba.
\xe They (looked) tiny, the trees that I saw.
\rf RS

\an wuluku-mirra

\lf kadirri

\lx kadiwirri
\mr
\hm
\sv
\sf
\sn
\ps noun
\pc
\sd plant
\la Sesbania cannabina
\la Sesbania brachycarpa [GB]	
\lt
\ge Spear Bush
\re
\so GB, JD93, DT, GW

\sy yiniyini

\an
\nt Described by Dymock (1993) as 'pea bush'

\dt
\lf

\lx kadu-nganja
\mr kardu-nganyja
\sf kardunganyja-Finlaw.wav
\sf kardunganyja02-Finlaw.wav
\sf kardunganyja-FinlawFR299C1.wav
\sn
\ps noun
\pc
\sd PEOPLE
\sd kin
\lt wife's father
\ge father-in-law
\ge father's cousin
\re
\so EF, RS, GB, EK
\xv Kardu-nganja nyulu kudarrijbi, budangku nyulu yanyba.
\xe The father-in-law is silent, he can't talk.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku nurri yanyba, kadu-nganja, ngunyarri-nganja, nawi-nganja.
\xe (When a person dies) we others can't speak, like the dead person's father-in-law, mother-in-law or husband.
\rf RS
\xv Manngurru ngawu, yurrwaliijbi, manngurru, kadu-nganja-anyi.
\xe I feel shame and am reticent with embarrassment, towards my father-in-law.
\rf RS
\xv Ngawu, ngawu, nganyi kadu-nganja.
\xe As for me, I'm your father-in-law.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf lambarra
\cf manduwala
\nt {Kadu} is word for 'person' in many Australian languages.
\cp
\nq
\dt 26/Oct/2006

\lx kaja
\mr
\hm
\sf
\sn
\ps noun
\pc
\sd quantity
\lt relatively large number more than two
\ge many
\ge lot of
\ge big mob
\ge several
\re
\so EF, RS, GB, CO, JD93, LP_SK
\xv Kaja-yudu nana.
\sfx kaja-yudu-nana_CO.wav
\xe That one has a lot.
\rf OSBORNE_C02-000165B.TMP
\xv Kaja nurri kurrkamala. Yarrbanji-darra.
\xe We were many young fellas.
\rf RS
\xv Winyaki mukara-adu kaja-adu.
\xe A kurdaitcha man with many spears.
\rf RS
\xv Jilaba yalu karriya marrkajini, kaja-adu dara-adu.
\xe They go hunting on the east side, with lots of dogs.
\rf RS
\xv Kaja-adu ninji wanami-yudu.
\xe You've got a lot of beer.
\rf RS
\xv Kaja bulunjurru.
\xe Many stars.
\rf RS
\xv Mudunama ngamba burrbijbi kaja-anyi kaku-anyi.
\xe Tomorrow we are going to get a lot of fish.
\rf RS
\xv Mayi yalu daba ngaan kudanba. Kalijbi, kajaa, kurrkamalaa burrurrii.
\xe They might kill me, spear me, that big mob of men.
\rf RS
\xv Jilaba nyulu nangkurru yanyi-anyi. Ngala ngawu, ngawu, jujuu ngawu jungku karurri, jujuu, kajana barrawunu. 
\xe He come here for some meeting, while I was far away to the east, away in the big town (among many buildings).
\rf RS
\xv Windijbi nurri yaluwanya kajaa yanyii.
\xe We supplied them with a lot of information.
\rf RS
\xv Bariyimbi ninya kuwada, kajaa barri, wawurraa.
\xe The big mob of kids is driving you made.
\rf RS
\xv Nayi kala, kaja-adu, kaku-yudu, nayi manangka.
\xe This place, this river, has a lot of fish.
\xe RS
\xv Jungkumu narri kaja-darra.
\xe Sit down you lot.
\rf IS_GB
\xv Jila yalu kaja-darra.
\xe They all go.
\rf MB_LH09
\xv Jungku ngamba kaja.
\sfx
\xe We are many.
\rf EF_R299EA1
\va
\sy 
\cf kurrkamala
\cf kurrkilinya
\cf murrku
\nt
\cp
\nq 
\dt 15/11/13 4:10 PM

\lf kajana

\lx kajakaja

\dt
\lf

\lx kajala
\mr kajala
\sf kajala_CO.wav
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd manufacture
\sd tool
\lt
\ge digging stick
\ge yam stick
\re
\so EF, RS, GB, EK, JD93, JP_TT
\xv Marijbi ngawu kajala ngaki.
\xe I'm holding my digging stick.
\rf RS
\xv Makirra, kurrijbi yalu kajalaa, manii.
\xe The white ochre, they dig it out with their digging stick and their hands. 
\rf rs2004-01
\xv Nayi nyulu bujubu jambana. Kurrijbi ngawu. Kajalaa.
\xe Here it (goanna) is lying in the earth. I'll dig it out, with (my) digging stick.
\rf rs2002-01
\xv Daba ngawu kajalaan janki barri, kudanba.
\xe I struck it on the back of the neck and killed it (goanna).
\rf RS
\xv Kurrijbi ngamba, kajalaa, kundaa. 
\xe We are digging with our wooden digging sticks.
\rf RS
\xv Rirrajba ngawu, kajalaa daba  baribarimbi. 
\xe I chase after it (goanna) and try to hit it with my digging stick, but miss.
\rf RS
\xv Jilaba ngawu kajala-adu wadaba-anyi, kujini.
\xe I go searching for goannas with my digging stick.
\rf RS
\xv Nayi nyulu bujubu jambana. Kurrijbi ngawu, kajalaa.
\xe It's lying in the ground. I dig it out with (my) digging stick.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf barrku
\nt Traditionally, women fought with {kajala} 'yamsticks' while men fought with {barrku} 'nullanullas' (EK).
\cp Wlp {kajalarra} 'wooden scoop for cleaning out Bush Tomatoes'; {kaja} 'spear' in some languages.
\nq
\dt 20/Sep/2006
\lf kajalaa
\lf kajala-adu
\lf kajala-anyi

\lx kajalaba
\mr kajala-ba
\sf kajalaba.wav
\sf kajalaba02.wav
\sf kajalaba_CO.wav
\sn
\ps verb
\pc
\sd motion
\lt X move upwards
\ge climb up
\ge climb over
\ge climb into
\ge go up
\ge ascend
\ge clamber
\re
\so EF, RS, GB, EK, CO
\xv Babaa nurri kajalaba kingkarri. Bala-wurru.
\xe We take off and climb up high towards the sky.
\rf RS2005-06
\xv Kajalaba nurri. Babaa nurri kingkarri kajalaba. Julakini.
\xe We climbed. We flew high upwards, in the plane.
\rf RS2005-06
\xv Kajala-kurru ngamba kuku-najba wawurra-wiya, kujarra.
\xe We are looking at two children climbing, two (of them).
\rf RS2004-05
\xv Kajalaba yalu kundana nana wawurra-darra.
\xe The children are climbing up the tree.
\rf RS
\xv Kajalaba ngawu julakini.
\xe I climb into the plane.
\rf RS
\xv Ngamuyu miya nayi kajalaba ngakinburru, nukamini.
\xe I thought it was a snake climbing up on me, onto my foot.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku nurri, kajalaba. Jujuu kingkarri.
\xe We can't climb it (mountain). It's too high.
\rf RS
\xv Kajalaba ninji kundana. Najba-najba nganyingka. Mayi ninji burrurru. 
\xe You are climbing up the tree. Look out for yourself. You might fall.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku barri ngawu kajalakanyi kundana.
\xe I couldn't climb up the tree then.
\rf GB
\xv Kundana kajalajini ngawu yirrbinkijbi.
\xe While climbing up the tree I fell down.
\rf GB
\xv Kajala!
\xe Climb up!
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Karana ngawu kajalaba.
\xe I climbed up the hill.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Balyanga kajala kundana!
\xe Don't climb the tree!
\rf MF_GB76
\xv Kajalaba karana.
\sfx
\xe Get up on the rock.
\rf EF_R299B1
\va kajilaba (GB)
\sy
\cf baba
\cf kingkarri
\an kulikulijbi
\an dakalijbi
\nt
\cp
\nq

\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd contact
\lt Xerg cause to be many of Y
\lt multiply
\ge divide into many
\ge multiply
\re
\so RS
\xv Ja-ninji kajamba barri [kajaambarri], ja-nimba kaja ngambalangi nanganjaa. Kaku ngambalangi.
\xe You will then get a lot, you two will get lots for us, fish for us.
\rf RS
\xv Kajamba ngawu walijin nimbalangi.
\xe I'll divide up this meat for you two.
\rf RS

\dt 20/Oct/2006


\lx kaku
\mr kaku
\sf kaku-fish.wav
\ps noun
\pc kaku.jpg
\sn 1
\sd animal
\sd fish
\lt generic term for fish
\ge fish
\re
\so RS, GB, EK, JD, SC_BB, PK_SK, MS_SK, AP+AF_PS, JP_TT
\xv Kaku kunyba walijin. Barrulkijini.
\xe The fish is good meat. It's oily.
\rf rs2003-01
\xv Kaku nyulu wilijirri.
\sfx kaku nyulu wilijirri.aif
\xe He's pulling in a fish.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Bajawaja nyulu nana kaku.
\xe That fish is thrashing about.
\rf rs2004-04
\xv Nanganja nyulu kakun.
\rf She's catching fish.
\sfx nanganja nyulu kakun.mp3
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Kaku nyulu bariyimbi ngambalangi.
\sfx
\xe He failed to catch any fish for us.
\rf RS
\xv Jariyamba nyulu bala. Kakuu nyulu jariyamba janyini.
\xe It took the hook away. The fish took it away in its mouth.
\rf rs2005-06
\xv Ramijbi nyulu kakuu, waduku ngaki.
\xe The fish broke my line.
\rf RS
\xv Nijbi yalu walijin balana. Balana yalu nijbi, kaku-anyi.
\xe They put the bait (=meat) on the hook. They put it on the hook to get fish.
\rf RS2005-08
\xv Jamurawa, jungku nyulu wanamini. Wakalinyi. Kudijbi nyulu jarrjini kakunu. 
\xe The water goanna, it lives down in the water. It lies (there) eating fish.
\rf RS2005-05
\xv Kaku-anyi, barranja-anyi ngawu, kaku-anyi. Mayi ngawu nanganjaa.
\xe I'll try for some fish. I might catch (some).
\rf rs2004-03
\xv Nungka jila kaku-anyi.
\xe Let's go to get fish.
\rf GB
\va
\sy Wlp. {yawu}
\cf karubu yanyba
\cf wajarrijbi
\nt
\cp Wambaya (gagu.wi}, {gagu.ma}
\nq ka:ku

\lf kaku


\lx kakulu
\mr kakulu
\sf kakulu.wav
\sn
\ps noun
\pc
\sd PEOPLE
\sd KIN
\lt younger sibling, or child of parent's younger same sex sibling
\ge younger brother
\ge younger sister
\re
\so RS
\xv Kakulu-nganja-anyi
\sfx kakulu-nganyja-anyi.wav
\xe For his younger brother.
\rf RS
\xv Nanangkuya kadimirra, jawaji-nganja ngakinkanyi kakulu-nganja-anyi, ngawu, ngawu bulangi bujarra-nganja.
\sfx bujarra-nganyja.wav
\xe Those two young ones, who are my young brother's children, me, I'm their aunt.
\rf rs2005-02
\xv Nyulu ngaki kadimirra kakulu-nganja ngaki
\xe He's younger than me, (he's) my younger brother.
\rf RS
\xv Bawa-nganja, mamanumbu nyulu kakulu-nganjaa.
\xe The younger brother lost his older brother.
\rf RS
\xv Bawa-nganja ngawu, ngaki kakulu-nganja nyulu.
\sfx
\xe I'm his older brother, he's my younger brother.
\rf RS2000-09
\va
\sy dawirri
\cf balala
\cf bawa
\cf bunyinyi
\cf maju

\dt
\lf kaku
\lf kuujbu


\lx kala
\mr kala
\hm 1
\sf kala.wav
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd country
\lt
\ge country
\ge home ^country
\ge own ^country
\ge own ^place
\ge land
\re
\so RS, JD93
\xv Kala mungkuji.
\sfx kala_mungkuji.wav
\xe Land owner.
\rf RS-RG1999
\xv Ngaki kala.
\xe My country.
\rf JD93
\xv Yakujkanyi nimba ngaan. Kannga-anyi nimba, kala-wurru.
\xe You two have to leave me. You've got to go back to your home country.
\rf RS
\xv Yakujbu ngawu, narriyanya. Kannga barri ngawu. Kala-wurru barri.
\xe I'm leaving you all. I'm going back home to my country.
\rf RS
\xv Winja-bunyi ninji kala-wunyi ninji?
\xe What place are you from?
\rf RS
\xv Julaki nurri nanganjaa jangkurr-yudu jamba-anyi. Kala-anyi=nurri jilaba. Yany-kanyi nurri. Yanyba nurri, Kala-anyi nurri yanyba, kala-anyi nurriyangi.
\xe We got a plane for the meeting about the land. We went about the land, to talk about it. We talked, we talked about the land, about our land.
\rf RS
\xv Naniwii ngamba jilaba kularra kala-wurru. Waanyi-anyi burrurri-anyi.
\xe We went off to the south to our country, belonging to the Waanyi people.
\rf RS2005-06
\xv Yurru-kadi nyulu kala-wunyi barrawunu lungkajii kijibajii.
\xe The cheeky policeman took him from his place and put him into a jail cell.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf raji
\cf jamba
\nt
\cp
\nq raji home?
\dt 30/Apr/2009
\lf kala-anyi
\lf kalana
\lf kala-wunyi
\lf kala-wurru

\lx kala
\mr kala
\hm 2
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd elements
\sd water
\sd country
\lt
\ge river
\ge creek
\re
\so EF, RS, GB, JD93, JP_TT, CO
\xv Bayinga nayi kala nurriyangi.
\xe This river is on the west side of us.
\rf rs2005-06
\xv Jilaba nimba nangkurru wajka, kala-wurru. Karubu-yanyba nimba.
\xe You two come down here, to the river. You two go fishing.
\rf RS
\xv Kalana ninji jungku, kalana.
\xe You are sitting by the river, on the river.
\rf RS
\xv Langkurri nyulu jilaba. Kalana, dandaraba.
\xe He walked north hugging the bank of the river all the way.
\rf RS
\xv Raji ngaki wajka kalana. Dumularraa ngan jakajba kala-wunyi.
\xe My camp was down near the river. The flood waters chased me away from the river.
\rf GB
\xv Nayi kala kaja-yudu kaku-yudu -- nayi manangka.
\sfx nayi_kala_kajayudu_kakuyudu_nayi_manangka.wav
\xe This river has a lot of fish. This stream (does).
\rf RS
\xv Jila ngawu kala-wurru.
\xe I'm going to the river.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\va kalaakala
\sy manangka
\cf jakuli
\cf kalabirr
\nt
\cp
\nq

\lx kalabirr
\mr kalabirr
\hm 1
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd elements
\sd earth
\lt
\ge sand
\ge loose soil
\re
\so EF, RS, GB, EK, JD, JP_TT
\xv Namany-kanyi nyulu kalabirrii.
\xe The sand can cause it (vehicle) to get stuck.
\rf RS
\xv Kalabirrini nyulu nukami jariijbi.
\xe The wheel sunk into the sand.
\rf RS
\xv Namanyba naan. Namanyba  nukami jambaa, kalabirrii, jalwaa jambaa kalabirrii. Budangku nangka mularrijbi. 
\xe It was stuck.Its wheels were held by the sandy soil, the strong sandy soil. It couldn't drive itself out of it.
\rf RS
\xv Ngarrangarra barri nayi jamba kalabirr.
\xe This sandy soil is hot now.
\rf RS
\xv Kalabirrini nurri jungku, yanjini. Kalana barri.
\xe We are sitting in the sand yarning, near the river.
\rf RS
\xv Wawurra yalu kalabirrini nawunu jurra.
\xe The kids are playing here in the sand.
\rf GB
\va kalabi
\sy
\cf jamba
\cf janja
\cf darrburarrbu
\nt Dymock (1993) also records KALANYIN (< kala-anyi 'creek-POSS')
\nt Trascribed as {kalabi} in JP_TT
\cp
\nq Garrwa <kalabirr> River Red Gum

\lx kalawunyi
\mr kalawunyi
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd spatial
\lt interior to or under some entity
\ge beneath
\ge in
\ge inside
\ge under
\ge underneath
\ge down under
\ge interior
\re
\so RS, MB_LH13
\xv Wilijirri yalu kalawunyi, barrawunu ja yalu nijbi naan.
\xe They are dragging him inside and will put him down in the building.
\rf rs2005-08a
\xv Yurru-kadi ngawu, ngadijbi ngawu. Ngakinkanyini. Kalawunyi, bindawarrana. 
\xe I'll put it, I'll hide it in mine. Inside the bag.
\rf rs2005-05
\xv Kudumbu nyulu barrawunu, kalawunyi.
\xe He locked him inside the house.
\rf RS2005-09
\xv Wanka nyulu bujubu, kalawunyi, barrawunu.
\xe He's lying there alive, inside, in the clinic.
\rf rs2005-08a
\xv Najba nungka kalawunyi, wakalinyi, najba nungka, budangku nayi. Jilaba nyulu.
\xe We look inside, underneath (down inside), we see that it is empty. He has gone.
\rf RS
\xv Jungku ninji wuja nawunu. Kudijbi kalawunyi barrawunu.
\xe You stay put here, lie down inside the house.
\rf RS2003-03
\xv Jangunu nurri nijbi, kalawunyi, makarraba, jibaa.
\xe We put it down (to cook) in the fireplace, cover it over with paperbark.
\rf RS
\xv Jungku yalu ngandunu kalawunyi. Kurrkamala.
\xe They are sitting down under a shady tree, a mob of them.
\rf RS
\xv Jungku yalu kurrkamala, kalawunyi barri julakini barri muwana.
\xe There were a lot of people sitting inside the belly of the aeroplane.
\rf RS
\xv Jarrba nungka kakun jungkunu kalawunyi jambana. Ngandunu.
\xe We are eating fish sitting down on the ground, under a shady tree.
\rf RS
\nt
\sy
\cf jarijbi
\cf wajka
\cf wakalinyi
\cf yurru-kadi
\nt
\cp
\nq 
\dt 30/Oct/2006

\lx kalijbi
\mr kali-j-bi
\sf kalijbi.wav
\sf kalijbi02.wav
\sf kalijbi-03.wav
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc spear.jpg
\sd contact
\sd impact
\lt Xerg cause point to come in contact with Y, and enter into Y
\ge pierce
\ge stab
\ge spear
\re
\so EF, RS, GB, EK, MS_SK
\xv Kalijbi ngambalanya mukuraa.
\sfx kalijbi=ngambalanya_mukuraa.aif
\xe He speared us.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Kuku-najba ngawu kalijkurru.
\sfx kalijkurru.aif
\xe I observed him stab it.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Kalijbi nyulu walijin.
\sfx kalijbi nyulu walijin.wav
\xe He speared the animal.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Kalijbi nyulu banjana-wunyi.
\xe He stabbed him from behind.
\rf GB
\xv Gudaa nyulu kalijbi bidirrikan waliji, mukuraa.
\xe He used to spear kangaroos before.
\rf GB
\xv Kudulu nyulu kalijbi.
\xe He speared him in the heart.
\rf RS
\xv Kalijbi ngawu, kudijbi-wurru.
\xe I speared it as it slept.
\rf RS
\xv Kalijkanyi niyanya mukuraa, nangkani, burrurrii, kijibajii.
\xe This angry man wants to spear us.
\rf RS
\xv Kalijbi nyulu karaa.
\sfx
\xe He jabbed him with a stone.
\rf MS_SK
\xv Kalijbi nyulu mukuraa.
\sfx
\xe He speared it.
\rf IS_GB
\va
\sy
\cf badawamba
\cf kurrijbi
\nt MF+EM_CO {bandama} 'spear (it)!'

\nq

\lx Kalkudungu

\sfx
\xe This land belongs to the Kalkudungu people.

\xe That man is Kalkudungu. We don't understand their language.
\rf RS
\xv Jungku ngamba nawunu. Dajaya yalu ngambalanya nana-waani burrurri-darraa, Kalkudunguu.
\xe We are staying here. Otherwise those Kalkudungu men might beat us up.
\rf RS
\xv Wadamba yalu ngaan kakuu, Kalkudunguu, ngila-ngilaa.
\xe Those young Kalkudungu girls gave me a good feed of fish.
\rf RS
\xv Jilaba nurri, buluka-adu, yarraman-adu. Barulajba. Kalana barri, Kalkudungu-yanyi-wurru raji-wurru. Kala. Dajarra nana, Kalkudungu-anyi.
\xe We used to go with cattle and horses following along the river down to the Kalkudungu people's country. That Dajarra belongs to Kalkudungu people.
\rf RS
