\mr kalu
\sf karlu
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc bark.jpg
\sd BODY
\sd body part
\sd animal
\sd plant
\lt natural covering of human, animal or plant
\ge skin
\ge bark (of tree)
\re
\so RS, GB, EK, MS_SK, RC+MF_SK, JP_TT
\xv Luwanjaa yalu kalu.
\xe They spin the bark (into string).
\rf RS
\va
\sy banyi
\sy barrki
\sy waba
\cf bangkijbi
\cf jadalwari
\cf wurrimbi
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt

\sn 2
\ps noun
\pc
\sd artifact
\lt spoon made from bark of tree
\ge spoon
\ge scoop
\re
\so RS
\xv Kalu nurri nanganja, nanganja nurri kalu. Ja-nurri kularrijbi nayi dirrbu.
\sfx
\xe We get a bark spoon, get a spoon so we can scoop out the honey.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt

\lx kalwarraka
\mr karlwarraka
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\hm 1
\sd spatial
\lt Xerg strike Y and cause disintegration of Y into particles which detach from original source and move rapidly through air and scatter.
\ge splinter
\ge send flying
\ge shatter
\ge stir up
\ge explode
\ge blow to pieces
\re
\so RS
\xv Janybijbi nurri kalwarraka.
\xe We throw away the shavings (of wood).
\rf RS
\xv Daba nyulu nayi, kalwarraka nayi jamban. Mularrijbi nyulu jamba rangkijbi nyulu.
\xe It (lightning) struck the ground here and sent it flying.  It raised the earth when it hit it.
\rf RS
\xv Mayi nyulu ngambalanya rangkijbi, kalwarraka.
\xe It might strike us and blow us to pieces.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf
\nt
\cp
\nq 
\dt 26/Oct/2006

\lx kalwarraka
\mr kalwarraka
\sf
\hm 2
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd plant related
\lt small pieces of something that is impacted
\ge wood chips
\ge wood shavings
\ge pieces
\ge bits
\re
\so RS
\xv Marrba-marrba. Daba nyulu kundan. Rangkijbi. Daba nyulu kalwarraka.
\xe The lightning, it hit a tree. It struck it. The impact shattered it into wood chips.
\rf RS
\xv Janybijbi nurri kalwarraka.
\xe We throw away the shavings (of wood).
\rf RS2000-05b
\xv Daba nyulu nayi, kalwarraka nayi jamban. Mularrijbi nyulu jamba rangkijbi nyulu.
\xe It (lightning) struck the ground here and sent it flying.  It raised the earth when it hit it.
\rf RS
\xv Mayi nyulu ngambalanya rangkijbi, kalwarraka.
\xe It might strike us and blow us to pieces.
\rf RS
\va 
\sy
\cf
\nt Extended to refer to small pieces of anything that is smashed by some force
\cp
\nq 
\dt 30/Sep/2006

\lx kamarrangi
\mr kamarrangi
\sf kamarrangi.wav
\ps noun
\pc
\sd PEOPLE
\sd kin
\lt skin name of male child of {burralangi} man and {niwanama} mother;  father of {burralangi} son and {nurralama} daughter; brother of {nimarrama} woman; straight marriage with {nularrima} woman
\ge skin name
\ge subsection name
\re
\so RS, GB
\xv Ninji, Kamarrangi ninji. Kamarrangi burrurri. Ngawu, Nularrima. Kirriya. Ngaki kayikayi.
\xe You are Kamarrangi, a Kamarrangi man. I'm a Nularrima woman. (You are) my brother-in-law (sister's husband).
\rf RS
\xv Ngurrubu ngawu ninya, kamarrangi ngawu.
\xe I'm telling you, I'm a Kamarrangi man.
\rf RS
\xv Mankuu ngawu ninya wululuku, Kamarrangi.
\xe I can hear you old man, Kamarrangi.
\rf RS
\xv Nimba, wululuku kamarrangi-wiya.
\xe You two, two old Kamarrangi men.
\rf RS
\xv Jawikajba ngawu, nimbalanya, kamarrangi-wiya. Yanyi-anyi.
\xe I'm asking you both, you two Kamarrangi, about (your) language.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf
\nt
\cp
\nq 
\dt 19/Sep/2006

\lx kamburru 
\mr kamburru
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd people
\sd kin
\lt mother's classificatory brother
\ge distant uncle
\re
\so RS, GB
\xv Windijbi nurri, nangangi, kamburru-nganja.
\xe We give her (as wife) to our uncle.
\rf RS
\xv Banka, winja nganyi kamburru-nganja?
\xe Cousin, where's your uncle? (Person asking about their own father)
\rf RS
\xv Kuyi-rajba nangka karaa. Ngindiyi nyulu kamburru-nganja-anyi. 
\xe She bashes her head with a stone. She cries for her (deceased) uncle.
\rf RS
\va 
\sy kadidi
\sy kabubu
\sy kabukabu
\cf bujarra
\cf ngakinburrunyi
\nt Appropriate way of referring to one's cousin's uncle who is father to speaker.
\cp
\nq CHECK IF NOT KAMBURU as rrecorded by GB
\dt 18/Sep/2006

\lx kamu
\mr kamu
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd ELEMENTS
\sd sky
\sd time
\lt
\ge sunset
\ge suppertime
\ge early evening
\ge dusk
\re
\so RS, GB, JD93
\xv Dabarra-kanyi yalu kamu, kakun.
\xe They will cook the fish in the evening.
\rf RS
\xv Jundukanyi ninji, kaku, kamu, mungamba.
\xe You'll have a good feed of fish in the evening, once it's dark.
\rf RS
\xv Jarrkanyi ngamba kamuu, maman.
\xe We want to eat in the evening.
\rf RS
\xv Wangkijkanyi yalu kamuu.
\xe They'll dance in the evening.
\rf RS
\xv Manku-manku nganyingka kamu mungana.
\xe You think about it tonight.
\rf RS
\xv Wanbiya nimba kamu barri, mungana.
\xe You two landed just on sunset, in the dark.
\rf RS
\xv Ja-ngamba kannga-yirrimbi, raji-wurru barri, kamu.
\xe We'll take it back home then, at sunset.
\rf RS
\xv Jilaba ngawu kamu ngabungabunu, ngajirrini, ngajirrini barri, jambana.
\xe I'll go later on at sunset when it's cooler, when the ground is cooler.
\rf RS
\xv Kamu ngawu kiya najba.
\xe I'll have to look tonight.
\rf GB
\xv Kamu ngawu jila.
\xe I'll go this evening.
\rf GB
\va
\sy ngabungabu
\sy yababala
\cf barriyi
\cf jiwala
\cf munga
\cf mungamba
\nt Recorded by JD93 as 'today'
\cp
\nq
\dt 30/Sep/2006

\sn 2
\ps noun
\pc
\sd 
\lt food eaten around sunset
\ge supper
\ge evening meal
\re
\so RS, CO
\xv Nanganjaa ninji jalanya maman ngaki, kamu-anyi, kamu-anyi barri.
\sfx
\xe You are getting food for me directly, for supper, so I can eat supper.
\rf RS
\xv Kamu-anyi kannga.
\sfx kamuanyi-kannga_CO.wav
\xe He's coming back for supper.
\rf OSBORNE_C02-000165B.TMP
\va
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt

\lx kamukamu
\mr kamukamu
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd food
\lt alcoholic drink
\ge booze
\ge grog
\ge alcohol
\ge beer
\re
\so RS, JD93
\xv Kamukamu yalu ngaraba.
\xe They are drinking grog.
\rf RS
\xv Warrakuujbu yalu, ngarakini, kamukamunu.
\xe They went silly in the head as they drank grog.
\rf RS
\xv Ngaraba nyulu wanamin, kamukamu
\xe He was drinking beer, grog.
\rf RS
\xv Buduramba nangka warrkulii, yarrbanjii, kuwadaajini, warrakujini, ngarakini kamumanunu, kuwada-yaan.
\xe The young man strangled himself with a rope as he lost his reason as he drank grog, lost his reason.
\rf RS
\xv Kamukamu-wunyi, warrakuujbu=nyulu kulajin.
\xe As a result of the grog, he went mad in the head.
\rf RS
\xv Wanamiin, kamukamuu, barimbi naan, kulajin.
\xe The beer and the grog wrecked his head.
\rf RS
\xv Wanamii, kamukamuu yalunya nana-waan warrakuumbu.
\rf RS The beer and the alcohol made them go mad.
\xe RS
\xv Kamukamunu nyulu jungku ngarakini.
\xe He was sitting drinking grog.
\rf RS
\xv Burrbijbi yalu kamukamu-anyi.
\xe They run after grog.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf wanami
\nt Recorded by Dymock (1993) as 'bitter tasting'
\cp
\nq
\dt 12/Sep/2006
\lf kamukamu-anyi

\lx -kana
\mr 
\sf
\sn 1
\ps suffix
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt negative suffix used on verb stem to make negative command
\ge not
\ge cease
\ge don't
\ge stop
\re
\so RS
\xv Dajkana yaku nana wawurra kadimirra.
\xe Don't hit that little child.
\rf RS
\xv Jarrkana nana maman, dawurrumbu ninji. Jarrkana yakujbu ngambalangi.
\xe Stop eating that food, you're eating it all up. Stop eating and leave some for all of us.
\rf RS
\xv Dabarra-kana! Ngaki nana. Yakujbu!
\xe Don't cook it. It's mine. Leave it.
\rf  RS
\xv Najkana ninji ngaan!
\xe Don't you look at me!
\rf RS
\xv Jungku ninji wuja! Jila-kana wunjuku!
\xe Stay put. Don't go anywhere.
\rf RS
\xv Bulinja-kana wululuku!
\xe Don't smoke, old man.
\rf RS
\xv Bulinja-kana! yaku nana wanu. Barii nana barii.
\xe Stop smoking! Leave that tobacco (alone). It's bad, really bad.
\rf RS
\xv Kurru-kana!
\xe Don't move away.
\rf RS
\xv Kalijkana yaku! Ngarrimba nganyi.
\xe Don't spear him. He's your mate.
\rf RS
\xv Jila-kana, jungku ninji ngakinbunu nawunu wuja.
\xe Don't go. You stay put here with me.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf balyanga
\cf budangku
\nt
\cp
\nq check if kurru-kana or kuru-kana, from kur(r)unbu 'move away'
\dt 01/Nov/2006

\lx kananganja
\mr karnanganyja
\sf karnanganyja.wav
\sf karnanganyja-emuF.wav
\sf karnanganyja03-emuF.wav
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc kananganyja1.jpg
\pc kananganyja2.jpg
\sd animal
\la Dromaius novaehollandiae
\lt
\ge emu
\re emu
\so RS, EF_R299D2, GB, EK, SC_BB, AP+AF_PS, JP_TT
\xv Wuluku kananganja waliji.
\sfx
\xe The emu is a big animal.
\rf RS
\xv Kurrkamala ngamba najba kananganja yubalina.
\xe We saw lots of emus on the road.
\rf RS
\xv Ngamuyu kananganja nukami. Najba nungka nukami.
\xe That looks like an emu track. We look at the footprint.
\rf RS
\xv Kananganja nungka najba, budangku nyulu winyaki. Kananganja nana waliji.
\xe We are seeing an emu's (foot), its not the track of a kurdaitcha man. That's the actual emu, the animal.
\rf RS
\xv Kananganja nyulu kalijbi mukuraa.
\xe He speared the emu.
\rf GB
\xv Budangku nyulu babaanyi, kananganja.
\xe Emus can't fly.
\rf GB
\va
\sy jakudukudu
\cf dangkarr-wuya
\cf kilili
\cf ngadarru
\cf ngaribundu
\cf wangkuwangku [GB]
\nt
\cp Wambaya; Warlpiri
\nq

\lx kanawa
\mr kanawa
\sf karnawa-longFR299D2.wav
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd size
\lt having one dimension relatively longer than other dimension(s), or relatively longer than that of another entity with which it is compared 
\ge long
\ge tall
\ge elongated
\ge slender
\re
\so EF, GB, RS, JP_TT
\xv Mulu kanawa.
\xe Long nose.
\rf RS
\xv Duka kanawa.
\xe Long neck.
\rf RS
\xv Ngarijaba wadaa, kangkarinyaa, kanawaa.
\xe (He) carved it with a long sharp knife.
\rf RS
\xv Wulukundirri, kanawa kanba nayi.
\xe It's very big, this grass is tall.
\rf RS
\xv Murrurrungku kadimirra, kanawa.
\xe The swordfish is long and thin.
\rf RS
\xv Kanawa ngalu-wurru.
\xe He's tall up to (my) chest.
\rf RS
\xv Warrkurrji ngawu nanganja kanawa.
\xe I get the long sinew (from the kangaroo's leg).
\rf RS
\xv Kanba nana kanawan.
\xe That grass is tall.
\rf MF_GB76
\va
\sy

\an kulaa
\nt Recorded as 'cirro cumulus, herringbone cloud' by Dymock (1993) 
\cp Wambaya {garnaa, garnawuma}
\nq
\dt 29/Sep/2006

\lx kanba
\mr karnba
\sf karnba.wav
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc karnba.jpg
\sd plant
\lt
\ge grass
\re
\so RS, GB, EF, EK, MS_SK, RC+MF_SK, JP_TT, MB_LH14
\xv Kanba yalu jarrba, bidirrikaa.
\xe Kangaroos eat grass.
\rf GB
\xv Kudumanjaa yalu bakarrijbi nana kanba, kunburrkii.
\xe They keep on setting fire to that grass using a firestick.
\rf rs2005-01
\xv Jungku nyulu kanbana nana bumbululu. 
\xe The fantail wren lives in the grass.
\rf RS
\xv Kudijbi nyulu kanbana, bungkina.
\xe The little wallaby is lying down in the grass.
\rf RS2004-04
\xv Wuluku-dirri, kanawa kanba nayi.
\xe There is too much of this tall grass (to be able to see the ground).
\rf RS
\xv Kanba rajba.
\sfx
\xe Burn the grass.
\rf EF_R299C2
\va
\sy
\cf binda
\cf ngunyarri kanba
\nt Also used of 'bush medicine' or 'herbs' (RS2000-07a) 
\cp Garrwa, Gunindirri; Ganggalida {garnda}
\nq
\dt 29/Sep/2006

\lx Kangkalida
\mr kangka-lida
\sf
\sn 1
\ps proper noun
\pc
\sd PEOPLE
\lt name of people to immediate east of Waanyi and their language
\ge Ganggalida
\re
\so RS, GB, EK
\xv Kangkalida nana.
\sfx Kangkalida nana.wav
\xe That's Ganggalida.
\rf RS2004-05
\xv Nana-waan-kanyi, Ganggalida-anyi Nyangka-anyi.
\xe It belongs to those (other) people, to the Kangkalida and Nyangka people.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku ngawu yanyba yalungi yanyi, Ganggalida-anyi.
\xe I don't speak their language, belonging to Kangkalida.
\rf RS
\xv Waanyi, Kangkalida yalu jungku nawunu Ngudurrini.
\xe Waanyi and Kangkalida people live here in Doomadgee.
\rf EK (ML-notes)
\va
\sy
\cf
\nt This language is also known as Yukulta.
\cp
\nq

\lx kangkarinya
\mr kangkarinya
\sf kangkarinya-knife.wav
\sn
\ps noun
\pc knife.jpg
\sd artifact
\lt elongated piece of stone or metal used for cutting
\ge knife
\ge blade
\re
\so RS, JD
\va
\xv Karrbijbi nyulu ngaan kangkarinyaa.
\xe He cut me with a knife.
\rf RS
\xv Kunkulurru ngawu ninya mundirri, kangkarinyaa.
\xe I'll slash your back with a knife.
\rf RS
\xv Ngarrijaba nurri, kangkarinyaa.
\xe We scrape it off with a knife.
\rf RS
\xv Yurrukadi nyulu, janyini, mukurana, kangkarinya.
\xe He would put the blade into the front end of the spear.
\rf RS
\xv Kudululu ngamba kaku kangkarinyaa.
\xe We gut fish with a knife.
\rf RS
\va kangkarra
\va kangkarri
\sy
\cf babakana
\cf KALIKALI
\nt Recorded as {kangkarri} in AP+AF_PS; as {kangkarra} in MB_LH14
\cp
\nq Check if not {kangkirinya}, Check GB files
\dt 19/Sep/2006
\lf kangkarinyaa

\lx kangku
\mr kangku
\sf kangku-FF.wav
\sf kangku-FF_R299b3.wav
\ps noun
\pc
\sd people
\sd kin
\lt father's father or sibling of father's father; man's son's child, brother's son's child
\ge father's father
\ge grandfather (paternal)
\ge great aunt (paternal)
\ge great uncle (paternal)
\ge grandchild (paternal)
\re
\so EF, RS, GB, EK, JD
\xv Ngaki kangku.
\xe My granddaughter (man referring to his son's daughter).
\rf RS
\xv Mimi-nganjaa, kangku-nganjaa, bikali yalu.
\xe His mother's fathers and his father's fathers carry him (young initiate).
\rf RS
\xv Ngawu, nijarrijbi ngawu ninya kangkun, ngaki.
\xe Me, I call you grandfather for me.
\rf RS
\xv Kangku ninji, ngaliyangi, kirriya-anyi. Ngila-wiya-anyi. Wululuku.
\xe You are our grandfather (father's father) for us two girls, old man.
\rf RS
\xv Kangku-anyi nana mukura.
\xe That spear belongs to my grandfather.
\rf GB
\va
\sy murimuri
\cf 
\nt
\cp Wambaya 
\nq RS's son's daughter
\dt 29/Sep/2006

\lx kanjijbi
\mr kanyji-j-bi
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd
\lt X come to be without something previously had
\ge finish
\ge run out
\ge use up
\re
\so RS, GB
\xv Kanjijbi ngawu.
\sfx kanjijbi ngawu.wav
\xe I've run out.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Budangku yalu nana wanba, barrawu kanjijbi. Karrinja nyulu.
\xe They haven't finished that house. It has stopped (being built).
\rf RS
\xv Budangku yalu mirramba, kanjijbi. Karrinja yalu nana-waan.
\xe They haven't finished building them. They have stopped (being built).
\rf RS
\xv Kanjijbi barri nyulu.
\xe It's finished now (of fire that has burned away to ash).
\rf RS
\xv Kanjijbi nyulu nana wanami.
\xe That rain has stopped.
\rf IS_GB78
\xv Wayi barri ninji kanjijbi dabarraba maman?
\xe Have you finished cooking the damper yet?
\rf IS_GB78
\va
\sy
\cf dawurrumbu
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt
\lf kanjimbi
\sn 2
\ps verb
\pc
\sd
\lt 
\ge waste
\ge not make good use of
\re
\so RS
\xv Kanjijbi nyulu maman. Budangku nyulu jarrba. Janybijbi nyulu, dara-wurru.
\sfx
\xe He's wasting the food, he's not eating it. He's throwing (it) away to the dog.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt Wambaya verb.
\cp
\nq

\lx kanjimbi

\sn 1
\ps verb

\ge use up
\ge finish
\re
\so RS
\xv Kanjimbi ngawu.
\sfx kanjimbi ngawu.wav
\xe I've finished (making them).
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Mirramba ngawu. Jukulin barri, kanjimbi ngawu. Budangku barri ngawu jungku. Maninyi.
\sfx mirramba=ngawu jukulin=barri kanjimbi ngawu budangku=barri ngawu jungku.wav
\xe I've finished making the boomerangs now. I no longer have any (to make). I've none.
\rf RS2005-04

\lx kankulu
\mr kankulu
\hm 1
\sf
\sn
\ps noun
\pc
\sd animal
\sd reptile
\la Amphibolurus gilberti
\lt small lizard sp. black body with white stripe on face 
\ge Ta-ta Dragon
\ge Left-hand Lizard
\so Doomadgee, IV_GB, GW
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\va kankulukulu
\sy wanbida
\cf wadaba
\cf jumbuuna
\cf warrnguna
\an
\nt Called "Blackboy Lizard" by some Waanyi speakers as the "old man" one is black.
\cp
\nq
\dt


\lx kankulu
\mr kankulu
\hm 2
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd food
\sd bodily activity
\lt Xerg eat Y (=food)
\ge have a feed
\ge eat a meal
\re
\so RS
\xv Kankulu nyulu maman, balikajba nyulu.
\xe He was having a feed, he was hungry.
\rf RS
\xv Kankulu nyulu kakun, balikajini. 
\xe He had a feed of fish as he was hungry.
\rf RS
\xv Jungku nyulu kankulunu.
\xe He was sitting having a feed.
\rf RS
\xv Kuku-najba nyulu ngambalanya kankulu-wurru.
\xe He's watching us eating.
\rf RS
\xv Kankulunu ngamba jungku, ngala nyulu jungku, kuku-najini.
\xe We were sitting having a feed while he was sitting watching (us).
\rf RS
\xv Kankulu-wurru nyulu jungku najini, niyanya.  Kuku-najba nyulu niyanya jarrkurru, kankulu-wurru.
\xe He's sitting looking at you and me having a feed. He's watching us both eating, having a feed.
\rf RS
\xv Nana walijin, kankulu nyulu jarrbana kanba. Binanyba nyulu burrurrii.
\xe That animal, he was having a feed of grass. The man crept up on him.
\rf RS
\xv Kankulu nyulu walijin mirrbu.
\xe He's having a feed of frog meat.
\rf RS
\xv Jarrba barri ngamba, kankulu barri. Dumbululujbu barri ngawu muwan.
\xe Then we ate it, had a good feed until my stomach was swollen.
\rf RS
\xv Jarrba nyulu kankulu.
\sfx
\xe He ate it, had a good feed.
\rf RS2005-09
\va
\sy
\cf jarrba
\cf jundujbu
\cf mukuja
\nt
\cp
\nq ?kangkulu
\dt 19/Sep/2006
\lf kankulu
\lf kankulujbu
\lf kankulunu
\lf kankulu-wurru
\lf kankulu-kanyi

\lx kankulukulu
\mr kankulukulu
\hm 1
\sf
\sn
\ps noun
\pc
\sd animal
\sd reptile
\la Amphibolurus gilberti
\lt 
\ge Ta-ta Dragon
\ge Left-hand Lizard
\re
\so EK, LM, GB, JP_TT, MS_SK, GW
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\va kankulu
\sy
\cf wadaba
\cf jumbuuna
\cf warrnguna
\an
\nt Called "Blackboy Lizard" by some Waanyi speakers
\nt Described by Mary Stark (KEEN_S01-001153A) as "river lizard, black one" 
\cp Wambaya {garngulugulu} 'lizard sp.'; Ganggalida; Garrwa
\nq
\dt

\lx Kanmangi
\mr kanmangi
\sf Kanmangi-Island Plain.wav
\sf Kanmangi-02.wav
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd place name
\lt
\ge Island Plain
\re
\so RS
\xv Jungku yalu nanawunu Kanmangini.
\sfx jungku yalu nanawunu Kanmangini.wav
\xe They stopped there at Kanmangi (Island Plain).
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Kanmangi-wurru, jilaba nurri, kudaya.
\sfx Kanmangi-wurru jilaba nurri kudaya.wav
\xe Some of us, we'll go to Kanmangi (Island Plain).
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Kanmangi-wurru bula jilaba, nukamin.
\xe They both went to Kanmangi on foot.
\rf RS
\xv Kanmangini, jungku bula. Karrinja bula, kunju bulangi. 
\xe They are both at Kanmangi. Their bodies stayed there.
\rf RS
\va
\sy

\lf karrba
\lf karrbijbi


\lx karrbijbi
\mr karrbi-j-bi
\sf kadbijbi.wav
\ps verb
\pc
\sd affect by contact
\lt Xerg cause part of y to become separated from other part of y, by contact with y
\ge cut
\ge pick (fruit, plant)
\ge skin (something)
\re
\so EF, RS, JD93
\xv Karrbijbi waliji.
\sfx
\xe Cut meat.
\rg EF_R299B3
\xv Karrbijbi nyulu kangkarinyaa. Karrbijbi kunkulaba.
\xe He cut him with that stone knife. Ripped him open.
\rf RS2002-03
\xv Karrbijbi nungka nayi bambularra ramijbi.
\xe We'll cut off its tail.
\rf rs2000-03
\xv Karrbijbi nurri. Jaluki, janybijbi nurri. Nijbi nurri dungalan.
\xe We cut it out. The intestines we toss aside. We put in hot stones.
\rf RS2003-03
\xv Karrbijbi nurri walijin, kangkarinyaa.
\xe We cut the meat with a knife.
\rf RS
\xv Karrbijbi nyulu jiba.
\xe He cuts the paperbark (from tree).
\rf RS
\xv Nanganja ngawu nayi wanu. Karrbijbi ngawu.
\xe I am getting this tobacco. I'm picking it.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku nungka karrbijbi, nayi waliji, mujii nangkani.
\xe We can't cut this meat, with this blunt one.
\rf RS
\xv Mayi nyulu karrbijbi ninya nukami, malangkarrii. Badawamba kalarrangi, badawamba nukamin.
\xe The sheet of iron might cut your feet. It might pierce right through the feet. 
\rf rs2005-06
\xv Wakadaba ngaka nanganbunyi waliji-wunyi karrbajinyi.
\xe I washed my hands after cutting up this meat.
\rf GB
\va
\sy karrba
\cf kurrkulaba ~ kukulaba ~ kungkularrba ??
\cf ramijbi
\nt Pronounced [kadbijbi].
\cp Garrwa {kalba} 'cut'
\nq check if these {kadba} forms are same verb or different one
\dt
\lf karrba (IMP)
\lf karrbaya (POT)
\lf karrbajinyi (ABL)

\lx karrinja

\sf karrinyja-stand.wav
\ps verb
\pc stand_leg_up.jpg
\sd stance
\lt
\ge stand
\re 
\so RS, BG, EF, MS_SK, CO
\xv Karrinja ngawu.
\sfx karrinyja-ngawu.wav
\xe I'm standing.
\rf EF_R299A7
\xv Karrinja nyulu.
\sfx karrinyja_nyulu-it_stand.wav
\sfx karrinyjaa_nyulu.wav
\xe It's standing.
\rf RS-RG1999
\xv Karrinja ngamba.
\sfx karrinja ngamba.mp3
\xe We were standing.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Karrinja nangangi mundurrini.
\sfx karrinja nangangi mundurrini.aif
\xe (He) stood behind him.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Karrinjama!
\xe Stand up!
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Balyanga karrinjama.
\xe Don't stand up.
\rf GB
\xv Karrinja nyulu langkurri najini.
\xe He's standing looking north.
\rf GB
\xv Najba ngambalanya nanangkani karrinjana.
\xe That man can see us while standing.
\rf GB
\xv Kalana karrinja wanami.
\xe The water is standing in the river.
\rf GB
\xv Kudarrijbi nyulu karrinjaa.
\xe He's standing there quietly.
\rf RS
\xv Karrinja nyulu, jambana najini. 
\xe He stood looking at the ground.
\rf RS
\xv Karrinja nyulu nayi kunda mama-yudu.
\xe This tree stands with fruit.
\rf RS
\xv Bakarrijbi nyulu ngaan nukami, karrinja-wurru.
\xe It burned my foot when I stood on it.
\rf RS
\xv Karrinja ninji, jilakanyi barri ninji!
\xe Stand up, you've got to get going.
\rf RS
\xv Karrinja yalu kalana, kundan.
\xe The trees stand (=grow) along the creek.
\rf RS
\xv Lalujbu nyulu, karrinja nyulu.
\xe He got up, he stood up.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku barri nyulu karrinja-anyi.
\xe He can't stand up now.
\rf GB
\xv Kudarri karrinjama!
\xe Stand there quietly.
\ref GB (Tape no. 579, side 1)
\va
\sy malba
\cf lalujbu
\nt
\cp Wambaya {garranbi}
\nq

\re

\xe They girls are going fishing.
\rf RS

\xe They are fishing. They will catch us some (fish) for supper.
\rf RS
\xv Karubu-yanyba yalu, wadukuu.
\xe They are fishing with hooked fishing lines.
\rf RS

\xe They make hooks with fishing lines.

\lx kayi
\mr kayi
\sf kayi.wav
\ps verb
\pc
\sd sound
\lt X call out in loud voice
\ge call out
\ge howl
\ge scream
\ge screech
\ge shout
\ge sing out
\ge yell out
\ge howl
\re
\so RS, EF, GB, EK, MF+EM_CO
\xv Kayii nana nganyi.
\sfx kayi-nana-nganyi.wav
\sfx kayi-nana-nganyi02.wav
\xe That one is calling out for you.
\rf EF
\xv Kayimi nanangkanyi!
\xe Sing out to that one!
\rf GB
\xv Nayi barrawal, durrajba nyulu burrurri-anyi. Kayi nyulu.
\xe This cockatoo takes fright because of the man. It screeches.
\rf RS
\xv Ngarrangarramba nangka. Kayi nyulu, bajawaja nyulu ngarrimbi-anyi.
\sfx
\xe He's getting all steamed up. He's kicking and screaming out for his friends (to come and help him).
\rf RS
\xv Kayi-wurru ngawu mankuu, kadimirra, warrwarri-darra.
\xe I can hear the little ones, all the children, calling out.
\rf RS
\xv Balyanga ngaan kayinma dabarra-kurru.
\xe Don't call out to me while I'm cooking.
\rf GB
\xv Kayimi nanangkanyi.
\xe Call out to that one.
\rf GB
\xv Kayini nyulu burrurru.
\xe As he fell he sang out.
\rf RS
\xv Kayi-anyi nyulu, ngada-nganja-anyi.
\xe He'll call out for his mother.
\rf RS
\xv Kayii nyulu warrki nayi.
\xe This dingo is howling.
\rf EK (ML notes)
\xv Lajibi ngawu kayi-wurru.
\xe I heard him call out.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Kayimi!
\xe Call out!
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Kayi nana nganyi. Jila lajibi.
\sfx

\sf kijibaji-cheeky_R299b2.wav
\sf kijibaji_RS.wav
\ps noun
\pc
\sd behavioural
\sd emotion
\lt of something having the potential to cause trouble, harm
\ge cheeky
\ge dangerous
\ge aggressive
\ge angry
\ge fierce
\ge wild
\ge savage
\re
\so EF, RS, EK, JD, GB
\xv Wurrarra bujimala kijibaji.
\xe The storm with wind and lightning is dangerous.
\rf RS2000-07b
\xv Duka-nanja nyulu marijbi, daraa kijibajii.
\xe The cheeky dog grabbed him by the throat.
\rf RS22005-01
\xv Kuna-najba ngawu nana burrurrin, kijibaji kuwada-yaan.
\xe I kept an eye on that man who was aggressive and making trouble. 
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Budangku nyulu bijbi ngambalanya miyaa kijibajii
\sfx budangku nyulu biijbi ngambalanya miyaa kijibaji.aif
\xe The dangerous snake can't bite us.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Yurru-kadi nyulu kala-wunyi barrawunu lungkajii kijibajii.
\xe The cheeky policeman took him from his place and put him into a jail cell.
\rf RS
\xv Kijibaji biraki.
\xe Cheeky ant.
\rf rs2005-06
\xv Duka yalu ngaan bijbi daraa kijibajii.
\xe Wild dogs might grab me by the throat.
\rf RS2004-untaped
\xv Wandajba nyulu wanamin. Kanungku barri langini, wanami, kijibaji.
\xe The clouds are moving around. They are coming from the north, those menacing storm clouds.
\rf RS2002-05
\xv Kalijbi nyulu ngaan, nguyarri, nukami, kanbaa kijibajii.
\xe The spinifex grass stabbed me in the foot, (that) grass that can hurt.
\rf RS
\xv Jambaa nurriyanya rajba nukami, kijibajii nangkani duruu.

\pc
\sd body

\ge swallow
\re
\so RS, MB_LH87
\xv Kirijbi nyulu.
\xe He swallowed it.
\rf RS2005-08b
\xv Budangku nurri kirijbi nana barrulki. Janybijbi nurri janyii.
\xe We can't swallow that fat. We spit it out.
\xv Kirijbi nyulu dukaa, nana walijin.
\xe He's swallowing that meat down his throat.
\rf RS2004-05
\xv Maman nyulu kirijbi.
\xe He swallowed the food.
\rf RS
\va kurijbi (GB)
\cf yurru-kadi
\nt Warlpiri {kiri} 'raspy throat', 'fluting'
\cp
\nq

\lx kirribirri

\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd ceremony
\lt Xerg hits Y (two boomerangs) together
\ge clap
\ge rattle
\re
\so RS
\xv Kirribirri nyulu jukulin. Wangkijbi yalu burrurri-darra.
\xe He’s clapping the boomerangs. The men are performing a corroborree.
\rf RS2000-05
\xv Waku nyulu kirribirri jukuli, waku.
\xe He's clapping the boomerangs together rapidly, fast.
\rf RS2000-05
\va dirribili
\sy 
\cf mindikirri
\nt Refers to how men use a pair of boomerangs or clapsticks as percussion instruments.
\cp

\lx kirriya

\sf kirriya-woman.wav
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd people
\lt
\ge woman
\ge girl
\ge female
\re woman
\so EF, RS, EK, GB, JD93, SC_BB, MF_SK, AP+AF_PS, JP_TT, CO
\xv Kirriya nayi jilaba ngambalangi, mama-anyi.
\sfx kirriyanayi jilaba ngambalangi mama-anyi.wav
\xe This woman is coming to us to (get) food.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Wawurra yalu bikali ngabana, kirriyaa, banga burrurrii, bulungu bulangi.
\xe Women and men, they carried children on their shoulders, their children.
\rf RS2005-05
\xv Daba nyulu ngaan nangkani kirriyaa. Kundaa nyulu ngaan daba, janki.
\xe This woman hit me. She hit me with a stick on the back of the neck.
\rf RS2005-06
\xv Yakujbu ngawu nayi kijibaji kirriya. Jila-kanyi ngawu raji-wurru.
\xe I left this women who was looking to fight me. I had to go home.
\rf RS2005-06
\xv Kirriya-darraa, mularrijbi yalu. Yurru-kadi yalu, narrungujana. 
\xe The women, they lifted him up. They put him into the car.
\rf RS2005-08a
\xv Mindikirri yalu, kirriya-darra.
\xe The women are dancing.
\rf RS2004-03
\xv Ngawu, kirriya ngawu. Jarrba ngawu warnu, bunija. Julwu-yudu.
\xe As for me, I'm a woman. I chew tobacco, mixed with ash.
\rf RS2002-02
\xv Ngaba nyulu ngaki, Waanyii kirriyaa wurrumbarraa.
\xe This young Waanyi girl bought it to me.
\rf RS2002-03
\xv Kirriyadu burrurri.
\sfx
\xe Married man.
\rf MF_SK
\xv Burrurri-yudu nana.
\sfx
\xe That (woman) is married.
\rf MF_SK
\xv Kirriyana nyulu jila.
\xe He's going with the woman.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Nana burrurri jungku kirriya-darrana.
\xe That man is sitting among the women.
\rf IS_GB
\va
\sy jinbajinba [GB]
\cf kudanngirri
\cf ngila
\cf wadukarra
\cf waduwarra
\cf wurrumbarra
\nt
\cp Wambaya

\lx kiya
\mr kiya
\hm 1
\sf
\sn 1
\ps particle
\pc
\sd modal
\lt expresses unrealized possibility either in past or present
\ge might
\ge should
\ge would
\ge if
\ge mightbe
\ge perhaps
\re
\so EF, RS, CO, GB
\xv Ngaba-kiya ninji, wanu nganyi, bulinja-anyi.
\xe You should have brought it, your tobacco, to smoke.
\rf RS2004-04
\xv Ngandu-kiya yalu mudurarrijbi, ngandun.
\xe They should erect a shelter, a shelter.
\rf RS2004-05
\xv Ngaba-kiya yalu marraja yalungi.
\xe They should have brought their swags.
\rf RS2004-08a
\xv Kularra-kiya nyulu jilaba Kayawana-wurru. Burrbijbi nyulu kuujini barri wululuku-anyi yanyi-yudu.
\xe He should have gone south to Kiana, driven to then look for the old man to give him the message.
\rf RS2003-12-01
\xv Windijbi-kiya ngawu ninya, namirraa, budangku ngawu, namirra-anyi.
\xe I would give you money but I haven't got any money.
\rf RS2003-03
\xv Rangkijbi-kiya nyulu ngaan.
\xe He would have shot me.
\rf RS2002-07
\xv Bungkana-kiya ninji jila.
\xe You could have gone yesterday.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Mudunama-kiya ninji jila.
\xe You might go tomorrow.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Jila-kiya nyulu.
\xe He might have gone.
\rf GB(W-G vocab)
\xv Jarrba-kiya ngawiji, ngala nyuluji ngabaa nayi.
\xe I was about to eat it when he carried it off.
\rf MF_GB76
\xv Barriyi-kiya ninji jilaba waliji-anyi, windijbi-kiya ngawu ninya balikaajkurru.
\sfx
\xe If you'd come for some meat last night, I would have given you (some) as you were hungry.
\rf EF_R299EA3
\xv Kiya ngawu ninya windijbi waliji-i, balikaajkurru.
\sfx
\xe I would have given you meat, as you were hungry.
\rf EF_R299EA3
\xv Najba-kiya ninji ngaki dawirrinyi.
\sfx
\xe You would have seen my younger sister.
\rf GB_grammarch6
\xv Budangku ngawu-kiya bilyikija-anyi.
\sfx
\xe I never swim. (I can't swim.)
\rf GB_grammarch6
\xv Ngurrubu ngawu-kiya ninya, ngala ngawiji kudujbu.
\sfx
\xe I was going to tell you but I forgot.
\rf GB_IS
\xv Wayi-kiya nimba windijbi ngaan mama-anyi?
\xe Can't you two give me some food?
\rf RS2004-04
\xv Wayi-kiya ninji jawikajba ngaliyanya mama-anyi.
\xe Shouldn't you have asked us for food.
\rf RS2004-04
\xv Ngamuyu-kiya ninji jungku nawunu. Budangku. Budangkun. Jungku ninji jujuu kularra.
\xe It was thought you would be here, but no. You were not. You were far away down south.
\rf RS2003-12-01
\xv Ngamuyu-kiya ngawu jilaba nanangkurru, nyulu-kiya bijbi ngaan.
\xe If I were to go there, it would bite me.
\rf RS2000-10
\xv Ngamuyu-kiya nyulu bijbi nayi burrurrin, miyaa. 
\xe I thought that the snake had bitten this man.
\rf RS2003-03
\va
\sy
\cf jala-kiya
\cf mayi
\cf ngamuyu
\cf wayi
\cf -waya
\nt Modal particle usually post-posed to clause-initial phrase, but also recorded clause initial.
\nt Note use of <kiya> encliticised to interrogative particle <wayi> and counterfactual particle <ngamuyu>.
\cp
\nq MF+EM_CO glosses as 'perhaps' in some example sentences.
\dt 02/Oct/2006

\lx kudamba
\mr kuda-mba
\sf kudamba.wav
\ps verb
\pc
\sd contact (impact and violence)
\lt Xerg do something to Y to cause Y to die, or be in bad state
\ge kill
\ge injure
\re kill
\re injure
\so EF, GB
\xv Kudamba nanangkani miyaa bijbi.
\xe That snake might bite and kill (it).
\rf IS_GB
\xv Daba kudamba.
\sfx
\xe Hit and kill.
\rf EF_R299B3
\va kudaamba
\sy
\cf janybijbi
\cf
\nt The usual way of expressing 'kill' is to use a verb referring to the manner of killing combined with {kudanba} 'dead'.
\cp
\nq
\dt
\lf kudajba
\lf kudanba

\lx kudanba
\mr kuda-n-ba
\sf kudanba.wav
\sf kudanba-dead-02.aif
\sf kudanba-dead.aif
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd resultant state
\lt X be dead
\ge die
\ge dead
\ge injure
\re kill
\re injure
\so GB, EF, RS
\xv Kudanba ngaki daran barri.
\sfx kudan-ngaki-daran-barri.wav
\xe My dog is now dead.
\rf EF
\xv Ngaki dara kudanbarri.
\sfx ngaki-dara-kudan-barri.wav
\xe My dog has now died.
\rf EF
\xv Burra-daba nyulu, daraa barri bijbi nana wadaba kudanba.
\xe He knocked it down, (and) then the dog bit that goanna (and) killed it.
\rf RS
\xv Bijbi nyulu, kudanba.
\sfx biijbi nyulu kudanba-it bites and kills.aif
\xe He bit it to death.
\rf RS2005-01
\xv Kudanba ngawu rangkijbi, burra-daba.
\sfx kudanba ngawu rangkijbi burradaba.wav
\xe I strike him dead, knock him down.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Mayi yalu ngambalanya daba kudanba kundaa, kalijbi mukuraa.
\xe They might kill us by hitting us with a stick and, or by spearing us.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Kudanba nyulu bijbi ngambalanya, miyaa kijibajii.
\xe The deadly snake, it can bite us and kill us.
\rf RS2004-05
\xv Jarrkanyi nangka kudanba, warrakujini.
\xe He tried to kill himself being deranged.
\rf RS2005-08a
\xv Kudanba nangka wululukuu. 
\xe The old man has died.
\rf RS2004-01
\xv Janybijbi nangka, kudanba nangka, nangkani wululukuu.
\xe He 'threw himself away', he died, this old man.
\rf RS2004-01
\va 
\sy
\cf janybijbi
\cf janyba
\an wanka
\nt Used with the reflexive pronoun, {kudanba} functions like detransitived verb. 
\nt 
\cp Garrwa {kudanba} 'die', 'half dead'
\nq
\dt 03/Sep/2006
\lf kudajba

\lx Kudanji
\mr kudanji
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd PEOPLE
\sd language
\lt name of language and people whose traditional land is along MacArthur River south west of Borroloola.
\ge Kurdanji
\re Kurdanji
\so RS2004-05

\lx kudarrijbi
\mr kurdarri-j-bi [kurdadi-j-bi]
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd state
\lt X be without producing sound
\ge be quiet
\ge be silent
\re
\so GB, RS, EK
\xv
\xe
\rf
\xv Kudarrijbi barri nyulu nayi wululuku, kudarrijbi, mankunu.
\sfx
\xe This old man is now silent. He is quietly listening.
\rf RS2005-02
\xv Karrinja nyulu kudarrijbi.
\xe He's standing in silence.
\rf RS2005-02
\xv Jungku ninji kudarrijbi bulinjana. 
\xe You're sitting down quietly smoking.
\rf RS2004-03
\xv Kudarrijbi nyulu jungku, jarrjini walijini, mamana.
\xe He sat quietly eating meat and vegetables.
\rf RS2004-05
\xv Jungku nyulu kudarrijbi, juraana ngambalangi.
\sfx jungku nyulu kudarrijbi juraana ngambalangi.wav
\xe He's sitting quietly feeling sorry for us.
\rf RS2004-05
\xv Jungku nyulu kudarrijbi barri. Budangku nyulu yanjini.
\sfx jungku nyulu kudarrijbi=barri #budangku nyulu yanjini.wav
\xe He's sitting quietly now. He's not talking.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Mankuu nyulu niyanya. Kudarrijbi nyulu jungku. Yanyba nungka, kudarrijbi=nyulu. 
\xe He is listening to us. He's sitting in silence. You and I are talking, (but) he is silent. 
\rf RS
\xv Kankulunu ngamba jungku, ngala nyulu jungku ngambalangi kudarrijbi, kudarrijini.
\xe We are sitting having a feed while he is sitting not talking to us, being quiet.
\rf RS2004-04
\xv Jungku ninji ngayini. Kudarri!
\xe You stay at your place. Be quiet!
\rf EK (ML notes)
\va kudadi
\sy
\cf
\nt
\cp
\nq GB has kudadi 'quiet' and I recorded kurdadi on one occasion from RS
\dt 01/Oct/2006

\lx kudiijbi

\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd motion
\lt be extended horizontal to supporting surface
\ge lie down
\ge lie
\re

\sfx kudijbi nyulu.wav
\xe He was lying down.
\rf RS2005-04

\sfx kudijbi-ngawu-jalanya-rajini_CO.wav
\xe I'll have a lie-down back home directly.
\rf OSBORNE_C02-000165B.TMP
\xv Kudiijbi nyulu nana nangulbuwarra.
\xe That wallaroo was lying down.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Jamurawa, jungku nyulu wanamini. Wakalinyi. Kudiijbi nyulu jarrjini kakunu. \xe The water goanna, it lives down in the water. It lies (there) eating fish.
\rf RS2005-05
\xv Kudiijbi nyulu ngunyi.
\xe He's lying asleep.
\rf RS2005-08a
\xv Kudiijbi ngawu ngunyi, najba ngawu buwarajini. 
\xe I was lying asleep, I was dreaming.
\rf RS2004-01
\xv Kudijbi nyulu kanbana, bungkina.
\xe The little wallaby is lying down in the grass.
\rf RS2004-04
\xv Kudiijbi nyulu nana ramin kuna-najini.
\xe He's lying there awake watching.
\rf GB
\xv Ninji ramin kudiijbi?
\xe Are you lying awake?
\rf GB
\xv Jilaba ngamba kudiyi.
\sfx jilaba-ngamba-kudiyi_CO.wav
\xe Let's go and lie down.
\rf OSBORNE_C02-000165B.TMP
\xv Kudiijkanyi barri ngawu.
\xe I'll have a sleep now.
\rf GB

\sy bujubu
\cf ngunyijbi
\cf
\nt
\cp
\nq Maybe leave as kudijbi
\dt 26/Sep/2006
\lf kudiijkanyi
\lf kudiyi

\sn 2
\ps verb
\pc
\sd body
\lt X sleep
\ge sleep
\ge be asleep
\ge lie sleeping
\re
\so GB, RS, JD
\xv Nana wawurra, kudiijbi barri nyulu, kadimirra juka.
\xe That child, that little boy has now gone to sleep.
\rf RS2005-06
\xv Kalijbi nyulu nana kudijkurru.
\sfx kalijbi nyulu nana kudij-kurru.wav
\xe He speared it as it lay sleeping.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Kudijbi yalu jambana.
\xe They used to sleep on the ground
\rf RS2005-08a
\xv Jakajba ngawu kaburrukaja, kudijbi nyulu.
\xe I chased the crocodile away, it was sleeping.
\rf RS2005-02
\xv Budangku nyulu kudijbi, ngunyi-ngunyijbi, jalwa rami.
\xe He can't sleep, he's wide awake.
\rf RS2005-02
\xv Kudiyi nyuluwa.
\xe Let him sleep.
\rf GB
\xv Jijajba nana kudiijbi.
\sfx
\xe He's pretending to be asleep.
\rf GB
\xv Kudijkanyi barri ngawu.
\xe I'll go and have a sleep now.
\rf GB
\xv Kudiijbi nyulu yunngumbu.
\xe He sleeps all day.
\rf GB
\xv Budangku nyulu kudijkanyi.
\xe He didn't sleep.
\rf GB
\xv Kudijkanyi wara ngawu.
\xe I'll have a sleep first.
\rf GB
\va
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt

\sn 3

\ge sleep over

\xe "When will you come back here?" "I'll spend a few nights away."
\rf RS2004-08a
\xv Kudiijbi ngawu nanawaana burrurri-darrana, yanjini. Murrku-darrana, kudiijbi ngawu.
\xe I'll stay talking with those people. I'll be away for several days.
\rf RS2004-08a
\xv Kujarra ngunyin ngawu jila kudijini.
\xe I'm going away for two days (lit. sleeps).
\rf GB
\sy

\nt

\lt heart
\ge heart
\re
\so EF, GB, RS, EK, EF, JD93, AP+AF_PS, JP_TT
\xv Kudulu nyulu kalijbi.
\xe He speared it in the heart.
\rf GB
\xv Barimbi nyulu ninya kudulu.
\xe It damages your heart.
\rf rs2004-04
\va
\sy
\cf
\nt 
\cp Yinjilanji {kurdulu} 'heart'; Wambaya {kurdurlu}
\nq Also transcribed as {kuduru} JP_TT
\dt


\lx kudululujbu

\ge gut

\xe We gut fish with a knife.

\lx kudulumbu
\mr kudulu-mbu
\hm
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd 
\lt 
\ge forget
\ge inadvertently leave behind
\ge forget to bring
\re
\so
\xv Jawikajba nurri ngarrawanyi. "Budangkun ngarrawanyi. Kudulumbu ngawu banja rajini."
\sfx
\xe We asked him for salt. "There is no salt. I forgot it (and left it) back  home."
\rf rs2002-10
\xv Budangku ninji kudulumbu, mama banga walijin.
\xe You didn't forget (and leave behind) the bread or the meat.
\rf rs2002-09
\xv Rajini ngawu kudulumbu wanu ngaki.
\sfx
\xe I forgot my tobacco back at the house.
\rf RS
\va
\sy kudujbu
\sy mamanumbu
\cf mudumbanyi
\an
\nt
\cp
\nq check spelling, also kurdurdumbu, kurdurrumbu

\xe He keeps holding on to it.

\xe It (the dog) kept holding the squirming (goanna) in its mouth.

\xe They keep on setting fire to that grass with a fire-stick.

\xe Two whitemen.
\rf RS2005-06
\xv Nanangkuya kadimirra, jawaji-nganja, ngakinkanyi kakulu-nganja jawaji-nganja nanangkujarra.

\xv Waanyi, Karrwa, kujarra yanyi.
\xe Waanyi and Karrwa are two languages.
\rf RS2005-03

\xe I'll come back in two month's time.
\rf RS2005-03
\xv Mudumbanyi bula nangkujarra, ngila-wuya, ngakinkanyi yanyi-anyi. Budangku bula mankuu.
\xe These two girls don't know my language. They don't understand it.

\xv Kajala-kurru ngamba kuku-najba wawurra-wiya, kujarra.
\xe We are looking at two children climbing, two (of them).

\rf RS

\sfx
\xe Two men are coming.
\rf MF_SK
\xv Kujarraa bulangka daba wawurra-wuyaa.
\sfx
\xe Two children are fighting.

\sfx
\xe Two dogs.

\cf nangkujarra

\ge peer at

\re look
\re watch

\xe We are leaving you to go and take a look.

\xe He's watching that man who is making a boomerang.
\rf RS2005-01

\xe I was sitting down watching him (and) he chased me away.
\rf RS2005-01

\xe The bird is peering at the water looking for fish.
\rf RS2005-02

\rf RS2004-03

\xe I kept an eye on this one here as I was hitting it.

\sfx
\xe You watch me.

\lx -kula
\mr -kula
\sf
\sn 1
\ps suffix
\pc
\sd kin
\lt dyadic suffix used on kin term to mark both sets of people related as indicated by kin term; the converse relation is included
\ge together
\re
\so RS
\xv Bawa-kula.
\xe Brothers (elder brother and his younger brothers and/or sisters)
\rf RS
\xv Kadirri-kula
\xe Maternal uncle and nephew/niece.
\rf RS
\xv Nayi bula jamaku-kula.
\sfx nayi_bula_jamaku_kula.wav
\xe These two here are cousins (to each other).
\rf RS-RG1999
\xv Mimi-kula nimba.
\xe You are maternal grandfather and grandson.
\rf RS2005-01
\xv Kannga bula maninyi. Budangkun kaku-anyi. Ngada-kula.
\xe They've come back empty handed. No fish. Mother and daughter.
\rf rs2005-03
\xv Nangkujarraa ngila-wuyaa, nijbi bulangka mimi-kula.
\xe These two girls, they call themselves cousins.
\rf rs2004-01
\va
\sy
\cf -nganja

\lx kulana
\mr kula-na
\sf kurlana.wav
\ps noun
\pc
\sd direction
\lt to the south of
\ge from the south
\re
\sd compass points
\so GB, RS, EK, JD93
\xv Kujarra nayi bula kulana.
\sfx kujarra_nayi_bula_kurlana.wav
\xe These two are on our south (side).
\rf RS-RG1999
\xv Kanungkumbu ninji, bangani, kulana. 
\sfx
\xe You approach here from the south.
\rf RS
\xv Kannga ngawu kulana, barulajba. Langkurri.
\xe I'm going back from the south, passing by here heading north.
\rf rs2002-04
\xv Kulana yalu yanngunyi Jirringirri-winyi. 
\xe Those travellers came from the south, from Jirringirri.
\rf GB
\xv Jilaba nyulu kulana, Nularrima kirriya, mundukana barri.
\xe (That) Nularrima woman is coming from the south, carrying (her swag) under her arm.
\rf RS
\xv Kannga ngawu nangkurru, jilaba nangkurru, kulana barri.
\xe I came back here, walked here, from the south.
\rf RS
\xv Wanami nayi kulana. Ngajirri-yudu.
\xe This rain from the south (has come) with cold weather.
\rf RS
\xv Karrinja yalu kalana kundan.
\sfx Karrinja_yalu_kalana_kundan-RS2002T09a.wav
\xe The trees are standing to the south (of us). 
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf
\nt
\cp
\nq

\ge south

\re

\xv Ngamuyu-kiya ninji jungku nawunu. Budangku. Budangkun. Jungku ninji jujuu kularra.
\xe It was thought you would be here, but no. You were not. You were far away down south.
\rf RS2003-12-01
\xv Naniwii ngamba jilaba kularra kala-wurru. Waanyi-anyi burrurri-anyi.
\xe We went off to the south to our country. It belongs to the Waanyi people.
\rf RS2005-06
\xv Kularra-kiya nyulu jilaba Kayawana-wurru.
\xe He should have gone south to Kiana Station.
\rf RS2003-12-01
\xv Kannga ngawu langini, kularra.
\xe I returned from the north, to the south.
\rf RS
\xv Burrbijbi ngamba kularra, narrunguja-yudu barri.
\xe We will drive down south with the car then.
\rf rs2005-05

\xe

\rf RS2005-04

\xe I'm spying on them fishing.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Kaku nyulu wilijirri nangkani burrurrii. Wilijirri-wurru, kuna-najba ngawu. 
\xe That man is pulling in a fish. I'm spying on him pulling it in. 
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Kuna-najba ninji ngaan.
\xe You're spying on me.
\rf RS2005-05
\xv Kuna-najba ngawu nana burrurrin, kijibaji kuwada-yaan.
\xe I kept an eye on that man who was aggressive and making trouble. 
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Kudijbi nyulu nana, ramin, kuna-najini.
\xe He's lying there awake watching.
\rf GB
\va
\sy
\cf 
\nt
\cp
\nq

\lx kunda
\mr kurnda
\sf kurnda.wav
\sf kurnda02.wav
\ps noun
\pc
\sd plant related
\lt wooded plant and woody part of plant
\ge tree
\ge stick
\ge wood
\ge log
\re
\so EF, RS, GB, EK, JD, MS_SK, RC+MF_SK
\xv Bajalijbi nurri nayi yilaka. Kunyba nayi kundan nangkanyi ngalya-anyi.
\xe We sniff these leaves. This tree is good for this sickness.
\rf RS
\xv Langanba nyulu kundana wajka-kulaji wululuku balarrka.
\xe The big flying fox hangs head down in the tree.
\rf rs2003-03
\xv Jaluki ngawu balawajba kundaa, manii. 
\xe I get hold of the intestines by hooking them with a stick, by hand. 
\rf RS
\xv Jungku nyulu banjana kundana, kuku-najini ngambalyanya.
\sfx
\xe He is sitting behind the tree observing us.
\rf rs11
\xv Barimbi ninji. Rangkijbi ninji kundaa.
\xe You missed it. Pelt it with a stick!
\rf rs2005-06
\xv Dadarrba ngawu. Mundirri ngawu bariyijbi, nayi mularrijbi kundan.
\xe I'm in pain. I hurt my back (when) I lifted this log.
\rf GB
\xv Bungkana ngawu kawa-najba, dirrbu, kundana.
\xe Yesterday I found some sugarbag, in a tree.
\rf RS
\xv Kajalaba ninji kundana. 
\xe You climb up the tree. 
\rf rs2000-09
\xv Dajkanyi nyulu kundaa, burra-daba.
\xe He's got to hit it with a stick and knock it down.
\rf RS 2005-01
\xv Nanganja ngawu kunda, dajkanyi ngawu nan dara.
\xe I'm getting a stick so I can hit this dog.
\rf GB
\xv Dakalijbi nyulu kunda-wunyi jambana wajka. 
\xe He quickly got down from the tree onto the ground.
\rf RS2005-02
\xv Mama nan diba-diba kunda-nanja. Yirrbinkijbi kunda-wunyi, langankini, jamba-wurru.
\xe This fruit was struck down from the tree. It fell from the tree (from) where it was hanging, to the ground.
\rf GB
\xv Dingurunguru ngawu kunda nayi. Marijbi barri ngawu.
\xe I gouge out a hole in the wood (describing making shield handle), and then I take hold of it.
\rf RS2000-05
\xv Mudamudajibi yalu jibana. Windijbi nyulu nanangkanyi kunda-anyi, diwurrurru-anyi. 
\xe They wrapped (it) in paperbark. He gave (him) that piece of wood, that message stick to him. 
\rf RS2005-03
\xv Kurrijbi ngamba, kajalaa, kundaa. 
\xe We are digging with our wooden digging sticks.
\rf RS
\xv Karrinja yalu kalana, kundan.
\xe The trees stand (=grow) along the creek.
\rf RS
\xv Ningkijbi nyulu kingkarri kunda-wurru.
\xe He looks upwards into the tree.
\rf RS2005-01
\xv Kunda nyulu lanjarrba.
\xe He split the log in two.
\rf GB, RS
\xv Kundaa, daba ngawu. Kundaa ngawu daba.
\sfx
\xe With a stick I'll belt him. I'll belt him with a stick.
\rf IS_GB
\xv Mayi ninji burrurru kunda-wunyi.
\sfx
\xe You might fall out of the tree.
\rf RS2000-09
\va
\sy
\cf barrku
\cf dalu
\cf diwurrurru
\cf jangu
\cf kajala
\cf kudakuda
\cf marraki ~ maraki ??
\cf ngandu
\nt Note that firewood is {jangu} and not {kunda}
\cp
\nq 
\dt 21/Sep/2006
\lf kundaa
\lf kunda-anyi
\lf kundana
\lf kunda-nanja
\lf kunda-wunyi
\lf kunda-wurru

\sn 2
\ps noun
\pc

\re native honey ^bee

\xe I am looking up in this tree to see if there's any honey. There are no bees.

\xv Dirrbu ngawu kawa-najba. Kawa-najba ngawu, kunuma. Baba-wurru. Rami ngawu najba.
\xe I've found a bee hive. I've found the forager bees flying around. I can see the hole (entrance to nest inside tree trunk).
\rf RS2003-02
\xv Ngungkurru nyulu kunuma. Manku ngawu, kuwadaa. Ngungkurru nyulu dirrbu.
\xe The bees are humming. I can hear them with my ear. The honey bees in the hive are humming.
\rf RS2003-02
\xv Budangku kunuma-anyi.
\xe There are no bees.
\rf rs2003-01
\va kunumu

\cf dirrbu

\sd motion

\ge scratch
\ge scrape
\ge dig
\re
\so RS, EF, GB, EK, JD93, CO
\xv Kurrijbi jamba.
\sfx kurrijbi_jamba-dig_earth-R299b2.wav
\xe Dig the ground.
\rf EF_R299b2
\xv Kuujbu ngawu kunda-anyi, kurrijkanyi ngaka mundirri.
\xe I'm looking for a stick so I can scratch my back.
\rf RS
\xv Kurrijbi ngaka. 
\xe I scratched myself.
\rf rs2003-05; JD93; EF_299A7
\xv Kurrijbi nyulu maniin jamba waliji-anyi biraki-anyi. Kuujbu nyulu biraki-anyi. Jarrba nyulu.
\xe It (echidna) digs the earth with its front legs (=hands) to find ants to eat. 
\rf rs2003-01
\xv Kurrijbi ngawu, nayi janja, wanami-yudu. Kurrijbi ngawu wanami-anyi nayi janja.
\xe I'll dig this wet earth, where there's moisture, I'll dig this soakage to find water.
\rf RS
\xv Kurrijbi nurriyangka.
\xe We scratch ourselves.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Kurringa!
\xe Scratch!
\rf MF+EM_CO
\va
\sy
\cf
\nt
\cp Ngarinyman {kurrij}
\nq

\lx kurrkamala
\mr kurrkamala
\sf kurrkamala-many.wav
\sf kurrkamala.wav
\ps noun
\pc lots.jpg
\sd quantity
\lt large quantity of
\ge many
\ge much
\ge a lot
\ge lots
\ge mob
\re
\so RS, GB, JD93, LP_SK
\xv Jungku ngamba nayi kurrkamala.
\sfx jungku_ngamba_nayi_kurrka.wav
\xe We are sitting here, a big mob of us.
\rf RS-RG1999
\xv Kurrkumala nyulu mirramba, wululukuu.
\sfx kurrkamala nyulu mirramba wululuku-u.wav
\xe He makes a lot (of things), that old man.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Kurrkamala yalu bulanja, nana-waan burrurri-darra.
\sfx
\xe There's a big mob of men whistling there.
\rf RS2005-01
\xv Jungku yalu kurrkamala, kalawunyi barri julakini barri muwana.
\xe There were a lot of people sitting inside the 'belly' of the aeroplane.
\rf RS
\xv Mayi yalu daba ngaan kudanba. Kalijbi, kajaa, kurrkamalaa burrurrii.
\xe They might kill me, spear me, that big mob of men.
\rf RS
\xv Barijbi nayi yubal. Karalbanja nyulu nayi. Kurrkamala-yudu nayi karalbanja.
\xe This road is bad. It's a rocky surface. This stony ridge has a lot of small stones.
\rf RS
\xv Kurrkamalaa karaa nyulu ngaan windijbi.
\xe He gave me a lot of money.
\rf RS
\xv Windikanyi ninya, manijaa, yanyi-yanyi kurrkamala-anyi.
\xe (I've) got to give you a lot more language next time.
\rf RS
\xv Marijkanyi nurri nana-waan kurrkamala wadungiji-darra.
\xe We've got to grab that mob of preinitiates.
\rf RS
\xv Nana wululuku, mirramba nyulu kurrkamala.
\sfx 
\xe That old man, he makes lots (of things).
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Yandujbu ngawu yanyi kurrkamala, nganyi.
\xe I've got many words of your language.
\rf RS
\xv Kanngu yalu kaku-yudu kurrkamala-yudu.
\xe They go back with a big lot of fish.
\rf RS
\xv Kudanba yalu kurrkamala barri, walijin, nangurrbuwala, yubalina.
\xe There are lots of dead animals including big kangaroos on the road.
\rf RS
\xv Ngabaa nurri, kurrkamala ngila-darra, ngila-ngila.
\xe We brought a big mob of young girls, young ladies.
\rf RS
\xv Kawa-najba yalungka, kurrkamalaa.
\xe They all meet up.
\rf RS
\xv Nanganja yalu kurrkamala kakun.
\sfx nanganja_yalu_kurrkamala_kakun-RS2002T09a.wav
\xe They have got a lot of fish.
\rf RS

\sy kurrkilinya
\cf kaja
\cf murrku

\lf

\lx -kurru
\mr -kurru
\sf
\sn 1
\ps suffix
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt allative suffix
\ge into
\ge to
\ge towards
\re 
\so RS
\xv Winja-kurru ninji jilaba, wululuku?
\xe Which way are you going, old man?
\rf rs
\xv Budangku nyulu niyanya ngurrubu, winja-kurru nyulu jilaba. 
\xe He doesn't tell us where he's going.
\rf RS2003-02
\xv Kawa nangkurru!
\xe Come here!
\rf RS
\xv Bayinga ngawu kannga, ngakinkurru kala-wurru.
\xe I'm heading back west to my place.
\rf RS
\va -burru
\va -wurru
\va -yurru
\sy
\cf
\nt {-kurru} is added to nouns ending in consonant, and to many verbs ending in either a vowel or a consonant.
\nt Demonstratives {na} 'this, here' and {nana} 'that, there' have a special allative form {-ngkurru}.
\nt In rapid speech this suffix is often reduced to {-rru} following a vowel.
\nt Allative suffix is added to verbs to signal that the understood Subject of that verb refers to the same entity as the Object of the main verb in the same sentence.
\cp
\nq
\dt 03/Sep/2006

\sn 2
\ps suffix
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt suffixed to predicate that is concurrent with main predicate such that referent of Object of main predicate is coreferent with implicit referent of subject of predicate to which {-kurru} is suffixed.
\ge while
\re 
\so EF, RS, GB
\xv Lajibi nyulu ninya Waanyi-wurru yanykurru.
\xe He's listening to you talking Waanyi.
\rf RS
\xv Ngajangaja-wurru burrbijkurru ngawu najba.
\xe I saw (him) running away fast.
\rf RS
\xv Kuku-najba nungka nayi wululuku, dabarra-kurru. Dabarraba nyulu nanyalu ngambalangi.
\xe We are watching this old man cooking. He is cooking tea for us.
\rf RS
\xv Bajalijbi nyulu warrki jila-kurru.
\xe He smells a dingo coming.
\rf RS
\xv Najba nyulu yalunya mularri-kurru.
\xe He saw them lifting (it) up.
\rf RS
\xv Kuku-najba ngamba yalunya kajala-kurru.
\xe We are watching them climb.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku ngawiji na jawikajanyi ngakinkurru raji-wurru jila-kurru.
\sfx
\xe I didn't ask him to come to my place.
\rf GB
\xv Barriyi-kiya ninji jilaba waliji-anyi, windijbi-kiya ngawu ninya balikaajkurru.
\sfx
\xe If you'd come for some meat last night, I would have given you (some) as you were hungry.
\rf EF_R299EA3
\va -wurru
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt

\sd spatial
\sd direction
\lt
\ge away
\ge along
\re
\so RS, GB

\sfx kuunii-jilanyji.wav
\xe Go away!
\rf RS2005-01
\xv Jakajba nyulu ngaan. "Kuuni jilanji! Kuuni jilanji ninji!"
\xe He hunted me away. "Go away! You go away!"
\rf RS
\xv Kuuni ninji jilanji kuuni! Mayi ninya rajba janguu, nukamin.
\xe You move away, away! The fire might burn your feet.
\rf RS
\va kuwini
\xv
\xe
\rf
\va
\sy

\xe The bees are humming. I can hear them, with my ears.

\xe I can hear you coughing, listening with (my) ears.
\rf RS2005-02
\xv Ngungkurru nyulu ngaki kuwadana.
\xe It (mosquito) buzzes in my ears.
\rf RS

\xe I'm listening to you talking with (my) ears.
\rf RS

\xv Rajini ngawu kudurrumbu, warrakuu kuwadaa.
\sfx
\xe I forgot my tobacco back at the house mindlessly.
\rf RS
\xv Bariyimbi ninya kuwada, kajaa barri, wawurraa.
\xe That mob of kids made you forget it (lit. spoilt your 'ear')
\rf RS
\xv Buduramba nangka warrkulii, yarrbanjii, kuwadaajini, warrakujini, ngarakini kamukamunu, kuwada-yaan.
\xe He strangled himself with a rope, the young man who lost his reason, who was crazy, who was drinking grog and lost his mind.
\rf rs2005-08b
\va
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt
\lf kuwadaa
\lf kuwadaajini
\lf kuwadana
\lf kuwada-yaa


\lx kuwada-yaa
\mr kuwada-yaa
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd body
\lt ear-without
\ge deaf
\ge senseless
\ge out of one's mind
\ge silly
\ge foolish
\ge mindless
\ge crazy
\re
\so RS
\xv Kijibaji kuwada-yaa.
\sfx kijibaji kuwada-yaa.aif
\xe Angry out of his mind.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Daba yaluwangka kundaa, wawurra-darraa, kuwada-yani.
\xe Those silly kids are hitting each other with sticks.
\rf RS
\xv Kalijbi nyulu kudumanjaa, kuwada-yani burrurrii, winyakii, nyubanyubanyii.
\sfx
\xe That crazy man, wild bush man, kept on spearing him, all on his own.
\rf RS
\va kuwada-yaan
\sy kuwada-maku [EK]
\cf
\nt Lit. ear-without
\nt Ergative form is {kuwada-yani}.

\dt 29/Sep/2006


\lx kuwada-yaan
\mr kuwada-yaa=n
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd body
\lt ear-without
\ge deaf
\ge senseless
\ge out of one's mind
\ge ignorant
\re
\so RS
\xv Mudumbanyi yalu, kuwada-yaan, larrwa-anyi. Budangku yalu mirramba. Budangku yalu kunymamba. 
\xe They don't know about those long pipes (aggressive style). They can't make them, they don't make them.
\rf RS2005-01
\xv Damarrijbi barri yalu janjana wanami-wurru ngila-darra, kuwada-yaan.
\xe The silly girls are slipping in the mud down into the water.
\rf RS2002-07
\xv Kudumanja nyulu, jadiyadi-yimbi daba, wawurra kuwada-yaan.
\xe He kept on severely hitting that senseless child.
\rf RS
\xv Windijbi yalu ngaan kijii, kuwada-yaani.
\xe They give me cheek those senseless ones.
\rf RS2003-01
\xv Jungku ngamba kuwada-yaan.
\xe We don't know anything (about this place).
\rf RS
\xv Damarrijbi barri yalu janjana wanami-wurru ngila-darra, kuwada-yaan.
\xe The silly girls are slipping in the mud down into the water.
\rf RS2002-07
\xv Jakakajba yalu nurriyanya kijibajii. Kuwada-yaan.
\xe Those angry people are swearing at us. (They've got) no sense.
\rf RS
\va kuwada-yaa
\sy kuwada-maku
\cf
\nt Lit. 'ear-without'
\nt The final 'n' on -yaan might be the enclitic {-n}.
\cp
\nq

\lx kuyalkuyal
\mr kuyal-kuyal
\hm
\sv
\sf
\sn
\ps noun
\pc
\sd plant
\lt Cymbopogon bombycinus
\ge 
\re Wild Lemon Grass
\so JD93, GW
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\va
\sy
\cf KAKAKARRA
\an
\nt Grows alongs hills. It has a white head and red grass at the bottom of stalk. People use the red part of the grass. They boil the red part of the grass until the water turns yellow. Then they throw away the grass and use the yellow water to wash the skin when they have a cold or 'flu or are sick. The water cannot be drunk because it's poison.(Yurumbarinya 'Limmerick' to JD)
\nt Dymock (1993) records as "red medecine grass"
\cp
\nq

\lx kuyi
\mr kuyi
\sf kuyi.wav
\sf kuyi02.wav
\sf kuyi-head.wav
\sf kuyi02-head.wav
\ps noun
\pc
\sd body
\lt head
\ge head
\ge skull
\re
\so RS, GB, EK, EF, JD93, JP_TT
\xv Ja-ngawu jabarri daba kundaa, kuyi.
\xe I'll pay him back by hitting him on the head.
\rf RS
\xv Rajba naan duruu, kuyi. Budangku nyulu kulabajarra-anyi.
\xe The sun will burn his head. He doesn't have a hat.
\rf RS
\xv Dadarrba nungka kuyi madaja.
\xe Our heads are hurting.
\rf RS
\xv Marijbi yalungka kuyi kirriya-darraa, burrurri-darraa.
\xe The men and women are holding their heads.
\rf RS
\xv Bibi-yudu ngawu kuyi. Balungka-yudu ngawu kuyi.
\xe I have a sore head. My head is covered in blood.
\rf RS
\xv Kudamanja ngawu ngaraba. Barijbi ngawu kuyi. Daba ngaan kamukamuu.
\xe I kept on drinking. My head is bad (aching). The grog has 'hit' me.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku nyulu jalkarra kulajini, kuyini.
\xe He's not wearing anything on his head, on top.
\rf RS
\xv Kuyi-mandaja! Mayi ninji kula-warrijbi.
\xe (Your) poor head! You might have a headache.
\rf RS
\xv Birajba nyulu buka-yuduu kuyii.
\xe The grey-haired one is singing.
\rf RS
\xv Kuyi nyulu daba, dungalaa, nana wululuku.
\xe She hit that old man on the head.
\rf RS
\va kuwi
\sy kulaji
\sy kabarra
\cf nguli
\cf wali
\nt Dymock (1993) also records {KUN(G)KALILI} 'skeleton'
\cp
\nq

\lf lajikanyi

\ge listen to
\ge understand
\ge take notice of
\ge pay attention to
\ge recall
\ge remember
\re
\so RS, GB

\rf rs2004-05
\xv Budangku ninji lajibi niyangi jangkurr, Waanyi.
\xe You don't understand our language, Waanyi.
\rf RS
\xv Yanyba ngamba yalungi, kuwada-yaan. Ngurrubu ngamba yaluwanya, budangku yalu lajibi ngambalanya.
\xe We talk to them who take no notice (lit. earless). We tell them, (but) they don't listen to us.
\rf RS
\xv Lajikanyi ninji, jilakanyi ngamba.
\xe You have to recall (where) we have to go.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku ngawu lajibi ninya. Mudumbanyi ngawu.

\xe I can't understand you. I don't know it (your language).

\sy manku

\lx lalujbu
\mr lalu-j-bu
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd spatial
\lt X move up or out of some location
\ge get up
\ge get out
\ge rise
\ge exit
\ge come out
\ge go out of
\ge go up
\re rise
\re get ^up
\re emerge
\so RS, GB, JD, MF+EM_CO
\xv Bakamba nyulu, wadabaa, nangangini kuwii. Lalujbu nyulu, jilaba barri nyulu.
\xe The goanna busts through (from its burrow) using its head. It comes out and it walks around.
\rf rs2002-14
\xv Laluwi!
\xe Get up!
\rf GB
\xv Lalujbu ngamba kambana barri.
\xe We get up once there's sunlight.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku nyulu jilaba dindi. Warrawarra nyulu. Yirrbinkijbi nyulu. Lalujbu nyulu, burra-daba nangka.
\xe He couldn't walk straight. He was all over the place. He was staggering and falling about. He would get up and then fall down again.
\rf rs2002-13
\xv Lalujbu nyulu walajba, jamba-wunyi.
\xe It comes up and moves out from (under) the ground.
\rf RS
\xv Lalujkanyi ngamba.
\xe We must get up.
\rf RS
\xv Laluyu barri ninji, laluyu. Dururruru.
\xe Get up now, get up. The sun's coming up.
\rf RS
\xv Najba barri ngamba duru. Lalujbu ninji. Ja ngamba, jilaba.
\xe We can see the sun. You get up. We've got to go.
\rf RS
\xv Lalujbu nyulu karrinja.
\xe He stood up.
\rf RS
\xv Najba ngawu ninya lalujkurru.
\xe I saw you get up.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Laluyi!
\xe Get up!
\rf MF+EM_CO
\va laluwujbu [GB]
\sy
\cf 
\nt Recorded by Dymock (1993) as 'lively'
\nt Recorded by Dymock (1993) as 'rise up, rise into view' (e.g., of hills)
\cp
\nq 
\dt 19/Sep/2006

\lf laluujkanyi

\lx lambarra
\mr
\hm
\sv

\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc

\lx langanba
\mr langan-ba
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd spatial
\lt X be suspended from one end
\ge hang
\ge be suspended
\re hang
\so RS, GB
\xv Langanba nyulu kundana wajka-kulaji wululuku balarrka.
\xe The big flying fox hangs head down in the tree.
\rf rs2003-03
\xv Balangarra nan langanba.
\xe The (new) moon is hanging (in the sky).
\rf GB
\xv Mama nan dibadiba kunda-nanja. Yirrbinkijbi kunda-wunyi, langankini, jamba-wurru.
\xe The fruit was struck down from the tree. It fell from the tree where it was hanging, to the ground.
\rf GB
\xv Nayi nyulu kingkarri langanba, kundana.
\xe Here it is hanging high up in the tree.
\rf RS2005-08a
\xv Najba ngawu langan-kurru nana yimbira.
\xe I saw that flotsam hanging up (there).
\rf RS
\xv
\xe
\rf
\va
\sy
\cf babararra
\cf badbarrarra (GB)
\nt Dymock (1993) records {langan-karrinja} of crescent moon in sky
\cp Wambaya {langan-}
\nq check yidbinkijbi.
\dt 09/Oct/2006
\lf langan-daba

\lf langan-kurru

\lx langan-daba
\mr langan-da-ba
\hm
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd STANCE
\lt Xerg cause Y to be suspended above ground
\ge hang
\ge dangle
\ge suspend
\ge deposit on high
\ge put up high
\re hang up
\so RS, JD, MB_LH13
\xv Langan-daba ngamba, kundana,  bindawarra kaku-yudu, dara-mukunu.
\sfx
\xe We hang the bag with the fish up in the tree to keep it away from dogs. 
\rf RS
\xv Langan-daba yalu waliji, jukuli, wadaba, bikali barri yalu.
\xe They used to hang the animals (they had caught), boomerangs, goannas (in their waistbelt) and they then carried them (that way).
\rf rs2005-05
\xv Mudamudajibi nangka duka. Duka-nanja nangka langandaba.
\xe He tied (the rope) around his throat. He hanged himself by the neck.
\rf RS2005-08b
\xv Rirrajba nyulu, daraa. Kunda-wurru nyulu langan-daba.
\xe The dog chased it (goanna) and made it go up and hang in a tree.
\rf RS
\xv Ngaba-ngaba nungka! Nangkurru. Kingkarri barri nungka langan-daba!
\xe Let's carry it here. Then let's hang it up high.
\rf RS
\xv Yimbira nyulu langan-daba warnamii dumularraa.
\xe The flood waters have deposited the flotsam high up (e.g., suspended in the trees).
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt
\cp
\nq

\lf langanba



\lx langini
\mr lang-i-ni
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd SPATIAL
\sd compass points
\lt from north
\ge from north
\ge northerly
\re north
\so RS, GB
\xv Jilaba nurri langini, nangkurru, kularra.
\xe We came here from the north, to the south.
\rf RS
\xv Wandamba nangka wurrarraa, langini barri.
\xe The wind is changing direction and is now coming from the north.
\rf RS
\xv Wandajba nyulu wanamin. Kanungku barri langini, wanami, kijibaji.
\xe The clouds are moving around. They are coming from the north, those menacing storm clouds.
\rf RS2002-05
\xv Kannga ngawu langini, kularra.
\xe I returned from the north, to the south.
\rf RS
\xv Wanami nayi langini ngambalangi kanungku.
\xe This rain from the north is coming towards us.
\rf RS
\xv Jilaba ninyji langini ngaki.
\xe You've come from the north to (see) me.
\rf RS
\va langina [EK]
\sy
\cf
\nt Locative form meaning 'moving away from north' is stem for other forms
\cp
\nq
\dt 29/Oct/2006

\xe He'll take you north (and) leave you (there).
\rf RS
\xv Kara-wurru ngawu jila, langkurri.
\xe I went north to the hills.
\rf GB
\xv Langkurri nyulu burrbijbi wanamin, dumularra, malu-wurru barri.
\xe The water in the river flows northwards to the sea.
\rf RS
\xv Langkurri nyulu jilaba nana wululuku.
\xe That old man has gone north.
\rf RS
\xv Nanawaan kudaya-waan, jilaba yalu bayinga. Wandajba yalu bayinga. Kannga yalu langkurri.
\xe Those others are walking by on our western side. They are travelling to our west as they go back north.
\rf rs2005-08b
\xv Bidangku, langkurri nyulu burrbijbi, Mungkubayi-yurri. 
\xe The Gregory River, it runs north towards Burketown.
\rf rs2005-09
\xv Nambunyi ngamba jilaba nanangkurru langkurri.
\xe From here we are going north to that (place).
\rf RS
\xv Ngajangaja ngamba narrunguja-yudu. Langkurri barri. Kannga barri langkurri.
\xe We drove off quickly heading north. We went back north.
\rf RS
\va langku
\sy

\lx lungkarr
\mr lungkarr
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd perception
\lt strong taste
\ge bitter
\ge sharp taste
\ge sour
\ge strong tasting
\ge salty
\re
\so RS, GB, MD
\xv Wanamiin, kamukamuu, barimbi naan. Barimbi naan lungkarra.
\xe The beer, grog, it has ruined this (fellow). The strong (stuff) has wrecked him.
\rf rs2005-01
\xv Windijbi nyulu, ngalyaa, nanangkani mamaa. Lungkarraa. Darimaa. Budangku ngamba jarrba. Wingki nyulu. Duruu, rajba barri nana maman, darima. Nanganja ngamba. Jarrba barri ngamba, jangkaranyi.
\xe That bitter unripe plum makes (us) sick. We can't eat it when it’s raw. When the sun has ripened the plum fruit, we pick it and then we eat it, ripe. 
\rf RS2002-11
\xv Lungkarr nana wanu. Jalwa nana wanu, jalwa.
\xe That tobacco is very strong tasting. It's strong, that tobacco, strong.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv "Budangku ngawu jarrba, lungkarra." "Janybijbi! Mayi nyulu windijbi niyanya ngalyaa."
\xe "I can't eat this (because) it's too bitter." "Throw it away. It might make us sick."
\rf RS
\va lungka
\va lungkarra
\sy
\cf jalwa
\cf wingki
\nt
\cp Wambaua {lungkarra}
\nq
\dt 25/Oct/2006

\xv Makarraba nangka, wadabaa. Barrulkijini. Jambaa nangka makarraba, bambularraa, burrkaa.
\xe The goanna buries himself (under the ground) and gets fat. It uses its tail to cover itself with dirt. 
\rf rs2003-03
\xv Dandi-wajba yalu, nanganja yalu nayi malumalu. Jarrkanyi. Dandi-wajba yalu. Makarraba jambaa.
\sfx
\xe They put them on hot stones in an earth oven when they get these freshwater mussels they want to eat. They bake them on hot stones and cover them over with earth.
\rf RS2002-10
\xv Mirramba nurri, jangu. Nijbi nurri jangunu, makarraba jibaa, dandini. 
\xe We make a fire. We put it (meat to cook) in the hot (earth), cover it with paperbark, in the earth oven.
\rf RS2002-10
\xv Makarraba ngambalanya rami jundurri, jambaa, wulukuu, jila-kurru. 
\xe The dust covers our eyes, the big quantity of dirt, as we go along.
\rf rs2004-07
\xv Winjika ninji makarraba?
\xe Who are you burying?
\rf RS
\xv Makarraba barri nayi walijin jamba-yudu.
\xe They then cover over this animal with earth.
\rf EK (ML notes)
\xv Makarra nana waliji, wangkula-mukunu!
\xe Cover that meat, or the crows will get it.
\rf GB78
\xv Makarraji!
\xe Cover (it)!
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Kurrijbi jamba, makarraba.
\sfx
\xe Dig the ground, bury it.
\rf EF_R299B2
\va
\sy
\cf
\nt
\cp
\nq MF+EM_CO {makaraji}
\dt 26/Oct/2006

\ge white ochre
\re ochre (white)
\so RS, EK2008-07, JD93, MB_LH17
\xv Makirra, kurrijbi yalu kajalaa, manii. Bunyarrijbi yalu bindawarrana manii.
\xe The white ochre, they dig it out with their digging stick and by hand. They pile it into a bag by hand.
\rf rs2004-01
\xv Ngabaa yalu kunjul, makirra, madukuru.
\xe They take red ochre, white pipe clay and white feather down.

\xe That nest has no baby birds in it. And no eggs.

\xe I found this egg.
\rf GB

\xe I don't eat goanna eggs.
\rf GB

\lx mama
\mr mama
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd food
\lt vegetable food
\ge food
\ge fruit
\ge tucker
\ge vegetable
\ge flour
\re food
\so RS, EF, GB, EK, JD93, JP_TT, MF+EM_CO, MB_LH13
\xv Mama banga walijin, kanjijbi nyulu.
\xe The vegetables and meat, he's wasting them.
\rf rs2005-02
\xv Mama ngalingi ngabama!
\sfx mama_ngalingi_ngabama.wav
\xe Bring us food.
\rf RS-RG1999
\xv Mama-anyi.
\sfx mama-anyi.wav
\xe For food.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Budangku ngawu mama-anyi.
\xe I've got no food.
\rf RS
\xv Jilaba ngamba mama-anyi langkurri.
\xe Let's head north to look for (vegetable) food.
\rf RS
\xv Mama nyulu jarrba balikajini, bajanguu.
\xe The dog is hungrily eating the food.
\rf rs2005-06
\xv Windijbi nyulu ngalyaa, nanangkani mamaa. Lungkarraa. Darimaa. Budangku ngamba jarrba. Wingki nyulu. Duruu, rajba barri nana maman, darima. Nanganja ngamba. Jarrba barri ngamba, jangkaranyi.
\xe That bitter unripe plum makes (us) sick. We can't eat it when it’s raw. When the sun has ripened the plum fruit, we pick it and then we eat it, ripe. 
\rf RS2002-11
\xv Jarrkana ninji! Jarrkana nana maman, dawurrumbu ninji.
\xe Don't you eat (it)! Don't eat that food, you're eating it all up.
\rf RS2005-05
\xv Wayi-kiya ninji jawikajba ngaliyanya mama-anyi?
\xe Couldn't you have asked us for food?
\rf RS2004-04
\xv Najba ngawu ninya, mama-wurru dabarra-kurru.
\xe I'm looking at you cooking the food.
\rf RS
\xv Najba ngawu dabarra-kurru mama-wurru.
\xe I saw him cooking the food.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Jungku nyulu mama-yudu.
\xe She's got food.
\rf RS
\xv Jajini bula jungku mamana. Jajini mamana bula jungku.
\sfx
\xe They are both sitting eating (their) food. They are sitting eating (their) food.
\rf IS_GB
\xv Mama-yan.
\sfx
\xe Without any food.
\rf MB_LH13
\va
\sy wada
\cf waliji
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt 03/Sep/2006

\lf mamana

\xe They are going along eating damper.
\rf GB
\xv Wayi barri ninji kanjijbi dabarraba maman?
\sfx

\rf  GB

\cf bululuma

\lx mamanumbu
\mr mamanu-mbu
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd mind
\lt Xerg come to be without memory or knowledge of Y
\ge lose
\ge forget
\re 
\so RS, EK
\xv Budangku ninji mamanumbu. Mayi ninji mamanumbu.
\xe Don't you forget it. You might forget it.
\rf RS2005-01
\xv Mamanumbu ngawu, yilaka, ngambalangi, banga wawun.
\xe I forgot (to bring) tea leaves for us, and the sugar.
\rf RS
\xv Yandujbu nana yanyin. Budangku ninji mamanumbu.
\xe Hold onto that language. Don't you forget it.
\rf RS
\xv Yanyba yalu, yanyi, mandaki-anyi. Mamanumbu yalu, yalungi, yanyi.
\xe They speak the whiteman's language now. They've forgotten their own language.
\rf RS
\xv Nijbi nyulu ngarrawa kudurrumbu nyulu. Budangku nyulu mankuu. Nijbi nyulu junuu. Mamanumbu nyulu.
\xe He's forgotten where he put the salt. He's can't recall. He put it somewhere. He's forgotten.
\rf RS
\xv Mamanumbu ninji nanyalu. Budangku ninji ngabaa.
\xe You forgot the tea. You didn't bring it.
\rf RS
\va 
\sy Kudurrumbu ~ kududumbu ~ kudulumbu (?)
\cf kudujbu
\nt 
\cp Garrwa
\nq 
\dt 18/Oct/2006

\sn 2
\ps verb
\pc
\sd SPATIAL
\lt Xerg come to be without Y
\ge lose
\ge be bereaved of
\ge be bereft of
\re lose
\so RS
\xv Bawa-nganja, mamanumbu nyulu kakulu-nganjaa.
\sfx
\xe His elder brother, the younger brother lost him.
\rf rs2002-14
\xv Nayi dara, jungku nyulu, mamanumbu nyulu, mungkuji nangangi.
\sfx
\xe This dog, he's (still) here. He lost his owner.
\rf RS
\xv Mamanumbu ninji nganyi nawi-nganja.
\xe You've lost your husband.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt Used to express loss of relative through death.
\cp

\lx manamba
\mr
\hm
\sv
\sf
\sn
\ps noun
\pc
\sd plant
\sd tree
\la Corymbia grandifolia
\lt
\ge White Bark Bloodwood
\re Bloodwood (White Bark)
\so LC, GW
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\va
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt This tree has smooth white bark, but a rough bit at the base of the trunk.
\nt Sugarbag, native bee-hives, that contain honey, wax and pollen, are often found in this tree.
\nt The timber is good firewood to make long lasting coals. The outer bark can be burnt to fine, white ashes to mix with chewing tobacco.
\nt People made necklaces with the pretty cup-shaped fruit.
\cp Garrwa {manamba}
\nq
\dt

\xe A little river is a stream.

\xe This place, this river, has a lot of fish.
\rf RS

\xe It's (called) Kanalanja here, the river, this section of the river.
\rf RS

\xe Tourists come for fish. They catch fish to the north, in the river.
\rf RS

\xe We went back to the river for water.
\rf RS

\xe This (part of) the river is (called) Kurrbali.
\rf RS
\xv Jungku nurri manangkana. Yanjini barri.
\sfx jungku-nurri-manangkana-RS2002T09a.wav
\xe We are sitting by the river, chatting.

\xe Your big brother is waiting for you at the river.
\rf GB

\xe He goes without a hat, with nothing. He's likely to get a headache from the sun. His poor head!

\lx mandaki
\mr marndaki
\sf mandaki.wav
\ps noun
\pc whitefellaman.jpg
\sd people
\lt man of European origin
\ge European
\ge whiteman
\ge whitefella
\re 
\so RS, EF, GB, EK, JD, SC_BB, AP+AF_PS, JP_TT
\xv Nana nyulu mandaki jila.
\sfx nana-nyulu-mandaki-jila.wav
\xe That whiteman is going.
\rf EF
\xv Kujarra mandaki-wuya.
\xe Two whitemen.
\rf RS2005-06
\xv Yanngunyi nayi, mandaki-darra, jilaba yalu, kaku-wanyi.
\xe These travellers, whitefellas, they go (to get) fish. 
\rf RS
\xv Ngumarri-yanyi nan mandaki burrurri.
\xe This white man belongs to Lawn Hill (Station).
\rf GB
\xv Ngabaa nurri bulaka, karurri, nukamii, mandakii wululukuu. Mungkuji ngaki.
\xe We took the cattle east, on foot, (with) the old white man. He was my boss.
\rf RS2002-10
\xv Bunyarrijbi nyulu kumbulungkana, mandakii. 
\xe The white man pours (it) into bottles.
\rf RS2005-08b
\xv Mandaki-yanyi yalu mankuu, yanyba yalu jangkurr mandaki-yanyi.
\xe They (only) understand the whiteman's (language), they (only) speak the whiteman's language.
\rf RS
\xv Nanganja nyulu ngaki murriba, nanangkani mandakii. 
\xe That white man caught my father.
\rf RS
\xv Mandakii nanganja kaburrukaja.
\xe The whiteman caught a crocodile.
\rf GB
\xv Burrbijbi nyulu mandaki-mukunu.
\xe He's running to get away from the whiteman.
\rf GB
\xv Jila nyulu niyangi mandaki nana. Yanyba ja nyulu niyangi.
\xe That white man is coming to us. He will speak to us.
\rf EK (ML notes)
\xv Birajba bula ngambalangi - mandakii, wanymarrii.
\xe They both sing for us -- the white man and the white woman.
\rf EK (ML notes)
\va
\sy
\cf wanymarri
\nt Dymock (1993) also records as 'ghost'
\cp
\nq

\lx mangkarri
\mr mangkarri
\sf mangkarri-wife.wav
\ps noun
\pc
\sd PEOPLE
\sd kin
\lt female spouse, sister of female spouse
\ge wife
\ge wife's sister
\ge man's sister-in-law
\re wife
\so EF, RS, GB, CO, EK, JD
\xv Budangku ninji ngaki kukudi, mangkarri-nganja ninji ngaki. 
\xe You are not my granny (mother's mother), you are my wife.
\rf RS2004-01
\xv Yakamarrina mangkarri-nganja Bangarinyi-anyi.
\xe A Yakamarrina woman is the (straight) wife of a Bangarinyi man.
\rf RS2005-01
\xv Budangku yalu yanyba, nawi-nganja, kadu-nganja, ngunyarri-nganja, mangkarri-nganja.
\xe The relations (of dead person) who cannot speak are a husband, father-in-law, mother-in-law and wife.
\rf RS
\xv Mijbi bulangka. Nawi-nganjaa, mangkarri-nganjaa.
\xe They are swearing at each other, the husband and wife.
\rf rs2002-04
\xv Daba nyulu mangkarri-nganyjaa dungalaa. Kuyi nyulu daba, dungalaa, nana wululuku, kijibajii kirriyaa.
\xe His wife hit him with a rock. The wild woman hit that old man on the head with a rock.
\rf RS2003-03
\xv Nijbi nurri, nganyi, nganyini nganana. Nayi nganyi mangkarri-nganja.
\xe We betroth (put her) for you, on your lap. This is your wife.
\rf RS
\xv Mangkarri-nganja nyulu ngaba.
\xe He's bringing his wife.
\rf GB
\xv Nangangi mangkarri-nganja nyulu yakujbu. Ngarri nyulu yingkan barri ngabaa.
\xe He left his own wife (behind). But he took another one (with him).
\rf IS_GB
\xv Mangkarri-nganja nana.
\sfx
\xe That's his wife.
\rf EF_R299B2
\va
\sy mani (GB)
\cf nawi
\nt This relationship is signed by touching upper arm with opposite hand.
\cp
\nq
\dt 21/Sep/2006

\pc
\sd Land
\lt open grassland
\ge tableland
\ge grass plain 
\re grassland
\so RS
\xv Burruji, miya kijibaji. Budangku nayi kala. Jungku yalu mangkurunu.
\sfx
\xe Death adders are dangerous snakes. This (Waanyi) country doesn't have any. They live on the open grassland.
\rf RS
\va
\sy kinkarra
\sy muwanbi
\cf
\an
\nt Recorded by Dymock (1993) as 'cold weather mirage'.
\cp Wambaya 
\nq 
\dt
\lf mangkurunu

\lx mani
\mr marni
\hm 1
\sf marni.wav
\sf marni02.wav
\sf marnii.wav
\sf marni-hand.wav
\sf marni-hand_R299b2.wav
\sf manin_CO.wav
\ps noun
\pc
\sd body
\lt hand or part of hand
\ge hand
\ge finger
\ge thumb
\re 
\so EF, RS, EK, GB, CO, LM, JD93, SC_BB, MS_SK, AP+AF_PS, JP_TT
\xv Ngamijbi nyulu manii. Nayi burrurrin.
\xe He paints this man by hand.
\rf RS2002-11
\xv Minimbi nangka manin ngaki mama-anyi, kara-anyi.
\xe She's putting out her hand to me (to give her) food, or money...
\rf RS2002-11
\xv Nanganja barri jangu-wunyi. Jarringkajba barri nyulu. Manii barri nanganja!
\xe Now get it from the fire. It's now cooked. Get it with your hand.
\rf rs2002-10
\xv Marijbi nyulu wanamin, jawuranya, manii.
\xe He's holding the water, the quartpot, in his hand.
\rf RS2004-03
\xv Dungkala ngawu manii. Janyi-wunyi.
\xe I'm removing it (fishhook) with (my) hand. From its mouth.
\rf RS2005-08b
\xe Dirrbu ngawu kularrijbi, manii.
\xe I scoop out the honey by hand.
\rf RS2002-03
\xv Jariyamba-kurru, najba ngawu naan, manini.
\xe I saw this (fellow) sneaking off (with it) in (his) hand.
\rf RS2004-04
\xv Wanyi ninji bikalii manini?
\xe What are you carrying in your hand?
\rf RS2003-01
\xv Ninji mirramba, jukuli ngaki. Manii.
\xe You, make me a boomerang by hand.
\rf RS2004-04
\xv Yanyba ngamba manii.
\xe We talk with our hands.
\rf RS2003-04
\xv Manii ngawu ngamijbi. Wanu.
\xe I roll my smokes by hand.
\rf RS2002-02
\xv Burrandi mani.
\xe Palm (lit. Middle of the hand)
\rf GB(W-G vocab)
\xv Manini kadikadi.
\xe Fingers (lit. hand-on little ones)
\rf GB (W-G vocab)
\xv Mani ngada-nganja.
\sfx
\xe Palm of the hand.
\rf GB
\xv Burrandi mani.
\sfx 
\xe Middle of the hand, palm.
\rf GB
\va
\sy
\cf jungkurri
\cf wakunyi
\nt
\cp Kudanji {marna}
\nq
\lf manii
\lf manini
\lf maninyi
\lf mani-wakala
\lf mani-yinya

\lx maninja
\mr maninja
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd relational
\lt belonging to another
\ge belonging to another
\ge not one's own
\ge someone else's
\ge another's 
\re else 
\so RS
\xv Maninja nana, maninja. Balyangka nanganjaa!
\sfx
\xe That belongs to someone else, (it's) someone else's. Don't take (it)!
\rf rs2004-04
\xv Yakujbu maninja nanangi wululuku-anyi. Mayi nyulu ninya dabaa. Maninja, nangangi.
\xe Leave that alone as it belongs to that old man. He's liable to hit you. It belongs to him.
\rf RS2004-04
\xv Maninja nayi jamba. Yanyula-anyi. Yanyula-anyi nayi jamba. Budangkun Waanyi-yanyi.
\xe This country (i.e. Borroloola, NT) belongs to other people. To Yanyula people. This land is for the Yanyula. It doesn't belong to Waanyi people.
\rf RS2002-04
\xv Ngamuyu ngaki, maninja.
\xe I thought it was for me, but it belongs to someone else.
\rf RS2000-08
\xv Maninja yakujbu! Yakujbu! Yaluwangi. Maninja. Balyanga nanganjama. Dajaya yalu ninya. Maninja.
\xe It belongs to someone else, leave it, leave it. It belongs to those others. It's theirs. Don't pick it up. Otherwise they might attack you, as it's theirs (not yours).
\rf RS2000-08
\va
\sy
\cf
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt

\xe We singe off the fur (by quickly turning the kangaroo from side to side in the flames). Then I scrape off the fur.
