\lx manku
\mr manku
\sf manku.wav
\ps verb
\pc
\sn 1
\sd mind
\sd sound
\lt Xerg perceives sound of Y
\ge hear
\ge listen
\re 
\so RS, EF, GB
\xv Budangku nyulu ngaan manku.
\sfx budangku nyulu ngaan manku.aif
\xe He didn't hear me.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Budangku nyulu manku nana burrurrin.
\sfx budangku nyulu manku nana burrurrin.wav
\xe It didn't hear that man.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Manku-wanyi nyulu nana-waan yanykurru. Manku-anyi barri nyulu  nambunyi.
\xe He wants to listen to them talking. He wants to listen from here.
\rf RS
\xv Birajini nyulu jungku. Manku nurri nana wululuku. Jukulini nangka birajba wululukuu, kuyii buka-aduu.
\xe He's sitting singing. We are listening to that old man. The old man with his grey hair is singing himself (clapping) a boomerang.
\rf rs2004-05
\xv Manku-wanyi ngawu ninya yanykurru, diindi ninji yanyba.
\xe I've got to listen to you talking (to see if) you're talking straight (i.e. correctly).
\rf RS2003-03
\xv Wungkurru nyulu kunuma. Manku ngawu, kuwadaa. 
\xe The bees are humming. I can hear them with my ears. 
\rf RS2003-02
\xv Mankuu nyulu niyanya julakii.
\xe The bird is listening to us.
\rf RS
\xv Kannga nyulu. Mankuu ngawu, narrunguja. Ngungkurru nyulu. Yirrkuu nyulu kanungku barri.
\xe She's coming back. I can hear the car. It is making a noise (of car motor). It's getting closer now. 
\rf RS
\xv Nukami, budangku nyulu manku nangangi.
\sfx nukami budangku nyulu  manku nangangi.wav
\xe His footsteps, he didn't hear them.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Kayi-wurru ngawu mankuu, kadimirra, warrwarri-darra.
\xe I can hear the little ones, all the children, calling out.
\rf RS
\va
\sy lajibi
\cf
\nt
\cp Garrwa; Wambaya
\nq
\dt 18/Sep/2006
\lf mankuu
\lf manku-manku
\lf manku-wanyi
\lf mankunu

\sn 2
\ps verb
\pc
\sd mind
\lt Xerg understand Y
\ge understand
\ge take notice of
\ge comprehend
\ge hear
\ge heed
\ge understand
\re
\so GB, RS
\xv Mudumbanyi bula nangkujarra, ngila-wuya, ngakinkanyi yanyi-anyi. Budangku bula mankuu.
\xe These two girls don't know my language. They don't understand it.
\rf RS2005-06
\xv Budangka ngawu mankuu.
\sfx budangku ngawu mankuu_RS.wav
\xe I can't understand (it).
\rf RS2004-05
\xv Budangku ngawu mankuu Yanyula
\sfx budangku_ngawu_mankuu_yanyula_RS.wav
\xe I can't understand Yanyula.
\rf RS2004-05
\xv Jalwa nana, yanyi yalungi. Budangku ngawu mankuu.
\sfx
\xe That language of theirs is hard. I can't understand it.
\rf RS2004-05
\xv Mandaki-anyi yalu mankuu, yanyba yalu jangkurr mandaki-anyi.
\xe They (only) understand the whiteman's (language), they (only) speak the whiteman's language.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku nurri Waanyii mankuu, yanyi Yanyula. Miyarrka nurri.
\xe We Waanyi don't understand the Yanyula language. We don't understand (it).
\rf RS
\xv Manku ngawiji nan wawurran, ngamuyu nyuluji ngilan, ngala nyulu jukan.
\xe I had heard (about) this child that it was supposedly a girl, whereas it's a boy.
\rf GB
\xv Budangku nungka mankuu wunjuku nyulu jilaba.
\sfx
\xe We don't know where he's gone.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt

\sn 3
\ps verb
\pc
\sd mind
\lt Xerg have mental image of Y
\ge recall
\ge remember
\re remember
\so RS
\xv Nijbi nyulu ngarrawa kudurrumbu nyulu. Budangku nyulu mankuu. Nijbi nyulu junuu. Mamanumbu nyulu.
\xe He's forgotten where he put the salt. He can't recall. He put it somewhere. He's forgotten (where).
\rf RS
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\va
\sy lajibi

\an

\xe He's thinking.

\cp Ganggalida {mawurraji} Macropus antilopinus "big black kangaroo" or "grey kangaroo"

\sfx wululukunu-ngamba-jungku-marakini-nawunu_CO.wav

\xe I'm going over to the shade.

\lx marrbamarrba
\mr marrba-marrba
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc lightning.jpg
\sd weather
\lt lightning
\ge lightning
\ge thunder
\re lightning
\re thunder
\so RS, GB, EK, JD
\xv Rangkijibi nyulu marrbamarrbaa. Kundan. Bujimala-yudu. Miya-yudu. Wurrarra jalwa. 
\xe Lightning strikes the trees. It comes with the force of the Rainbow Serpent. It is a strong wind.
\rf rs2003-01
\xv Dumijbi jamba, marrbamarrbaa kijibajii.
\xe The wild lightning blew up the ground.
\rf RS2002-04
\xv Marrbamarrbaa kijibajii, daba nyulu kunda. Jambalamba, karrawarraka.
\xe Powerful lightning struck a tree. It struck it with such force that it shattered into wood chips which flew everywhere.
\rf RS2002-04
\xv Ngungkurru nyulu wanamin. Ngungkurru nyulu. Marrbamarrba.
\xe The thunder is roaring. There's the sound of thunder and lightning.
\rf RS
\xv Marrbamarrbaa, daba nana kunda.
\xe The lightning, it struck that tree.
\rf EK (ML notes)
\va marrbumarrbu 
\sy NGULWA
\sy NGULWANGULYU
\cf bayimilanya
\cf bujimala
\nt Pronounced [madbamadba].
\cp
\nq redup
\nq check if marrbumarrbu is found in GB notes -- taken from phonology writeup
\dt 07/Oct/2006

\lx marrijbi
\mr marri-j-bi
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd contact (impact and violence)
\lt
\ge grab hold of
\ge hold
\ge hold on to
\ge take hold of
\ge catch
\re hold
\re grab
\so EF, RS, GB, EK
\xv Marrijbi manii.
\sfx
\xe Hold in hand.
\rf EF_R299B2
\xv Marrijkanyi nurri nana-waan kurrkamala wadungiji-darra.
\xe We've got to grab that mob of preinitiates.
\rf RS
\xv Duka-nanja nyulu marrijbi. Bajawaja nyulu, wadaban. Kudumanjaa nyulu marrijbi.
\xe It (dog) grabbed it (goanna) by the neck. The goanna thrashed around, but it (the dog) kept hold of it.  
\rf rs2005-01
\xv Wilijirri bambularra-nanja! Marrijbi ninji, manii! Bambularra!
\xe Pull it by the tail. Grab hold of (its) tail with your hand.
\rf rs2000-03
\xv Marrijbi nyulu. Bijbi nyulu kadimirra, wanamini.
\xe It (crocodile) grabbed hold of him. It held that child down in the water in its mouth.
\rf rs2005-01
\xv Marrijbi bulangka, manangka-wuyaa. 
\xe The two rivers join up. (Lit. They grab hold of each other.)
\rf rs2005-09
\xv Mayi ninya nanganja kaburrukajaa, nanganja-anyi ninya, marrijbi manii. Bijbi ninya. Jidimbi ninya duka.
\xe A crocodile might get you. It'll get you, grab you with its claws, bite you, and squeeze you by the throat.
\rf RS2004-07
\xv Jambana nyulu kurrijbi, mirrbuu. Jarrkanyi nyulu jamurawaa barrulkijini. Kurrijbi nyulu manii, nanganja nyulu mirrbu; jamba-nanja nyulu marrijbi.
\xe Frogs dig down in the earth. The water goanna tries to eat them and get fat (on them). It digs using its front legs (=hands), it gets a frog, it grabs hold of it and pulls it out of the ground.
\rf RS2005-05
\xv Marrijbi nyulu wanamin, jawuranya, manii.
\xe He's holding the water, the quartpot in his hand.
\rf RS2004-03
\xv Marrijbi nyulu kudaanyu.
\xe He's still holding on (won't let go).
\rf rs2005-01
\xv Naa ninji marringi!
\xe Here, you hold this!
\rf IS_GB78
\xv Marriijbi bulangka jurrana.
\xe They are holding each other in play (making love).
\rf IS_GB78
\va marrimbi
\sy
\cf nanganja
\nt
\cp Garrwa {marrimba} 'grab, hold'
\nq mari ~ marri (?) {need entry for marimbi} Breen (W-G vocab) has [marijbi]
\dt 27/Oct/2006

\lx mayangka
\mr mayangka
\sfx mayangka.wav
\sfx mayangka02.wav
\sf mayangka-push_R299b2.wav
\sf mayangka02-push_R299b2.wav
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc push.jpg
\sd spatial
\sd contact
\sd movement
\lt Xerg cause Y to move away from X by exerting pressure on Y
\ge push
\re

\lx mayi
\mr mayi
\hm 1
\sf mayi.wav
\sf mayi02.wav
\ps particle
\pc
\sd Grammar: mood
\lt Potential
\ge can
\ge could
\ge may
\ge might
\ge possible
\ge probable
\ge liable
\re
\so RS, EK
\xv Mayi ninya burra-daba, wanuu. Mayi ninji bajawajaa.
\sfx mayi ninya burra-daba#wanuu.wav
\sfx mayi ninji bajawajaa.wav
\xe The tobacco, it might knock you out. You might throw a fit.
\rf rs2005-04
\xv Jarriyamba narriyanya kadajalaa ngilangila. Mayi nyulu jarriyamba narriyanya, ngilangila.
\xe The kurdaitcha man will take you little girls away. He might carry you little girls off.
\rf rs2003-01
\xv Mayi ngaan miyaa jakajba, kudijkurru.
\xe A snake might come and get me while I'm sleeping.
\rf rs2003-02
\xv Mayi ninya bijbi miyaa. 
\xe A snake might bite you.
\rf rs2003-02
\xv Mayi nyulu jungku nanawunu, rajini.
\xe He might be there, in camp.
\rf rs2003-03
\xv Budangku ngawu jirringkijbi nana. Mayi ngaki, nangangi.
\xe I don't recognize that one. It might be mine, or his.
\rf rs2004-01
\xv Lalujbu nyulu, mayi nyulu ninya rirrajba.
\xe (If) he wakes up, he might chase after you.
\rf RS
\xv Kudijbi nyulu nana bungkina. Mayi nyulu binanyba burrurrii. Binanyba nyulu mukura-adu.
\xe That wallaby is lying asleep. The man might sneak up on it. He might sneak up on it with his spear.
\rf rs2004-04
\xv Langan-daba ngamba, kundana, bindawarra kaku-yudu, dara-mukunu. Mayi yalu jarrba daraa.
\xe We hang the bag with the fish up in the tree to keep it safe from the dogs. Otherwise the dogs might eat (the fish).
\rf rs2002-14
\xv Mayi kawa wanu-yudi?
\xe Can you bring tobacco?
\rf EK (ML notes)
\xv Mayi yalu ninya daba. Jungku ninji nganyini. Kudarri.
\xe They might hit you. You stay home, be quiet.
\rf EK (ML notes)
\va
\sy
\cf
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt 12/Sep/2006

\xe The old man is teaching him.
\rf RS
\xv Yanyba ngawu nganyi milidimbi ninya, milidimbi ninya. Ngaki yanyi Waanyi. Milidimbi ngawu ninya ngakinkanyi yanyi-yanyi.

\re glance (keep glancing backward)

\rf RS2005-01
\xv Milwa-milwa ngawu.
\xe I kept looking back.
\rf RS

\xe I took off, looking around behind me, frightened. It was over this woman.

\xe He walked along glancing back.
\rf RS

\xe He's sneaking around looking back all the time.
\rf RS

\sfx
\xe He's running away looking back all the time.

\lx minaminanumbu
\mr minamina-nu-mbu
\sf minaminanumbu_RS.wav
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd contact (impact and violence)
\lt Xerg hit Y repeatedly with force
\ge thrash
\ge give good hiding to
\ge beat severely
\re thrash
\re beat 
\re hit
\re punish
\so RS
\xv Burra-daba ngaan. Daba nyulu ngaan jadiyadiyimbi. Minaminanumbu ngaan kundaa.
\xe He knocked me down. He hit me and gave me a thrashing. He beat me severely with a stick.
\rf RS
\xv Daba ninji ngaan, kundaa, minaminanumbu, barrkuu. 
\xe You hit me with a stick, gave me a thrashing with a nullanulla.
\rf RS
\xv Dabaraba nyulu barrkuu, minaminanumbu.
\xe He kept on hitting him with a nullanulla, gave him a real hiding.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku ninji kannga nangkurru, dajaya ngawu ninya, minaminanumbu.
\xe Don't come back here or I will beat you up, give you a thrashing.
\rf RS
\xv Daba yaluwangka minaminanumbu kundaa.
\xe They are fighting each other, beating each other up with sticks.
\rf RS
\sy jadiyadiyimbi
\cf daba
\cf dabaraba
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt 25/Oct/2006


\lx mindikirri
\mr mindikirri
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd CEREMONY
\lt
\ge dance women's style
\re
\so RS
\xv Nawan ngilangila, kirriya-darra, ja yalu mindikirri.
\xe These young girls, and women, they must dance.
\rf RS
\xv Ja yalu wangkijbi mindikirri.
\xe They will dance {mindikirri} style.
\rf RS
\xv Najba nurri yaluwanya mindikirri-wurru.
\xe We watched them dancing {mindikirri} style.
\rf RS
\xv Mungamba yalu mindikirri kirriya-darra.
\xe The women dance tonight.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf wangkijbi
\nt
\cp Wambaya
\nq

\lx mirramba
\mr mirra-mba
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd effect
\lt Xerg cause Y to come into existence, or become better
\ge make
\ge make good
\ge fix
\ge repair
\ge build
\ge do (something)
\re
\so RS, GB, MF+EM_CO
\xv Nana wululuku, mirramba nyulu kurrkamala. Jukuli. Nana-darra. Mukura,  barrku.
\sfx nana wululuku-mukura.wav
\xe That old man, he makes lots of things.Those boomerangs, spears, nullanullas.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Wunjukuu ninji nana mirramba, mirramba mukuran?
\sfx wunyjuku_ninyji_mirrambaF.wav
\xe How did you make that spear?
\rf EF_R299EA1
\xv Mirramba yalu babakana. Daba yalu karaa. Ramijbi yalu. Ngukujaba yalu yamarrina barri.
\xe They used to make stone knives. They would strike them with a rock and break them (in two). They would sharpen it on a flat rock.
\rf rs2002-04
\xv Mirramba nyulu nangangi nana mukura. Binany-kanyi nyulu walijin bungkina.
\xe He's making himself that spear. He wants to hunt that wallaby.
\rf rs2004-04
\xv Jawikajba ngawu ninya, ja ninji mirramba jukuli ngaki?
\xe I'm asking you, will you make me a boomerang?
\rf RS
\xv Winjuraba ngambalanya. Burra-daba wanami ngambalangi. Mirramba nyulu dumularra. 
\xe It's raining on us. The rain is pouring down on us. It's forming a fast running current.
\rf RS
\xv Janban nyulu mirramba.
\xe It made a nest.
\rf GB
\xv Mirramba nurri, jangu. 
\xe We make a fire.
\rf RS2002-10
\xv Kudumanja nyulu mirramba; mirramba nyulu jukuli, wululukuu.
\xe The old man keeps on making it, making the boomerang.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku yalu mirramba, kanjijbi. 
\xe They haven't finished building them (houses).
\rf RS
\xv Kunymamba-wurru nurri najba, mirramba-wurru.
\xe We watch him making it, perfecting it.
\rf RS
\xv Mirramba-kurru ngawu naan kuku-najba, nana wululuku, kijibaji.
\xe I kept an eye on that cheeky old man as he did it.
\rf RS
\xv Mirramba yalu, kunymamba nana nukami nangangi.
\xe They fixed it, repaired that wheel for him.
\rf RS
\xv Mirrambakanyi nyulu jangu.
\xe She's got to make a fire.
\rf RS
\xv Mirramba ngawu mama nganyi balikajbarri.
\xe I'm making food for you (because you're) hungry now.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Najba ngawu nana mirramba-kurru.
\xe I saw that one making (it). 
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Ngurrubu ngawu nan mirrambajudu.
\xe I told him to do it.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Mirrama!
\xe Make (it)!
\rf MF+EM_CO
\va
\sy kunymamba
\cf yawanba
\nt Related to Yukulta {mirra} 'good'.
\cp
\nq

\lx mirrbu
\mr mirrbu
\sf midbu.wav
\ps noun
\pc
\sn 1
\pc
\sd animal
\la

\ge frog
\re frog
\so RS, GB, JD, SC_BB, JP_TT
\xv Jambana nyulu kurrijbi, mirrbuu. Jarrkanyi nyulu jamurawaa barrulkijini. Kurrijbi nyulu manii, nanganja nyulu mirrbu. Jamba-nanja nyulu marrijbi.
\xe Frogs dig down in the earth. The water goanna tries to eat them and get fat (on them). It digs using its front legs (=hands), it gets a frog, it grabs hold of it and pulls it out of the ground.
\rf RS2005-05
\xv Kankulu nyulu walijin mirrbu.
\xe He's having a feed of frog meat.
\rf RS
\xv Kuujbu nyulu waliji-yanyi mirrbu-wanyi.
\xe It's looking for frogs to eat.
\rf RS

\sy wanbun

\sfx miyaanyi-ngawu-durrajba.wav

\xe This dangerous snake can bite you.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Nijbi ngawu nan miya, bariyimbi.
\xe I almost trod on the snake.
\rf GB
\xv Marijbi ngawu ngamuyu kundan, jangun. Miya ngawu marijbi miyan. Janybijbi ngawu.
\xe I picked up what I thought was a stick, a piece of firewood, (but) I had picked up a snake. I threw it away.
\rf RS
\xv Ngamuyu miya nayi kajalaba ngakinburru, nukamini.
\xe I thought it was a snake climbing up on me, onto my foot.
\rf RS
\xv Rangkijbi narri karaa, kudanba, miyan.
\xe You lot pelted the snake with stones and killed it.
\rf RS
\xv Ngamuyu-kiya nyulu bijbi nayi burrurrin, miyaa. 
\xe I thought that the snake had bitten this man.
\rf RS2003-03
\xv Mayi ngaan miyaa jakajba, kudijkurru.
\xe A snake might come and get me while I'm sleeping.
\rf rs2003-02
\xv Wikijbi nyulu miya, badada-yangka.
\xe A snake is crawling near the baby.
\rf GB
\xv Miyana nana!
\sfx
\xe That one's near the snake.
\rf EF_R299EB1
\xv Barranyi jila miya-anyi. Yirrku nana miya.
\sfx
\xe Get away from the snake. That snake is close.
\rf EF_R299EB1

\sy
\cf balangkali
\cf bujada
\cf bujimala
\cf bulalangu
\cf kululu
\cf kurralbungku
\cf kurrana
\cf ngulwayi

\lx miyarrka
\mr miyarrka
\hm 
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd cognition
\lt Xerg not have knowledge or experience of Y
\ge not understand
\ge not know
\ge ignorant of
\ge unfamiliar with
\ge unused to
\re
\so RS, EK, JD93
\xv Milirrimbi ninji ngaan nangkanyi kaku-anyi. Mudumbanyi ngawu. Miyarrka ngawu.
\xe You teach me about this fish. I don't know (about it). I'm ignorant.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku ninji jilaba nanangkurru. Miyarrka yalu ninya.
\xe You don't go there. They don't know you.
\rf RS
\xv Miyarrka yalu ngaki yanyi.
\xe They don't know my language.
\rf RS
\xv Miyarrka nyulu ngambalanya,  mandakii. 
\xe The white man doesn't understand us.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku nurri Waanyii mankuu, yanyi Yanyula. Miyarrka nurri.
\xe We Waanyi don't understand the Yanyula language. We don't know (it).
\rf RS
\xv Nayi kala, miyarrka ngawu.
\xe This country, I'm not familiar with it.
\rf RS
\xv Miyarrkana ninji jungku nawunu. Miyarrka nana-waan burrurri-darra. Budangku ninji jirringkijbi nana-waan burrurri-darra. Budangku ninji lajibi yanyin yalungi.
\sfx
\xe You are on unknown (foreign) country here, (you) don't know about those men. You don't know those men. You can't understand their language.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf junuu
\cf mudumbanyi
\an jirringkijbi
\nt Also recorded as 'stranger' by Dymock (1993)
\cp
\nq don't know
\dt 27/Oct/2006

\lx mudamudajibi
\mr mudamuda-ji-bi
\sf mudamudajibi.wav
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd contact (impact and violence)
\lt Xerg cause Y to be wrapped around with some entity (Zerg/loc)
\ge entwine
\ge handcuff
\ge restrain
\ge roll up
\ge tie up
\ge twist around (something)
\ge wind around
\ge wrap up
\re
\so RS, GB, CO
\xv Mudamudajibi yalu jibana. 
\xe They wrapped (it) in paperbark. 
\rf RS2005-03
\xv Mudamudajibi yalu yurruduu. Mudamudajibi, yurruduu, binyiin. Kangkarinyana.
\xe They wind hairstring all around it. Encircle it with hairstring and with bees wax. On the knife.
\rf rs2002-13
\xv Mudamudajibi nangka duka. 
\xe He tied (the rope) around his neck. 
\rf RS2005-08b
\xv Jalu-wiya, mudamudajibi ngawu.
\sfx
\xe Its two forelegs (of kangaroo), I tied (them) together.
\rf RS2002-02
\xv Mudamudajibi nyulu lungkajii, janakii.
\xe The policeman handcuffed him.
\rf RS
\xv Mudamudajibi ngamba nayi jukan, jaladuu.
\xe We drape this lad (initiate) with hairstring.
\rf RS2002-11
\xv Mudamudajibi nurri kalawa. Yakujbu nurri, kumayangunu. Mudamudajibi yalu jibana.
\sfx
\xe We tied up the bones (of the dead person) and we left them in a cave. They used to wrap them up in sheets of paperbark.
\rf RS2002-09
\xv Mudamudajibi ninji jumbala nganyi. 
\xe You tie up your swag.
\rf RS2005-05
\xv Madamba bulanya, madamba jalu, mudamudajibi. Mudamudajibi jalu-wiya. 
\xe They join both forelegs (arms) together and they bind them together. Tie both forelegs together.
\rf RS
\xv Mudamudajibi yaluwangka.
\xe They put on their seatbelts. (lit. They tie themselves in.)
\rf RS
\xv Mudamudajibi yalungka,  nyungka, janakii.
\xe They tied up their hair with hairstring.
\rf RS
\xv Yilaka yalu mudamudajibi, nalana.
\xe They tie leafy branches onto their legs.
\rf RS
\xv Mayi narriyanya mudamudajibi, kurralbungkuu.
\xe The water snake might wrap itself around us.
\rf RS
\xv Durrajba nyulu lungkaji-anyi. "Mayi nyulu ngaan mudamudajibi janakii."
\xe He was frightened of the policeman. "He might handcuff me."
\rf RS2004-03
\xv Mudamudaji!
\xe Tie (him) up!
\rf MF+EM_CO
\va 
\sy karrbilijbi
\cf madamba
\nt
\cp
\nq redup; handcuff
\dt 19/Sep/2006

\lx mudi
\mr mudi
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd spatial
\lt
\ge keep low
\ge be down
\re down ; low ; out of sight
\so RS, CO, MB_LH09

\xv Mudii nyulu wajka niyangi.
\sfx
\xe He's down hiding from us.
\rf RS2005-02
\xv Budangku nyulu ngaan najba. Mudi ngawu wajka.
\sfx
\xe He can't see me. I'm down out of sight.
\rf RS2004-04
\xv Kuku-najba ngamba naan, mudi-wurru.
\sfx
\xe We are watching this fellow hiding down there.
\rf RS2004-06
\xv Mudi nana.
\xe That's too small (of clothing).
\rf MB_LH09
\xv Burrbijbi barri nyulu mudi-mudi.
\sfx
\xe He's now running keeping low down.
\rf RS2004-06
\xv Jangajba ngawu mudi-mudi.
\sfx
\xe I'm sneaking up (on it) keeping low down.
\rf RS2004-07
\xv Mudi-mudi nana.
\sfx mudimudi-nana_CO.wav

\rf OSBORNE_C02-000165B.TMP

\sn 1
\ps noun

\xe Leave that name, (say) "the deceased".
\rf RS
\xv Mudinyi nana niji. Budangku narri nijarrijbi niji. Nijarrijbi narri mudinyi.
\xe That name is taboo. You don't call his name. You call him "the deceased".
\rf RS
\va mudunyi
\sy
\cf
\nt
\cp
\nq Name to use to refer to deceased person.

\lx mudumbanyi

\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd mind
\lt X not have knowledge of Y
\ge not ^know
\ge be ^ignorant of
\re
\so RS

\sfx mudumbanyi ngawu_RS.wav

\xe These two girls don't know my language. They don't understand it.
\rf RS2005-06
\xv Mudumbanyi ngali wunjuku ninji jilaba.
\xe We didn't know where you had gone.
\rf rs2003-02
\xv Mudumbanyi ngali wunjuku ninji jilaba. Budangku ninji ngurrubu ngaliyanya.
\xe We didn't know where you had gone. You didn't tell us (where you were going).
\rf rs2000-09
\xv Ngawu, mudumbanyi. Budangku ngawu mankuu.
\sfx
\xe Me, I don't know it. I don't understand it.
\rf rs2002-01b
\va
\sy kudujbu
\cf junuu
\cf kudumbanyi
\cf miyarrka
\cf ngamiri
\nt Y may be expressed by dative case-marked phrase or by finite clause.
\cp Breen records as Garrwa
\nq one example of kudumbanyi, check recording

\lx mudunama
\mr murdunama
\sf mudunama.wav
\sf mudunama.CO-wav
\ps noun
\pc
\sd time
\lt day following time of speech act
\ge tomorrow
\ge next day
\ge tomorrow morning
\re
\so EF, RS, GB, EK, CO, JD93, JP_TT, MB_LH09
\xv Mudunama nungka jila.
\sfx mudunama-nungka-jila.wav
\xe Let's go tomorrow.
\rf EF
\xv Mudunama ngamba jarrba waliji.
\sfx mudunama-ngamba-jadba-waliji_CO.wav
\xe We'll eat meat tomorrow.
\rf OSBORNE_C02-000165B.TMP
\xv mudunama-anyi
\sfx mudunamanyi.wav
\xe for tomorrow
\rf RS2005-05
\xv Jilaba ngamba mudunama, naniwiin barri, kularra.
\sfx mudunama-kularra.wav
\xe Tomorrow we are going in another direction, south.
\rf RS2005-05
\xv Lalujbu ngawu mudunama.
\xe I’ll get up in the morning.
\rf RS
\xv Jawikajba nyulu ngaan bungkana, jila-kanyi nungka mudunama.
\xe He asked me yesterday if we two would go the next day.
\rf RS
\xv Nanganja ngali julaki mudunama.
\xe We catch the plane tomorrow.
\rf RS
\xv Yakujbu ngawu narriyanya, dururruru, mudunama.
\xe I leave you all at first light, tomorrow morning.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku ngawu wanu-anyi. Jilakanyi ngawu mudunama, kularra, wanu-anyi. 
\xe I don't have any tobacco. Tomorrow I have to go south to get tobacco.
\rf RS
\xv Kudijkanyi ngamba mudunama-anyi.
\sfx
\xe We've got to go to bed to be ready for tomorrow morning.
\rf RS2005-05
\xv Junuu ngamba jilaba mudunama.
\xe Don't know where we are going tomorrow.
\rf RS
\xv Mudunama ngamba burrbijbi kaja-anyi kaku-anyi.
\xe Tomorrow we are going to get a lot of fish.
\rf RS
\xv Kannga-yirrimbi nyulu ngaan mudunama, wululukuu, barrawu-wurru.
\xe The old man will take me back to the station tomorrow.
\rf RS
\xv Wangkijkanyi ngamba, mudunama.
\xe We've all got to dance tomorrow.
\rf RS
\xv Wunjuku ngamba jilaba mudunama?
\xe Where are we going tomorrow?
\rf RS
\xv Mudunama ngamba nayi na kannga -- nangkurru.
\sfx muduna-ngamba-nayina-kannga-nangkurru_CO.wav
\xe We will come back here tomorrow.
\rf OSBORNE_C02-000165B.TMP
\xv Winja ninji jila mudunama?
\xe Where are you going tomorrow?
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Najba ngawu nimbalanya mudunama. Jilaba nyulu bawa-nganja nganyi.
\xe I'll see you two tomorrow. Your brother is coming.
\rf IS_GB78
\xv Mudunama ngawu najba nan.
\sfx
\xe I'll see this one tomorrow.
\rf MB_LH09
\va
\sy ngunyiyana
\cf bungkana
\cf jala
\cf jalanya
\an bungkana
\nt Also recorded by Dymock (1993) as 'day' in sense of unit of time, e.g., mudunama kujarra 'in two days (time)'
\cp
\nq

\ge lest

\ge to get out of way of
\re

\xe To avoid the dirt.
\rf RS

\xe Pick up that baby, to keep it out of the prickles.
\rf RS
\xv Jarriya ngamba wurrurra-mukunu, kumayangunu.
\xe Let's go inside the cave to get out of the wind.
\rf GB, RS
\xv Nanganja nana badada, miyan-mukunu.
\xe Pick up that baby, to get it away from the snake.
\rf GB
\va
\xv Jungku ngawu nawunu kinngarrini,liwi-mukunu.
\xe I was sitting here in the smoke to avoid the mosquitoes.
\rf GB
\xv Kawa nangkurru! Miya-mukunu.  Mayi ninya bijbi miyaa.
\xe Come here! To get away from snakes. A snake might bite you.
\rf RS
\xv Makarra nana wangkula-mukunu.
\xe Cover that so the crows can't get at it.
\rf GB

\lf mularrijbi

\lx mularrijbi
\mr mula.rri-j-bi
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd hold (holding and transfer)
\lt Xerg raise Y, typically by means of hands and arms
\ge lift
\ge pick up
\ge get
\ge hold up
\re
\so RS, GB
\xv Mularrijbi ngawiji nana bulumirri, ngindi-wurru.
\xe I picked up that child who was crying.
\rf rs
\xv Kirriya-darraa, mularrijbi yalu. Yurrukadi yalu narrungujana. 
\xe The women, they lifted him up. They put him into the car.
\rf RS2005-08a
\xv Mularri-kurru nyulu kuku-najba nana-waan kirriya-darra.
\xe He looked at those women as they were lifting him.
\rf rs2005-08a
\xv Mularrijbi nyulu manii.
\xe He picked it up in his hands.
\rf rs204-04
\xv Mularrijbi yalu jamba-wunyi, janki-wurru barri. Janki-wurru yalu mularrijbi bikali yalu jankini.
\xe They pick them up from the ground and put them on their shoulders (around their neck). They lift them onto their shoulders and carry them on their shoulders (astride their neck).
\rf rs2004-03
\xv Dadarrba ngawu. Mundirri ngawu bariyijbi, nayi mularrijbi kundan.
\xe I'm in pain. I hurt my back (when) I lifted this log.
\rf GB
\xv Budangku nangka mularrijbi jamba-wunyi. Namanyba nukami jambaa, kalabirri, jalwaa jambaa, kalabirri.
\xe It couldn't pull itself out from the ground. The earth kept hold of its wheels, the sand, the strong earth, the sand. (of vehicle stuck in soft sand)
\rf RS2004-08b
\xv Mularrijbi nyulu jamba rangkijbi nyulu.
\xe It raised the dirt where it struck the ground.
\rf RS
\xv Mularri nana badadan!
\xe Pick up that baby!
\rf GB
\xv Nanganja ngawu bawanyin ngaki. Ja-nyulu mularri.
\xe I fetched my brother for him to lift it.
\rf GB
\xv Mularri nana! Budangku ngYanyinawu mularrikanyi.
\xe Lift that! I can't lift it.
\rf MF_GB76
\xv Ja-nyulu mularri. Jalwa nyulu.
\xe He will lift it. He's strong.
\rf MF_GB76
\va
\sy
\cf bikali
\cf bikali-daba
\cf marijbi
\cf ngaba
\cf nanganja
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt 19/Sep/2006

\lf mula-mula

\lf mularrikanyi
\lf mularrikurru

\lx mulu
\mr mulu
\sf mulu.wav
\ps noun
\pc nose.jpg
\sd BODY
\sd body part
\lt nose
\ge nose
\re nose
\so EF, RS, GB, EK, LM, JD93, SC_BB, MS_SK, JP_TT
\xv Mulu kanawa.
\xe Long nose.
\rf RS
\xv Duwarrijbi mulu.
\sfx
\xe Blow nose.
\rf GB
\xv Janybijbi ngawu, kurrkulu ngawu. Janybijbi ngawu ngalurr, mulu-nanja.
\xe I cast it out, I cough and I blow out the mucous, from (my) nose.
\rf RS
\xv Durrajini nyulu kungkulu mulu.
\xe Being afraid it (horse) snorted (through its) nose.
\rf RS2005-08b
\xv Wanami nyulu bajalijbi, muluu.
\xe He was sniffing liquid through his nose.
\rf rs2005-08a
\xv Kalarrangi mulu.
\xe Nostril (lit. hole nose)
\rf JD93
\va
\sy
\cf
\nt
\cp Yinjilanji {mulu} 'mouth'
\nq

\lx mulungu

\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd people
\lt man said to live away from people in wild country who can cause harm to people
\ge wild man
\ge bogeyman
\ge kudaitcha man
\re
\so RS, JD
\xv Mayi nyulu kalijbi ninya wawurra mukuraa, mulunguu, winyakii.
\xe A wild man, a bogeyman might spear you child.
\rf RS
\xv Jilaba nyulu mulungu, kuujbu nyulu, najkanyi nyulu ngambalanya.
\xe The wild man moves around looking to find us.
\rf RS
\xv Mungamba,  jilaba nyulu mulungu. Kudijbi ngamba, ngurruwijbi. Najba  nungka,"Burrurri nayi jilaba, mulungu. Jakajba nyulu ngambalangi."
\xe At night the wild man moves around (while) we are sleeping and snoring. We see him, "There's a man coming here, a bogeyman. He's sneaking up on us."
\rf RS
\va
\sy winyaki
\cf ngabaya
\cf kadajala
\nt
\cp Wambaya

\xv Mundirri ngawu barijbi. Makanijkanyi ngaka mundirrin.
\xe I've got a bad back. I've got to straighten my back up.
\rf RS

\xe The horse reared up and made me fall back, and it pinned me down on my back.
\rf RS

\xe I'll slash your back with a knife.
\rf RS
\xv Mundirri nyulu ngaan bijbi, jindali.
\xe The mosquito is biting me on the back.
\rf RS

\xe I'm in pain. I hurt my back (when) I lifted this log.

\xv Maka-nijkanyi nganyingka mundirrin.
\xe You will straighten your back.
\rf RS

\xe I have (carry) it (i.e. the mark) on my back.
\rf GB78

\lx munduka
\mr munduka
\hm 1
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd body
\sd hold (holding and transfer)
\sd transfer
\lt Xerg carry Y under arm (supported on hip, or by strap over shoulder)
\ge carry under arm
\ge carry in coolamon
\re carry
\so RS, GB, EK
\xv Mundukaa yalu wanami jukiyana.
\sfx
\xe They carry water in coolimons held under their arm.
\rf GB
\xv Jilaba nyulu kulana, Nularrima kirriya, mundukana barri.
\xe (That) Nularrima woman is coming from the south, carrying (her swag) under her arm.
\rf RS
\xv Mundukaa ngawu. Ngaki bulungu mundukaa.
\xe I carry (it under my arm). Carry my baby under my arm (on hip).
\rf RS
\xv Bulungu kadimirra yalu mundukaa.
\xe They carry little babies under their arms.
\rf RS
\xv Mundukama!
\xe Carry it under your arm.
\rf GB
\va mundukaa
\va mundukama
\va mundukaya
\sy
\cf ngaba
\cf bikali
\nt This is how babies were carried traditionally in a wooden coolamon, also water in wooden water-carrier, with the coolamon supported by a shoulder strap.
\cp
\nq same as "swag" ; ngaba shoulder carry ; same with other body parts?
\dt 21/Sep/2006

\lx mungamba

\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc night_moon.jpg
\sd TIME
\lt
\ge night
\ge night time
\ge tonight
\ge dark
\re
\so EF, RS, EK, JD93, EM_SK, RC_SK, RC+MF_SK
\xv Jangayarrijbi ngawu. Mungamba. Budangku yalu ngaan najba.
\xe I snuck away, at night. They didn't see me.
\rf RS2002-07
\xv Jundu-kanyi ninji kaku, kamu, mungamba. Jundu-kanyi ninji, jalwamba ninya muwan.
\xe You'll have a good feed of fish this evening, come nightfall. You'll eat up, so that your stomach will feel tight. 
\rf RS2004-05
\xv Mungamba yalu mindikirri kirriya-darra.
\xe The women dance tonight.
\rf RS
\xv Mungamba, jilaba nyulu mulungu. Kudijbi ngamba, ngurruwijbi. Najba nungka: "Burrurri nayi jilaba, mulungu. Jakajba nyulu ngambalangi."
\xe At night the wild man moves around (while) we are sleeping and snoring. We see him: "There's a man coming here, a bogeyman. He's sneaking up on us."
\rf RS
\xv Dabarra-kanyi yalu kaku ngaki mungamba kamu.
\xe They will cook the fish for me tonight.
\rf RS
\xv Burrbijkanyi ngamba jalanya mungamba barri. Mungambana ngamba burrbijbi.
\xe It's dark now (so) we've got to be going. We drive at night.
\rf RS
\xv Jungku yalu wajarrijini, mungamba, kalana.
\xe They spend the night fishing in the river.
\rf RS
\xv Babaa ngawu mungamba.
\xe I fly through the night.
\rf RS
\xv Kulikulijibi duru, jindal nana jilaba barri, mungana, mungamba.
\xe Once the sun goes down, those mosquitoes come out, once it's dark, at night.
\rf RS
\xv Warrakuujbu yalu naa-wan, barriyi, mungamba. Ngarakini yalu jungku, kamukamu yalu ngaraba.
\xe These (fellows) went mad last night. They were drinking. They were drinking beer.
\rf RS
\va
\sy kuluwu
\sy yarrba (?)
\cf barriyi
\cf kamu
\cf mungana
\cf nguji
\cf yababala
\an duru

\lx mungkuji
\mr mungkuji
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd PEOPLE
\lt person having some social relationship with another person, entity or place
\ge boss
\ge countryman
\ge owner
\ge relation
\re
\so RS, JD93
\xv Ngaki mungkuji.
\sfx ngaki_mungkuji_RS.wav
\xe My countryman.
\rf RS2004-05
\xv Ngaki mungkuji, Karrwa, nana-waan badibadi, wululuku.
\xe My relations are Garrwa, those old women and old men.
\rf rs2004-05
\xv Kalijkana yaku! Ngarrimbi nganyi. Barrakalaba ngawu ninya. Mungkuji nganyi.
\xe Don't spear him. He's your mate. I'm stopping you (from hitting him). He's your countryman.
\rf rs2004-04
\xv Ngabaa nurri bulaka, karurri, nukamii, mandakii wululukuu. Mungkuji ngaki.
\xe We took the cattle east, on foot, (with) the old white man. He was my boss.
\rf RS2002-10
\xv Nayi dara, jungku nyulu, mamanumbu nyulu, mungkuji nangangi.
\sfx
\xe This dog, he's (still) here. He lost his owner.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku ninji mungkujin yalungi.
\sfx
\xe You're not related to them.
\rf RS2004-05
\xv Dawurrumbu nawunu mungkijin kudajba.
\sfx
\xe The people from around here have all died out.
\rf GB
\va mungkiji
\sy
\cf ngarrimbi
\nt The person or animal with whom the referent is related is expressed in the dative form.
\cp
\nq mungkiji in 2000-08; owner, dweller, relation
\dt 29/Oct/2006

\sn 2
\ps noun
\pc
\sd people or animal
\lt self
\ge self, by one's self
\re
\so RS
\xv  Lalujbu nyulu, burra-daba nangka. Burra-daba nangka, mala barri nangka burra-daba, mungkujii. Kuwada-yaan.
\sfx
\xe He got up and collapsed (again). He collapsed, he fell down again all by himself. He was crazy.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt
\lf mungkujii

\lx -mungkuji
\mr
\sn
\ps suffix
\pc
\sd relational
\lt belong to (place)
\ge belonging to
\ge from
\ge owner of
\re belonging ; from ; owner
\so RS
\xv Na-mungkuji ngawu.
\sfx na_mungkuji_ngawu.wav
\xe I'm from here.
\rf RS-RG1999
\xv Bujada Jiranyku-mungkuji. 
\xe The quiet snake (Dreaming ancestor) is from Jiranyku (Newcastle Waters). 
\rf rs2002-06
\xv Kala-mungkuji.
\sfx kala_mungkuji.wav
\xe Land-owner.
\rf RS-RG1999
\xv Bujabuja-mungkuji kirriya.
\sfx
\xe The woman from Bujabuja.
\rf GB
\xv Kinkarra-mungkuji ngawu, mudumbanyi ngawu muwada-anyi.
\xe I'm from the dry country, I don't know about boats.
\rf RS
\xv Winja-mungkujin ninji burrurrin?
\xe Where are you from, man?
\rf 
\va
\sy
\cf
\nt
\cp
\nq mungkiji in 2000-08; owner, dweller, relation
\dt 29/Oct/2006

\lx murriba
\mr murriba
\sf murriba-father.wav
\sf murriba02-father.wav
\sf murriba-F_R299b3.wav
\ps noun
\pc
\sd PEOPLE
\sd kin
\sd kin term
\lt be father to X
\ge father
\ge father's brother
\re
\so EF, EK, RS, GB, JD93, MF_SK
\xv Murribanyi.
\xe My father.
\rf GB_IS
\xv Jilaba ngawu yanngu, murribana.
\xe I'm going away with my father.
\rf GB
\xv Nana wawurra, bujiji nyulu. Budangkun, ngada-nganja-anyi. Jungku nyulu bujiji. Budangkun murriba-nganja-anyi.
\xe That child, he's an orphan. He has no mother. He's orphaned. (And) he has no father.
\rf rs2002-14
\xv Nanganja nyulu ngaki murriba, nanangkani mandakii. 
\xe That white man caught my father.
\rf RS
\xv Jukuli nana murriba-anyi.
\xe That boomerang belongs to my father.
\rf RS
\xv Murriba-yurru.
\xe Deceased father.
\rf GB
\xv Murriba-yangkurru.
\xe (My) late father.
\rf GB
\xv Murriba-anyi jamba.
\xe My father's land.
\rf RS
\xv Ngakin murriba, Kungayinmaji.
\xe My father (was) Kungayinmaji.
\rf RS
\xv Winjikaa daba? Murribaa daba.
\xe Who killed it? Father killed it.
\rf MF_GB76
\va
\sy barringi
\cf bana 
\cf kawija
\cf wulu
\cf wululuku
\cf bibi-yurru
\nt Speaker uses {murriba} to refer to own father.
\cp
\nq

\lx murrku
\mr murrku
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd quantity
\lt relatively small number greater than two, typically three or four
\ge several
\ge some
\ge few
\re several
\so EF, RS, JD, JP_TT
\xv Murrku-darra.
\sfx murrku-darra.wav
\xe A few.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv "Yangulu ninji kannga nangkurru." "Kudijbi ngawu murrku-darrana ngunyini."
\xe "When will you come back here?" "I'll spend a few nights away."
\rf RS2004-08a
\xv Kudijbi ngawu nana-waana burrurri-darrana, yanjini. Murrku-darrana, kudijbi ngawu.
\xe I'll stay talking with those people. I'll be away for a few days.
\rf RS2004-08a
\xv Murrku-darra balangarra.
\xe Four months.
\rf JD93
\xv Ngamba jungku nawunu murrkun, kujarra yingkanyi (lit. two one).
\sfx
\xv A few of us are sitting here, three (of us).
\rf EF_R299EA1
\va 
\sy
\cf kujarra
\cf kaja
\cf kurrkamala
\nt Sometimes pronounced [mudku].
\nt Recorded as 'four' by Dymock (1993) and Flint; also 'three'
\cp Wambaya {murrku-}
\nq more than two 2005-06
\dt 19/Oct/2006

\sn 2
\ps noun
\pc
\sd quantity
\lt four
\ge four
\re
\so RS
\xv murrku-darran.
\sfx murrkudarran-several.wav
\xe Four
\rf RS-RG1999

\xe Are you staying for two (nights)? No, for four.
\rf rs2003-01
\xv Ngamba jungku nawunu murrkun.
\xe There are four of us sitting here.
\rf EF
\xv Makulu kujarra-kujarra, julaki-yanyi makulu, janbana murrku-darra.
\xe Four eggs, bird eggs, four in the nest.
\rf RS
\xv Kawa-najba ngawu murrku-darra jambana. 
\xe I found four (frogs) in the ground.
\rf RS
\xv Murrku-darra dara, nganyi.
\sfx
\xe The four dogs are yours.
\rf RS
\xv Murrku-darra burrangku.
\xe Four years (Lit. summers).
\rf RS
\xv Murrkunu ngunyini ngawu jungku.
\xe I'm stopping here for three days (lit. sleeps).
\rf GB
\xv Kudijbi ngawu murrku-darrana ngunyini.
\sfx
\xe I'm camping away for four nights.
\rf RS2000-09b
\va
\sy kujarra-kujarra
\cf -darra
\an
\nt Glossed as 'three' by GB.

\lx muwa
\mr muwa
\sf muwa.wav
\sf muwa03.wav
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd BODY
\sd body part
\lt
\ge belly
\ge stomach
\re
\so EF, RS, GB, EK, JD93, MS_SK, JP_TT
\xv Balikajka nyulu muwa.
\sfx balikajba nyulu muwa.wav
\xe She's hungry (in her) stomach.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Balunbu ngawu, yujurru. Maman, muwa-nanja.
\xe I'm vomiting, chucking up. It's food from the stomach.
\rf rs2002-04
\xv Budangku ngawu jarrkanyi barri, dumbululujbu ngawu muwa.
\xe I don't want to eat any more, my belly is full up.
\rf RS2004-07
\xv Dungkalaba ngawu muwan. Jaluki-anyi barri.
\xe I remove the stomach to get the intestines.
\rf RS2000-03
\xv Jalwamba ninya muwan, walijii kakuu.
\sfx
\xe Fish meat gives you a strong stomach (i.e. fills you up).
\rf rs2004-05
\xv Yurru-kadi nurri dandi, kara, muwana.
\xe We put hot stones, rocks, in the belly (of animal being cooked in earth oven).
\rf RS
\xv Wirrikaji-wirrikaji, muwa malala.
\sfx
\xe The {wirrikaji-wirrikaji} catfish has a red belly.
\rf RS
\xv Wadamba nangka muwan, walijii.
\xe He filled his belly with meat.
\rf RS
\xv Muwa ninji ngaan daba.
\xe You hit me in the stomach.
\rf GB_IS
\va
\sy ngajbara
\cf
\nt The stomach symbolises a maternal relationship; handsign for mother's brother is made against the stomach.
\cp
\nq 
\dt 20/Sep/2006
\lf muwaa
\lf muwana
\lf muwa-nanja
\lf muwarra

\sn 2
\sd spatial
\lt concave side, or interior of enclosed area
\ge inside
\ge sole (of foot)
\ge palm (of hand)
\ge pouch (of marsupial)
\re
\so EF
\xv Muwa nukami.
\sfx muwa-nukami.wav
\xe sole of the foot.
\rf EF
\xv Jungku yalu kurrkamala, kalawunyi barri julakini barri muwana.
\xe There were a lot of people sitting inside the belly of the aeroplane.
\rf RS
\xv Kingkarri muwa.
\sfx kinkarri muwa.wav
\xe Upper concave side (of coolimon).
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Muwana kuyuwarrunu, kurrijbi ngawu, kadimirra bulungu.
\xe Inside a coolimon is where I slept when I was a little baby.
\rf rs2000-05
\xv Junabu, bulungu-yudu muwana. 
\xe The female kangaroo has a joey in (her) pouch.
\rf 2000-08
\va
\sy
\cf
\an mundirri
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt

\sn 3
\ps noun
\pc
\sd EMOTION
\lt seat of emotions and feelings
\ge feelings
\ge emotion
\re
\so RS

\sfx juraa nyulu muwa.wav
\xe He's feeling sad inside.

\xe They had a fight because they were very angry (with each other).
\rf rs2002-03
\xv Burrurri kijibaji, yulurri muwa.
\xe An aggressive person (is said to be) hot tempered (Lit. angry belly).

\lx na-
\mr na-
\sf naan.wav
\sn 1
\ps demonstrative
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt proximate demonstrative
\ge this
\ge here
\ge this one
\re
\so RS, GB
\xv Ramii ngawu kuku-najba naan.
\sfx ramii ngawu kuku-najba naan.wav
\xe I saw this one with (my own) eyes.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Bajaliwa nan walijin.
\xe Smell this meat.
\rf GB
\xv Wanamiin, kamukamuu, barimbi naan. Barimbi naan lungkarra.
\xe The beer, grog, it has ruined this (fellow). The strong (stuff) has wrecked him.
\rf rs2005-01
\xv Jakajba na burrurri!
\xe Hunt this man away.
\rf GB
\xv Naanjudun barri.
\sfx naanyjurdunbarri.wav
\xe With this now.
\rf RS
\xv Nanganja ngawu kunda, dajkanyi ngawu nan dara.
\xe I'm getting a stick to hit this dog.
\rf GB
\xv Wanamiin, kamukamuu, barimbi naan. Barimbi naan lungkarra.
\xe The beer, the grog, it has ruined this (fellow). The strong (stuff) has wrecked him.
\rf rs2005-01
\xv Wilijirri yalu kalawunyi. Barrawunu ja yalu nijbi naan.
\xe They are dragging (him) inside. They will put this (fellow) down inside the house.
\rf rs2005-08a
\xv Mudi nyulu. Dakalijbi nyulu. Budangku ngawu naan najba. 
\xe He's low down. He's has ducked down. I can't see him (Lit. this (one)). 
\rf RS2004-04
\xv Budangku nangka mularrijbi jamba-wunyi. Namanyba naan. Namanyba nukami jambaa kalabirri, jalwaa jambaa kalabirrii.
\xe It (motorcar) couldn't lift itself out from the sand. It was stuck. Its wheels were held in place by the sandy earth, that strong sandy soil.
\rf RS2004-08
\xv Jarriyamba-kurru, najba ngawu naan, manini. 
\xe I saw this (fellow) carrying (it) off, in (his) hand. 
\rf rs
\xv Budangku ngawiji nan burrurri najanyi wabula.
\xe I haven't seen this man before.
\rf GB
\va 
\sy
\cf bangani
\nt The length of the vowel 'a' varies between short /a/ and long /aa/. Final 'n' is heard in most examples.
\nt {na(an)} is one of many words which translate as 'this' or 'these'. 
\nt {na(an)} is only used for the Object of a verb, i.e., to refer to the person or thing that one does something to.
\nt Often best translates English 'him' or 'her'.
\cp
\nq {\ps should be demonstrative } {add in entry for (nayi)}
\pc
\dt 03/Sep/2006

\lf nangkujarra

\lx -na
\mr -na
\sf
\sn 1
\ps suffix
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt Locative suffix
\ge at 
\ge in
\ge on
\ge near
\re at 
\re in
\re on
\so RS, GB, CO
\xv Kanalanjana.
\xe At Kanalanja.
\rf EK
\xv Balana.
\xe In the sky.
\rf RS
\xv Jungku nurri manangkana, yanjini barri.
\xe We are sitting by the river, chatting now.
\rf RS
\xv Jungku ngawu kingka kabarrana.
\xe I am sitting on top of the high bank (of river). (lit. on top of the head)
\rf MF+EM_CO
\va -ni
\va -nu
\sy
\cf
\nt Locative suffix {-na} is added to a word ending in the vowel 'a'.

\lx namanyba
\mr namany-ba
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd contact (impact and violence)
\lt Xerg exert pressure on Y and prevent Y from moving
\ge hold onto
\ge hold down
\ge pin down
\ge restrain
\ge stop
\ge press down on
\ge weigh down on
\re 
\re 
\so RS
\xv Burruru nyulu kingkarrini. Namanyba nyulu niyanya, mangkanyii, kudanba.
\xe He [horse] can fall on top (of us) and pin us down under him with his body and kill us.
\rf RS2005-08a
\xv Namanyba ngawu ninya nukamii, duka.
\xe I'll press down on your throat with my foot (and choke you).
\rf RS2002-03
\xv Budangku nangka mularrijbi jamba-wunyi. Namanyba naan. Namanyba nukami jambaa kalabirri, jalwaa jambaa kalabirrii.
\xe It (motorcar) couldn't lift itself out from the sand. It was stuck. Its wheels were held in place by the sandy earth, that strong sandy soil.
\rf RS2004-08
\xv Namanyba nyulu janjaa narrunguja. Barijbi nyulu, budangku nyulu jalwa. 
\xe The wet sand held that car in place. (i.e., the car was stuck in the wet sand.) It (car) couldn't get itself out, it wasn't strong enough.
\rf RS2004-08
\xv Nijbijbi ngawu kunda nukamii, namanyba. Namanyba wajka jambana.
\xe I stand on the stick and hold it down. Hold it down on the ground.
\rf RS
\xv Kalarramba nyulu ngaan,  namanyba mundirri.
\xe It (horse) threw me and pinned (me) down on my back.
\rf RS
\xv Namanyba ngawu ninya. Jungku ninji nawunu wuja.
\xe I'm stopping you.  You stay here, stay put.
\rf RS
\xv Namanyba ngawu yanyii.
\xe I talked him out of it. (lit. I stopped him with (my) talk.) 
\rf RS
\xv Kudumanja nyulu namanyba.
\xe He kept hold of him.
\rf RS
\xv Namanyba nyulu manii nanangkani daraa.
\xe That dog holds him down with his paw.
\rf RS
\xv Winjarramba nyulu ngambalanya wanamii. Namanyba ngambalangi narrunguja.
\xe It rained on us and bogged our car.
\rf RS

\so RS
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\va namira
\sy kalabirr
\cf dungala
\cf kara
\an
\nt
\cp Wambaya {namirra} 'stone'
\nq
\dt

\sn 2
\ps noun
\pc
\sd manufacture
\lt
\ge money
\re
\so RS
\xv Nanganja-anyi ngawu namirra ngaki, Kayawana-wurru ngawu jilaba. 
\xe I've got to get my money (so) I'm going to Kiana.
\rf RS
\xv Yandujbu nyulu ngaki namirra. Nanajba nyulu ngaki namirra-yudu.
\xe She's looking after my money. She's waiting for me with the money.
\rf rs2004
\xv Budangku yalu narriyanya windijbi, budangkun namirra-anyi.
\xe They can't give you any, there's no money.
\rf RS
\xv Windijbi kiya ngawu ninya, namirraa. Budangku ngawu. Jungku ngawu, budangkun maninyin. Dungalanyin.
\sfx
\xe I would give you money, but I don't have any. I've nothing, I'm empty-handed. Penniless.
\rf RS2003-03
\va
\sy dungala
\sy kara
\sy kijululu
\sy mani
\nt
\cp
\nq

\lx nana
\mr nana
\sf nana.wav
\ps demonstrative
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt non-proximate demonstrative
\ge that
\ge that one
\ge there
\re that 
\re there
\so GB, EK, RS, EF, MF_SK, LP_SK, EM_SK
\xv Nana burrurri.
\sfx nana burrurri.mp3
\xe That man.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Nana nyulu mandaki jila.
\sfx nana-nyulu-mandaki-jila.wav
\xe That whiteman is going.
\rf EF
\xv Midiba nana Ambaya-anyi.
\xe That Midiba (place name) belongs to Wambaya (people).
\rf rs2002-04
\xv Winjikanyi nana bajangun? Budangku ngamba jirringkijbi.
\xe Who does that dog belong to? We don't recognize it.
\rf rs2005-06
\xv Najba nungka bajawaja-wurru. Bajawaja nyulu nana kaku.
\xe We can see it thrashing about. That fish is thrashing about.
\rf rs2004-04
\xv Kiinyba nyulu janyini, nana bala.
\xe That hook is stuck in its mouth.
\rf rs2005-08b
\xv Balyanga nana lalumbu.
\xe Don't wake that one.
\rf rs-2000-09
\xv Bambularra-yudu, nana baribari.
\xe That comet had a tail.
\rf rs2004-07
\xv Budangku ngali najba nana-waan. Jilaba yalu nana-wunyi.
\xe We didn't see anyone. They had gone from there.
\rf RS
\xv Najba ngawu nana daran. Dara ngawu najba nana.
\sfx
\xe I can see that dog. I see the dog over there.
\rf EM_SK
\xv Nanawankanyi dara.
\xe Their dog.
\rf MF_GB76
\va
\sy
\cf na
\cf nayi
\nt
\cp Wambaya {nana} 'this', {nanama} 'that';
\nq 
\dt 07/Oct/2006
\lf nanambunyi

\lf nana-waan



\lx nanajba
\mr nana-j-ba
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd state
\lt X not move from some place (for some purpose)
\ge wait
\ge stop
\re 
\so RS, GB
\xv Nanajba nyulu.
\sfx nanajba_nyulu.wav
\xe It (aeroplane) was waiting.
\rf RS-RG1999
\xv Nanajba yalu nawunu.
\xe They are waiting here
\rf rs2005-03
\xv Ja nyulu dabarraba walijin, wululukuu. Waliji-anyi, nanajba ngawu. Nanajba nungka, ngala nyulu dabarraba walijin.
\xe The old man, he will cook the meat. I'm waiting for that meat (to be cooked). Let's wait while he cooks the meat.
\rf rs 2004-04
\xv Nanajba nungka narrunguja-anyi. Wajamba nungka yubal, wululuku-anyi.
\xe We waited for the car (to come). We were watching the road looking out for the old man.
\rf rs
\xv Jilaba nyulu, banyajba nyulu ngaan. Budangku nyulu nanajba.
\xe He's going straight past me. He's not stopping (for anyone).
\rf rs2004-04
\xv Jungku ninji, nanajba. Nangkanyi waliji-anyi.
\xe You sit and wait for this meat.
\rf rs2002-09
\xv Yandujbu nyulu ngaki namirra. Nanajba nyulu ngaki namirra-yudu.
\xe She's keeping my money.She's waiting for me with the money.
\rf rs2004
\xv Bawa-nganja nganyi nanajba manangkana.
\xe Your brother is waiting for you at the river.
\rf IS_GB78
\xv Nanajba ngawu nangangi burrurri-anyi barrku-yudu.
\xe I'm waiting with a nullanulla for this man.
\rf RS2004-03
\xv Nananji ninji nawunu, ngala ngali jilaa.
\xe You wait here while we two go.
\rf MF_GB76
\va
\sy
\cf walajba
\cf jungku
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt 12/Sep/2006
\lf nananji

\lx nanambunyi
\mr nana-m-bunyi
\hm
\sf
\sn 1
\ps demonstrative
\pc
\sd spatial
\lt ablative form of non-proximate demonstrative
\ge from that
\ge from there
\re
\so RS
\xv Mayi yalu ninya jakajba nanambunyi jamba-wunyi.
\xe They might hunt you away from that place.
\rf RS
\xv Nanawunu nyulu jungku langkuu. Najba nyulu ngambalanya, nanambunyi, ngandu-wunyi.
\xe He's sitting there to our north. He's looking at us from over there, from the shade (where he's sitting).
\rf RS
\xv Kuujbu yalu nangangi. Jangayarrijbi nyulu nanambunyi wanba-wunyi.
\xe They were looking for him. He had sneaked away from that station.
\rf rs2004-06
\xv Najba nyulu ngambalanya nanambunyi ngandu-wunyi.
\sfx
\xe He looked at us from that shady tree.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf nambunyi
\an
\nt
\cp

\lf nana

\lx nanangkani
\mr nana-ng-ka-ni
\sf
\sn 1
\ps demonstrative
\pc
\sd spatial
\lt Ergative form of non-proximate demonstrative {nana}
\ge that
\ge those
\re that
\re those
\so GB, RS
\xv Mayi ninya bijbi, nanangkani miyaa kijibajii.
\xe That dangerous snake might bite you.
\rf rs2005-04
\xv Rami ngawu barijbi. Nanangkani ramii, bariyimbi nyulu ngaan nanangkani ramii, nanangkani jalwaa ramii.
\xe My eyes are no good. Those glasses, those strong eye-glasses hurt me.
\rf rs2005-08a
\xv Windijbi nyulu ngalyaa, nanangkani mamaa. Lungkarraa darimaa. 
\xe That bitter unripe plum makes (us) sick. 
\rf RS2002-11
\xv Nguwajba nyulu nangangi dawirri-nganja-anyi, nanangkani kirriyaa.
\xe That woman is jealous of her younger sister.
\rf GB
\xv Diba ngaa nanangkani burrurrii, karaa.
\xe That man struck me with a stone.
\rf GB
\xv Nanganja nyulu ngaki murriba, nanangkani mandakii. 
\xe That white man caught my father.
\rf RS
\xv Namanyba nyulu manii nanangkani daraa.
\xe That dog holds him down with his paw.
\rf RS
\xv Nanangkani daba ngaki bawanyi.
\sfx
\xe That one hit my brother.
\rf IS_GB
\va
\sy
\cf nangkani
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt
\lf nana

\lx nanangkanyi
\mr nana-ng-kanyi
\sf
\sn 1
\ps demonstrative
\pc
\sd spatial
\lt Dative form of non-proximate demonstrative {nana}
\ge that
\ge those
\re that
\re those
\so RS, GB
\xv Ninji, nanangkanyi bawa-nganyja-anyi, ja-ninji nanganja.
\xe You, you will marry (Lit. 'get') that (woman) who belonged (=was married) to your elder brother.
\rf rs2002-14
\xv Ngajabarra, bujimala-yudu. Nana raji, nanangkanyi wululuku-anyi, Balyarrinji-anyi.
\xe Ngajabarra is associated with the Rainbow Serpent. That place belongs to that old man, Balyarrinyi (skin).
\rf rs2004-08b
\xv Kuujbu ngawu nanangkanyi ngila-anyi. Budangku ngawu najba.
\xe I am looking for that little girl. I can't find her.
\rf rs2003-01
\xv Budangku ninji kirinji nanangkanyi. Yakujbu, maninja.
\xe Don't you touch what belongs to that one. Leave it. It belongs to someone else.
\rf RS2004-04
\xv Kudinyi ngawu nanangkanyi waduku-anyi.
\xe I don't know about that fishing line.
\rf RS2005-01
\xv Wayi-kiya nimba ngaan windijbi nanangkanyi mama-anyi?
\xe Shouldn't you two have given me some of that food?
\rf RS2004-01 
\xv Kuujbu ngawu nanangkanyi julaki-anyi, jukuu-jukuu-anyi.
\xe I'm looking for that bird, for that Topknot Pigeon.
\rf RS
\xv Kayimi nanangkanyi!
\xe Sing out to that one!
\rf GB
\xv Junuu, kudinyi ngawu, nanangkanyi burrurri-anyi.
\xe Don't know, I don't know about that man (where he comes from).
\rf RS
\xv Winjakanyi na lakija? Nanangkanyi badada-yudu-kanyi.
\xe Whose is this coolimon? (It) belongs to that (woman) with the baby.
\rf GB
\xv Ninji, nanangkanyi bawa-nganyja-anyi, ja-ninji nanganja.
\xe You, you will marry (Lit. 'get') that (woman) who belonged (=was married) to your elder brother.
\rf rs2002-14
\xv Nana raji, nanangkanyi wululuku-anyi, balyarrinji-anyi.
\xe That place belongs to that old man, to Balyarrinyi (skin).
\rf rs2004-08b
\xv Kuujbu ngawu nanangkanyi ngila-anyi. Budangku ngawu najba.
\xe I am looking for that little girl. I can't find her.
\rf rs2003-01
\xv Durrajba ngawu nanangkanyi miya.
\sfx
\xe I'm frightened of that snake.
\rf MF_GB76
\va
\sy
\cf nangkanyi
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt
\lf nana

\lx nanangkujarra
\mr nana-ng-kujarra
\sf nanangkujarra_RS.wav
\sn
\ps noun
\pc
\sd spatial
\lt dual form of non-proximate demonstrative {nana}
\ge those two
\re
\so RS, EF
\xv Burrandi bula jungku yanjini, nanangkujarra wululuku-wiya.
\xe Those two old men sat talking along the way.
\rf RS
\xv Nanangkuya kadimirra, jawaji-nganja, ngakinkanyi kakulu-nganja, jawaji-nganja nanangkujarra.
\xe Those two little ones, his children, are my younger brothers, those two sons of his.
\rf RS2005-02
\xv Jiwarrana bula jungku jiwarrana, nanangkujarra makulu-wuya.
\xe Those two 'eggs' (Magellanic Clouds) sit near the Milky Way.
\rf RS
\xv  Kujarra makulu-wuya nanangkujarra, nayi kingkarri balana.
\sfx
\xe Those two Magellanic Clouds (Lit. 'eggs-two') are up here in the sky.
\rf RS
\xv Balakarraba nyulu bulanya, nanangkujarra.
\xe She is blocking those two (who are fighting).
\rf rs2005-03
\xv Jungku bula nanangkujarra burrurri-wuya, wakalinyi ngandunu 
\xe Those two men are sitting inside the shelter.
\rf RS
\xv Mayi bula rangkijbi ngaan karaa nanangkujarraa.
\xe Those two might pelt me with stones.
\rf RS
\xv Waanyi, Karrwa, nanangkujarra yanyi-wiya.
\xe Waanyi and Garrwa, those two are both languages.
\rf RS
\xv Ngaraba bula, wanami, kamukamu, nanangkujarraa burrurri-wiyaa.
\xe Those two men are drinking grog.
\rf RS
\xv Durrajba ngawu nanangkujarra-anyi.
\sfx
\xe I'm afraid of those two.
\rf RS
\xv Nanangkujarran ngaki dara malukarra wadaba-baji.
\sfx
\xe Those two dogs of mine are expert goanna hunters.
\rf EF_R299EA3
\va
\sy nanangkuya
\cf nangkujarra
\cf kujarra
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt
\lf nana
\lf nanangkujarraa
\lf nanangkujarra-anyi

\lx nanangkurru
\mr nana-ng-kurru
\sf nan
\sn nanangkurru_CO.wav
\ps demonstrative
\pc
\sd spatial
\lt allative non-proximate form of demonstrative {nana}
\ge to(wards) that
\ge to(wards) those
\ge to there
\re that (to); those (to)
\so RS, CO, MB_LH14
\xv Jilaba ngamba, ngandu-wurru barri, nanangkurru kunda-wurru. 
\sfx
\xe We'll move to where there's shade now, over to that tree.
\rf RS
\xv Jilaba bula, ngakinkuya, ngada-nganja, ngaliyangi ngada-nganja, wanu-anyi. nanangkurru barri kara-wurru.
\xe Our two mothers, our mothers would both go to that rocky county to (get) that tobacco.
\rf rs2000-11
\xv Ngabama ninji waliji nayi, maman, nanangkurru badibadi-wurru, ngandaarra-wurru.  
\xe You take this meat and tucker over to that old person. To that old woman. 
\rf rs2000-09
\xv Ngamuyu-kiya ngawu jilaba nanangkurru, nyulu-kiya bijbi ngaan.
\xe If I were to go there, it might bite me.
\rf RS2000-10
\xv Kudaya yalu jilaba nanangkurru, kudanngirri-darra. "Budangku ngamba jila naniwii." Jungku yalu nanawunu Kanmangini.
\xe Some other Dreaming women [who were from a different country] went there. "We can't go any further that way." They stopped there at Kanmangi. 
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Kurrbali-wurru ngamba jilaba nanangkurru wabula kala-wurru.
\xe We went to that Kurrbali a long time ago, to the river.
\rf RS2004-untaped.
\xv Nambunyi ngamba jilaba nanangkurru langkurri.
\xe From here we are going north to that (place).
\rf RS
\xv Wawurran jila nanangkurru.
\xe The child went to that one.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Balyanga jila nanangkurru miyawurru! Biyaa ninya.
\xe Don't go towards that snake. It might bite you.
\rf MF_GB76
\xv Balyanga jila nanangkurru.
\sfx
\xe Don't go over there.
\rf MB_LH14
\va
\sy
\cf nangkurru
\nt naniwii
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt
\lf nana

\lx nanangkuya
\mr nana-ng-kuya
\hm
\sf
\sn
\ps noun
\pc
\sd spatial
\lt dual form of non-proximate demonstrative {nana}
\ge those two
\re
\so RS, GB
\xv Nanangkuya dara-wiya. 
\xe Those two dogs.
\rf GB
\xv Nanangkuya kadimirra, jawaji-nganja ngakinkanyi kakulu-nganja-anyi, ngawu, ngawu bulangi bujarra-nganja.
\sfx bujarra-nganyja.wav
\xe Those two young ones, who are brother's children, my young brother's children, me, I'm their aunt.
\rf rs2005-02
\xv Baraku-yanyba nurri bulanya nanangkuya yukalini, darru-wuya.
\xe We warm those two initiates in the smoke.
\rf rs2004-08a
\xv Nginngirri bulangka nanangkuya barri mungana-mungana-wunyi.
\xe Those two have been watching each other since sunset.
\rf GB
\xv Daba bulangka nanangkuya(a).
\sfx
\xe Those two had a fight.
\rf IS_GB
\xv Nanangkuya-anyi, bulangi.
\sfx
\xe It belongs to those two, (it's) theirs.
\rf IS_GB
\xv Winjika nanangkuya?
\xe Who are those two?
\rf MF_GB76
\va
\sy nanangkujarra
\cf nangkuya
\an

\dt


\lx nana-waan
\mr nana-waan
\sf nana-waan.wav
\ps demonstrative
\pc
\sd demonstrative
\lt plural form of non-proximate demonstrative {nana}
\ge those
\ge they
\re those
\so
\xv Nana-waan-kanyi, budangku yalu yakujbu.
\sfx nana-waankanyi#budangku yalu yakujbu.wav
\xe For the others, they didn't leave any.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Kuwada-yaan nana-waan, ramijbi yalu waduku ngaki, ramiramba.
\xe Those senseless ones, they broke my fishing line, ruined it.
\rf RS
\xv Nana-waan, banjana yalu jilaba, ngambalangi, jalanya. Narrunguja-yudu.
\xe Those (people), they are coming right behind us, with a truck.
\rf rs2002-13
\xv Ngaki mungkuji, Karrwa, nana-waan badibadi, wululuku.
\xe My relations are Garrwa, those old women (and) old men.
\rf rs2004-05
\xv Bayangarrinyi, jilaba yalu nana-waan kaku-anyi.
\xe Those ones have gone over to the west side (of the river) to fish.
\rf rs2005-05
\xv Nana-waan kudaya-waan, jilaba yalu bayinga.
\xe Those others, they are going on the west side. 
\rf rs2005-08b
\xv Mungkubayi, nana-waan-kanyi, Kangkalida-anyi Nyangka-anyi. 
\xe Burketown belongs to those Ganggalida and Nyangka people. 
\rf rs2005-09
\xv Birajba yalu, kujikaa, nana-waan jukajuka.
\xe They are singing those boys with Kujika songs.
\rf rs2004-07
\xv Budangku nurri najba nana-waan, narrunguju-yudu. Budangku yalu jilaba nangkurru.
\xe We didn't see anyone with a car. Nobody came here.
\rf rs2003-01
\xv Dajaya yalu ngambalanya nana-waani burrurri-darraa, Kalkudunguu. Dajaya yalu ngambalanya, jungku ngamba nawunu, Kanmangini, Waanyi-darra.
\xe Lest those Kalkudungu men beat us up, lest they fight us, we'll stop here at Kanmangi as we are Waanyi.
\xv Jarrba yalu dawurrumbu. Budangku yalu yakujbu, nana-waan-kanyi.
\sfx jarrba yalu dawurrumbu-they ate all.wav
\sfx budangku yalu yakujbu nana-waan-kanyi.wav
\xe The barramundi, she cooked it. They ate it all up. They didn't leave anything for anyone (else).
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Budangku ngali najba nana-waan. Jilaba yalu nana-wunyi.
\xe We didn't see anyone. They had gone from there.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku ngawu daba nana-waan.
\xe I didn't hit anyone.
\rf RS
\xv Dandaraba yalu nana-waan burrurri-darra, kirriya-darra. 
\xe Those men and women are following the river. 
\rf RS
\xv Kirriya-darra nana-waa.
\sfx
\xe Those women.
\rf GB
\xv Kudijbi ngawu nana-waana burrurri-darrana, yanjini. Murrku-darrana, kudijbi ngawu.
\xe I'll stay talking with those people. I'll be away for several days.
\rf RS2004-08a
\xv Nana-waan kudaya, wandajba yalu kularriya, marrkajini
\xe Those others, they walk around on the south side, hunting.
\rf RS2005-08b
\xv Winjika nanawaan?
\xe Who are those (ones)?
\rf MF_GB76
\xv Nana-wan yalu karrinja.
\xe Those ones are standing.
\rf PC_GB76
\va nana-waa
\sy
\cf naa-wa(n)
\cf -wa(a)(n)
\nt When in a negative sentence, marked by {budangku}, {nana-waan} may be non-referential 'anyone'.
\cp
\nq
\dt 07/Oct/2006
\lf nana

\lf nana-waan-kanyi

\lx nangalama
\mr nangalama
\hm
\sf
\sn
\ps noun
\pc
\sd kin
\lt subsection or 'skin' name of mother of {nularrima} woman or {balyarrinyi} man; straight marriage with {bulanyi} man; daughter of {nungarrima} woman and {yakimarri} man
\ge
\re
\so GB, EK, RS
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\va
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt

\dt
\lf


\lx nangangi
\mr na.nga-ngi
\sf nangangi.aif
\sn 1
\ps pronoun
\pc
\sd pronoun
\lt dative form of third person singular pronoun
\ge his
\ge her
\ge its
\ge for him
\ge for her
\ge for it
\re
\so RS, GB, CO
\xv Karrinja nangangi mundurrini.
\sfx karrinja nangangi mundurrini.aif
\xe (He) stood behind him.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Kunjunu balungka nanganginbunu.
\xe He has blood on his body. (Lit. On body (is) blood on him.)
\rf GB
\xv Ngakinkanyi bawa-nganja-anyi. Budangku ngaki, nangangi.
\xe That belongs to my big brother. It's not mine, it's his.
\rf rs2000-10
\xv Bakamba nyulu, wadabaa, nangangini kuwii. Lalujbu nyulu, jilaba barri nyulu.
\xe The goanna busts through (from its burrow) using its head. It comes out, then it walks around.
\rf rs2002-14
\xv Mirramba nyulu nangangi nana mukura.
\xe He's making himself that spear.
\rf rs2004-04
\xv Kuujbu yalu nangangi.
\xe They were looking for him.
\rf rs2004-06
\xv Nanganginburru.
\xe Towards him (or her).
\rf RS
\xv Nguwajba nyulu nangangi dawirri-nganja-anyi, nanangkani kirriyaa.
\xe That woman is jealous of her younger sister.
\rf GB
\xv Kawa-najba nurri nukami nangangi. 
\xe We came across his tracks. 
\rf RS2005-01
\xv Jijajba ngawu nangangi.
\xe I played a trick on him.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku ngawu jiringkijbi nana. Mayi ngaki, nangangi.
\xe I don't recognize that one. It might be mine, or his.
\rf rs2004-01
\xv Jila ngawu nanganginbunu.
\xe I'm going with him.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Nangangi.
\sfx
\xe (It's) his.
\rf IS_GB
\xv Nangangi bawa-nganja nyulu daba.
\sfx
\xe He hit his (own) brother.
\rf IS_GB
\xv Bulangka bawa-nganja daba nangangini.
\sfx
\xe The two brothers fought each other.
\rf IS_GB
\va
\sy
\cf 
\nt
\cp Wambaya {nanga} 'oblique third person masculine pronoun'
\nq 
\dt 21/Sep/2006
\lf nanganginbunu
\lf nanganginburru
\lf nangangini
\lf nangka

\lx nanganginbunu
\mr nangangi-n-bu-nu
\hm
\sv
\sf
\sn
\ps pronoun
\pc
\sd grammar
\la
\lt locative form of third person sungular pronoun {nyulu}
\ge on him/her/it
\ge over him/her/it
\re
\so GB
\xv Kunjunu balungka nanganginbunu. 
\sfx
\xe There's blood all over his body. (Lit. on body blood on him)
\rf GB_IS
\va
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt
\cp
\nq

\lf nangangi

\lx nanganja
\mr nanganyja
\sf nanganyja.wav
\sf nanganyja02.wav
\sf nanganyja03.wav
\sf nanganja_CO.wav
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd transfer
\lt Xerg come to have Y
\ge catch
\ge fetch
\ge gain
\ge get
\ge obtain
\ge pick up
\ge take
\re
\so EF, GB, RS, EK, MF_CO, MB_LH13, MB_LH14
\xv Nanganja wanamin.
\sfx nanganyja-warnami.wav
\xe Fetch water.
\rf EF
\xv Budangku yalu nanganjaa.
\sfx budangku_yalu_nanganjaaRS.wav
\xe They can't take (it).
\rf RS2002-15
\xv Nanganja nyulu kakun.
\sfx nanganja nyulu kakun.wav
\xe She caught a fish.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Nanganja waliji bayiki-nanja.
\sfx nanganyja_waliji_bag-nanyja-R299b2.wav
\xe Get the meat out of the bag.
\rf EF
\xv Wanami ngaki nanganja!
\sfx wanami-ngaki-nanganja_CO.wav
\sfx wanami-ngaki-nanganja_02_CO.wav
\xe Get me some water!
\rf Elsie Moreland OSBORNE_C02-000165B.TMP
\xv Ja nyulu nanganja ngaki nangkani wululukuu. 
\xe This old man will get it for me.
\rf RS2005-08a
\xv Nanganja ngawu kumbulungka wanami-yudu.  
\xe I'm fetching a bottle of water.
\rf RS2002-12
\xv Maninja nana, maninja. Balyangka nanganjaa!
\sfx
\xe That belongs to someone else, (it's) someone else's. Don't take (it)!
\rf rs2004-04
\xv Maninja yakujbu! Yakujbu! Yaluwangi. Maninja. Balyanga nanganjama. Dajaya yalu ninya. Maninja.
\xe It's belongs to someone else, leave it, leave it. It belongs to them. It's theirs. Don't pick it up. Otherwise they might attack you, as it's theirs (not yours).
\rf RS2000-08
\xv Nanganja-anyi ngawu namirra ngaki, Kayawana-wurru ngawu jilaba. 
\xe I've got to get my money (so) I'm going to Kiana.
\rf RS
\xv Mayi ninya nanganja, kaburrukajaa. Nanganja-anyi ninya, marrijbi manii. Bijbi ninya.
\xe A crocodile might get you. It will get you, grab hold of you with its claws (hand), bite you.
\rf RS
\xv Burrbijbi nyulu wululuku. Kannga nyulu. Nanganjana nana-waan. Warrwarri.
\xe The old man raced back and picked up those kids.
\rf RS
\xv Ninji jilanji nanganjana wanamini.
\xe You go and get water yourself.
\rf GB
\xv Nanganja maman ngaki!
\sfx nanganja-maman-ngaki_CO.wav
\xe Get me some food.
\rf MF_CO (OSBORNE_C02-000165B.TMP)
\xv Najba ngawu nanganja-wurru kaku-wurru.
\xe I saw him catching fish.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Nanganjama!
\xe Get (it)!
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Nanaganja ngawu jangun.
\sfx
\xe I'm getting fire wood.
\rf IS_GB
\xv Nanganjaa ngawu wanami, jadimbi jangu.
\xe I'll fetch water and put out the fire.
\rf EF_R299Ea3
\sy
\cf kilimbi
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt 05/Sep/2006
\lf nanganjaa
\lf nanganjama
\lf nanganjana
\lf nanganja-anyi
\lf nanganja-wurru
\sn 2
\ps verb
\pc
\sd possession
\lt Xerg (man) take Y as wife
\ge marry
\ge take as wife
\re
\so RS
\xv Ninji, nanangkanyi bawa-nganja-anyi, ja-ninji nanganja.
\xe You, you will marry that (woman) who belonged (=was married) to your elder brother.
\rf rs2002-14
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\va
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt This verb is used to denote action of man in taking a wife, but not that of woman having a husband.
\cp
\nq

\lx nangka
\mr na-ngka
\hm 2
\sf
\sn 1
\ps pronoun
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt third person singular reflexive/reciprocal pronoun
\ge himself
\ge herself
\ge itself
\re
\so RS, EK
\xv Kudumbu nangka rami.
\sfx
\xv He shut his eyes.
\rf RS2005-01
\xv Burrka-nijbi nangka.
\sfx Burrka-nijbi-nangka.wav
\xe It covered himself (with dirt) using his tail.
\rf RS2004-07
\xv Wunamba barri nangka jalun.
\sfx wunamba barri nangka jalun_RS.wav
\xe She's now stretching out her arm.
\rf RS2002-11b
\xv Lalujbu nyulu, burra-daba nangka.
\xe He would get up and then fall down again.
\rf rs2002-13
\xv Kudanba nangka wululukuu. Janybijbi nangka, kudanba nangka. Nangkani wululukuu.
\xe The old man died. This old man passed away, died.
\rf rs2004-01
\xv Wadamba nangka, muwan.
\xe He fills his belly.
\rf rs2002-14
\xv Dabarraba nyulu binjirri, winjaraba nangka.
\xe He boils the paperbark leaves and pours the water on himself.
\rf rs2004-03
\xv Makarraba nangka, wadabaa. Barrulkijini.
\xe The goanna buries itself (under the ground) and gets fat.
\rf rs2003-03
\xv Jukulini nangka birajba wululukuu, kuyii buka-aduu.
\xe The old man with his grey hair is singing himself (clapping) a boomerang.
\rf rs2004-05
\xv Dajkanyi nangka, warrakujini.
\sfx
\xe He'll kill himself in a fit of madness.
\rf RS
\xv Ngadijbi nangka burrurrii, durrajini.
\xe The man is hiding himself as he's afraid.
\rf RS2004-04
\xv Mudamudajibi nangka duka. Duka-nanja nangka langandaba.
\xe He tied (the rope) around his neck. He hanged himself by the neck.
\rf RS2005-08b
\xv Budangku nangka mularrijbi jamba-wunyi. Namanyba naan.
\xe It (motorcar) couldn't lift itself out from the sand. It was stuck.
\rf RS2004-08
\xv Juraa nangka muwan.
\xe He's feeling sorry for himself.
\rf RS
\xv Kurrijbi nangka nanangkani daraa.
\xe That dog is scratching himself.
\rf EK (ML notes)
\va
\sy
\cf
\nt
\cp
\nq

\lx nangkani
\mr na-ng-ka-ni
\sf nangkani_CO.wav
\sn 1
\ps demonstrative
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt ergative form of proximate demonstrative {na-}, {nayi}
\ge this
\ge the
\ge he
\ge she
\ge it
\re this ; the ; he ; she ; it
\so RS, GB, CO
\xv Nangkani nanganja.
\sfx nangkani-nanganja_CO.wav
\xe She got it.
\rf OSBORNE_C02-000165B.TMP
\xv Daba nurri ramijbi, nangkani wuliwulii.
\xe We break it off by striking it with this small round rock.
\rf rs2002-04-13
\xv Nyulu-kiya bijbi ngaa nangkani daraa.
\sfx
\xe This dog would have bitten me.
\rf rs2000-10
\xv Ngabama nyulu nangkurru nangkani kadimirraa. Waanyii kirriyaa. Wadukarraa.
\xe This little one brought (it) here. The little Waanyi girl did.
\rf rs2002-04-3
\xv Kaku nyulu wilijirri, nangkani burrurrii.
\sfx kaku nyulu wilijirri nangkani burrurrii.wav
\xe This man is pulling in a fish.
\rf RS2005-4
\xv Ja nyulu nanganja ngaki nangkani wululukuu.
\xe This old man will get it for me.
\rf RS2005-08a
\xv Daba nyulu ngaan nangkani kirriyaa.
\xe This woman hit me.
\rf RS2005-06
\xv Nangkani barri wuliwulii, wiyala ngawu.
\xe Then with this round stone, I grind it up.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku nungka karrbijbi, nayi waliji, mujii nangkani.
\xe We can't cut this meat, with this blunt (one).
\rf RS
\xv Kalijkanyi niyanya mukuraa, nangkani, burrurrii, kijibajii.
\xe This angry man wants to spear us.
\rf RS
\xv Windijbi ngawu ninya, nangkani bunanganyii, kunybaa walijii. 
\xe I'll give you this bream (which is) good meat.
\rf RS200312-01
\va
\sy
\cf nanangkani

\lf nayi

\lx nangkanyi
\mr na-ng-kanyi
\sf
\sn 1
\ps demonstrative
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt dative form of proximate demonstrative {na-}, {nayi}
\ge for this
\ge of this
\ge belonging to this (one)
\ge this one's
\ge about this
\re
\so RS
\xv Kunyba nayi kundan nangkanyi ngalya-anyi.
\xe This bush is good for this sickness.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku bula ngurrubu ngaan, nangkanyi wanami-yanyi. 
\xe They didn't ask me for this drink.
\rf RS
\xv Darraku nayi, kanba nayi, nangkanyi kala-anyi.
\xe This leafy tree and this grass belongs to this country.
\rf rs2002-07
\xv Jawikajba yalu ngambalanya, nangkanyi kala-anyi.
\xe They ask us about this land.
\rf RS
\xv Nanajba nyulu julakii nangkanyi kaku-wanyi.
\xe The bird is waiting for this fish.
\rf RS
\xv Ngurrubu nurri milirrimbi nangkanyi kujika-anyi. 
\xe We are telling about this {kujika} ceremony. 
\rf RS
\xv Milirrimbi ninji ngaan nangkanyi kaku-anyi.
\xe You teach me about this fish.
\rf RS
\xv Burrbijbi ngawu, milwamilwa, durrajini. Nangkanyi kirriya-anyi. 
\xe I took off looking around behind me, frightened. It was over this woman. 
\rf RS
\xv Jungku ninji, nanajba, nangkanyi waliji-anyi.
\xe You sit and wait for this meat.
\rf rs2002-09
\xv Bangkijbi nurri, nayi jiba, dirrbu-anyi, nangkanyi ngulungka-anyi.
\xe We pull off some bark, this paperbark, for the honey, for this sugarbag.
\rf RS
\xv Winjikaa ninya windijbi nangkanyi mama-anyi?
\xe Who gave you this money?
\rf RS
\xv 
\xe
\rf
\va
\sy
\cf nanangkanyi
\nt
\cp
\nq also 'here'?

\lx nangkurru
\mr na-ng-kurru
\sf nangkurru.wav
\sf nangkurru02.wav
\sf nangkurru-hither.wav
\sf nangkurru_co.wav
\ps demonstrative
\pc
\sd spatial
\lt towards location of speaker; allative form of proximate demonstrative {na-}
\ge here
\ge to here
\ge towards here
\ge hither
\ge to this (one)
\re
\so GB, RS, CO
\xv Jila nungka nangkurru.
\sfx Jila-nungka-nangkurru_CO.wav
\xe Let's come here.
\rf OSBORNE_C02-000165B.TMP
\xv Budangku yalu jilaba nangkurru.
\xe Nobody came here.
\rf rs2003-01
\xv Jilaba nimba nangkurru. Mukunjana-anyi.
\xe You two go to this one, for lunch. 
\rf rs2002-03
\xv Budangku ninji kannga nangkurru. Dajaya ngawu ninya, jadiyadiyimbi barrkuu.
\xe Don't you come back here, or I'll beat you up, give you a good hiding with a nullanulla.
\rf rs2005-01
\xv Bindawarra kadimirra, ngabama nangkurru ngaki.
\xe The little bag, bring it over here for me.
\rf rs2002-03
\xv Bungkana, jilaba ngawu nangkurru, windijbi nyulu ngan waliji-anyi. 
\xe Yesterday, I came here, and he gave me some meat. 
\rf RS2000-10
\xv Jalanya ninji jilaba nangkurru. Budangku ninji jilaba nangkurru wabula. Jala-wanyi ninji.
\xe You came here recently. You haven't been coming here for a long time. You're a new-comer.
\rf RS
\xv Jilaba nyulu nangkurru yanyi-anyi. 
\xe He come here for some meeting.
\rf RS
\xv Jilaba nimba nangkurru wajka, kala-wurru. 
\xe You two come down here, to the river. 
\rf RS
\xv Jilanji kanngama, nangkurru.
\xe Come back here!
\rf GB
\va

\lx nangurrbuwala
\mr nangurrbuwala
\sf nangulbuwarra-02.wav
\sf nangulbuwarra.wav
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc nangulbuwarra1.jpg
\pc nangulbuwarra2.jpg
\pc nangulbuwarra3.jpg
\sn 1
\sd animal
\la Osphranter antilopinus
\lt adult male Kangaroo or Wallaroo
\ge buck Kangaroo
\ge buck Wallaroo
\re
\so RS, GB
\xv Kudijbi nyulu nana nangurrbuwala.
\sfx kudijbi nyulu nana nangulbuwarra.wav
\xe That buck kangaroo was lying asleep. 
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Jilaba-nyulu nyubana, waliji-anyi. Binanyba nyulu, kudijkurru, walijin. Nangurrbuwala. Wululuku.
\xe He's going along alone looking for game. He's sneaking up on an animal that's asleep. It's a big old man kangaroo.
\rf rs2002-13
\xv Jangajba ngawu, waliji-yanyi. Walijin, kudijbi nyulu ngurruwijbi, nangurrbuwala.
\xe I was sneaking up on the animal. The big old kangaroo, it was lying there snoring.
\rf RS
\xv Kalijbi nurri, nangurrbuwala, mukuraa.
\xe We spear the old man kangaroo.
\rf RS
\va nangurrbawala
\sy
\cf maraji
\cf badakalinya
\cf bidirrika
\cf junabu
\cf wadal
\nt Pronounced [nangudbuwala].
\nt Described by Roy Seccin as "from hill country, old man kangaroo" (RS_RG99)
\cp
\nq Garrwa {nangurrbawala}.
\dt 19/Sep/2006

\lx naniwii
\mr naniwii
\sf naniwii.wav
\ps noun
\pc
\sd direction
\lt moving away from point of reference 
\ge that way
\ge away from
\ge further away
\re
\so RS2005-01, CO, GB
\xv Budangku yalu jilaba naniwii.
\sfx budangku yalu jilaba naniwii.wav
\xe They couldn't go any further away.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Jila ninji naniwii, ngali jungku nayi yanjini.
\xe You go away, we are having a talk.
\rf IS_GB
\xv Naniwii jilanji!
\sfx naniwii-jilanji_CO.wav
\xe Go further away!
\rf OSBORNE_C02-000165B.TMP
\va
\sy
\cf
\nt Used in contrast with 'this way' indicating direction towards speaker.
\cp
\nq   karurri ; south? east?

\lx -nanja
\mr -nanyja
\sf
\sn 1
\ps suffix
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt
\ge from
\ge by
\ge over
\ge because of
\ge out of
\re
\so GB, RS
\xv Nanganja waliji bayiki-nanja.
\sfx nanganyja_waliji_bag-nanyja-R299b2.wav
\xe Take the meat out of the bag.
\rf EF
\xv Daba yalungka mama-nanja.
\xe They are fighting over food.
\rf RS2005-02
\xv Kurrijbi nyulu manii. Nanganja nyulu milbu. Jamba-nanja nyulu marijbi.
\xe He digs with his front paws. He grabs hold of the frog. He grabs it from the ground.
\rf RS2005-05
\xv Wanyinbu-nanja ninji daba naan?
\xe Why (what from) are you hitting this one?
\rf RS2005-06
\xv Kingkarri-nanja, walajba ninji nurriyanya, jungku-wurru.
\xe From above, you'll look down on us sitting (here).
\rf RS2005-08a
\xv "Wanyinkanyi ninji daba nan, maju-nyanja-anyi?" "Waliji-nanja."
\xe "For what thing belonging to your big sister did you hit this one?" "Because of the meat."
\rf RS
\xv Wilijirri ngawu jangu-nanja.
\xe I pulled it out of the fire.
\rf RS2002-02
\xv Mama nan diba-diba kunda-nanja. Yirrbinkijbi kunda-wunyi, langankini, jamba-wurru.
\xe The fruit was struck down from the tree. It fell from the tree where it was hanging, to the ground.
\rf GB
\xv Burrurri-nanja, nguwajini, daba bulangka kirriyaa.
\xe Over a man, being jealous the two women are fighting.
\rf RS2002-03
\xv Balunbu ngawu, yujurru. Maman, muwa-nanja.
\xe I vomited up vomit, food from the stomach.
\rf RS2002-08
\xv Walijbi ngawu janyi-wunyi barri, muwa-nanja. Balunbu ngawu.
\xe I have it come out from my mouth, from the stomach. I'm vomiting.
\rf rs2002-04
\xv Wilijirri nyulu, nyungka-nanja.
\xe She dragged him by the hair.
\rf rs2002-04
\xv Duka-nanja nyulu marijbi, daraa, kijibajii.
\xe That dog, that savage one, grabbed him by the throat.
\rf RS2005-01
\xv Wadaba, marijbi ngawu, bambularra-nanja. 
\xe The goanna, I grabbed hold of it by the tail.
\rf RS2000-03
\va
\sy
\cf -wunyi
\nt

\ge make soft
\ge soften
\re
\so RS, JD93

\xe You soften it so you can eat it.
\rf RS

\xe He softened it by pounding it.
\rf RS
\xv Nanjarr-nanjarrba nurri wuliwulii, yamarrina.
\xe We used to soften it by (striking it) with a round rock on a flat grinding stone.
\rf RS

\lx nanka
\mr nanka
\hm 1
\sf nangka_RS.wav
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd ELEMENTS
\sd water
\lt small body of surface water
\ge lagoon
\ge pool
\ge puddle
\ge billabong
\ge swamp
\re
\so DJ93, RS, GB
\xv Nanka, wanami-yudu kadimirra-yudu, wanami-yudu.
\xe {Nanka} is a small body of water.
\rf rs2003-01
\va nankawa
\sy
\cf dumularra
\cf jakuli
\cf wanami
\nt Recorded by Dymock (1993) as "lagoon"
\cp Garrwa {nangkawa}
\nq

\lx nanyalu
\mr nanyalu
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc tea.jpg
\sd food
\lt tea leaves and infusion made with tea leaves
\ge tea
\re
\so RS, GB
\xv Dabarraba nyulu nanyalu ngambalangi. Ngarakanyi ngamba.
\xe He's making (cooking) tea for us to drink.
\rf RS
\xv Dabarraba nyulu niyanya duka, nangkani nanyaluu ngarrangarraa.
\xe This hot tea is burning our throats.
\rf RS2004-04
\xv Ngarrangarramba wanamin jangunu. Nanyalu-anyi.
\xe Heat the water on the fire. For tea.
\rf RS
\xv Mamanumbu ninji nanyalu. Budangku ninji ngabaa.
\xe You forgot the tea. You didn't bring it.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf yilaka
\nt
\cp Wambaya {nyanyalu}

\lf


\lx narri
\mr narri
\sf
\sn 1
\ps pronoun
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt Second person plural nominative pronoun
\ge you
\ge you mob
\ge you all
\re
\so EF, RS, GB, CO, MB_LH13
\xv Jilaba narri.
\sfx jilaba_narri-you_all_go.wav
\xe You all go.
\rf RS-RG1999
\xv Jungkumu narri kaja-darra.
\xe Sit down, you lot!
\rf GB
\xv Jungku narri, nawunu jambana.
\xe You all sit down here on the ground!
\rf GB
\xv Kanngama narri! Balyanga narri wanami-wurru jilanji!
\xe Come back! Don't you go near the water.
\rf GB
\xv Rangkijbi narri karaa, kudanba, miyan.
\xe You lot pelted the snake with stones and killed it.
\rf RS
\xv Mudinyi nana niji. Budangku narri nijarrijbi niji. Nijarrijbi narri mudinyi.
\xe That name is taboo. You don't call his name. You refer to him as "the deceased".
\rf RS
\xv Winjika narrimi?
\sfx
\xe Who are you lot?
\rf IS_GB
\xv Narri langku jungku.
\sfx
\xe You lot are sitting to (our) north.
\rf EF_R299EA1
\va
\sy
\cf ninji
\cf nimbala
\nt Used to refer to more than two people.
\cp
\nq
\dt 29/Aug/2006
\lf narriyangi
\lf narriyangka
\lf narriyanya

\lx narriyangi
\mr narri-ya-ngi
\hm
\sf
\sn
\ps pronoun
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt Second person plural dative pronoun
\ge for you (all)
\ge to you (all)
\ge your
\ge yours
\ge belonging to you mob
\re
\so RS, CO
\xv Kannga ngawu narriyangi.
\sfx
\xe I have come back to you mob.
\rf RS2003-02
\xv Yanyba ngawu narriyangi: "Waanyi ngawu burrurrin".
\sfx
\xe I say to you: "I'm a Waanyi man".
\rf RS
\xv Nayi narriyangi raji?
\xe Is this your home?
\rf GB
\xv Maninja ngawu kannga nangkurru narriyangi
\xe I've come back here to you mob empty-handed.
\rf RS
\xv Manku nurri, yanyi narriyangi, mandaki-anyi. 
\xe We understand your white-fella language.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku ngawu jijajba. Diindi ngawu yanyba narriyangi.
\xe I'm not lying. I'm telling you (really) straight.
\rf RS
\xv Nanganja ngawu wanami narriyangi.
\xe I'm getting water for you mob.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Narriyangi dara.
\xe Your dog.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Narri, nanganjama dara narriyangi.
\xe You lot, grab you dog.
\rf MF_GB76
\va
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt Used to refer to more than two people.
\cp
\nq
