\mr narri-ya-ngka
\hm
\sf
\sn 1
\ps pronoun
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt Second person plural reflexive & reciprocal pronoun
\ge yourselves
\ge you yourselves
\re
\so RS, GB
\xv Narri, daba narriyangka jukulii. Rangkijbi narriyangka jukulii.
\sfx
\xe You mob, you are fighting (each other) with boomerangs. You're pelting each other with boomerangs.

\sy
\cf nganyingka
\cf nimbalangka
\an
\nt Used to address more than two people, when performing action on themselves or each other.

\lf narri
\lf narriyangi
\lf narriyanya

\lx narriyanya
\mr narri-ya-nya
\sf
\sn 1
\ps pronoun
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt Second person plural accusative form of pronoun {narri}
\ge you
\ge you lot
\ge you all
\ge you mob
\re
\so RS, EK, MB_LH13
\xv Ngira narriyanya, ngila-darra. Jarriyamba.
\xe He'll steal you girls away. Carry (you) off.
\rf rs2002-07
\xv Najba ngawu narriyanya, kingkarrinyi.
\xe I'll see you lot from above.
\rf RS2005-08a
\xv Ngabaa ngali narriyanya raji-wurru barri.
\xe We are taking you lot back home now.
\rf rs2004-untaped
\xv Yakujbu ngawu narriyanya, dururruru, mudunama.
\xe I leave you tomorrow morning at first light.
\rf RS
\xv Ngurrubu nurri milirrimbi nangkanyi kujika-anyi.  Ngurru-kanyi. Milirrimbi nurri narriyanya.
\xe We are explaining about this {kujika} ceremony. (We) want to tell you and teach you (about it).
\rf RS
\xv Budangku yalu narriyanya windijbi, budangkun namirra-anyi.
\xe They can't give you any, there's no money.
\rf RS
\xv Budangkun ngawu ngabaa narriyanya.
\xe I won't take you lot.
\rf RS
\xv Kijibaji nayi dara. Bijbi barri narriyanya.
\xe This is a cheeky dog. It will bite you lot now.
\rf EK (ML notes)
\va
\sy
\cf ninya
\cf nimbalanya
\nt Used to address more than two people, when object of some action.
\cp
\nq

\lx narrunguja
\mr narrunguja
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc car.jpg
\sd manufacture
\lt
\ge vehicle
\ge car
\ge truck
\re
\so RS, GB
\xv Narrunguja-yudu.
\sfx narrunguja-yudu.wav
\xe With a vehicle.
\rf RS
\xv Banjana narrungujana. 
\xe Behind the vehicle.
\rf rs2004-08a
\xv Mayi yalu barimbi ngambalangi narrunguja.
\xe They might wreck our vehicle.
\rf rs
\xv Budangku nurri najba nana-waan, narrunguju-yudu. Budangku yalu jilaba nangkurru.
\xe We didn't see anyone with a car. Nobody came here.
\rf rs2003-01
\xv Wawurra-darra nyulu burra-daba. Wawurra-darra, bikali nyulu narrungujaa. 
\xe He's dropping off the kids. He's taking the kids with the truck.
\rf rs2005-05
\xv Nanajba ngamba nanangkanyi narrunguja-wanyi, wuluku-wanyi.
\xe We are waiting for that big truck.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf
\nt Breen (W-G vocab) records as {narunguja}
\cp Wambaya

\lf narrungujaa
\lf narrungujana
\lf narrunguja-wanyi
\lf narrunguja-yudu

\lx na-wan
\mr na-wa(n)
\hm
\sf
\sn 1
\ps demonstrative
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt plural form of proximate demonstrative
\ge these
\re these
\so RS
\xv Na-waan warrwarri kuwada-yaan.
\xe These kids have no sense.
\rf RS
\xv Warrakuujbu yalu naa-wan, barriyi, mungamba. Ngarakini yalu jungku, kamukamu yalu ngaraba.
\xe These (fellows) went mad last night. They were drinking. They were drinking beer.
\rf RS
\xv Ngabaa nyulu na-waan nangkurru, kannga nyulu. Na-waan, yakujbu nawunu.
\xe He's bringing them (=these ones) back here. He's coming back. These ones, he's dropping (them) off here.
\rf RS
\xv Kanungku yalu na-waan.
\xe These (people) are approaching.
\rf RS
\xv Dabarra-kanyi yalu, walijin wingki, na-waanii ngilaa, kadimirraa ngilaa.
\sfx
\xe These little girls have to cook the raw meat.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku ngamba, ngurrubu na-waan ngila-darra.
\xe We won't tell these girls anything.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku nyulu windijbi na-wan burrurri-darra, namira-anyi.
\xe He didn't give these men any money.
\rf RS
\xv Na-wan ngila-darra.
\sfx nawan-ngila-darra-RS2002T09a.wav
\xe These girls.
\rf RS
\xv Wajarrijbi yalu kaku, na-wani ngila-darraa.
\sfx
\xe These young girls are fishing.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku nurri mankuu nawan burrurri-darra.
\xe We don't understand those men.
\rf RS
\va na-waan
\va naa-wan
\va naa-waan
\sy
\cf nana-wan
\cf -wa(n)
\an
\nt The length of the vowel 'a' in this word varies between short and long.
\cp
\nq

\pc

\lt husband
\ge husband
\re husband
\so

\xe They are jealous of each other. They are fighting over their husbands.

\xv Budangku nurri yanyba, kadu-nganja. ngunyarri-nganja, nawi-nganja.
\xe (When a person dies) we others can't speak, like the dead person's father-in-law, mother-in-law or husband.
\rf RS
\xv Mijbi bulangka, nawi-nganjaa, mangkarri-nganjaa.
\xe They are swearing at each other, the husband and wife.

\lx nawunu
\mr na-wu-nu
\sf
\sn 1
\ps demonstrative
\pc
\sd spatial
\lt locative form of proximate demonstrative {na-}
\ge here
\ge at this (one)
\ge on this (one)
\re
\so RS, GB, CO, MB_LH13
\xv Jungku yalu nawunu, yanjini barri.
\xe They were sitting here talking.
\rf rs2003-01
\xv Dajaya yalu ngambalanya, jungku ngamba nawunu, Kanmangini, Waanyi-darra.
\xe Lest they fight us, we'll stay here at Kanmangi as we are Waanyi.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Dabarraba ngamba nawunu jangunu.
\xe We are cooking it here on the fire.
\rf RS2004-01
\xv Jila-kana. Jungku ninji wuja nawunu ngakinbunu.
\xe Don't go. Stay here with me.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku yalu jungku nawunu wuja. Jilalaba yalu.
\sfx
\xe They don't stay put here. They walk around all the time.
\rf RS
\xv Jungku narri, nawunu jambana.
\xe You all sit down here on the ground!
\rf GB
\xv Jungku ngawu nawunu kinngarrini, liwi-mukunu.
\sfx
\xe I'm sitting here in the smoke to keep mosquitoes away.
\rf GB
\xv Yunngumbu-kiya ngawu jungku nawunu.
\xe I may stay here for a long time.
\rf MF+EM_CO

\sy

\lx ngaa
\mr nga
\hm
\sf
\sn 1
\ps pronoun
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt first person singular accusative form of pronoun {ngawu}
\ge me
\re
\so EF, GB, RS
\xv Wanyingkanyi ninji ngaa laluwumbu?
\sfx
\xe Why did you wake me up?
\rf GB
\xv Windi ngaa kundaa!
\sfx
\xe Give me a stick!
\rf GB
\xv Nyulu-kiya bijbi ngaa nangkani daraa.
\sfx
\xe This dog would have bitten me.
\rf rs2000-10
\xv Ngakin bulungu wuluku barri, banyajba barri nyulu ngaa.
\xe My child is big now, he's now bigger than me.
\rf GB
\xv Diba ngaa nanangkani burrurrii, karaa.
\xe That man struck me with a stone.
\rf GB
\xv Kuluu ngaa windingi, daya-anyi ngawu jangun.
\xe Give me the axe so I can chop wood.
\rf GB
\xv Daraa ngan bijbi.
\xe A dog bit me.
\rf MF_GB76
\xv Daraa ngaan najba.
\sfx
\xe A dog saw me.
\rf EF_R299EB1
\va nga
\va ngaan
\va ngan

\cf ngaliyanya
\cf ngambalanya

\lx ngaan

\sf ngaan.wav
\sf ngaan-me_R299b2.wav
\ps pronoun
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt first person singular accusative form of pronoun {ngawu}
\ge me
\re me
\so RS
\xv Budangku nyulu ngaan najba.
\sfx budangku nyulu ngaan najba.wav
\sfx budangku nyulu ngaan najba-02.wav
\xe He didn't see me.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Janguu ngaan bakarrijbi nukamin, danyali. Nijbijbi ngawu. Budangku ngawu najba. Bakarrijbi nyulu ngaan.
\xe The hot coals burned me on the foot. I stood on it, I didn't see it. It burned me.
\rf rs2003-05
\xv Jilaba nyulu, banyajba nyulu ngaan.
\xe He's walking, he's passing me by.
\rf rs2004-04
\xv Bijbi nyulu ngaan kijibajii. 
\xe The cheeky one (ant) bit me.
\rf rs2004-04
\xv Daba nyulu ngaan burru-daba, barrkuu.
\xe He hit me and knocked me down with a nullanulla.
\rf rs2004-03
\xv Bajalijbi nyulu warrki jila-kurru. "Jilaba nyulu warrki. Binanyba nyulu ngaan. Binanyba. Warrkii."
\xe He (wallaby) smells a dingo coming. "There's a dingo coming. He is hunting me. The dingo is after me."
\rf rs2002-01
\xv Kadimirraa birakii ngaan bijbi nukamin kadimirraa.
\xe Little ants are biting me on the foot. Tiny ones.
\rf rs2005-06
\xv Windijbi ja nyulu ngaan kara-anyi.
\xe He will give me money.
\rf RS2002-07
\va ngaa

\cf ngaliyanya
\cf ngambalanya
\cf nurriyanya

\lf ngawu

\lx ngaba
\mr ngaba
\hm 1
\sf ngaba.wav
\sf ngaba02.wav
\sf ngaba03.wav
\sf ngabaa.wav
\sf ngabaa-bring_R299b2.wav
\ps verb
\pc
\sd motion
\sd hold (holding and transfer)
\sd transfer
\lt Xerg cause Y to move along with X
\ge carry
\ge shoulder
\ge bring
\ge have
\ge take
\re
\so RS, GB, EF, LM
\xv Ngabama!
\sfx ngaba_ma-bring.wav
\xe Bring it!
\rf RS-RG1999
\xv Mama ngalingi ngabama!
\sfx mama_ngalingi_ngabama.wav
\xe Bring us food.
\rf RS-RG1999
\xv Ngaba wanami.
\sfx ngaba_warnami-bring_waterR299b2.wav
\xe Bring water!
\rf EF_R299B2
\xv Ngaki ngaba wanami!
\sfx
\xe Bring me water!
\rf EF_R299B2
\xv Budangku nyulu ngabaa.
\sfx budangku nyulu ngabaa.wav
\xe He doesn't carry one.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Ngaba nyulu ngaan narrungujaa, kularra, raji-wurru, barrawu-wurru.
\xe He took me home by car, south to (my) place, to the station.
\rf RS
\xv Ngaba nyulu yaluwanya, lungkajii, kudumbu. 
\sfx
\xe The policeman took them and locked them up.
\rf RS2005-02
\xv Ngaba-kiya ninji, wanu nganyi, bulinja-anyi.
\xe You should have brought it, your tobacco, to smoke.
\rf RS2004-04
\xv Jukuli ngawu ngabaa, karrilana.
\xe I carry my boomerang on my hip.
\rf RS
\xv Ngaba-ngaba nungka! Nangkurru. Kingkarri barri nungka langan-daba!
\xe Let's bring it here. Then let's hang it up high.
\rf RS
\xv Ngabaa nurri bulaka, karurri, nukamii, mandakii wululukuu. Mungkuji ngaki.
\xe We took the cattle east, on foot, (with) the old white man. He was my boss.
\rf RS2002-10
\xv Mangkarri-nganja nyulu yakujbu, ngaba nyulu yingka-anyi.
\xe He left his (own) wife, and took another's.
\rf RS
\xv Wayi barri ninji ngaba maman?
\xe Have you brought any food?

\xe He's bringing his wife.

\xe We are sitting talking in the cool shade.

\lx ngaka
\mr ngaka
\sf ngaka.wav
\sf ngaka02.wav
\ps pronoun
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt first person singular reflexive form of pronoun {ngawu}
\ge myself
\ge me
\re
\so RS, GB, EF, EK, JD
\xv Yurru-kadi ngaka wanamini.
\sfx yurru-kadi ngaka wanamini.wav
\xe I'm getting into the water. (lit. I'm putting myself into the water.)
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Bajalijbi ngaka manin.
\xe I can smell my hands.
\rf rs2000-09
\xv Makarraba ngaka, bulinjaa.
\sfx makarraba ngaka bulinjaa.wav
\xe I'll cover myself with watergrass.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Ja ngaka durramba.
\sfx ja-ngaka-durramba.wav
\xe I'll get frightened.
\rf EF
\xv Wakadaba ngaka, mani, janja-yudu.
\sfx
\xe I wash my hands with soap.
\rf RS2000
\xv Budangku ngaka minimbi.
\xe I won't show myself.
\rf RS2004-untaped
\xv Kuujbu ngawu kunda-anyi, kurrijkanyi ngaka mundirri.
\xe I'm looking for a stick to scratch my back (with).
\rf RS
\xv Kurrijbi ngaka manii.
\xe I'm scratching myself with my hand.
\rf EK (ML notes)
\xv Najba ninji nga wakada-kurru ngaka-wurru?
\xv Did you see me washing myself?
\rf GB

\lx ngaki
\mr ngaki
\sf ngaki_RS.wav
\sf ngaki.wav
\sf ngaki03.wav
\sn 1
\ps pronoun
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt first person singular dative form of pronoun {ngawu}
\ge mine 
\ge my
\ge for me 
\ge to me
\ge me
\re me ; mine ; my
\so RS, GB, EF, JD93, MB_LH12
\xv Dara ngaki kudajba.
\sfx dara-ngaki-kujajba.wav
\xe My dog has died.
\rf EF
\xv Kuujbu yalu ngaki.
\sfx kuujbu yalu ngaki.wav
\xe They are looking for me.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Ngaki dara, wadaba-baji.
\xe My dog is a (good) goanna-hunter.
\rf EF_R299AE2
\xv Ngaki ngada-nganja.
\xe My mother.
\rf RS
\xv Ngaki waliji ngawu jarrba balikajini.
\sfx
\xe I'll eat my meat as I'm hungry.
\rf EF
\xv Jilaba ninji ngaki banjana. Jilaba ngawu yajanga.
\xe You come behind me. I'll go ahead.
\rf RS
\xv Jarrba kiya ngawu, daraa barri ngaki bikalii wakuu.
\xe I was about to eat it, when the dog quickly took it from me.
\rf GB
\xv Bindawarra kadimirra, ngabama nangkurru ngaki.
\xe The little bag, bring it over here for me.
\rf rs2002-03
\xv Wayi barri ninji ngaba ngaki danya? Budangku ngawu, budangku ngawu ngaba nganyi. 
\xe Did you bring me (any) clothes? I didn't. I didn't bring you any.
\rf rs2003-01
\xv Budangku ngawu jiringkijbi nana. Mayi ngaki, nangangi.
\xe I don't recognize that one. It might be mine, or his.
\rf rs2004-01
\xv Nanajba ninji ngaki nawunu.
\xe You wait for me here.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku ngaki, nganyi nana.
\xe It's not mine, that's yours.
\rf RS
\xv Yanyba ninji ngaki, lajibi ngawu ninya, yanykurru.
\xe You are talking to me, I'm listening to you talking.
\rf RS
\xv Kirajba ngaki danya.
\xe Send me clothes.
\rf RS
\xv Ngaki waliji ngawu jarrba balikajini.
\sfx
\xe My old grandfather is elderly.
\rf rs2005-02
\xv Bawa, ngaki? Budangku ngawu bawa-nganja-anyi.
\xe An elder brother, for me? I don't have an elder brother.
\rf rs2000-10
\xv Jangajba nyulu ngaki. 
\xe He's sneaking up on me.
\rf RS2002-01
\xv Jawikajba ngawu ninya, ja ninji mirramba jukuli ngaki?
\xe I'm asking you, will you make a boomerang for me?
\rf RS
\xv Nanganja maman ngaki!
\sfx nanganja-maman-ngaki_02_CO.wav
\xe Get some food for me!
\rf Elsie Moreland OSBORNE_C02-000165B.TMP
\xv Ngaki kala.
\xe My country.
\rf JD93
\xv Nanganja ngawu ngaki wanami jilajini.
\xe I'm getting water for myself as I'm going.
\rf MF+EM_CO

\xe That belongs to me.

\lx ngakinbiyangka
\mr ngaki-n-bi-yangka
\hm
\sf
\sn
\ps pronoun
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt proximate form of first person singular pronoun {ngawu}
\ge near me
\ge close to me
\re
\so RS, GB
\xv Jila nyulu barulajba ngakinbiyangka.
\xe He walked straight past me.
\rf GB
\xv Yunngu ngakinbiyangka wikijbi. 
\xe It (snake) kept crawling towards me. 
\rf GB
\xv Babaa nawunu ngakinbiyangka.
\sfx
\xe He's flying here near me.
\rf GB
\xv Jungku ngakinbiyangka.
\xe Sit near me.
\rf GB
\xv Ngakinbiyangka wikijbi, ngala ngawu barri durrajba, ngamuyu nanangkani kiya ngan bijbi.
\xe It was crawling near me so I then got afraid that it might bite me.
\rf GB
\xv Barulajba nyulu ngakinbiyangka.
\xe It past close to me.
\rf GB
\va ngakinbuyangka
\sy
\cf
\an

\lf ngaki

\lf ngakinbunu
\lf ngakinburru


\lx ngakinburru
\mr ngaki-n-bu-rru
\hm
\sf
\sn
\ps pronoun
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt allative form of first person singular pronoun {ngawu}
\ge to me
\ge towards me
\re
\so RS, CO, MB_LH12
\xv Ngamuyu miya nayi kajalaba ngakinburru, nukamini.
\xe I thought it was a snake climbing up on me, onto my foot.
\rf RS
\xv Kannga yalu, kaku-yudu. Jangkaranyi, ngabaa ngakinburru.
\xe They come back with fish. They bring cooked (fish) to me.
\rf RS2002-10
\xv Mayi bula janybijbi kara ngakinburru.
\xe They might throw a stone at me.
\rf RS
\xv  Mukujana, walajba nyulu, ngakinburru. Najba nurri mukujana. Nyulu barri, wululuku.
\xe He arrived to get me at breakfast time. We saw him as we were having breakfast. He turned up, the old man (did).
\rf RS
\xv Ninji, jilaba ninji! Yirrkuu! Wirrkirrbi ninji! Ngakinburru.
\xe You, you come (here)! Close! Move closer! Towards me.
\rf RS
\xv Bangini ninji ngakinburru jilaba ninji yanyi-yudu. Jungku ninji nayi yirrkuu ngaki ngakinburru.
\sfx
\xe You've come here to me from the west (to learn) about language.
\rf RS
\xv Nana wawurra jila ngakinburru.
\xe That child came to me.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Kara ninji janybijbi ngakinburru.
\xe You threw a stone at me.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\va
\sy
\cf ngakinbiyangka
\an
\nt {Ngakinburru} 'towards me' contrasts with {ngakinkurru} 'to/towards mine'.
\cp
\nq
\dt
\lf ngaki
\lf ngakinbunu
\lf ngakinbunyi

\lx ngakinburrunyi
\mr ngaki-n-burru-nyi
\hm
\sf
\sn
\ps noun
\pc
\sd people
\sd kin
\lt man's daughter's husband 
\ge son-in-law
\re son-in-law
\so EK, RS
\xv Ninji nurriyangi ngakinburrunyi. Windijbi ninya, ngakinkanyi jawaji-nganja-anyi.
\xe You're our son-in-law. (I) give you my daughter (in marriage).
\rf RS 
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\va
\sy
\cf kadunganja
\cf kamburru-nganja
\cf mimayi
\an
\nt Man's ideal son-in-law comes from set of his mother's brothers; woman's son-in-law {mimayi} comes from set of mother's cross-cousins or mother's mother's father.
\cp
\nq
\dt



\lx ngakinkanyi
\mr ngaki-n-kanyi
\sf ngakinkanyi.wav
\sn 1
\ps pronoun
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt dative form of first person singular possessive pronoun
\ge mine
\ge my
\ge my one
\re
\so RS, GB
\xv Mudumbanyi bula nangkujarra, ngila-wuya, ngakinkanyi yanyi-anyi. Budangku bula mankuu.
\xe These two girls don't know my language. They don't understand it.
\rf RS2005-06
\xv Budangku bula ngurrubu ngaan, nangkanyi wanami-anyi. Ngakinkanyi wanami-anyi. Jangayarrijbi bula wanami-yudu.
\xe They didn't tell me (they were taking) this drink, my drink. They slipped away with the drink.
\rf rs2003-02
\xv Ngakinkanyi bawa-nganja-anyi. Budangku ngaki, nangangi.
\xe That belongs to my big brother. It's not mine, it's his.
\rf rs2000-10 ; 2002-14
\xv Yurru-kadi ngawu, ngadijbi ngawu, ngakinkanyini. Kalawunyi, bindawarrana. 
\xe I'll put it inside, I'll hide it in mine. Inside the bag.
\rf rs2005-05
\xv Nanangkuya kadimirra, jawaji-nganja ngakinkanyi kakulu-nganja-anyi. Ngawu, ngawu bulangi bujarra-nganja.
\sfx bujarra-nganyja.wav
\xe Those two young ones are my young brother's children.  Me, I'm their aunt.
\rf rs2005-02
\xv Ngakinkanyi wanami, jarriyamba bula.
\xe My water, they took it away.
\rf RS2004-06
\xv Ninji nurriyangi ngakinburrunyi. Windijbi ninya, ngakinkanyi jawaji-nganja-anyi.
\xe You're our son-in-law. (I) give you my daughter (in marriage).
\rf RS 
\xv Yanyba ngawu nganyi milirrimbi ninya, milirrimbi ninya, ngaki yanyi Waanyi. Milirrimbi ngawu ninya ngakinkanyi yanyi-yanyi.
\xe I'm talking to you, teaching you, I'm teaching you.  My language is Waanyi. I'm teaching you about my language.
\rf RS
\xv Yanykanyi ngawu, ngakinkanyi yaji-anyi.
\xe I got to talk up about my place.
\rf RS2005-06
\xv Jawikajba ninji ngaan, ngakinkanyi yanyi-anyi.
\sfx
\xe You are asking me about my language.
\rf RS
\xv Ngadan ngakinkanyi, murriban.
\xe My mother's father.
\rf GB
\xv Kara-anyi, ngakinkanyi.
\xe For the money belonging to me.
\rf RS
\xv Ngakinkanyi bawa-anyi.
\sfx
\xe (It's) for my brother.
\rf IS_GB
\va
\sy
\cf 
\nt
\cp
\nq

\lx ngakinkurru

\hm
\sf
\sn
\ps noun
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt allative form of first person singular possessive pronoun
\ge to mine
\ge towards mine
\re
\so RS, GB
\xv Bayinga ngawu kannga, ngakinkurru kala-wurru.
\xe I'm heading back west to my place.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku ngawiji na jawikajanyi ngakinkurru raji-wurru jila-kurru.
\sfx
\xe I didn't ask him to come to my place.
\rf GB
\xv Jilanji ngakinkurru raji-wurru.
\sfx
\xe Come to my camp.
\rf GB
\va
\sy
\cf ngakinburru
\an
\nt {Ngakinkurru} means 'to/towards something belonging to me'; {ngakinburru} means 'towards me'.

\lx ngala
\mr 
\sf
\sn 1
\ps particle
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt used to contrast two related situations
\ge as
\ge but
\ge when
\ge while
\ge even though
\re
\so RS, EF, GB, MB_LH14
\xv Nanajba nungka, ngala nyulu dabarraba walijin.
\xe We'll sit and wait while he cooks the meat.
\rf RS2004-04
\xv Kankulunu ngamba jungku, ngala nyulu jungku ngambalangi kudarrijbi, kudarrijini.
\xe We are sitting having a feed while he is sitting silent, being quiet.
\rf RS2004-04
\xv Ngala ngamba jungku nawunu.
\sfx ngala-ngamba-jungku-nawunu.wav
\xe While we stay here.
\rf EF
\xv Kuku-najba nyulu ngambalanya kankulu-wurru. Ngala ngamba jungku kankulunu. Kankulunu ngamba jungku, ngala nyulu jungku kuku-najini.
\xe He was looking at us having a feed. While we were eating. We were sitting having a feed while he was sitting looking (at us).
\rf RS2004-04
\xv Kudumanja nyulu marrijbi. Ngala nyulu bajawaja.
\xe He kept hold of him while he struggled to get away.
\rf rs2005-09
\xv Jilaba nyulu nangkurru yanyi-anyi. Ngala ngawu, ngawu, jujuu ngawu jungku karurri, jujuu, kajana barrawunu. 
\xe He came here for some meeting, but me, I was far away to the east of here, far away in a big town.
\rf rs2003-02
\xv Kudijbi ngawu, ngala miyaa, ngaan durramba.
\xe I was lying down asleep when the snake, it (came and) frightened me.
\rf rs2003-03
\xv Ngurrubu ngawu kiya ninya, ngala ngawiji kuduujbu.
\xe I was going to tell you, but I forgot.
\rf GB
\xv Jungku ngawu nayi, najini, ngala ngawu lalujbu barri.
\xe I was sitting here looking but then I got up.
\rf RS
\xv Ngakinbiyangka wikijbi, ngala ngawu barri durrajba, ngamuyu nanangkani kiya ngan bijbi.
\xe It was crawling near me so then I was afraid thinking that it might bite me.
\rf GB
\xv Wabula nana yaliji ngaan nijarri, ngala ngawiji ngila.
\sfx
\xe They named me that a long time ago, when I was a little girl.
\rf MB_LH14
\va
\sy
\cf
\nt Also used in Garrwa and Yukulta/Kangkalida.
\cp
\nq Yukulta/Garrwa? {not common in Waanyi corpus, common in Y and G; Also in Yukulta (Keen 1983)
\dt

\sn 2
\ps particle
\pc
\sd discourse
\la
\lt used to introduce a new topic in contrast with previous one; may have interrogative function
\ge ^as for
\ge and ^what about
\re as (as for)
\re what (and what about)
\so RS
\xv Ngala ninji, wunjuku?
\sfx
\xe And what about you? Which way (are you going)?
\rf RS2000-05a
\xv Ngala ninji wululuku? Wunjuku ninji jilaba?
\sfx
\xe And what about you old man? Where are you going?
\rf RS2000-05a
\xv Ngala ngawu, jungku ngawu.
\sfx ngala_ngawu_jungku_nga.wav
\xe As for me, I'm staying.
\rf RS-RG1999
\va
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt

\lx ngali
\mr ngali
\sf
\sn 1
\ps pronoun
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt first person dual exclusive nominative form of pronoun
\ge we two (excluding you)
\ge us two
\re
\so RS, GB, EF, MB_LH13
\xv Windijbi kiya ngali ninya.
\sfx windijbi_kiya_ngali_ninyaF.wav
\xe We would have given you (some).
\rf EF_R299AE2
\xv Kawa-najba ngali nukami nangangi.
\xe We have found his tracks.
\rf rs2005-01
\xv Kannga ngamba raji-wurru barri, ngaba ngali narriyanya raji-wurru barri.
\xe We'll (all) return home then. We two will then take you lot back home.
\rf rs2004-untaped
\xv Jilaba ngali, jalanya, raji-wurru.
\xe We're going home now.
\rf rs2005-01
\xv Jilaba barri ngali.
\sfx jilaba_barri_ngali-we-go.wav
\xe We two are going now.
\rf RS-RG1999
\xv Kannga ngali manangka-wurru wanami-anyi.
\xe We went back to the river for water.
\rf RS
\xv Mudumbanyi ngali wunjuku ninji jilaba. Budangku ninji ngurrubu ngaliyanya.
\xe We didn't know where you had gone. You didn't tell us (where you were going).
\rf rs2003-02
\xv Nanganja ngali julaki mudunama.
\xe We catch the plane tomorrow.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku ngali najba nana-waan. Jilaba yalu nana-wunyi.
\xe We didn't see anyone. They had gone from there.
\rf RS
\xv Jila ninji naniwii, ngali jungku nayi yanjini.
\xe You go away, we are having a talk.
\rf GB
\xv Jungku ngali nawunu.
\sfx
\xe We (two) are here.
\rf MB_LH13
\xv Kudijkanyi ngali.
\sfx
\xe We two will go and lie down.
\rf
\va
\sy
\cf nungka
\cf ngamba
\cf nurri
\nt Speaker talking about self and one other person, not the person being spoken to.
\cp
\nq

\lx ngalika

\sd artefact

\re
\so EF, RS, EK, JD, MB_LH14

\xe Throw a spear with a spearthrower.
\rf EF_R299B3
\xv Nanganja yalu mukura, banga jukulin, barrku, ngalika.
\xe They gather up (their) spears and boomerangs, nullanullas, woomeras.
\rf rs2005-03
\xv Mukura-yudu nyulu, ngalika-yudu nyulu.
\xe He's got a spear and he's got a spear-thrower.
\rf GB
\xv Jilaba nyulu, yingkanyi, burrurri, mukura-yudu, ngalika-yudu.
\xe The man is walking alone with spears and spear-thrower.
\rf RS
\xv Ngalika-darra.
\sfx
\xe Spear-throwers.
\rf MB_LH14
\xv Naja ngalika!
\sfx
\xe Watch the woomera!

\lx ngalingi
\mr ngalingi
\sf
\sn 1
\ps pronoun
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt first person dual exclusive dative form of pronoun {ngali}
\ge for us (two)
\ge to us (two)
\ge our
\re us (two)
\so
\xv Mama ngalingi ngabama!
\sfx mama_ngalingi_ngabama.wav
\xe Bring us food.
\rf RS-RG1999
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\va ngaliyangi
\sy
\cf
\nt Possibly Garrwa pronoun. The most commonly used form in RS corpus is {ngaliyangi}.
\cp
\nq
\dt
\lf ngali

\lx ngaliyangi
\mr ngali-ya-ngi
\sf
\sn 1
\ps pronoun
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt dative form of first person dual exclusive pronoun {ngali}
\ge our
\ge his and mine
\ge hers and mine
\ge us (two)
\re our, us
\so RS, GB
\xv Kangku ninji ngaliyangi, kirriya-anyi. Ngila-wiya-anyi. Wululuku.
\sfx
\xe Old man! You are  (paternal) grandfather to us two girls. To us two little girls.
\rf rs2002-12
\xv Jilaba bula, ngakinkuya, ngada-nganja, ngaliyangi ngada-nganja, wanu-anyi. nanangkurru barri kara-wurru.
\xe Our two mothers, our mothers would both go to that rocky county to (get) tobacco.
\rf rs2000-11
\xv Balyanga nana nanganjama ngaliyangi nana.
\xe Don't touch that, it belongs it us two.
\rf GB
\xv Ngakin murriba, Murrunmurrula, Janaruwa, jamba nana ngaliyangi.
\xe As for my father, Murrunmurrula and Janaruwa, that country belongs to us two.
\rf RS
\xv Balyanga nana nanganjama! Ngaliyangi nana.
\sfx
\xe Don't get that. It belongs to us two (not you).
\rf IS_GB
\xv Balyanga ngaliyangi yanjimi.
\sfx
\xe Don't talk to us two.
\rf IS_GB
\va ngalingi
\sy
\cf niyangi
\cf ngambalangi
\cf nurriyangi
\nt 
\cp
\nq Note pattern of stem formation of dual and plural pronouns similar to Yukulta: -ya- following 'i', -la- following 'a', -wa- following 'u'.
\dt

\xe We've got to go now.

\lx ngambalangi

\sf
\sn 1

\pc

\ge to us
\ge for us
\ge our
\ge ours
\re
\so RS, GB, JD93, CO
\xv Kirriya nayi jilaba ngambalangi, mama-anyi.

\xe This woman is coming to us to (get) food.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Dabarraba nyulu nanyalu ngambalangi.
\xe He's making (=cooking) tea for us.
\rf RS2005-01
\xv Budangku nyulu karrinjaa ngambalangi. Banyajba nyulu ngambalanya jilajini.
\xe He didn't stop for us. He went straight past us.
\rf rs2004-04
\xv Mayi nyulu jangayarrijbi ngambalangi. Kuujbu barri ngamba banjana nangangi.
\xe He might sneak away from us. We'll then go after him and look for him.
\rf rs2004-08a
\xv Mayi yalu barimbi ngambalangi narrunguja.
\xe They might wreck our car.
\rf rs
\xv Kaku nyulu bariyimbi ngambalangi.
\sfx
\xe He failed to catch any fish for us.
\rf RS
\xv Mayi nyulu janybijbi ngambalangi barrawu, jalwaa wurrarraa.
\xe The strong wind might blow our house down.
\rf rs2005-02
\xv Budangku nyulu nanajba ngambalangi.
\xe He didn't wait for us.
\rf RS

\xv Ngambalangi dara.
\sfx
\xe Our dog.

\hm
\sf
\sn 1
\ps pronoun
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt reflexive-reciprocal form of first person plural inclusive pronoun {ngamba}.
\ge us
\ge ourselves
\re
\so RS, GB, CO
\xv Kudumbu ngambalangka rami jamba-wunyi.
\xe We shut our eyes from the dirt. (to stop dirt getting into eyes)
\rf RS
\xv Ngurrubu ngambalangka Waanyi-yanyi.
\sfx
\xe We are telling each other about Waanyi. (i.e., we are discussing)
\rf RS
\xv Rangkijbi ngambalangka jukulii.
\xe We pelt each other with boomerangs.
\rf RS
\xv Mudamudajibi ngambalangka, narrungujana.
\xe We fasten our seatbelts in a vehicle. (lit. we tie ourselves in)
\rf RS
\xv Kurrijbi ngambalangka.
\xe We scratch ourselves.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\va
\sy
\cf ngaliyangka
\cf niyangka
\cf nurriyangka
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt
\lf ngamba

\lf ngambalanya


\lx ngambalanya
\mr ngamba.la.nya

\sf
\sn 1
\ps pronoun
\pc

\lt accusative form of first person plural inclusive pronoun {ngamba}
\ge us
\re
\so RS, GB, CO

\sfx dajaya yalu ngambalanya.wav
\xe So they don't kill us.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Budangku nyulu bijbi ngambalanya.
\sfx budangku nyulu biijbi ngambalanya.aif
\xe It didn't bite us.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Ngurruju nyulu niyanya yakujbu ngambalanya, yanykanyi ngamba.
\sfx ngurrubu-nyulu-niyanya-yakujbu-ngambalanya-yanykanyi-ngamba_CO.wav
\xe He told us two that he was leaving us so that we would talk (among ourselves).
\rf Elsie Moreland OSBORNE_C02-000165B.TMP
\xv Yarraman, barrkidikidi. Daba nyulu ngambalanya, yarramana, kudanba.
\xe Horses are dangerous. Horses can kick us to death.
\rf rs2005-08a
\xv Kingkarri, balana nyulu babaa. Banyajba ngambalanya.
\xe He flew right over us, in the sky.
\rf rs2004-05
\xv Banyajba nyulu ngambalanya, ngungkurrunu.
\xe He roared past us.
\rf rs2004-07
\xv Winjuraba ngambalanya. Burra-daba wanami ngambalangi. 
\xe It's raining on us. The rain is pouring down on us. 
\rf RS
\xv Nanangkani burrurrii ngambalanya najba.
\xe That man is looking at us.
\rf GB
\xv Mayi nyulu ngambalanya wuyunbu, julakii, danmurraa.
\xe It might be a bird, a kookaburra, laughing at us.
\rf RS2005-02
\xv Yakujbu nyulu ngambalanya. 
\xe He left us. 
\rf RS2004-07
\xv Jawikajba yalu ngambalanya, nangkanyi kala-anyi.
\xe They ask us about this land.
\rf RS
\xv Ngurrubu nyulu ngambalanya wanami-yanyi, julakii, jukuu-jukuuu.
\xe The Topknot Pigeon bird is warning us about the (approaching) rain.
\rf RS
\xv Makarraba ngambalanya rami jundurri, jambaa, wulukuu, jila-kurru. 
\xe The dust covers our eyes, the big quantity of dirt, as we go along.
\rf rs2004-07
\va
\sy
\cf nurriyanya
\cf ngaliyanya
\cf niyanya
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt
\lf ngamba
\lf ngambalangi
\lf ngambalangka

\lx ngamuyu
\mr ngamuyu
\sf
\sn 1
\ps particle
\pc
\sd MOOD
\lt expresses a hypothetical proposition which is disconfirmed
\ge seems like
\ge (wrongly) thought to be
\ge supposedly
\re
\so RS, GB
\xv Ngamuyu ngaki, maninja.
\xe I thought it was for me, but it belongs to someone else.
\rf RS2000-08
\xv Manku ngawiji nan wawurran, ngamuyu nyuluji ngilan, ngala nyulu jukan.
\xe I had heard (about) this child that it was supposedly a girl, whereas it's a boy.
\rf GB
\xv Ngamuyu nangangi nyulu jarriyamba.
\xe He might sneak them away reckoning that they are his.
\rf RS
\xv Ngamuyu jukuli-waya balangarra kadimirra.
\xe That little moon looks like a boomerang.
\rf rs2005-07
\xv Nayi manangka kadimirra. Ngamuyu jakuli-waya.
\xe This river is small. It's (more) like a small creek.
\rf RS2004-03
\xv Marijbi ngawu ngamuyu kundan, jangun. Miya ngawu marijbi miyan.
\xe I picked up what I thought was a stick, a piece of firewood, (but) I had picked up a snake.
\rf RS
\xv Ngamuyu wululuku-waya nyulu jilaba nana kadimirra jukajuka.
\xe That little boy walks as though he's an old man.
\rf RS
\xv Ngamuyu miya nayi kajalaba ngakinburru, nukamini.
\xe I thought it was a snake climbing up on me, onto my foot.
\rf RS
\xv Ngamuyu-kiya nyulu bijbi nayi burrurrin, miyaa. 
\xe I thought that the snake had bitten this man.
\rf RS2003-03
\xv Ngamuyu-kiya ninji jungku nawunu. Budangku. Budangkun. Jungku ninji jujuu kularra.
\xe It was thought you would be here, but no. You were not. You were far away down south.
\rf RS2003-12-01
\xv Ngamuyu-kiya ngawu jilaba nanangkurru, nyulu-kiya bijbi ngaan.
\xe If I were to go there, it might bite me.
\rf RS2000-10
\xv Jungku ngawu nanawunu, kunaringan yanngu ngakinbiyangka wikijbi. Ngawu barri durrajba, ngamuyu nanangkani kiya ngaan bijbi.
\xe I was sitting there (and) a snake kept crawling towards me. So I was afraid then thinking it was going to bite me.
\rf GB(IG)
\xv Ngamuyu ninji kudajba.
\xe I thought you were dead.
\rf GB
\xv Ngamuyu nyuluji ngilan, ngala nyulu jukan.
\xe I thought it was a girl, but it was a boy.
\rf PC_GB76
\va ngamiyu
\sy
\cf kiya
\cf ngamuku
\cf -waya
\nt {Ngamuyu} is used in combination with the particle {kiya} to express a situation which is counter to expectation or desire, or which refers to a hypothetical situation.
\cp
\nq 
\dt 02/Oct/2006

\lx ngandaarra

\xe That old woman gave me this food.
\rf RS

\xe From the old woman.
\rf RS

\sfx kurlarni_nyulu_ngandaarra.wav
\xe To the south is the old woman.

\xe You take this meat and tucker over to that old person. To that old woman. 
\rf rs2000-09
\xv Juraa ngawu muwan ngandaarra-anyi.
\xe I feel sorry for the old woman.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku nimba mayi-anyi, wululuku, ngandaarra.
\xe You two don't have any food, old man and woman.
\rf RS
\xv Ngabaa nyulu, maman nanangkanyi ngandarra-anyi.
\xe He takes food for that old woman.
\rf RS

\lx ngandu
\mr ngandu
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc shelter.jpg
\sd manufacture
\sd shelter
\lt entity (natural or man-made) which provides shade
\ge shade
\ge shady tree
\ge bough-shade
\ge shelter
\re
\so RS, GB, EK, JD
\xv Ngandu kiya yalu mudurarrijbi, ngandun.
\xe They should erect a shelter, a shelter.
\rf RS2004-05
\xv Nanawunu nyulu jungku langkuu. Najba nyulu ngambalanya, nanambunyi, ngandu-wunyi.
\xe He's sitting there to our north. He's looking at us from over there, from the shade (where he's sitting).
\rf RS
\xv Jilaba ngamba, ngandu-wurru barri, nanangkurru kunda-wurru. 
\sfx
\xe We'll move to where there's shade now, over to that tree.
\rf RS
\xv Jungku ngawu wuja ngandunu, kundanan.
\xe I'm staying put in the shade, under the tree.
\rf RS
\xv Jungku nungka, ngandunu. Kalawunyi ngandunu.
\xe Let's (you and I) sit in the shade. Under the shady tree.
\rf RS
\xv Jarrba nungka kakun jungkunu kalawunyi jambana. Ngandunu.
\xe We are eating the fish sitting down on the ground. In the shade.
\rf RS
\xv Kuujbu ngamba ngandu-anyi.
\xe We are looking for some shade.
\rf RS
\xv Nanganja ngawu nganyi wabinbarra. Kudijbi ninji wululuku. Ngandunu. Kalawunyi, kundana.
\xe I'm catching you a turtle. You have a sleep, old man, in the shade, under the tree.
\rf RS
\xv Mudurrayijbi yalu, yilaka, ngandunu.
\xe They put the leafy branches over the top of the shelter.
\rf RS
\va
\sy dalu
\cf kunda
\cf maraki ~ marraki (??)
\cf yilaka
\nt Dymock (1993) also records as 'ghost'
\cp Garrwa

\lx -nganja

\sn 1
\ps suffix
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt anaphoric suffix on kin terms indicating person to whom the referent of the kin expression is related
\ge one's
\ge his
\ge her
\ge their
\ge the
\re
\so RS, GB, JD93, JP_TT
\xv Ngada-nganja.
\xe His mother.
\rf RS
\xv Maku-nganja.
\sfx maku-nganjaRS.wav
\xe One's cousin.
\rf RS
\xv Bajawajana nyulu ngindii wanaminin, ngada-nganja-anyi.
\xe He's crying and kicking around in the water, wanting his mother.
\rf rs2004-05
\xv Ngindii nyulu, kuujbu nyulu ngada-nganja-anyi.
\xe He's crying, he's looking for his mother.
\rf rs2000-10
\xv Jawaji-nganja banga wulu-nganja.
\xe Father and son.
\rf GB
\xv Ngaki ngada-nganja.
\xe My mother.
\rf RS
\xv Bawa-nganjaa nyulu daba balala-nganja.
\sfx
\xe The brother is hitting his sister.
\rf GB
\xv Bawa, ngaki? Budangku ngawu bawa-nganja-anyi.
\xe An elder brother, for me? I don't have an elder brother.

\xe Mother, give him a drink of milk.

\lf nganmarrkijbi

\lx nganmarrkijbi
\mr nganmarrki-j-bi
\sf nganmarrkijbi.wav
\ps verb
\pc thirsty.jpg
\sd bodily function
\lt X thirst
\ge be thirsty
\ge have dry throat
\re thirsty
\so EF, RS, GB, JD93, MF+EM_CO
\xv Nganmarrkijbi ngawu wanami-anyi.
\sfx nganmakijbi-ngawu-warnami.wav
\sfx nganmakijbi-ngawu-warnami02.wav
\sfx nganmarrkijbi-ngawu-warnami3.wav
\sfx nganmarrkijbi-ngawu-warnami4.wav

\xe My throat is getting dry from talking.

\xe He's drinking the water being thirsty.
\rf GB
\xv Nganmakijbi bula, ngabulu-anyi.
\xe They are both thirsty for milk.
\rf RS2005-06
\xv Ngabama ninji wanami nangkurru ngakinburru.  Nganmarrkijbi ngawu. 
\xe Bring the water here to me. I'm thirsty.
\rf RS
\xv Ngada, jilaba ngawu, wanami-wurru. Nganmarrkijbi ngawu.
\xe Mum, I'm going to the water(hole). I'm thirsty.
\rf RS
\xv Nanganja ngawu nganyi wanami, nganmarrkijbi ninji. 
\xe I fetched water for you (as) you were thirsty.
\rf MF+EM_CO

\xe I gave you water when (you were) thirsty.
\rf MF+EM_CO

\sy

\nt Pronounced [nganmadkijbi]

\nq CO transcribes [nganmadgegurru]

\lf 

\lx nganyi
\mr nganyi
\hm 2
\sf nganyi.wav
\sf nganyi02.wav
\sf nganyi03.wav
\ps pronoun
\pc
\sd GRAMMAR
\lt dative form of second person singular pronoun {ninji}
\ge your
\ge yours
\ge to you
\ge for you
\re
\so RS, GB, EF, MB_LH
\xv Nganyi bawa-nganja.
\xe Your elder brother.
\rf rs2005-02
\xv Nganyi nana maman. 
\xe That tucker is yours. 
\rf rs2005-05
\xv Wayi barri ninji ngaba ngaki danya? Budangku ngawu ngaba nganyi. Mamanumbu ngawu.
\xe Did you bring me (any) clothes? I didn't bring you any. I forgot.
\rf rs2003-01
\xv Kuujbu ngawu nganyi bungkana.
\xe I was looking for you yesterday.
\rf RS
\xv Karrinja nganyi yajangu, nganyinbuyangka dalu. 
\xe It's standing in front of you, the shady tree is near you.
\rf RS2000-11
\xv Ja ngawu nganyi kirajba.
\xe I'll send (it) to you.
\rf RS
\xv Ngabaa ngawu nganyi, danyan barri. Budangku nukami-anyi, ngawu ngabaa nganyi jabunukaji.
\xe I'm wearing your gear now. (I) don't have any boots, (so) I'm wearing your boots.
\rf RS2003-01b
\xv Budangku nayi jamba nganyi. Yalungi nayi jamban. 
\xe This land is not yours, this land is theirs.
\rf RS2004-05
\xv Budangku ngawu, jijajba, nganyi.
\xe I'm not lying to you.
\rf RS
\xv Mudamudajibi ninji jumbala nganyi. 
\xe You roll up your swag.
\rf RS2005-05
\xv Banka, winja nganyi kamburru-nganja?
\xe Cousin, where's your uncle? 
\rf RS
\xv Kayi nana nganyi.
\sfx kayi-nana-nganyi.wav
\sfx kayi-nana-nganyi02.wav
\xe That one is calling out for you.
\rf EF
\xv Ngada, kilimbi ngawu wanami nganyi.
\xe Mum, I'll fetch water for you.
\rf RS
\xv Kannga ninji nganyinburru jamba-wurru, kala-wurru, jungku-anyi ninji jambana nganyinbunu. Nayi nganyin jamban, budangku yalungi. 
\xe You have returned to your land, to your country, to live on your land. This is your land. It doesn't belong to other people.
\rf RS2004-05
\xv Nganyi nana mani.
\xe That money is yours.
\rf IS_GB
\xv Nganyini ngaan bijbi -- daraa.
\sfx
\xe Your dog bit me.
\rf EF_R299EB1
\va
\sy
\cf nimbalangi
\cf narriyangi
\nt Only used to address one person.
\nt Ergative form is {nganyini} used if subject of transitive verb
\cp Wambaya {nganga}
\nq
\dt 03/Sep/2006

\lx nganyinbiyangka
\mr nganyi-n-bi-yangka
\hm
\sf
\sn
\ps pronoun
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt second person singular proximate form of pronoun {ninji}
\ge near you
\ge on you
\re
\so GB, RS
\xv Karrinja nganyi yajangu, nganyinbuyangka dalu. 
\xe It's standing in front of you, the shady tree is near you.
\rf RS2000-11
\xv Jungku nyulu nganyinbiyangka.
\sfx
\xe She's sitting near you.
\rf GB
\va nganyinbuyangka

\cf narriyanginbuyangka

\lx nganyinbunu
\mr nganyi-n-bu-nu
\hm
\sf
\sn
\ps pronoun
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt locative possessive form of second person singular pronoun {ninji}
\ge at yours
\ge on yours
\ge in yours
\ge with you
\ge in your company
\re
\so RS, GB, CO
\xv Kannga ninji nganyinburru jamba-wurru, kala-wurru, jungku-anyi ninji jambana nganyinbunu. Nayi nganyin jamban, budangku yalungi. 
\xe You have returned to your land, to your country, to live on your land. This is your land. It doesn't belong to other people.
\rf RS2004-05
\xv Janja nganyinbunu walini. Wakada nganyingka.
\xe There's mud on your face. Wash it off. (Lit. Wash yourself)
\rf GB
\xv Ngaki juka yaja nganyinbunu.
\sfx
\xe My boy is bigger (ahead of) than yours.
\rf GB
\xv Wayi ngawu nganyinbunu jilaa?
\xe Can I go with you?
\rf GB
\va
\sy
\cf ngakinbunu
\cf nimbalanginbunu
\cf ninji
\cf narriyanginbunu
\an
\nt

\lf nganyinburru

\lf nganyingka
\lf nganyinkanyi

\lx nganyinburru
\mr nganyi-n-bu-rru
\hm
\sf
\sn
\ps pronoun
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt second person singular allative (possessive) form of pronoun {ninji}
\ge to you
\ge towards you
\ge to yours
\ge towards yours
\re
\so RS, GB, CO, MB_LH13
\xv Kannga ninji nganyinburru jamba-wurru, kala-wurru, jungku-anyi ninji jambana nganyinbunu. Nayi nganyin jamban, budangku yalungi. 
\xe You have returned to your land, to your country, to live on your land. This is your land. It doesn't belong to other people.
\rf RS2004-05
\xv Yawu, jilaba ngawu, nganyinburru, yanykanyi nungka yanyi.
\xe Yes, I’m moving towards your place, so we can have a yarn.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku yalu jilaba, nganyinburru.
\sfx
\xe They didn't come to (see) you.
\rf RS
\xv Wawurran jila nganyinburru.
\xe The child comes to you.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Ngawu janybijbi kara nganyinburru.
\xe I threw a stone at you.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\va
\sy
\cf nimbalanginburru
\cf narriyanginburru
\an
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt
\lf nganyi
\lf nganyinbunu
\lf nganyinbiyangka
\lf nganyinkurru

\lx nganyingka
\mr nganyi-ngka
\sf
\sn 1
\ps pronoun
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt second person singular reflexive form of pronoun {ninji}
\ge yourself
\re
\so RS, GB, EF
\xv Jila-kanyi ninji wajka wanami-wurru. Burru-kadi nganyingka wanamini! 
\xe You've got to get down into the water. Get yourself down into the water.
\rf RS
\xv Yaku nana! Karrbaya nganyingka, mani.
\xe Put that down! You might cut yourself on the hand.
\rf RS
\xv Maka-nijkanyi nganyingka mundirrin.
\xe You will straighten your back.
\rf RS
\xv Wakadaba nganyingka, mani!
\xe Wash your hands.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku nganyingka durrkan wakadakanyi.
\xe You haven't really washed yourself.
\rf RS
\xv Makarraba nganyingka!
\xe Cover yourself!
\rf RS
\xv Balyanga nganyingka mani niya! Ngarajudukanyi nana wanami.
\xe Don't put your hand (into it). That water is for drinking.
\rf IS_GB78
\xv Karrbaya nganyingka. Yaku nana.
\xe You might cut yourself. Leave that alone.
\rf MF_GB
\va
\sy
\cf nimbalangka
\cf narriyangka
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt
\lf nganyi
\lf ninji
\lf ninya
\sn 2
\ps pronoun
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt This form of pronoun is used with [often reduplicated] perception verbs to express meanings like 'think, plan' ({lajibi} 'hear'), 'take care, look out for, watch out for' ({najba-najba} 'see-see').
\ge yourself
\re
\so RS, GB
\xv Kajalaba ninji kundana. Najba-najba nganyingka. Mayi ninji burrurru. 
\xe You climb up the tree. Watch out for yourself. You might fall.
\rf rs2000-09
\xv Najba-najba nganyingka! Kaburrukaja-anyi. Mayi ninya nanganja, kaburrukajaa.
\xe Look out for crocodiles. A crocodile might grab hold of you.
\rf RS
\xv Manku-manku nganyingka.
\sfx mankumanku-nganyingka.wav
\xe You are thinking.
\rf RS2005-05
\xv Wanyinkanyi nganyingka lajibi?
\sfx
\xe What are you thinking about doing?
\rf RS
\xv Manku-manku nganyingka kamu mungana.
\xe You think about it tonight.
\rf RS
\xv Wanyimba nganyingka?
\sfx wanyimba_nganyingka-whatUdoF.wav
\xe What are you doing?
\rf EF_R299EA2
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\va
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt Reflexive pronoun forms are also used to intransitivize verbs.
\cp
\nq
\dt

\xe Leave that spear alone, it belongs to your uncle.

\xe You've got to go home, to your place.
\rf RS
\xv Minimbi nganyinkanyi.
\sfx
\xe Show yours.
\rf RS
\xv Ngawu, nganyinkanyi, jawaji-nganja-anyi.

\lx ngaraba
\mr ngara-ba
\sf ngaraba.wav
\sf ngaraba02.wav
\sf ngaraba03.wav
\sf ngaraba04.wav
\ps verb
\pc
\sd body
\sd bodily function
\lt
\ge drink
\re drink
\so RS, EF, GB, EK, JD93, MF+EM_CO
\xv Ngaraba ngawu.
\sfx ngaraba-ngawu.wav
\sfx ngaraba=ngawu.wav
\xe I drink (it).
\rf EF
\xv Ngaraba ngawu wanami.
\sfx ngaraba-ngawu-warnami.wav
\xe I'm drinking water.
\rf EF
\xv Ngaraba nurri ngarrki. Ngaraba nurri bunbujaa.
\xe We drink that gravy. We suck it up.
\rf RS
\xv Ngaraba ngawu dawurrumbu, wanamin, ngajirrin.
\xe I've finished drinking up all the cold water.
\rf rs2005-01
\xv Janyii ngawu ngaraba.
\xe I sucked it (poison) out with my mouth.
\rf RS
\xv Jawuranyaa nyulu ngaraba wululukuu.
\xe The old man is drinking from a quartpot.
\rf rs
\xv Ngaraba nyulu wanamin, kamukamu
\xe He was drinking beer, grog.
\rf RS
\xv Dabarraba nyulu nanyalu ngambalangi. Ngarakanyi ngamba.
\xe He's making (cooking) tea for us, so we can drink it.
\rf RS
\xv Ngarakanyi wawurra-anyi wanami nyulu nanganja.
\xe He's getting water for the child to drink.
\rf RS
\xv Ngarakanyi ngamba, nanyalu.
\xe We'll drink some tea.
\rf RS
\xv Ngarakini nyulu jungku kudarrijbi.
\sfx
\xe He is sitting quietly drinking.
\rf RS2004-03
\xv Jungku yalu ngarakini. Kamukamu yalu ngaraba.
\sfx
\xe They were sitting drinking. They were drinking beer.
\rf RS2004-06
\xv Warrakuujbu yalu, ngarakini, kamukamunu.
\xe They went silly in the head as they drank grog.
\rf RS
\xv Najba ngawu wanami-yurru ngarakurru.
\xe I saw him drinking water.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Ngurrubu ngawu nan nyulu ngarakanyi.
\xe I told him that he should drink it.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Ngurrubu ngawuji ngarajudu.
\xe I told him to drink it.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Balyanga nganyingka mani niya! Ngarajudukanyi nana wanami.
\xe Don't put your hand (into it). That water is for drinking.
\rf IS_GB78
\xv Nayi, ngara nayi -- nanyalu!
\sfx
\xe This, drink this -- tea!
\rf RS2005-09
\va
\sy
\cf jarrba
\cf nganjali-wajba
\nt
\cp Wambaya {ngarabi}

\lx ngarajaba
\mr
\hm
\sv
\sf
\sn
\ps verb
\pc
\sd contact
\sd effect
\lt Xerg apply linear pressure to surface of Y, typically by means of instrument such as file or adze
\ge carve
\ge file
\ge scrape
\ge press down along
\re
\so MB_LH14
\xv Jungku ngawu ngarajakini, jukulini.
\sfx
\xe I'm sitting here carving a boomerang.
\rf MB_LH14
\xv Ngarajaba nyulu.
\sfx
\xe He's carving it.
\rf MB_LH14
\va ngarijaba
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt
\cp Wambaya {ngarajabi} 'make boomerang/spear'
\nq

\lx ngaribundu
\mr ngari-bundu
\sf ngaribundu_RS.wav
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd animal
\lt more than two emus together
\ge flock of emus
\re emus
\so RS, GB
\xv Kananganja ngaribundu. Dangkarr-wuya, kananganja kujarra. Ngaribundu, kurrkamala.
\sfx
\xe A flock of emus. A pair {dangkarr-wuya} is (how we refer to) two emus. {Ngaribundu} is a big number (of emus).
\rf RS
\va ngarilbundu
\sy
\cf kananganja
\cf dangkarr-wuya
\cf nujungunyi
\cf wididi
\nt Breen records as {ngarilbundu}
\nt Ngaribundu 'Many Emu' Dreaming belongs to people of Ngarrijbalangi and Bangarinyi skin groups (Seccin tape2002-09a).

\nq

\lx ngarijaba
\mr ngarija-ba
\sf ngarijaba-carve.wav
\sf ngarijaba-carve-02.wav
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd contact (impact and violence)
\sd effect
\lt Xerg apply linear pressure to surface of Y, typically by means of instrument such as file or adze
\ge carve
\ge file
\ge scrape
\ge press down along
\re
\so RS, GB, MB_LH14
\xv Jinangu nyulu ngarijaba.
\sfx jinangu nyulu ngarijaba.wav
\xe He carved a design (in it).
\rf Rs2005-04
\xv Ngarijaba ngawu jukuli, binymalaa.
\xe I filed down the boomerang with an adze.
\rf rs2002-03
\xv Ngarijaba nyulu jinanguu, kubijaa, kuyiwarru.
\xe He carved the shield with fluting, using a small adze with sharp point.
\rf RS
\xv Ngarijaba nurri, kangkarinyaa.
\xe We scrape it off with a knife.
\rf RS
\xv Ngarijaba wadaa, kangkarinyaa, kanawaa.
\xe (He) carved it with a long sharp knife.
\rf RS
\xv Ngarijaba ngawu nayi jaluki. Jarrkanyi ngawu, jaluki.
\xe I'm pressing down and running my hand along the intestines, as I want to eat the intestines.
\rf RS2002-02
\xv Jukuli nyulu nangangi ngarijaba.
\xe He filed down his boomerang.
\rf RS
\va ngarajaba [MB]
\sy ngarrbara
\cf
\nt Recorded by Breen as "adze"
\cp
\nq (compare with ngarrijaba 'squeeze'; check if not ngarrijaba) GB ngarijaba
\dt 17/Oct/2006

\lx ngarrangarra
\mr ngarra-ngarra
\sf ngarrangarra.wav
\sf ngarrangarra02.wav
\sf ngarrangarra03.wav
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd atmosphere
\lt be high in temperature
\ge hot
\ge warm
\re
\so EF, RS, GB, EK, JD
\xv Ngarrangarra duru.
\xe The sun is hot.
\rf RS
\xv Ngarrangarra, wurrarra-n
\xe The wind is hot.
\rf
\xv Wukarrijbi ngambalanya, duruu. Ngarrangarra ngamba.
\xe The sun is cooking us. We are getting hot.
\rf RS
\xv Manini nyulu bikali, kijibajii ngarrangarraa.
\xe The wild, angry man is carrying them (spears) in this hand.
\rf rs2005-8b
\xv Ngarrangarraa, janguu nurriyanya rajba.
\xe The heat from the fire is burning us.
\rf RS
\xv Jila nurri ngarrangarra nukami.
\xe We went with burning feet.
\rf RS
\xv Ngarrangarra barri nurri, bilikija-anyi, wanamini barri.
\xe We are hot now, and (want) to go swimming in the water.
\rf RS
\va 
\sy
\cf rajba
\cf wukarrijbi
\cp Jingulu {ngarra} 'heat'; Garrwa {ngarrangarra} 'burn'; Wambaya 'be hot'
\nt 
\dt 03/Sep/2006
\sn 2
\ps noun
\pc
\sd behavioural
\lt be with anger
\ge angry
\ge hot-headed
\ge bad-tempered
\ge fierce
\re
\so RS, JD
\xv Kuujbu yalu, nanangkanyi burrurri-anyi. Kijibaji, kijibaji, ngarrangarra burrurrin.
\xe They were looking for that man. He was a trouble-maker, a troubler-maker and (very) hot-headed.
\rf RS
\xv Manini nyulu bikali, kijibajii ngarrangarraa.
\xe The wild, angry man is carrying them (spears) in this hand.
\rf rs2005-8b
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\va
\sy
\cf kijibaji
\cf yulurri muwa
\an
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt
\lf ngarrangarraa
\lf ngarrangarrajba
\lf ngarrangarramba



\lx ngarrangarrajba
\mr ngarrangarra-j-ba
\hm
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd
\lt X be hot
\ge heat
\ge be hot
\ge get hot
\ge warm
\re
\so RS
\xv Budangku nayi dalu-anyi. Jungku nurri durunu. Rajba nurriyanya duruu. Ngarrangarrajba nurri.
\xe There's no shade here. We are sitting in the sun. The sun is baking us. We are getting hot.
\rf RS2002-10
\xv Ngarrangarrajba barri. Nayi barri duru, kingkarri nayi ngambalangi.
\sfx
\xe It's getting hot now. It's sunny here now, up above us.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt
\lf ngarrangarra
\lf ngarrangarramba


\lx ngarrangarramba
\mr ngarrangarra-mba
\hm
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd
\lt Xerg cause Y to increase in temperature
\ge heat
\ge make hot
\re
\so RS
\xv Ngarrangarramba wanamin jangunu. Nanyalu-anyi.
\xe Heat the water on the fire. For tea.
\rf RS
\xv Ngarrangarramba nangka. Kayi nyulu, bajawaja nyulu ngarrimbi-anyi.
\sfx
\xe He's getting all steamed up. He's kicking and screaming out for his friends (to come and help him).
\rf RS
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\va
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt
\lf ngarrangarra
\lf ngarrangarrajba
\sn 2
\ps verb
\pc
\sd behavioural
\lt Xerg cause Y to act in angry manner
\ge anger
\ge make angry
\ge stir up (with anger)
\re
\so RS
\xv Ngarrangarramba nangka. Kayi nyulu, bajawaja nyulu ngarrimbi-anyi.
\sfx
\xe He's getting all steamed up. He's kicking and screaming out for his friends (to come and help him).
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt When used with a reflexive/reciprocal pronoun, this verb refers to change of state and behaviour in someone, as in English 'get stirred up', 'get steamed up', 'fly into a temper'.
\cp
\nq
\dt

\lx ngarra-rajba
\mr
\hm
\sv
\sf
\sn
\ps verb
\pc
\sd heat
\la
\lt
\ge feel ^hot
\re
\so EF

\lx ngarrimba
\mr ngarrimba
\sf ngarrimba-barri.wav
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd people
\lt
\ge company
\ge companion
\ge friend
\ge mate
\re
\so RS, GB
\xv Kalijkana yaku! Ngarrimba nganyi. Barrakalaba ngawu ninya. Mungkuji nganyi.
\xe Don't spear him. He's your mate. I'm stopping you (from hitting him). He's your countryman.
\rf rs2004-04
\xv Budangku nyulu ngarrimba-yudu.
\xe He doesn't have any mates with him.
\rf RS
\xv Nyubana nyulu. Budangku ngarrimba-anyi.
\xe He's alone. He doesn't have any companions.
\rf RS
\xv Kujarra bajangu, kannga ngawu, ngarrimbi ngaki.
\xe The two dogs, I came back with, are my companions.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku ngarrimba-yanyi. Jilaba nyulu nyubana. Ngajangaja.
\xe He's got no company. He's going alone. He's racing (away).
\rf RS
\xv Dara-yudu ngawu kudijbi. Ngarrimba ngaki. Dara ngaki.
\xe I camp with (my) dog. He's my companion, my dog.
\rf RS
\xv Mungkuji nganyi nana burrurri. Mungkuji, ngarrimba
\xe That man is your countryman. He's a countryman, a friend.
\rf RS
\va ngarrimbi
\sy
\cf mungkuji
\nt
\cp
\nq

\lx ngarringkajba
\mr ngarringka-j-ba
\sf
\sn
\ps verb
\pc
\sd effect
\lt Xerg deprive Y of Zdat
\ge deprive of
\ge rob of
\ge steal off
\ge take from
\re
\so RS, GB, MF_CO
\xv Ngarringkajba ninji, nana wawurra, waliji-anyi.
\xe You took meat off that child.
\rf RS
\xv Daraa ngaan ngarringkajba waliji-anyi, manini, kujukujuu.
\xe The dog snatched the meat out of my hand, the little puppy did.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku yalu ninya ngarringkajba, nganyi mangkarri-nganja.
\xe They can't take her off you, she's your wife.
\rf RS
\xv Waliji, maman ngawu ngadijbi, nangkanyi burrurri-anyi. Mayi nyulu, ngarringkajba ngaan. Maman ngaki.
\xe The meat and bread, I'm hiding away from that man. (Otherwise) he's likely to steal it from me. It's my food.
\rf RS
\xv Ngarringkajba nana burrurri -- mukura-anyi.
\sfx
\xe He robbed that man of the spear.
\rf MF_CO (OSBORNE_C02-000165B.TMP)
\xv Ngarringkajba burrurrii kujarra wawurra mukara-anyi.
\sfx
\xe The man takes spears from the two boys.
\rf MF_CO
\xv Ninji ngan ngarringkajba waliji-yanyi.
\xe You robbed me of meat.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\va
\sy
\cf dulwaraba
\an windijbi
\nt
\cp
\nq

\lx ngawiji
\mr ngawu-ji
\hm 2
\sf
\sn 1
\ps pronoun
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt First person singular nominative pronoun {ngawu} mostly used in past tense contexts
\ge I
\ge me
\re
\so GB, RS, MF+EM_CO, MB_LH13
\xv Budangku ngawiji ninya dajkanyi.
\xe I didn't mean to hit you.
\rf GB
\xv Ngurrubu yalu lungkaji, ngawiji nana mandaki daba.
\xe They told the policeman (that) I hit that man.
\rf GB
\xv Kuujbu ngawiji nganyi.
\xe I've been looking for you.
\rf GB
\xv Yakujbu ngawiji Bujabuja barriyi.
\xe I left Bujabuja (Adels Grove) early morning.
\rf GB
\xv Budangku ngawiji balangarra najkanyi barriyi.
\xe I didn't see the moon last night.
\rf GB
\xv Mularrijbi ngawiji nana bulumirri, ngindi-wurru.
\xe I picked up that child who was crying.
\rf gb2003.73
\xv Wambu ngawiji bungkana.
\xe I was sick yesterday.
\rf gb
\xv Ngurubu ngawu-kiya ninya, ngala ngawiji kudujbu.
\xe I was going to tell you, but I forgot.
\rf GB
\xv Manku ngawiji nan wawurran, ngamuyu nyuluji ngilan, ngala nyulu jukan.
\xe I had heard (about) this child that it was supposedly a girl, whereas it's a boy.
\rf GB
\xv Jilaba ngawiji, yanngu. Burrbijbi ngawu, yarraman-adu.
\xe I went away for good. I raced off with a horse.
\rf RS
\xv Ngurrubu ngawuji ngabadu.
\xe I told him to bring it.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\va ngawu
\va ngawuji
\sy
\cf ninjiji
\cf nyuluji
\nt The suffix {-ji} on the pronoun is mostly used in past contexts and seems to indicate past tense in the manner of the Garrwa suffix {-i} on subject pronouns. However the citation form {ngawu} without the suffix {-ji} is more commonly used in contexts where past time is implied.
\nt Osborne (MF+EM_CO) analyses {-ji} as emphatic suffix.
\cp
\nq alternative form for ngawu {possibly indicating past tense (see Breen 2008)}
\dt 30/Oct/2006
\lf ngawu

\lx ngila
\mr ngila
\sf ngila.wav
\sf ngila-girl.wav
\ps noun
\pc
\sd PEOPLE
\lt prepubescent female
\ge young girl
\re
\so EF, RS, GB, EK, JD, MF_SK, AP+AF_PS
\xv Ngila-wiya, balikajba nimba.
\xe You two girls are both hungry.
\rf rs2002-03
\xv Nangkujarra, ngila-wiya. Bankanya-wiya. Maku-nganja-wiya. Nangkujarraa ngila-wuyaa, nijbi bulangka mimi-kula.
\xe These two girls, they are two cousins, two cross cousins. These two girls, they refer to themselves as a pair of cousins.
\rf rs2004-01
\xv Kuujbu ngawu nanangkanyi ngila-anyi. Budangku ngawu najba.
\xe I am looking for that little girl. I can't find her.
\rf rs2003-01
\xv Jangayarrijbi nyulu nayi ngila ngambalangi bayungu.
\xe This little girl is sneaking away from us (going) west.
\rf rs2005-06
\xv Mudumbanyi bula nangkujarra, ngila-wiya, ngakinkanyi yanyi-anyi.
\xe These two girls don't know about my language.
\rf rs2005-06
\xv Damarrijbi barri yalu janjana wanami-wurru ngila-darra, kuwada-yaan.
\xe The silly girls are slipping in the mud down into the water.
\rf RS2002-07
\xv Nawaan ngila-ngila, kirriya-darra, ja yalu mindikirri.
\xe These young girls, and women, they must dance.
\rf RS
\xv Maman barri yalu jundujbu, kadimirraa, wawurraa, jukajukaa, ngila-ngilaa.
\xe The little ones, the children, boys and girls, are now stuffing themselves with bread.
\rf RS2005-02
\xv Wadamba yalu ngaan kakuu, Kalkudunguu, ngila-ngilaa.
\xe Those young Kalkudungu girls gave me a good feed of fish.
\rf RS
\xv Dabarra-kanyi yalu, walijin wingki, nawaani ngilaa, kadimirraa ngilaa.
\sfx
\xe These little girls have to cook the raw meat.
\rf RS
\xv Jangu ninji mirramba, kadimirraa ngilaa wadukarraa.
\xe You make a fire, little girl.
\rf RS
\xv Ngindi-ngindijbi kadimirra ngila, ngada-nganjaa naan daba kundaa. Jadiyadiyimbi.
\xe The little girl is crying (because) her mother is hitting her with a stick.
\rf RS

\lx ngindi

\ge mourn
\ge wail
\re cry
\so EF, RS, GB, EK, JD
\xv Wawurra ngindiyi.
\sfx wawurra-ngirndii.wav
\xe The child is crying.
\rf EF
\xv Bajawaja nyulu, yingkanyi wawurra, ngindini.
\xe One child is thrashing around and crying.
\rf RS
\xv Bajawajana nyulu ngindiyi wanaminin, ngada-nganja-anyi.
\xe He's crying and kicking around in the water, wanting his mother.
\rf rs2004-05
\xv Ngindiyi nyulu, bariyimbi nyulu.
\sfx
\xe She is mourning as she lost him (i.e., her baby died).
\rf GB
\xv Mularrijbi ngawiji nana bulumirri, ngindi-wurru.
\xe I picked up that child who was crying.
\rf gb2003.73
\xv Kuyi-rajba nangka karaa. Ngindiyi nyulu kamburru-nganja-anyi. 
\xe She bashes her head with a stone. She cries for her (deceased) uncle.
\rf RS
\xv Ngindiyi nyulu muwa ngambalangi.
\sfx ngindiyi nyulu muwa ngambalangi.wav
\xe He's crying out of pity for us.
\rf RS2004-05
\xv Nana-waan kadimirra, ngindiyi yalu ngaki, nana-waan wawurra-darra.
\xe Those little ones, those children are crying for me.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku nyulu ngindi-yanyi.
\xe He's not crying.
\rf GB
\xv Ngindu nyulu, marrala nyulu -- nana bulungi.
\xe That baby is crying, he is afraid.
\rf EK (ML notes)
\xv Ngindiyi ngawu nganyi.
\xe I'm crying for you.
\rf EM_SK

\lx nginngi

\sf

\pc

\ge argue
\re

\sfx
\xe Those two have been arguing since sunset.
\rf GB

\xe That one saw us two arguing supposedly.
\rf GB
\xv Banjana ngawiji yakujbu bulanya, nginngi-wurru bulangka-wurru.
\xe I left them both behind, arguing with each other.
\rf GB
\va nginngirri*2*

\cf mijbi
\an
\nt The pronoun referring to the ones arguing is in the reflexive-reciprocal form.

\lx ngirraa
\mr ngirra-a
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd hold (holding and transfer)
\lt Xerg deprive Ydat of Z (without permission of Y)
\ge steal
\ge take away from
\re
\so EF, RS, GB, CO
\xv Ngirraa narriyanya, ngila-darra. Jarriyamba.
\xe He'll steal you girls away. Carry (you) off.
\rf rs2002-07
\xv Ngirraa yalu burrurrii yarrbanjii. Budangku yalu jawikajba ngaan.
\xe The young men stole it. They didn't ask me (for it).
\rf RS
\xv Winjikaa nanangkanyi walijin ngirraa?
\xe Who stole that one's meat?
\rf GB
\xv Nginngirri ngawu naan, ngira-wurru. Najba ngawu ramii, ngirra-wurru.
\xe I saw him stealing (it). I saw him stealing it with (my own) eyes.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku ninji ngirraa nayi larrwa ngaki.
\xe Don't you steal this pipe of mine.
\rf RS
\xv Mayi yalu ngirraa kaku ngambalangi.
\xe They might steal our fish.
\rf RS
\xv Ngirraa bula ngaki wanami. Budangku bula jawikajba. Jangarrijbi bula.
\xe They stole my drink. They didn't ask. They sneaked away (with it).
\rf RS
\xv Ngirraa ngamba yalungi wanami, mama, waliji.
\xe We stole their water, bread and meat.
\rf RS
\xv Ngirra-wurru, najba ngawu naan, ramii.
\xe I saw this fellow stealing, with my own eyes.
\rf RS
\xv Ngirraa narri ngaki.
\xe You're stealing from me.
\rf RS
\xv Ngirrakanyi nyulu, julakii, balikaajini 
\xe The bird wants to steal it (fish) away, because it's hungry.
\rf RS
\xv Ngilaa nyulu ngirraa walijin.
\xe The little girl stole the meat.
\rf RS
\xv Ngirraa ngawu yarraman.
\xe I stole a horse.
\rf RS
\xv Ngirrama!
\sfx
\xe Steal it!
\rf MF_EM_CO
\va 
\sy
\cf jariyamba
\nt 
\cp Wambaya {ngirra}
\nq GB has ngirraa and ngira; ML also has ngirraa in many ex & ngiraa CHECK; MF+EM_CO {ngirra} 'steal (it)!'

\lx ngukurrijbi
\mr ngukurri-j-bi
\sf ngukurrijba-block.wav
\ps verb
\pc
\sd contact (impact and violence)
\lt Xerg prevent Y from coming into contact with something
\ge block
\ge defend
\ge intercept
\ge interpose
\ge protect
\re
\so RS, EK, AD
\xv Ja ngaka ngukurrijbi barrkuu.
\xe I will protect myself with my nullanulla.
\rf RS
\xv Ngukurrijkanyi ngaka.
\xe I want to protect myself.
\rf RS
\xv Ngukurrijbi ngaka.
\xe I'm protecting myself.
\rf RS
\xv Ngukurrijbi jukuli, kuyuwarruu.
\xe A shield blocks boomerangs.
\rf RS
\xv Ngukurrijkanyi ngaka barrkuu. Nanajba nangangi burrurri-yanyi barrku-yudu.
\xe I will protect myself with my nullanulla. I am waiting for that man with my nullanulla.
\rf EK (ML notes)
\va ngukudijbi
\sy kurrukumbu
\cf balakarraba
\cf ngalijibi
\cf wujamba
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt 07/Oct/2006
\lf ngukurrijkanyi

\xe I've got to suck that blood out of the leg.

\xe That blood will come out strongly.
\rf RS
\xv Jilaba ngawu, dajkanyi ngawu. Kingkarri kuyi. Ngulyaanu.
\xe I'm going, I will hit him over the head and make him bleed.

\rf GB

\xe Previously I used to live there at Ngumarri.

\lf ngungkurru

\lx ngungkurru
\mr ngungkurru
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd sound
\lt X emit continuous non-speech sound
\ge buzz
\ge hum
\ge growl
\ge roar
\re
\so RS, JD93, MB_LH87
\xv Wanyi nana ngungkurru ngambalangi?
\sfx wanyi_nana_ngungkurru_ngambalangi.wav
\xe What's that humming sound we can hear?
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Ngungkurrunu nyulu baba.
\sfx ngungkurrunu_nyulu_baba_RS
\xe It's roaring (its motor) as it flies (of aeroplane).
\rf RS2004-05
\xv Banyajba nyulu ngambalanya, ngungkurrunu.
\xe It roared past us (of truck).
\rf rs2004-07
\xv Manku ngawu kuwardaa, ngungkurru-wurru. Burrbijbi nyulu.
\xe I can hear it (=motor) roaring. It's running.
\rf RS
\xv Ngungkurru nyulu wanamin. Ngungkurru nyulu. Marrbamarrba.
\xe The thunder is roaring. There's the sound of thunder and lightning.
\rf RS
\xv Ngungkurrirri nyulu, ngungkurru miya-yudu. Kannga nyulu ngambalangi, kijibaji.
\xe It's roaring towards us, roaring dangerously (lit. with a snake). It's coming back towards us, threatening us (of storm).
\rf RS
\xv Ngungkurru nyulu ngaki kuwadana.
\xe It (mosquito) buzzes in my ears.
\rf RS
\xv Ngungkurru nyulu kunuma. Manku ngawu, kuwadaa.
\xe The bees are humming. I can hear them with my ears.
\rf RS2003-02
\va 
\sy
\cf ngurru-wijbi
\cf wunjirri
\nt Dymock (1993) records {ngungkurru kuwada} 'ringing ears'
\cp
\nq wungkurru ??
\dt 24/Oct/2006
\lf ngungkurrirri

\lx ngunyarri
\mr ngunyarri
\sf ngunyarri-Minlaw.wav
\ps noun
\pc
\sd PEOPLE
\sd kin
\lt wife's mother; sister of wife's mother
\ge mother-in-law
\re
\so EEF, RS, GB, EK
\xv Budangku nurri yanyba, kadu-nganja. ngunyarri-nganja, nawi-nganja.
\xe (When a person dies) we others can't speak, like the dead person's father-in-law, mother-in-law or husband.
\rf RS
\xv Durrajba yalu, manngurru: ngunyarri-nganja, kadu-nganja, nawi-nganja.
\xe The mother-in-law, father-in-law and husband (of dead person) feel fear and embarrassment.
\rf RS
\xv Windijbi ninya, ngakinkanyi jawaji-nganja-anyi. Windijbi nurri ninya. Windijbi ninya. Nganyini, nganyini, ngunyarri-nganjaa. Nganyi barri.
\xe (I)'m giving you my daughter (man speaking). We are giving (her) to you. Your mother-in-law is giving you (her). (She's) yours now (i.e., promised wife).
\rf RS
\va
\sy mimayina
\cf kadu-nganja
\nt
\cp
\nq

\lx ngunyi
\mr ngunyi
\sf ngunyi.wav
\ps noun
\pc
\sd body state
\lt
\ge asleep
\ge sleep
\ge sleepy
\re
\so EF, RS, GB, EK, MF_SK
\xv Kudijbi nyulu ngunyi.
\xe He's lying asleep.
\rf RS2005-08a
\xv Bujubu nyulu ngunyi, ngurruwijbi.
\xe He's lying fast asleep snoring.
\rf rs2005-08b
\xv Bulubarrba nyulu ngunyi-wunyi. Najba nyulu buwarajini. Bulubarrba nyulu.
\xe He jumped up from his sleep. He had been dreaming (and) he jumped up (startled).
\rf RS
\xv Dururruru. Lalujbu nyulu ngunyi-wunyi.
\xe At first light, he woke up and got out of bed.
\rf RS
\xv Jala ninji lalujbu ngunyi-wunyi.
\xe You've just woken up from (your) sleep.
\rf RS
\xv Mungana nyulu kannga raji-wurru ngunyi-anyi barri.
\xe At nightfall he came back home to sleep.
\rf RS
\xv Wadabaku, kudijbi nyulu, ngunyi.
\xe The little lad is sound asleep.
\rf RS
\xv Jilakanyi ngamba ngunyi-ngunyi.
\xe We'll go and have a nap.
\rf OSBORNE_C02-000165B.TMP
\xv Dara kudi ngunyi.
\xe The dog is sleeping.
\rf MF_SK
\xv Kudijbi ngunyi.
\sfx
\xe Be sound asleep.
\rf EF_R299B1
\xv Lalujbu ngali kambana ngunyi-wunyi.
\sfx
\xe We'll get up at sunup from sleep.
\rf RS2000-09
\va
\sy
\cf bujubu
\cf kudijbi
\nt 
\cp Yinjilanji {ngunngu}
\nq n or v? n=night, moon {n and v; need to have two senses }
\dt 01/Oct/2006
\lf ngunyijbi
\lf ngunyiyana

\sn 2
\ps noun
\pc
\sd time
\lt period of time marked by night's sleep
\ge sleep
\ge nights
\ge days
\re
\so RS, GB
\xv "Yangulu ninji kannga nangkurru." "Kudijbi ngawu murrku-darrana ngunyini."
\xe "When will you come back here?" "I'll spend a few nights (lit. sleeps) away."
\rf RS2004-08a
\xv Murrkunu ngunyini ngawu jungku.
\xe I'm stopping here for three days (lit. sleeps).
\rf GB
\xv Jilaba ngawu, kannga ngawu, yanyi-anyi. Jungku ngawu yanyini barri, murrku-darrana ngunyini.
\xe I'm going back for the meeting. I'll be away at the meeting for four days.
\rf RS
\xv Waliji nungka yandujbu kujarrana ngunyini.
\xe We'll keep the meat for two days.
\rf GB
\va
\sy
\cf duru
\nt
\cp

\pc

\ge go to sleep
\ge fall asleep
\ge nod off
\re

\xe They don't nod off as their eyes are strong (i.e., they can stay awake). They don't close their eyes.
\rf RS2004-08
\xv Ngunyijbi barri nyulu.
\sfx
\xe He's gone to sleep now.
\rf GB
\xv Budangku ngawu ngunyijbi, budangku ngawu ngunyingunyijbi.
\xe I can't fall asleep, I don't feel sleepy.

\lx ngurrubu
\mr ngurru-bu
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd sound
\lt xERG cause Y to know about zDAT by speaking to Y 
\ge tell
\ge advise
\ge order
\ge warn
\re
\so AD, RS, MF_EM_CO, GB
\xv Budangku nyulu niyanya ngurrubu, winja-kurru nyulu jilaba. "Wunjuku ninji jilaba, wululuku? Ngurrubu ninji ngaan. Diindi ngaan ngurrubu."
\xe He doesn't tell us where he's going. "Where are you going old man? You tell me. Tell me straight."
\rf RS2003-02
\xv Ngurrubu nyulu, ngaliyanya, nganyi.
\xe He told us about you.
\rf RS
\xv Ngurrubu nyulu, ngaliyanya, budangku nganyi nawunu. Jungku ninji Kayawanana.
\xe He told us that you were not here, that you were at Kiana.
\rf RS
\xv Diindi ninji ngurrubu nayi lungkaji.
\xe You tell this policeman the truth.
\rf RS2004
\xv Budangku bula ngurrubu ngaan, nangkanyi wanami-anyi. Jangayarrijbi bula wanami-yudu.
\xe They didn't ask me for this drink. They sneaked away with the drink (without telling me).
\rf RS
\xv Ngurrubu nyulu ngambalanya wanami-yanyi, julakii, jukuu-jukuuu.
\xe The Top Knot Pigeon bird is warning us about the (approaching) rain.
\rf RS
\xv Yanyba ngamba yalungi, kuwada-yaan. Ngurrubu ngamba yaluwanya, budangku yalu lajibi ngambalanya.
\xe We talk to them who take no notice (lit. earless). We tell them, (but) they don't listen to us.
\rf RS
\xv Mudumbanyi ngali wunjuku ninji jilaba. Budangku ninji ngurrubu ngaliyanya.
\xe We didn't know where you had gone. You didn't tell us (where you were going).
\rf rs2000-09
\xv Ngurrubu nurri milirrimbi nangkanyi kujika-anyi. Ngurru-kanyi. Milirrimbi nurri narriyanya.
\xe We are telling about this {kujika} ceremony. (We) want to tell you and teach you (about it).
\rf RS
\xv Ngurrubu ngawu-kiya ninya, ngala ngawiji kudujbu.
\xe I was going to tell you, but I forgot.
\rf GB
\xv Ngurrubu ngawu ninya jilajudu.
\xe I told you to go.
\rf MF_EM_CO
\xv Ngurruji nana-wan jilakanyi yalu.
\xe Tell those ones they should go away.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Ngurrubu bulangka nangkanyi jamba-anyi.
\sfx
\xe They are talking about this country.
\rf RS2000-08b
\va 
\sy
\cf jangkurr
\cf jawikajba
\cf nijarrijbi
\cf yanyba
\nt
\cp
\nq Check if not {ngurubu}
\dt 18/Oct/2006

\lx ngurujbu
\mr nguru-j-bu
\sf ngurujbu.wav
\ps verb
\pc
\sd state
\lt be without energy to continue some action
\ge tire
\ge run out of breath
\ge knock up
\ge be exhausted
\re tire
\so EF, RS, MF+EM_CO, MB_LH13
\xv Ngurujbu ngawu. Burrbijbi ngawu wunamba.
\xe I knocked up. I had run a long way.
\rf RS2005-01
\xv Ngurujbu nyulu. Kudijkanyi nyulu.
\xe He was exhausted. He wanted to lie down.
\rf RS
\xv Ngurujbu ngawu, ngurujbu. Budangku ngawu jilaba. Kudijkanyi ngawu.
\xe I'm exhausted, worn out. I can't go on. I want to lie down.
\rf RS
\xv Ngurujbu ngawu. Jungku ngawu, nyungurrijini.
\xe I'm exhausted. I'll sit down and have a rest.
\rf RS
\xv Ngarrkudujbu nyulu nana wawurra. Ngurujbu nyulu.
\xe That child was short-winded. He knocked up.
\rf RS2005-01
\xv Jungku nyulu nawunu, ngurujbu nyulu.
\xe He's staying here (because) he's tired.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Jungku nyulu nawunu ngurujini.
\xe He's staying here as he's tired.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Ngurujbu ngawu burrbijini.
\xe I'm tiring as I run.
\rf MF_EM_CO
\xv Ngurujbu barri ngawu jilajini.
\sfx
\xe I'm tiring now as I'm going along.
\rf MB_LH13
\xv Ngawu jungku ngurujbu.
\sfx
\xe I'm stopping to rest.
\rf EF_R299B1
\va
\sy
\cf ngarrkudujbu
\nt Breen (W-G vocab) records {ngurujbayi} 'tired'; Dymock (1993) records as {MURUJBU]
\cp
\nq MF+EM_CO transcribed as [ngurudgini]

\lx -ni
\mr -ni
\hm 1
\sf
\sn 1
\ps suffix
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt locative
\ge on
\ge in
\ge at
\ge into
\re
\so RS, EF, GB, CO
\xv Wanamini ngawu bulwa.
\sfx warnamini-ngawu-bulwa.wav
\xe I bathe in water.
\rf EF
\xv Ngudurrini.
\xe At Ngudurri (Doomadgee).
\rf RS
\xv Wurrumbu ninya, kadimirra wawurra, wajka wanamini. 
\xe It (crocodile) will pull you down, little boy, down in the water.
\rf RS
\xv Kingkarri balana, kingkarri madarrini kayangka.
\xe High up in the sky above the clouds.
\rf rs 2005-06
\xv Manini nyulu bikali, kijibajii ngarangaraa.
\xe The wild, angry man is carrying them (spears) in this hand.
\rf rs2005-8b
\xv Bunyarrijbi dirrbu. Jawaranyana. Bujilini barri.
\xe Pour honey into a pannikin. Into a billycan.
\rf rs2002-03
\xv Baraku-yanyba nurri bulanya nanangkuya yukalini, darru-wuya.
\xe We warm those two initiates in the smoke.
\rf rs2004-08a
\xv Wanamini jakulini.
\xe In the water in the creek.
\rf RS
\xv Jangkurr nungka yanyini niyangini, budangku yalu mankuu.
\xe When we are speaking in our language, they can't understand (it).
\rf RS
\xv Jungku ngawu rajini.
\xe I'm staying in the camp.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\va -ini
\va -na
\va -nu
\sy
\cf
\nt Only used on words ending in 'i'.
\nt Variant {-ini} is used if word ends in consonant, e.g., {yukal-ini} 'in  smoke'.
\cp
\nq
\dt 29/Oct/2006

\sn 2
\ps suffix
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt suffixed to noun expressing period of time to indicate duration
\ge for (units of time)
\ge during (period of time)
\re
\so RS
\xv Jungku nurri yingkanyini durunu, kannga nurri yababalana.
\xe We'll stay away during the day and return in the evening.
\rf RS
\xv Murrkunu ngunyini ngawu jungku.
\xe I'm stopping here for three days (lit. sleeps).
\rf GB
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\va
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt

\sn 3
\ps suffix
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt suffixes to non-finite verb to indicate that its subject refers to same entity as subject of verb in matrix clause.
\ge same subject
\re
\so GB, RS
\xv Dajini ngawu najba nana burrurrin.
\sfx dajini_ngawu_najba.mp3
\xe I saw that man (as I) hit him.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Birajba yaluwangka yurrul. Jungku yalu birajini yurrulini nana-waan burrurri-darra.
\xe They're singing (themselves) a corroboree. Those men are sitting singing a corroboree song.
\rf rs2004-01
\xv Buduramba nangka warrkulii, yarrbanjii, kuwadaajini, warrakujini, ngarakini kamukamunu, kuwarda-yaan.
\xe He strangled himself with a rope, the young man who lost his reason, who was crazy, who was drinking grog and lost his mind.
\rf rs2005-08b
\xv Walijin yalu dabarraba. Dabarrajini yalu jungku.
\xe They are cooking meat. They are sitting cooking (it).
\rf RS2005-08b
\xv Darrandarra, dakalijbi nyulu balikaajini. Dakalijbi nyulu kaku-anyi, kuujini kaku-anyi.
\xe The Diver Duck, it ducks down (under the water) when hungry. It dives down to get fish, looking for fish.
\rf rs2005-02
\xv Jamurawa, jungku nyulu wanamini. Wakalinyi. Kudijbi nyulu jarrjini kakunu. \xe The water goanna, it stays down in the water. It lies (there) eating fish.
\rf RS2005-05
\xv Jungku ngawu nayi yanjini, jangkurrini.
\xe I'm sitting here talking, chatting.
\rf RS
\xv Jungku nyulu ngindini nana kadimirra, jukajuka.
\sfx
\xe That little baby boy is sitting crying.
\rf RS2004-04
\xv 
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\va
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt Where the verb is transitive, the Object noun is also marked with locative suffix.
\cp
\nq
\dt

\sn 4
\ps suffix
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt used on verb derived from noun to indicate property related to the noun
\ge having the property of
\re
\so RS
\xv Kaku kunyba walijin. Barrulkijini.
\xe The fish is good meat -- being oily.
\rf rs2003-01
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\va
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt


\lx -ni
\mr -ni
\hm 2
\sf
\sn 1
\ps suffix
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt Ergative suffix on closed set of words including demonstrative and some other determiners, possessive pronouns and words ending in a consonant. It is also used on words ending in a case suffix including the privative or negative suffix {-ya(a)}, comitative {-yudu} and dative {(k)anyi}.
\ge 
\re
\so RS, GB, EF
\xv Bakamba nyulu, wadabaa, nangangini kuwii. 
\xe The goanna busts through (from its burrow) using its head.
\rf rs2002-14
\xv Waliji ngakini daraa walyukuu bijbi, malukarraa.
\xe My good dog kills game, (being) a good hunter.
\rf GB
\xv Janybijbi mukura ngalikaduni.
\sfx ngarlika-dini.wav
\xe Throw a spear with a spearthrower.
\rf EF_R299B3
\xv Wanyini ninji diba?
\sfx
\xe What did you chop it with?
\rf GB_IS
\xv Kalijbi nyulu kudumanjaa, kuwadayani burrurrii, winyakii.
\sfx
\xe He kept on spearing him, did the crazy man, the wild bush man. 
\rf RS2004-05
\xv Banyajba nyulu ngambalanya, muwadaa — mandakii, kuwadayaani.
\sfx
\xe The whitefella, a mindless one, passed us with (his) boat.' 
\rf RS2004-07
\va
\sy
\cf nangkani
\cf nanangkani
\nt Marks word referring to subject of transitive verb, or to means expression
\cp Wambaya
\nq for possessive pronouns?

\lx nijarrijbi
\mr nijarri-j-bi
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd sound
\lt Xerg call Y by X(name)
\ge call (by name)
\ge name
\ge refer to as
\re
\so RS, MB_LH14
\xv Waanyini jangkurrini, Waanyii, nijarrijbi ngawu nayi karan.
\xe In the Waanyi language, (talking) Waanyi I call this 'kara' (stone).
\rf RS
\xv Mudinyi nana niji. Budangku narri nijarrijbi niji. Nijarrijbi narri mudinyi.
\xe That name is taboo. You don't call his name. You refer to him as "the deceased".
\rf RS
\xv Nijarrijbi ngawu ngurral. Kuku nyulu ngaan nijarrijbi.
\xe I call her granddaughter (ZDD) and she calls me granny (MMB).
\rf RS 
\xv Jawikajba ninji ngaan. Wanyi ninji nayi nijarrijbi?
\xe You ask me. What do you call this?
\rf RS
\xv Nijarrijbi yalu niji nangangi Darby Seccin.
\xe They called him by the name Darby Seccin.
\rf RS
\xv Wabula nana yaliji ngaan nijarri, ngala ngawiji ngila.
\sfx
\xe They named me that a long time ago, when I was a little girl.
\rf MB_LH14
\va
\sy
\cf nijbi
\cf niji
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt 12/Sep/2006
\lf nijarri



\lx nijbi
\mr ni-j-bi
\hm 1
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd hold (holding and transfer)
\lt Xerg cause Y to be at some place
\ge put
\ge place
\ge deposit
\re
\so EF, GB, RS, JD, CO, MB_LH13
\xv Nijbi yalu walijin balana. Balana yalu nijbi, kaku-anyi.
\xe They put meat on the hook. They put it on the hook, to (catch) fish.
\rf rs2005-08b
\xv Makarraba yalu najarrii. Nijbi yalu balakurrunu barri.
\xe They cover it with paperbark. They then put it in a ground oven.
\rf rs2005-08b
\xv Balungkana nangka nijbi.
\xe He sticks it (feather down) on himself with blood.
\rf GB
\xv Ngadarru yalu nijbi, banmarrana. Jarrkarra yalu, banmarrana 
\xe They put the plumage made of bird feathers in the headdress. They stand them up straight in the headdress.
\rf rs2005-03
\xv Wilijirri yalu kalawunyi. Barrawunu ja yalu nijbi naan.
\xe They are dragging (him) inside. They will put this (fellow) down inside the house.
\rf rs2005-08a
\xv Bulkunyi yalu nijbi, ngalunu. 
\xe They are putting a design on his chest.
\rf RS
\xv Karrbijbi nurri. Jaluki, janybijbi nurri. Nijbi nurri dungalan.
\xe We cut it (open). The intestines we toss aside. We put in hot stones.
\rf RS2003-03
\xv Nijbi nyulu, makulu nangangi, janbana.
\xe She lays (lit. 'puts') her eggs in a nest.
\rf RS2002-11
\xv Nijbi nyulu ngarrawa kudurrumbu nyulu. Budangku nyulu mankuu. Nijbi nyulu junuu. Mamanumbu nyulu.
\xe He's forgotten where he put the salt. He can't recall. He put it somewhere. He's forgotten (where).
\rf RS
\xv Nijbi nurri, nganyi, nganyini nganana. Nayi nganyi mangkarri-nganja.
\xe We betroth (place) her for you, (put her) on your lap. This is your (promised) wife.
\rf RS
\xv Nijbi wajka jambana.
\sfx
\xe He put it down on the ground.
\rf EF_R299B2
\va
\sy
\cf jarrkarra
\cf nijbijbi
\cf yakujbu
\nt A young girl's betrothal was traditionally marked by the future parents-in-law placing the little girl in the lap of her future husband.
\nt Note that the imperative or command form is {niya}.
\cp
\nq

\lf nimbalangi

\lx nimbalangi
\mr nimba-la-ngi
\sf
\sn 1
\ps pronoun
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt second person dual dative pronoun
\ge your
\ge yours
\ge belonging to you (two)
\ge for you (two)
\ge to you (both)
\re
\so RS, GB, MF+EM_CO

\xe You two have the same mother. You shouldn't be fighting.
\rf RS
\xv Ngaba ngawu walijin nimbalangi.
\xe I'm bringing meat for you two.
\rf RS
\xv Kajamba ngawu walijin nimbalangi.
\xe I'll divide up this meat for you two.
\rf RS
\xv Nanganja ngawu waliji nimbalangi wululuku-wiya.
\xe I'm fetching meat for you two old men.
\rf RS
\xv Durrajba nyulu nimbalangi.
\xe He's afraid of you two.
\rf GB
\xv Jawikajba ngawu, nimbalanya, kamarrangi-wiya. Yanyi-yanyi, Waanyi-anyi barri. Yanyi-anyi nimbalangi-yanyi.
\xe I'm asking you two kamarrangi men about language, about the Waanyi language, about your language.
\rf RS
\xv Nimbalangi mimi.
\xe Your mother's father.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku nimbalangka daba, yingkamali ngada-nganja, nimbalangi.
\xe You two can't fight because you have one mother for both of you.
\rf RS
\xv Nimbalangi nana dara.
\xe That dog belongs to you two.
\ef MF+EM_CO

\sy
\cf nganyi
