\lx ninji
\mr ninji
\sf ninyji.wav
\ps pronoun
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt Second person singular nominative pronoun
\ge you
\re you
\so EF, EK, GB, RS, JD93
\xv Ninji ngaki yanyba.
\sfx ninyji-ngaki-yanyba.wav
\xe You talk to me.
\rf EF
\xv Ninjimi karrinjaa.
\sfx ninyjimi-karrinyjaa.wav
\xe You stay!
\rf EF
\xv Winjika ninji?
\xe Who are you?
\rf RS
\xv Mayi ninya burra-daba, wanuu. Mayi ninji bajawajaa.
\sfx mayi ninya burra-daba#wanuu.wav
\sfx mayi ninji bajawajaa.wav
\xe The tobacco, it might knock you out. You might throw a fit.
\rf rs2005-04
\xv Balyanga ninji lalumbu. Kudijbi nyulu.
\xe Don't you wake (him). He's sleeping.
\rf rs-2000-09
\xv Yakujbu ninji banjana rajini.
\xe You left it back home.
\rf rs2004-04
\xv Ngabama ninji waliji nayi, maman. Nanangkurru badibadi-wurru.  
\xe You take this meat and tucker over to that old person.
\rf rs2000-09
\xv Ja-ninji baba barulajba. Kingkarri-nanja, walajba ninji nurriyanya, jungku-wurru.
\xe You will fly over. From up there, you'll look down on us sitting (here).
\rf rs2005-08
\xv Ninji, nanangkanyi bawa-nganja-anyi, ja-ninji nanganja.
\xe You, you will marry (that woman) who belonged (=was married) to that elder brother (of yours).
\rf rs2002-14
\xv Wayi barri ninji ngaba ngaki danya? Budangku ngawu, budangku ngawu ngaba nganyi. Mamanumbu ngawu.
\xe Did you bring me (any) clothes? I didn't bring you any. I forgot.
\rf rs2003-01
\xv Winja-bunyi ninji? Kala-wunyi ninji?
\xe Where are you from? What place are you from?
\rf RS
\xv Winja ninji dadarrba?
\xe Where are you hurting?
\rf GB
\xv Miya-anyi ninji wayi durrajba?
\sfx miyaanyi-ninyji-wayi-durrajb.wav
\xe Are you frightened of snakes?
\rf EF
\va
\sy
\cf nimba
\cf narri
\nt Only used to address one person.
\nt Suffix {-mi} on {ninji} marks emphasis.

\dt 29/Aug/2006
\lf ninjiji
\lf ninya
\lf nganyi
\lf nganyingka

\lx ninjiji
\mr ninji-ji
\hm
\sf
\sn
\ps pronoun
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt Past form of second person singular nominative pronoun {ninji}
\ge you
\re
\so
\xv Ninjiji ngaa daba?
\xe Did you mean to hit me?
\rf GB
\xv Ninjiji ngaki kuujbu.
\xe You were looking for me.
\rf GB
\xv Ngamuyu ninjiji kudajba wabula, ngala ninji wankan jungku.
\xe I thought you had died a long time ago, but you are still alive.
\rf GB
\va 
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt The suffix {-ji} is only used in our corpus on sentences referring to past events or actions, comparable with the suffix {-i} in Garrwa. However, past events are more commonly referred to without any indication of tense, so there is no formal distinction between present and past events.
\cp
\nq
\dt
\lf ninji


\lx ninya
\mr ninya
\sf ninya.wav
\sf ninya02.wav
\sf ninya03.wav

\sd grammar
\lt accusative form of second person singular pronoun {ninji}
\ge you
\re

\sfx biijbi ninya nangkani-it'll bite you.aif
\xe This one can bite you.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Bijbi nyulu ninya.
\sfx biijbi nyulu ninya.aif
\xe It can bite you.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Mayi ninya burra-daba wanuu. Mayi ninji bajawajaa.
\xe The tobacco might knock you out. You might throw a fit.
\rf rs2005-04
\xv Bakarrijbi ngawu ninya kunburrkii.
\xe I'll burn you with a fire-stick.
\rf rs2003-05
\xv Windijbi kiya ngawu ninya, namirraa. Budangku ngawu.
\sfx
\xe I would give you money, but I don't have any.
\rf RS2003-03
\xv Barimbi nyulu ninya kudulu.
\xe It damages your heart.

\xv Danyalamba ngawu ninya balungka-anyi, jukulii.
\xe I bashed you till you bled, with a boomerang.
\rf rs2002-03
\xv Mayi nyulu karrbijbi ninya nukami, malangkarrii. 
\xe The sheet of iron might cut your feet. 
\rf rs2005-06
\xv Ninya, kiya ngawu ninya windijbi walijii balikajkurru.
\sfx ninya_kiyangawuninyawindijbF.wav
\xe You, I would have given you meat when you were hungry.

\xv Barrakalaba nyulu ninya lungkajii.
\xe The policeman is restraining you.
\rf rs2004

\xe He's got you.

\xe I robbed you of meat.
\rf MF+EM_CO

\sy

\sn
\ps pronoun
\pc

\lt first and second person dual dative pronoun

\ge our

\re our (yours and mine)

\lx -nu
\mr -nu
\sf
\sn 1
\ps suffix
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt locative suffix
\ge at
\ge in
\ge on
\ge near
\re
\so GB, EF, RS, CO
\xv Bakarrijbi yalu jangunu.
\xe They burn (them) in the fire.
\rf rs2002-03
\xv Makarraba yalu najarrii. Nijbi yalu balakurrunu barri.
\xe They cover it with paperbark. They then put it in a ground oven.
\rf rs2005-08b
\xv Barrawunu ja yalu nijbi naan.
\xe They will put this (fellow) down inside the house.
\rf rs2005-08a
\xv Banyajba nyulu ngambalanya, ngungkurrunu.
\xe He roared past us.
\rf rs2004-07
\xv Kudijkanyi barri ngawu, ngandunu.
\xe I want to lie down in the shade now.
\xv RS
\xv Bulkunyi yalu nijbi, ngalunu. 
\xe They are putting a design on (his) chest.
\rf RS
\xv Muwana kuyuwarrunu, kudijbi ngawu, kadimirra bulungu.
\xe Inside a coolimon is where I slept when I was a little baby.
\rf rs2000-05
\xv Bulwidarri, makulunu bulwidarri.
\sfx
\xe The white, the white in the egg.
\rf RS
\xv Burrandi ngawu kudijbi, kujarrana jangunu.
\xe I sleep between two fires.
\rf RS
\xv Jungku nyulu dalunu.
\xe She's sitting in the shade.
\rf RS2004-08a
\xv Kindiba ngamba jungku, jalanya, durunu barri.
\xe We are now sitting here sweating, now that we are in the sun.
\rf RS2004-04
\xv Jungku ngawu dundunu.
\xe I stayed on the island.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\va -na
\va -ni
\va -ini
\sy
\cf
\nt The variant {-nu} is only used when suffixed to word ending in vowel {u}.
\nt See entry for {-ni} for more information on the use of this suffix.
\cp
\nq
\dt 29/Aug/2006

\sn 2
\ps suffix
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt Suffixed to a compass direction term the locative suffix indicates direction away from
\ge from
\re
\so RS
\xv Bayungunu ngawu jilaba.
\xe I came from the west.
\rf rs2005-06
\xv Bayungunu nurri babaa karurri.
\xe From the west we flew east.
\rf rs2005-06
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\va
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt

\sn 3
\ps suffix
\pc
\sd time
\lt expresses duration when suffixed to noun referring to period or unit of time
\ge for
\ge during
\re
\so RS
\xv Jungku nurri yingkanyini durunu, kannga nurri yababalana.
\xe We'll stay away during the day and return in the evening.
\rf RS
\xv Jilaba nurri dururrurunu.
\xe We are going at first light.
\rf RS
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\va
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt

\sn 4
\ps suffix
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt suffixed to the non-finite form of verb it signals that understood subject of the non-finite verb refers to same person or thing as subject of related clause.
\ge while
\re
\so RS, GB
\xv Banyajba nyulu ngambalanya, ngungkurrunu.
\xe He roared past us (lit. (He) passed us roaring).
\rf rs2004-07
\xv Jamurawa, kudijbi nyulu jarrjini kakunu. 
\xe The water goanna, it lies (there) eating fish.
\rf RS2005-05
\xv Jungkunu nyulu yanyba ngambalangi.
\xe He sits and talks to us.
\rf RS
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\va
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt Object of verb is also marked by locative suffix
\cp
\nq

\lx nukami
\mr nukami
\sf nukami.wav
\sf nukami-foot.wav
\sf nukami02-foot.wav
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc nukami.jpg
\pc foot.jpg
\sd BODY
\lt foot or hind leg of animal
\ge foot
\ge feet
\ge hoof
\re 
\re hind leg
\so EF, EK, GB, RS, CO, LM, JD93, SC_BB, MS_SK, AP+AF_PS, JP_TT
\xv Ninji nukami-yudi jilanji yiniyini nanganjana.
\xe You've got feet (so) go and get it yourself.
\rf GB
\xv Dadarrba barri ngawu nukamin.
\xe My foot is now hurting.
\rf RS2002-3
\xv Mayi nyulu karrbijbi ninya nukami, malangkarrii. Badawamba kalarrangi, badawamba nukamin.
\xe The sheet of iron might cut your feet. It might pierce right through the feet. 
\rf rs2005-06
\xv Janguu ngaan bakarrijbi nukamin, danyali. 
\xe The hot coals burned me on the foot. 
\rf rs2003-05
\xv Babararra nyulu, balarrka, walijin. Babararra nyulu, kingkarri-nukami.
\xe The bat hangs (there), it is (good) meat. It hangs with its feet  upwards.
\rf rs2003-04
\xv Mayi ninji barijbi barri. Nukamin, balungka.
\xe Your feet might get hurt, and bleed.
\rf rs2005-06
\xv Kadimirraa birakii ngaan bijbi nukamin, kadimirraa.
\xe Little ants are biting me on the foot. Tiny ones.
\rf rs2005-06
\xv Ngabaa nurri bulaka, karurri, nukamii, mandakii wululukuu. Mungkuji ngaki.
\xe We took the cattle east, on foot, (with) the old white man. He was my boss.
\rf RS2002-10
\xv Namanyba ngawu ninya nukamii, duka.
\xe I'll press down on your throat with my foot (and choke you).
\rf RS2002-03
\xv Jarrbalajba nyulu nukamin, darrandarra.
\xe The Diver Duck has splayed feet.
\rf RS2003-03
\xv Ngamuyu miya nayi kajalaba ngakinburru, nukamini.
\xe I thought it was a snake climbing up on me, onto my foot.
\rf RS
\xv Nukami muwa.
\sfx
\xe Arch of foot.
\rf EFR299A1
\va
\sy
\cf
\nt Also given as 'claw' of bird MF_SK
\cp Yinjilanji {lukami} 'foot'; Wlp {luku} 'heel'

\xv Jungku nurri durunu. Rajba nurriyanya duruu. 
\xe We are sitting in the sun. The sun is baking us.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf ngambalanya
\an
\nt
\cp

\dt 19/Sep/2006
\lf nyungurrijini


\lx rajba
\mr ra-j-ba
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd heat
\lt Xerg (source of heat) produces characteristic effect on Y
\ge burn
\ge heat
\ge bake
\ge cook
\ge ripen
\re
\so RS, EF, JD, JP_TT, GB, MB_)LH
\xv Kawa jangu-wunyi! Rajba ninya.
\xe Come away from the fire! It can burn you.
\rf EF
\xv Rajba ngaan. Duruu. Rajba niyanya jalwaa janguu.
\xe It's burning me, the sun (is). The strong heat is burning us.
\rf rs2005-09
\xv Jungku nurri durunu. Rajba nurriyanya duruu. Ngarrangarrajba nurri.
\xe We are sitting in the sun. The sun is baking us. We are getting hot.
\rf RS
\xv Jambaa nurriyanya rajba nukami, kijibajii nangkani duruu.
\xe The ground is burning our feet, (because of) this fierce sun.
\rf RS
\xv Kuuni ninji jilanji kuuni! Mayi ninya rajba janguu, nukamin.
\xe You move away, away! The fire might burn your feet.
\rf RS
\xv Rajba ngaan ngadaraa, duruu. Kindiba ngawu.
\xe The sun is baking me, the sun is. I'm sweating
\rf RS2004-12-04
\xv Jilana nurri dadarrba nukami. Rajba nurriyanya jila-wurru.
\xe Our feet hurt as we go along. It burns us as we going along.
\rf RS
\xv Windijbi nyulu ngalyaa, nanangkani mamaa. Lungkarraa. Darimaa. Budangku ngamba jarrba. Wingki nyulu. Duruu, rajba barri nana maman, darima. Nanganja ngamba. Jarrba barri ngamba, jangkaranyi.
\xe That bitter unripe plum makes (us) sick. We can't eat it when it’s raw. When the sun has ripened the plum fruit, we pick it and then we eat it, ripe. 
\rf RS2002-11
\xv Duruu rajba nukami.
\sfx
\xe The sun burns the feet.
\rf JP_TT
\xv Ngaliyangi wawurranyi, waliji ranja!
\xe Cook the meat for me and my kid.
\rf MF_GB76
\xv Nukami ngaan rajba.
\sfx
\xe [Hot sand] burnt my feet.
\rf GB_IS
\va yajba
\sy
\cf bakarrijbi
\cf dabarraba
\cf jarringkajba
\cf jangkaranyi
\cf ngarrangarra
\cf wukarrijbi
\nt Note that this verb is distinct from one where a source of heat is manipulated to cause something to become hot. Another word is used of something which is getting hot when the source of heat is not specified.
\cp
\nq cook? 2005-03
\dt 21/Sep/2006
\lf jangka-rajba
\lf kuyi-rajba
\lf ngarra-rajba
\lf ranja

\sn 2
\ps verb
\pc
\sd heat
\lt X be source of heat
\ge burn
\ge heat
\ge heat up
\ge get hot
\re
\so EF, GB
\xv Rajba nana jangun.
\sfx
\xe That fire is burning.
\rf GB
\xv Duru nana rajba.
\xe That sun is heating up.
\rf GB
\xv Rajba nyulu.
\sfx
\xe It's burning.
\rf IS_GB
\xv Jangun rajba.
\sfx
\xe The fire is burning.

\va

\cf ngarrangarra

\lx raji
\mr raji
\sf raji.wav
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd land
\lt habitual living area
\ge main camp
\ge country
\ge home
\ge homeland
\ge place
\re 
\so EF, RS, GB, JD93, SC_BB, JP_TT, MF_CO, MB_LH13
\xv Raji-wunyi.
\sfx raji-wunyi.wav
\xe From home
\rf EF
\xv Raji-wurru
\sfx raji-wurru.wav
\xe to home
\rf RS
\xv Yakujbu ninji banjana rajini.
\xe You left it back home.
\rf rs2004-04
\xv Kannga nyulu ngambalangi, bikali-daba, ngabaa, kanngaa raji-wurru barri.
\xe He's coming back for us to pick us up and then take us back home.
\rf rs2005-08a
\xv Ngajabarra, bujimala-yudu. Nana raji, nanangkanyi wululuku-anyi, balyarrinji-anyi.
\xe Ngajabarra is associated with the Rainbow Serpent. That place belongs to that old man, Balyarrinyi (skin).
\rf rs2004-08b
\xv Kannga-anyi ngamba raji-wurru barri jalanya.
\xe We'll return home directly.
\rf RS2005-02
\xv Mayi nyulu jungku nanawunu, rajini.
\xe He might be there, at home.
\rf rs2003-03
\xv Jungku nimba rajini.
\xe You two are staying at home.
\rf RS
\xv Winjana kalana yalu jungku, winjana rajini?
\xe At what place do they live, at what homeland?
\rf RS
\xv Warrakuujbu nungka. Budangku nungka kawa-najba raji niyangi.
\xe We're lost. We can't find our camp.
\rf RS
\va yaji
\sy
\cf jamba
\cf kala
\nt
\cp
\nq

\ge eye
\re eye
\so GB, EF, RS, EK, LM, JD, SC_BB, MS_SK, JP_TT, MB_LH12
\xv Kudumbu nangka rami.
\sfx
\xe He shut his eyes.
\rf RS2005-01
\xv Najba ngawu ramii.
\sfx najba ngawu ramii.wav
\xe I see him with my eyes.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Kuujbu nyulu rami-yanyi kunuwaa.
\xe Flies go for (our) eyes.
\rf RS2005-06
\xv Bijbi niyanya kunumaa ramin. Dumbu-lulujbu nungka rami.
\xe The flies bite us in the eyes. Our eyes swell up.
\rf RS2005-06
\xv Bariyijbi ngawu ramin. Rami ngaan bariyimbi.
\xe My eyes are getting bad. It's damaging my eyes.
\rf RS2005-8a
\xv Makarraba ngambalanya rami jundurri, jambaa, wulukuu, jila-kurru. Kudumbu ngambalangka rami jamba-wunyi. 
\xe The dust covers our eyes, the big quantity of dirt, as we go along. We close our eyes to keep out the dirt.
\rf rs2004-07
\va yami
\sy
\cf
\nt Meaning also extends to 'sight'

\nq

\lf ramii

\lx ramijbi

\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd contact (impact and violence)
\sd effect
\lt
\ge break
\ge split
\ge tear
\re
\so EF, RS, MF_SK, CO, GB
\xv Ramijbi nyulu kakuu, waduku ngaki.
\xe The fish broke my line.
\rf RS

\xe Those senseless ones, they broke my fishing line, ruined it.
\rf RS
\xv Jawikajba ngawu, winjikaa ngaki ramijbi wadukun?
\xe I ask him, who broke my fishing line?
\rf RS2004-03
\xv Najba ngawu ramijkurru.
\xe I saw it break.
\rf RS
\xv Karrbijbi nungka nayi bambularra ramijbi.
\xe We cut off the tail.
\rf RS2000-03
\xv Jalwa nayi walijin. Ramijbi nyulu ngaan mayi.
\sfx
\xe This meat is tough. It broke my tooth.
\rf RS2002-04-14
\xv Daba nurri ramijbi, nangkani wuliwulii.
\xe We break it off by striking it with this small round rock.
\rf rs2002-04-13
\xv Mirramba yalu babakana. Daba yalu karaa. Ramijbi yalu. Ngukujaba yalu yamarrina barri.
\xe They used to make stone knives. They would strike (the core)  with a rock and break it (in two). They would sharpen it on a flat rock.
\rf rs2002-04
\xv Ramijbi ngawu, ramijbi -- danyan.
\sfx
\xe I tore (them), tore the clothes.
\rf MF_SK
\xv Rama!
\xe Break (it)!
\rf MF+EM_CO

\sy
\cf karrbijbi

\ge strike
\re
\so RS, GB
\xv Rangkijibi nyulu marrbamarrbaa. Kundan. Bujimala-yudu. Miya-yudu. Wurrarra jalwa. 
\xe Lightning strikes the trees. The strong wind comes with the force of the Rainbow Serpent. 
\rf rs2003-01
\xv Rangkijbi nyulu kunda. Jambalamba nyulu kundan.
\xe It (lightning) struck a tree. It blew the tree to pieces.
\rf RS2002-04
\xv Mularrijbi nyulu jamba rangkijbi nyulu.
\xe It raised the ground where it struck.
\rf RS
\xv Jukulii rangkijbi bawayi.
\sfx
\xe (My) brother killed (it) with a boomerang.

\lf rangkimbi
\sn 2
\ps verb
\pc
\sd
\lt Xerg cause Zerg to move through air and come into contact with Y
\ge hit
\ge hurl at
\ge pelt
\ge shoot
\ge strike
\ge throw at
\re
\so RS
\xv Rangkijbi jukulii. Burra-daba. Dangalbangi janki.
\xe He hit him with a boomerang, knocked him down. Smashed it against the back of his neck.
\rf RS2002-03
\xv Rangkijbi kiya nyulu ngaan.
\xe He would have shot me.
\rf RS2002-07
\xv Kudanba ngawu rangkijbi, jukulii, burra-daba.
\sfx kudanba ngawu rangkijbi burradaba.wav
\xe I strike him dead, with a boomerang, knock him down.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Kuyii ngawu rangkijbi.
\sfx kuyii ngawu rangkijbi.wav
\xe I hit him with the 'head' (of the boomerang).
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Narri, daba narriyangka jukulii. Rangkijbi narriyangka jukulii.
\sfx
\xe You mob, you are fighting with boomerangs. You're pelting each other with boomerangs.
\rf RS2000-07b
\xv Rangkij-kana  yakujbu! Yakujbu ninji! Ngarrimba nganyi.
\xe Stop hitting him. You leave him alone. (He's) your friend.
\rf RS
\xv Najba ngawu rangkij-kurru.
\sfx
\xe I saw (him) shoot it.
\rf RS
\xv Rangkijbi yalu Waanyi-darra, burrurrin, mandaki-darraa. Rangkijbi ngajarrii.
\xe The white men shot the Waanyi men, shot (them) with rifles.
\rf RS
\xv Jukulii nyulu rangkijbi, ngaba.
\xe He struck (him) on the shoulder with a boomerang.
\rf GB
\xv Barimbi ninji. Rangkijbi ninji kundaa.
\xe You missed it. Pelt it with a sick!
\rf rs2005-06
\xv Mayi bula  rangkijbi ngaan karaa nanangkujarraa.
\xe Those two might pelt me with stones.
\rf RS
\xv Rangkijbi bulangka, jukulii, kujarraa.
\xe These two are pelting each other with boomerangs.
\rf RS
\xv Kuna-najba ngawu rangkij-kurru nana burrurrin.
\xe I spied on that man (when he was) shooting.
\rf RS
\sy

\lx rirrajba
\mr rirra-j-ba
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc chase.jpg
\sd motion
\lt
\ge chase after
\ge run down
\ge hunt down
\re
\so RS
\xv Rirrajba ninji ngaa.
\xe You chased me.
\rf RS2002-04
\xv Rirrajba nurri. Jaruu.
\xe We chased after him, but couldn't catch him.
\rf RS2005-01
\xv Mayi ninya bijbi. Rirrajba ninya daraa kijibajii.
\xe It might bite you. That savage dog might chase you down.
\rf RS2004-04
\xv Rirrajba nyulu nan, yarraman-yuduu.
\xe He chased him down on horseback.
\rf RS2005-09
\xv Rirrajba nyulu nana kakun, wandika-yudu-nii.
\xe He went after that fish with a big fish net.
\rf RS2004-07
\xv Barimbi nyulu, barimbi, nanangkani kirriyaa. Daraa barri rirrajba, rirrajba naan. Daraa, rirrajba barri nyulu nana wadaban.
\xe That woman missed (hitting) it. Then the dog gave chase, chased it. The dog, it then chased down that goanna.
\rf RS2004-07
\xv Bulaka nurri rirrajba, yarraman-yuduu.
\xe We chased down cattle on horseback.
\rf rs2002-03
\xv Burrbijbi ngawu, milwa-milwa, durrajini. Nangkanyi kirriya-anyi. Rirrajba nyulu ngaan, nguwajini.
\xe I took off looking around behind me frightened. It was over this woman. He chased after me out of jealousy.
\rf RS
\xv Burrbijbi nyulu. Rirrajba ngawu, kajalaa daba bari-barimbi.
\xe It ran off. I chased it down and tried to hit it with my yamstick but kept missing it.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf binanyba
\cf jakajba
\cf malijibi
\nt
\cp
\nq MF+EM_CO {rirarrajba} 'follow'

\lx -waan
\mr -waan
\sf
\sn 1
\ps suffix
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt plural suffix on demonstrative and quantifier words
\ge more than two of
\ge many of
\ge several
\re many
\re several
\so RS, GB
\xv Kanungku yalu na-waan.
\xe These (people) are approaching.
\rf RS
\xv Nana-waan, banjana yalu jilaba, ngambalangi, jalanya. Narrunguja-yudu.
\xe Those (people), they are coming right behind us, with a truck.
\rf rs2002-13
\xv Ngaki mungkuji, Karrwa, nana-waan badibadi, wululuku.
\xe My relations are Garrwa, those old women and old men.
\rf rs2004-05
\xv Nana-waan kudaya-waan, jilaba yalu, bayinga. 
\xe Those others, they are going on the west side. 
\rf rs2005-08b
\xv Birajba yaluwangka yurrul. Jungku yalu birajini yurrulini nana-waan burrurri-darra.
\xe They're singing (themselves) a corroboree. Those men are sitting singing a corroboree song.
\rf rs2004-01
\xv Ngurrubu nurri nana-waan wawurra, budangku yalu jiringkijbi nurriyanya.
\xe We tell those kids, (but) they take no notice of us.
\rf rs2003-01
\xv Dajaya yalu ngambalanya nana-waani burrurri-darraa, Kalkudunguu. Dajaya yalu ngambalanya, jungku ngamba nawunu, Kanmangini, Waanyi-darra.
\xe Lest those Kalkudungu men beat us up, lest they fight us, let's stay here at Kanmangi as we are Waanyi.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Ngulumirri, dabarraba nyulu. Jarrba yalu dawurrumbu. Budangku yalu yakujbu, nana-waan-kanyi.
\sfx jarrba yalu dawurrumbu-they ate all.wav
\sfx budangku yalu yakujbu nana-waan-kanyi.wav
\xe The barramundi, she cooked it. They ate it all up. They didn't leave anything for others.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Mularri-kurru nyulu kuku-najba nana-waan kirriya-darra.
\xe He was looking at those women who were lifting (him).
\rf RS2005-08a
\xv Budangku ninji yanyba nana-waan-kanyi.
\xe You can't speak those (people's) language.
\rf RS
\xv Na-waan warrwarri kuwada-yaan.
\xe These kids have no sense.
\rf RS
\xv Ngabaa nyulu na-waan nangkurru, kannga nyulu. Na-waan, yakujbu nawunu.
\xe He's bringing them (=these ones) back here. He's coming back. These ones, he's dropping (them) off here.
\rf RS
\va -wa
\va -waa
\va -wan
\sy 
\cf -darra
\nt
\cp

\lx wabula
\mr wabula
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd time
\lt relatively distant time before present
\ge before
\ge previously
\ge long time ago
\ge some time ago
\ge olden days
\re
\so EF, RS, GB, EK, CO
\xv Wabula ninji ngaan manii windijbi.
\xe You gave me money before.
\rf GB
\xv Kurrbali-wurru ngamba jilaba, nanangkurru wabula kalawurru-wurru.
\xe We went to Kurrbali, went there to the river before.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku ngawiji nan burrurri najanyi wabula.
\xe I haven't seen this man before.
\rf GB
\xv Jalanya ninji jilaba nangkurru. Budangku ninji jilaba nangkurru wabula. Jala-wanyi ninji.
\xe You came here recently. You haven't been coming here for a long time. You're a newcomer.
\rf RS
\xv Jungku nyulu nayi ngila wabula. Budangku ngawu, jala-wanyi ngawu.
\xe This girl has been here before. Not me, I'm a newcomer.
\rf RS
\xv Wabula nyulu jila. 
\xe He went a long time ago.
\rf GB
\xv Jungku ngawu wabula, barrawunu.
\xe I stayed a long time in the settlement.
\rf RS
\xv Jila ngawu nangkurru wabula.
\xe I came here a long time ago.
\rf GB
\xv Wabula-kiya ninji jila.
\xe You might go for a long time.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Jungku ngawu wabula.
\sfx
\xe I've been sitting a long time.
\rf IS_GB
\xv Bidirrikan nurri jarrba, bidirrika, wabula.
\sfx
\xe We ate kangaroo, mountain kangaroo, a long time ago.

\dt 20/Sep/2006
\lf wadukarraa


\lx waduku
\mr warduku
\sf waduku-fishingline.wav
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd manufacture
\lt
\ge fishing line
\ge fishing ^hook
\re
\so RS, EK, EF, JD, CO, GB
\xv Nanganja wadukun.
\sfx nanganyja-wardukun.wav
\xe Get the fishing line.
\rf EF
\xv Murrurrungku, wakaramba ngawu wadukuu. Bala-wajba ngawu, wadukuu.
\xe I catch swordfish using a fishing line with a hook. I hook (them) with a fishing hook.
\rf RS
\xv Ramijbi nyulu kakuu, waduku ngaki.
\xe A fish broke my fishing line.
\rf RS
\xv Wajarrijbi yalu kaku-wanyi, wadukuu.
\xe They are fishing with fishing lines.
\rf RS
\xv Bala yalu manii nanganja, waduku-wanyi wadaba-wunyi. Nanganja yalu
nguli bala wadaba-wunyi.
\xe They got the hook for their fishing line from a goanna, by hand. They got the bone for the hook from a goanna.
\rf RS
\xv Ngulumirri-yanyi nyulu kuujbu waduku-yudu.
\xe They look for barramundi with fishing lines.
\rf RS
\xv Kannga nayi ngila ngambalangi waduku-yudu.
\xe This little girl is coming back with (her) fishing line.
\rf RS
\xv Karubu-yanyba yalu, wadukuu.
\xe They are fishing with fishing lines.
\rf RS
\xv Nanganja yalu bala. Nijbi yalu wadukunu. Wajka yalu, jilaba wajka kala-wurru. Wajarrijbi yalu, kakun. 
\xe They get the hook (and) they put it onto the fishing line. They go down to the river. They go fishing.
\rf RS
\xv Wilijirri nyulu. Wilijirri wadukuu.
\sfx wilijirri nyulu wilijirri wadukuu.wav
\xe He's pulling it in (of fish). Pulling it in with a fishing line.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Nanganja ngawu nganyi waduku, jila-kanyi ninji wurrunkunmijini.
\xe I've got a hook for you so you can go fishing.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\va
\sy
\cf bala
\cf warrku
\nt Hook traditionally made from collarbone of goanna (JD93).
\cp
\nq glossed as hook in 2002-2 ; warduku
\dt 19/Sep/2006

\rf RS

\rf RS

\xe They want to catch fish, catch fish for us.

\lx wajili
\mr 
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd animal
\sd insect
\la
\lt native bee that makes hive on ground
\ge ground ^bee
\re
\so IS_GB78, AD2000
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\va
\sy
\cf kunmarri
\cf KURUDU
\cf marrji
\cf ngiri
\cf wangka
\an
\nt "He sit down longa ground." (Ivy George in IS_GB78)
\nt According to Archie Dick (2000) {wajili} is bigger than bee with hive in tree, and is called "black bee".
\nt Archie Dick explained, "They even live in ant nests; they eat out all the ants and make their honey store in there underground, on top or under."
\cp
\nq
\dt
\lf

\sn 2
\ps noun
\pc
\sd insect related
\sd food
\la
\lt honey found in hive under rocks on ground, or in ant-bed
\ge ground honey
\ge Ground Sugarbag
\ge Ant-bed Sugarbag
\so RS, GB, EK, GW
\xv
\xe
\rf
\va
\sy
\cf binnyi
\cf dirrbu
\cf kunuma
\cf mungi
\cf GURUDA (JD93)
\nt This honey is said to be dark colour and is described by Dymock (1993) as "Girl Sugarbag".
\cp
\nq found under rocks on the ground
\dt 30/Oct/2006

\lx wajka
\mr wajka
\sf wajka.wav
\sf wajka-down.wav
\sf wajka02-down.wav
\sf wajka03-down.wav
\sf wajka-down_R299b2.wav
\ps noun
\pc
\sd spatial
\sd direction
\lt position that is lower than reference position
\ge down
\ge below
\re
\so EF, EK, RS, GB, JD
\xv Langanba nyulu kundana wajka-kulaji wululuku balarrka.
\xe The big flying fox hangs head down in the tree.
\rf rs2003-03
\xv Banyajba ninji nurriyanya, jungku-wurru. Wajka.
\xe You will pass over us, sitting (here) below.
\rf rs2005-08a
\xv Mayi bulangka burru-daba, wajka jamba-wurru.
\xe They might knock each other down to the ground.
\rf rs2004-05
\xv Jayajayamba nyulu burra-daba nana mama wajka jamba-wurru. Jalwaa wurrarraa.
\xe That strong wind shakes it (the tree) and makes that fruit fall down to the ground.
\rf RS
\xv Dakalijbi nyulu kunda-wunyi jambana wajka. 
\xe He quickly got down from the tree onto the ground. 
\rf RS2005-02
\xv Damarrijbi barri yalu, wajka, wanami-wurru.
\xe They are now slipping down into the water.
\rf RS2002-07
\xv Raji ngaki wajka kalana. Dumularraa ngan jakajba kala-wunyi.
\xe My camp was down near the river. The flood waters chased me away from the river.
\rf GB
\xv Wurrarra-mukunu, jarrijbi ngamba, wajka, wakalinyi. Kumayangunu.
\sfx
\xe To get out of the wind, let’s go down inside the cave.
\rf RS2000-09
\xv Jarrijbi nyulu ngambalangi wajka barri, kulikulijibi.
\xe It (sun) is now setting on us, is now down low, is going down.
\rf RS2005-02
\xv Mudii nyulu wajka niyangi.
\sfx
\xe He's down hiding from us two.
\rf RS2005-02
\xv Nijbijbi ngawu kunda nukamii, namanyba. Namanyba wajka jambana.
\xe I stand on the stick and hold it down. Hold it down on the ground.
\rf RS
\xv Jilaba nimba nangkurru wajka, kala-wurru. 
\xe You two come down here, to the river. 
\rf RS
\xv Makarraba nangka jambana wajka barri nayi.
\xe He (goanna) buries himself way down in the ground.
\rf EK
\xv Wajka kuyi.
\xe Face down.
\rf JD93
\va
\sy kalawunyi
\cf kulikulijibi
\cf mudii
\cf wakalinyi
\an kingkarri
\nt
\cp
\nq

\xe He's having a spell under a shady tree.

\lx Wakaya

\so EK

\lx wakijbi
\mr waki-j-bi
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd SPATIAL
\lt x be absent from some location
\ge  be absent
\ge be away (from)
\ge be out
\re
\so RS
\xv Budangku nana wululuku. Wakijbi nyulu wululuku, bikalini. Wawurra-darra nyulu burra-daba. Wawurra-darra, bikali nyulu narrungujaa.
\xe That's not the old man. The old man is still away, transporting (them). He's dropping off the kids. He took the kids with the truck.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf budangkuujbu
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt


\lx waku
\mr waku
\sf waku.wav
\sf waku02.wav
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd motion
\lt activity occuring in less time than average
\ge fast
\ge quick
\ge rapid
\re
\so EF, GB, RS, EK, CO, JD
\xv Waku nana yanyba.
\sfx waku-nana-yanyba.wav
\sfx waku-nana-yanyba02.wav
\xe That (person) is talking quickly.
\rf EF_R299A4
\xv Waku jila.
\sfx waku-jila.wav
\xe Go quickly!
\rf EF
\xv Jila waku barri.
\sfx jila-waku-barri_CO.wav
\xe Go quickly now.
\rf OSBORNE_C02-000165B.TMP
\xv Waku nyulu kirribirri jukuli, waku.
\xe He's clapping the boomerangs together rapidly, fast.
\rf RS2000-05
\xv Waku ninji nanganja! Minja, minja ninji jungku.
\xe Get it quick! Steady, hold on, not so quick!
\rf RS
\xv Waku ninji, mirramba ngaki jangu.
\xe Make me a fire, quick!
\rf RS
\xv Waku ninji, karubu-yanyba.
\xe Be quick, catch the fish.
\rf RS
\xv Nanajba ninji, nanajba. Dabarraba ngawu waku-anyi.
\xe You wait, wait, (while) I cook it quickly.
\rf RS
\xv Waku nyulu burrbijbi, wululuku, mimi-nganja.
\xe The old fella, his grandfather, ran fast.
\rf RS
\xv Wanami ngaki nanganja wakuwaku!
\xe Get me some water quick!
\rf MF_GB76
\xv Jila nana waku.
\sfx
\xe He's to go fast.
\rf EF_R299EB1
\va
\sy
\cf ngajangaja
\an minja
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt 17/Oct/2006

\lx wakubaji
\mr waku-baji
\sf wakubaji.wav
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd motion
\lt something that moves at great speed
\ge fast
\ge quick
\ge rapid
\ge goes like anything
\re
\so RS
\xv wakubaji-yudu
\sfx wakubaji-yudu.wav
\xe with a fast one.
\rf RS2005-05
\xv Burrbijbi ngamba kularra, narrunguja-yudu barri. Wakubaji-yudu.
\xe We will drive down south with the car then, with the really fast one.
\rf rs2005-05
\va
\sy
\cf 
\nt Suffix {-baji} is found on limited number of words, forming compound word that denotes entity having the characteristic of the word to which {-baji} is affixed.
\cp
\nq

\an ningkijbi

\lf walijii
\lf walijini
\lf walijudu (waliji-yudu)

\sn 2
\sd food
\sd animal
\pc meat.jpg
\lt edible flesh from an animal
\ge meat
\ge beef
\re
\so EF, EK, RS, GB, MF_CO, JD93, GB
\xv Walijin barri ngamba dabarraba.
\sfx walijin_barri_ngamba_dabar.wav
\xe We are now cooking the meat.
\rf RS-RG1999
\xv Waliji-ya nungka jungku.
\sfx
\xe We have no meat.
\rf EF_R299AE2
\xv Waliji ngaki nanganja!
\sfx waliji-ngaki-nanganja_CO.wav
\sfx waliji-ngaki-nanganja_02_CO.wav
\xe Get me some beef!
\rf Elsie Moreland OSBORNE_C02-000165B.TMP
\xv Ngawu waliji-yudu.
\xe I've got meat. (Lit. I meat-with)
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Ngurrubu-kiya ninji ngaan walijudu?
\sfx
\xe Why didn't you tell me you had meat?
\rf GB_IS
\va
\sy
\cf
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt 03/Sep/2006

\sf
\sn 1

\ge out of

\ge remove
\ge get out of
\re
\so RS, CO, EF

\sfx walimi_barri02-exit.wav
\xe Leave now.
\rf RS-RG1999
\xv Walimi ngawu.
\sfx walimi_ngawu-I'm_leaving.wav
\sfx walimi_ngawu03-I'm leaving.wav
\xe I'm leaving.
\rf RS-RG1999
\xv Walimi ngawu kannga kularra.
\xe I'm leaving to go back south.
\rf RS
\xv Walimi barri nurri jangu-wunyi malumalu.
\xe We take the mussels out of the fire.
\rf RS
\xv Walimi barri nyulu, jilaba, wanu-anyi, wululuku.
\xe He's already gone for tobacco, the old man (has).
\rf 3
\xv Walimi barri ngawu. Yakujbu, walimi, ngawu yakujbu ninya.
\xe I’m off now. (I’ll) leave (you), (I’m) off, I’ll leave you (here).
\rf 4
\xv Walimi ngawu nganyi yanyba.
\sfx walimi-ngawu-nganyi-yanyba.wav
\xe Come out so I can talk to you.
\rf EF
\xv Walimi nungka jila namburrini.
\xe Let's go out hunting.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Walimi kiya nana bidirrika.
\xe That kangaroo must have gone.
\rf GB
\va walijbi
\sy
\cf walirrijbi
\nt
\cp
\nq not sure, is it a nominal? ie 'not here'

\lx walyuku
\mr walyuku
\sf walyuku.wav
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd evaluative
\lt
\ge good
\ge quenching
\ge refreshing
\ge mild
\ge pleasant
\ge nice
\re
\so EF, RS, JD, JP_TT, GB
\xv Walyuku nayi, kunyba.
\sfx walyuku nayi kunyba.wav
\xe This (water) is refreshing, good.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Walyuku nayi.
\sfx walyuku nayi.wav
\xe This (tobacco) is mild (to chew).
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Walyuku nayi bulinja-anyi nayi wanu
\sfx walyuku nayi bulinja-anyi nayi wanu.wav
\xe This is good to smoke, this tobacco.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Bajalijbi nurri nayi yilaka. Kunyba nayi kundan ngalya-anyi. Walyuku nayi kunda binjirri. Walyuku nayi bajalijbi.
\xe We smell these leaves. This tree is good for sickness. This paperbark tree is good. It smells good.
\rf rs2004-03
\xv Budangku nayi jalwan. Kunyba nayi, wanu. Walyuku nayi wanu, bulinja-anyi.
\xe This one is not strong. This is good tobacco. This tobacco is good to smoke.
\rf RS2005-04
\va
\sy kunyba
\cf
\an bari
\nt Also used of something that is in good order and/or new, fresh
\cp
\nq ? another word for quench? glossed as good too...
\dt 02/Oct/2006

\lf


\lx wanduraba
\mr wandura-ba
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd sound
\lt
\ge bark
\ge howl
\re
\so RS2005-01, EK, EM_SK, GB
\xv Wanduraba nyulu, nana barri miyan, wikijkurru.
\xe (The dog) barked at that snake that was crawling.
\rf RS
\xv Wanduraba nanangkani yunngumbu, warrakujini.
\xe That one barks all the time. It's mad.
\rf IS_GB78
\xv Lalumbu nyulu ngaan, daraa; wanduraba nyulu.
\xe The dog wakes me up, he barks.
\rf RS2000-09
\xv Wanduraba nayi dara mungana. Kikiwijbi dara nayi.
\xe This dog barks at night. This dog is growling.
\rf EK (ML notes)
\xv Dara nyulu nana wanduraba.
\sfx
\xe That dog is barking.
\rf EM_SK
\xv Ngunyi nyulu kudijbi. Budangku nyulu wandurakanyi.
\xe He sleeps. He doesn't bark.
\rf MF_GB76
\xv Daba ngawu dara wandurakurru.
\sfx
\xe I hit the dog that was barking.
\rf RS2000-10b
\va
\sy
\cf kikiwijbi
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt 25/Oct/2006

\lx wangkijbi
\mr wangki-j-bi
\sf wangkijbi.wav
\ps verb
\pc dancing.jpg
\sd ceremony
\lt
\ge dance
\ge perform ^corroborree
\re
\so EF, RS2002-3, JD, CO, GB, MB_LH17
\xv Wangkijbi yalu. Jurrangkimbi yalungka, burrurri-darraa.
\xe They are dancing. The men are performing.
\rf RS
\xv Wangkijkanyi yalu kamuu.
\xe They'll dance in the evening.
\rf RS
\xv Kirribirri nyulu jukulin. Wangkijbi yalu burrurri-darra.
\xe He’s clapping the boomerangs. The men are performing.
\rf RS2000-05
\xv Kirriya-darra, wangkijbi yalu luluka-anyi.
\xe The women, they dance for the novice.
\rf RS
\xv Ja yalu wangkijbi mindikirri.
\xe They will dance {mindikirri} style.
\rf RS
\xv Namijbi nangka, wangkijkanyi nyulu.
\xe He paints himself, so he can dance.
\rf RS
\xv Wangka!
\xe Dance!
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Ninji wangkijbi?
\xe Are you dancing?
\rf IS_GB78
\xv Ngawu ngurujbu wangkijinyi.
\xe I'm too tired to dance.
\rf IS_GB78
\xv Wangkijbi yalu jalanya ngambalangi.
\xe They are dancing today for us.
\rf PC_GB76
\va
\sy
\cf mandiwa
\cf mindikirri
\cf yarrambaja
\nt
\cp
\nq glossed as corroborree in 2002-3, used for women's dancing too
\dt 21/Sep/2006
\lf wangkijinyi
\lf wangkijkanyi

\lx wangkula
\mr wangkula
\sf wangkula.wav
\sf wangkurla-crowF.wav
\sf wangkurla02-crow(slow)F.wav
\ps noun
\pc
\sd animal
\sd bird
\la Corvus orru
\lt
\ge Torresian ^Crow
\re 
\so RS_2003-01d, EF_R299D2, GB, EK, JD, MS_SK, GW
\xv Wangkulan jungku kundana.
\xe A crow is sitting in the tree.
\rf RS
\xv
\xe
\rf
\va
\sy
\cf WAMIRI
\nt Noted by Dymock (1993) as a popular name for pet dog.
\cp Garrwa, Gunindirri
\nq
\dt 30/Oct/2006

\lx wanyi
\mr wanyi
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd
\lt
\ge what
\ge something
\re
\so RS, MF+EM_CO, MB_LH14
\xv Wanyi nana yanyin?
\sfx wanyi nana yanyin.wav
\xe What's that language?
\rf RS2004-05
\xv Kannga nyulu nayi, wanyinkanyi barri. Nayi kirriya.
\sfx kannga nyulu nayi wanyinkanyi-barri nayi kirriya.wav
\xe She's going back, for something now. This girl (is).
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Wanyinkanyi nganyingka manku-manku?
\xe What are you thinking to do?
\rf RS2005-05
\xv "Wanyinkanyi ninji daba nan, maju-nganja-anyi?" "Waliji-nanja."
\xe "For what thing belonging to your big sister did you hit this one?" "It was over the meat."
\rf RS
\xv Wanyi ninji najba?
\xe What can you see?
\rf RS
\xv Ngurruji ngan wanyi ninji jarrba.
\xe Tell me what you're eating.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Ngurruji ngan wanyini yawanjibi ninji.
\xe Tell me what you've been doing.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Wanyika ninji jungku?
\sfx
\xe What are you sitting doing?
\rf MB_LH14
\xv Wanyinbu-nanja ninji daba nana?
\sfx
\xe Why did you hit that (one)?
\rf RS2005-06
\va
\sy
\cf winjika
\cf wunjuku
\cf winja
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt 04/Sep/2006
\lf wanyimba
\lf wanyinbala
\lf wanyinbu-nanja
\lf wanyini
\lf wanyinkanyi

\lx -wanyi
\mr -wanyi
\sf
\sn 1
\ps suffix
\pc
\sd 
\lt dative case suffix
\ge belonging to
\ge for
\re
\so RS
\xv Bala yalu manii nanganja, waduku-wanyi wadaba-wunyi. Nanganja yalu
nguli bala wadaba-wunyi.
\xe They got the hook for their fishing line from a goanna, by hand. They got the bone for the hook from a goanna.
\rf RS
\xv Nanajba ngamba nanangkanyi narrunguja-anyi, wuluku-wanyi.
\xe We are waiting for that truck, for the big one.
\rf RS
\xv Yakuu nana! Yakuu! Maninja, nanangi wululuku-wanyi.
\xe Leave that! Leave (it)! It belongs to that old man.
\rf RS
\xv Dayi ngawu, durukii, nayi kundan, dirrbu-wanyi. 
\xe I chop this tree with a tommyhawk to get the honey.
\rf RS
\va -anyi
\va -kanyi
\va -ngkanyi
\va -nyi
\va -yanyi
\sy
\cf
\nt {-wanyi} is used following [u].
\cp
\nq
\dt 29/Oct/2006


\lx wanyimba
\mr wanyi-mba
\sf
\sn
\ps verb
\pc
\sd
\lt Xerg do something to Y
\ge do something to
\re do
\so
\xv Wanyimba nganyingka?
\sfx wanyimba_nganyingka-whatUdoF.wav
\xe What are you doing?
\rf EF_R299EA2
\xv Wanyimba ninji?
\xe What are you doing to it?
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf
\nt Intransitive form is expressed by use of reflexive pronoun.
\cp
\nq

\dt 24/Oct/2006


\lx warraku
\mr warraku
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd mind
\lt unable to hear
\ge can't hear
\ge deaf
\so GB, RS, JD93, MB_LH15
\xv Warraku kuwada.
\xe Deaf ear.
\rf JD93
\va
\sy
\cf kuwada-yaa
\nt 
\cp
\nq
\dt

\sn 2
\ps noun
\pc
\sd mind
\lf having poor cognitive function
\ge can't understand
\ge can't recall
\ge can't remember
\ge bad memory
\re
\xv Warraku ninyji. Budangku ninji lajibi yanyi.
\xe You can't understand. You can't understand the language.
\rf RS
\xv Rajini ngawu kududumbu, warrakuu kuwadaa.
\xe I left it at home as I've got a bad memory.
\rf RS

\sn 3
\ps noun
\pc
\sd mind
\lt
\ge mad
\ge silly
\ge crazy
\re
\so
\xv Warraku ninji, kadimirra, wawurra. Warrakuujbu ninji. Kuwada-yaan.
\xe You little mad one, you don't know. You got no sense.
\rf RS
\xv Yurrukadi nyulu barrawunu nana burrurrin warraku, lungkajii kijibajii.
\xe The angry policeman put that crazy man in jail.
\rf RS
\xv Mimi-kula, warraku-wuya.
\xe Two cousins, mad ones.
\rf RS
\xv Warraku nana wululuku.
\xe That old man is crazy.
\rf RS
\xv Daba yalungka warrakuu.
\xe Those mad (people) are fighting.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku yalu yakujkanyi nana wanamin, warraku-darraa.
\xe Those mad people can't leave grog alone.
\rf RS
\xv Janyii nyulu bijbi mayii, warrakuu, daraa kijibajii. 
\xe The mad angry dog bites with its mouth and teeth.
\rf RS
\xv Warraku ninji, warraku. Kuwada-yaan ninji.
\xe You're crazy, mad. You've got no sense.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf 
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt 03/Sep/2006
\lf warrakuujbu
\lf warrakuumbu
\lf warrakuu
\lf warrawarra

\lx warrakuujbu
\mr warraku-u-j-bu
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd mind
\lt perception
\ge fail to hear
\ge hard of hearing
\ge deaf
\re
\so RS, EK, JD
\xv Barijbi ngawu kuwada. Budangku ngawu mankuu ninya. Warrakuujbu ngawu. Kuwada-yaan ngawu.
\xe My ears are bad. I can't hear you. I'm deaf. I can't hear.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf kuwadajbu
\nt
\cp
\nq 
\dt 03/Sep/2006

\sn 2
\ps verb
\pc
\sd behavioural
\lt
\ge fail to take notice of
\ge not understand
\ge not pay heed to
\ge not look
\ge fail to find out
\re
\so
\xv Warrakuujini nyulu burrbijbi, durajini.
\xe Without looking (to see what it was) he ran off, in fright.
\rf RS
\xv Wabudala nyulu burrbijbi, warrakuujini.
\xe He raced past without stopping to look.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt

\sn 3
\ps verb
\pc
\sd mind
\lt
\ge go mad
\ge crazy
\ge dumb
\ge foolish
\ge silly
\ge out of one's mind
\re
\so RS, EK
\xv Jungku yalu ngarakini. Warrakuujbu yalu. Daba yalungka.
\sfx
\xe They were sitting drinking. They got silly. They were fighting.
\rf RS2004-06
\xv Warrakuujbu bula kulajin, barijbi bula.
\xe They went silly in the head. They were bad.
\rf RS
\xv Warrakujini, daba bulangka.
\xe They were fighting acting crazy.
\rf RS
\xv Ngaba nana jujuu. Warrakuujbu nyulu, ngaraba nyulu  wanamin.
\xe Take that (man) away. He's going mad. He's drinking wine.
\rf RS
\xv Jilaba nyulu nukamin barri. Warrakuujbu nyulu kadimirra wawurra.
\xe He's walking now. The little child is acting silly (now).
\rf RS
\xv Kamukamu-wunyi, warrakuujbu nyulu.
\xe It's from grog that he's gone mad.
\rf RS
\xv Jarrkanyi nangka kudanba, warrakujini.
\xe He wanted to kill himself, being out of his mind.
\rf RS
\xv Wanduraba nanangkani yunngumbu warrakujini.
\xe That dog barks all the time as it's no good in the head.
\rf GB
\va
\sy
\cf
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt

\sn 4
\ps verb
\pc
\sd mind
\lt fail to find
\ge not find
\ge be disoriented
\ge get lost
\re
\so RS, GB
\xv Warrakuujbu yalu.
\sfx warrakujbu_yalu.wav
\xe They can't find it.
\rf RS-RG1999
\xv Jumbuunaa bulangka wandaba, warrakujini.
\sfx
\xe Having got lost the two Goanna Men turned into stone.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku nungka kawa-najba. Warrakuujbu nungka.
\xe We can't find (the way). We're lost.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt

\lf
\sn 3
\ps verb

\ge drive out of one's mind
\ge make silly
\re
\so

\xe The mosquito drove me mad when I was lying down (trying to sleep).

\sfx
\xe The grog made him go crazy.
\rf RS

\xe The grog made that old man go silly (in the head).
\rf RS
\xv Mayi yaluwanya jariyamba, warrakuumbu. 
\xe He might sneak off with them and make them go mad.
\rf RS

\sy

\an

\lx warrki

\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc warrki.jpg

\sd mammal
\la Canis lupus dingo

\ge dingo
\ge wild ^dog
\re

\xe He smells a dingo coming.
\rf rs2002-04
\xv Warrki bulungu.
\xe Dingo pup.
\rf rs2005-03
\xv Jilaba nyulu warrki. Binanyba nyulu ngaan, warrkii.
\xe A dingo is coming. The dingo is hunting me down.
\rf RS
\xv Durrajba ngawu nangkanyi barri, warrkiyanyi.
\xe I'm frightened of this dingo, now.
\rf RS
\xv Warrki bulungu, nanganja yalu, wandaraba yalu.
\xe They used to get a dingo pup and then rear it.
\rf RS

\sy
\cf bajangu
\cf burawa
\cf dara
\cf kujukuju

\va

\xe With string.
\rf EF

\rf RS
\xv Budangku ngawu warrkul-anyi.
\xe I don't have any rope.
\rf GB
\xv Buduramba nangka warrkulii, yarrbanjii, kuwadaajini warrakujini. 
\xe The young man went mad and choked himself with a rope. 
\rf RS

\xe She spins that hairstring with a spindle.
\rf RS

\xe I led him away by a rope.
\rf GB

\va warrkuu
\va warrkuji

\cf nyungka
\cf yurrudu

\lx warrwarri
\mr warrwarri
\hm
\sf
\sn
\ps noun
\pc
\sd human
\lt 
\ge children
\ge kids
\re
\so RS
\xv Budangku ngali najba nana-waan, warrwarri.
\sfx
\xe We didn't see any of those children.
\rf RS
\xv Ja nyulu wadamba barri, warrwarri nangangi.
\xe He will feed his kids.
\rf RS
\xv Burrbijbi nyulu wululuku. Kannga nyulu. Nanganjana nana-waan. Warrwarri.
\xe The old man is racing back picking up those kids.
\rf RS
\xv Janybijbi nyulu nana-waan warrwarri-darra. Narrunguja-wunyi. Warrwarri. 
\xe He's dropping off those kids from the truck. The kids.
\rf RS
\xv Kayi-wurru ngawu mankuu, kadimirra, warrwarri-darra.
\xe I can hear the little ones, all the children, calling out.
\rf RS
\xv Lalumbu yalu ngaan,  kudij-kurru, warrwarrii.
\xe The children wake me up when I'm sleeping.
\rf RS
\va
\sy

\an
\nt Special plural form corresponding to {wawurra} 'child'.

\lx wawurra
\mr wawurra
\sf wawurra.wav
\sf wawurra02.wav
\sf wawurra03.wav
\sf wawurra04.wav
\sf wawurra-child.wav
\sf wawurra_CO.wav
\ps noun
\pc child.jpg
\sd PEOPLE
\lt
\ge child
\ge kid
\re
\so GB, RS, EF, LM, JD, JP_TT, MF_CO
\xv Wawurra nganyi ngindii.
\sfx wawurra-nganyi-ngirndii.wav
\xe Your child is crying.
\rf EF
\xv Wawurra ngindii.
\sfx wawurra-ngirndii.wav
\xe The child is crying.
\rf EF_R299A4
\xv Wawurra nayi ngaki jilaba.
\sfx wawurra-nayi-ngaki-jilaba_CO.wav
\xe This child of mine went.
\rf OSBORNE_C02-000165B.TMP
\xv Ngara-kanyi wawurra-anyi wanami nyulu nanganja.
\xe He's getting water for the child to drink.
\rf RS
\xv Kuwada-yaan nana wawurra-darra.
\xe Those senseless kids.
\rf RS
\xv Nangkani ngaan burru-daba, nangkani wawurraa kadimirraa.
\xe It's this one who  knocked me down, this little child.
\rf RS
\xv Jurrangkimbi yalungka, jurrangkimbi, wawurra-darraa.
\xe The children are playing with each other, playing.
\rf RS
\xv Nanangkani yingkaa wawurraa, daba nyulu kudumanjaa, kundaa. 
\xe That same child kept on hitting (him) with a stick.
\rf RS
\xv Yakujbu nana wawurra.
\xe Leave that child (alone).
\rf RS
\xv Ramiramba-wurru ngawu najba, wawurra.
\xe I saw the child breaking it.
\rf RS
\xv Nana-waan kadimirra, ngindiyi yalu ngaki, nana-waan wawurra-darra.
\xe Those little ones, those children are crying for me.
\rf RS
\xv Mayi nyulu kalijbi ninya wawurra mukuraa. Mulunguu, winyarrkii.
\xe That feather foot, bogeyman, he might spear you in the foot, child.
\rf RS
\xv Wawurra yalu bikali. ngabana, kirriyaa, banga  burrurrii, bulungu bulangi.
\xe Men and women used to carry chilren, their children, on their shoulders.
\rf RS
\xv Yakujbu ngawu wawurra ngada-nganjana, wulu-nganjana.
\xe I left (my) kid with mother and father.
\rf GB
\xv Wanami nanganja wawurra-anyi.
\xe Fetch water for the child.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\va
\sy
\cf badada
\cf bulungu
\cf juka
\cf ngila
\nt The special plural form is {warrwarri} 'children'.
\cp Garrwa
\nq warrwarri in 2004-03
\dt 07/Oct/2006
\lf wawurraa
\lf wawurra-anyi

\lx wawuru
\mr
\hm
\sv
\sf
\sn
\ps particle (?)
\pc
\sd 
\la
\lt
\ge for no reason
\ge nothing
\re reason (for no reason)
\so GB_IS
\xv "Wanyingkanyi ninji nanangkurru jila?" "Wawuru."
\sfx
\xe "Why did you go there?" "For no reason."
\rf GB_Grammar_ch6
\xv Budangku ngawu ninya wawurun dajkanyi, kawaaba ngawu ninya.
\sfx
\xe I didn't hit you for any reason, I didn't mean (to hit) you.
\rf GB_grammar_ch6
\va
\sy
\cf balyanga
\cf budangku
\an
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt
\lf


\lx -waya
\mr -waya
\sf
\sn 1
\ps suffix
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt semblative
\ge like
\ge similar to
\re
\so RS, GB
\xv Dara-waya.
\xe Like a dog.
\rf GB
\xv Bukaji kadimirra, nayi wulukun, jarrbikala-waya.
\xe The Kite Hawk is smaller, this one is big, like a Wedgetail Eagle.
\rf rs2004-08b
\xv Burrurri-wayan nyulu jungku, bankala.
\xe He's sitting like an Aboriginal man -- cross-legged.
\rf GB
\xv Ngamuyu wanu-waya.
\xe It seems like tobacco.
\rf RS
\xv Ngamuyu jukuli-waya balangarra kadimirra.
\xe That little moon looks like it's a boomerang.
\rf RS
\xv Ngamuyu wululuku-waya nyulu jilaba nana kadimirra jukajuka.
\xe That little boy walks like an old man.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf ngamuyu
\nt When combined with {ngamuyu} the meaning is partially negated, e.g., the moon may look like a small boomerang, but it's not a boomerang. You might think it's like tobacco, but it's not tobacco.
\cp
\nq
\dt 02/Oct/2006

\lx wayi
\mr wayi
\sf
\sn 1
\ps particle
\pc
\sd grammar
\sd interrogative
\la
\lt used to signal a polar question or ask permission
\ge is it true that
\re true (is it true that)
\re can (is it possible that)
\so EF, RS, GB, CO
\xv Wayi ngawu nganyinbunu jilaa?
\xe Can I go with you?
\rf GB
\xv Wayi barri nimba kawa-najba nukami?
\xe Have you (two) found his tracks yet?
\rf rs2005-01
\xv Wayi barri ninji ngaba ngaki danya? 
\xe Did you bring me (any) clothes? 
\rf rs2003-01
\xv Wayi barri ninji kanjijbi dabarraba?
\xe Have you finished cooking yet?
\rf GB
\xv Wayi ninji jila? Jila ninji-wa?
\xe Are you going? You going?
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Wayi ninji najba nana jila-kurru?
\xe Did you see him go?
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Wayi ninji durrajba miya-anyi?
\sfx
\xe Are you scared of the snake?
\rf EF_R299A4
\xv Miya-anyi ninji wayi durrajba?
\sfx miyaanyi-ninyji-wayi-durrajb.wav
\xe Are you frightened of snakes?
\rf EF
\xv Wayi barri ninji jilajudu ngamanjibi?
\sfx
\xe Are you ready to go?
\rf GB-IS
\va
\sy
\cf -kiya
\cf ngamuyu
\cf -wa
\nt <wayi> is typically clause initial, but may be later in clause.
\cp
\nq
\dt 29/Sep/2006

\sn 2
\ps particle
\pc
\sd
\la
\lt The combination of <wayi> followed by the enclitic <-kiya> is used to mark a question expressing a counterfactual
\ge couldn't
\ge why not
\ge shouldn't
\re
\so RS, GB
\xv Wayi-kiya nimba ngaan windijbi nanangkanyi mama-anyi?
\xe Shouldn't you two have given me some of that food?
\rf RS2004-01 
\xv Wayi-kiya ninji jawikajba ngaliyanya mama-anyi?
\xe Why didn't you ask us for food?
\rf rs2004-04
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\va
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt

\lx wilijirri
\mr wirlijirri
\hm
\sf wirlijirri.wav
\sf wirlijirri-pull_R299b2.wav
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd spatial
\sd contact
\sd motion
\lt Xerg cause Y to move along ground by exerting pressure on Y or entity containing Y
\ge pull on
\ge pull out
\ge roll
\ge drag
\ge tug
\ge push
\re
\so EF, RS, EK, GB, CO
\xv Wilijirri ngawu jangu-nanja.
\xe I pulled it out of the fire.
\rf RS2002-02
\xv Wilijirri bambularra-nanja. Marijbi ninji, manii. Bambularra.
\xe Pull it by the tail. Grab (its) tail with your hand.
\rf rs2000-03
\xv Wilijirri yalu kalawunyi, barrawunu ja yalu nijbi naan.
\xe They are dragging him inside and will put him down in the room.
\rf rs2005-08a
\xv Birrki-marijbi nyulu, nyungka, nyungka-nanja. Wilijirri nyulu, nyungka-nanja.
\xe She grabbed hold of his hair, grabbed him by the hair. She pulled him along by the hair.
\rf rs2002-04
\xv Wilijirri ngawu jaluki wadaba-anyi.
\xe I pull the intestines out of the goanna.
\rf RS2005-06
\xv Wilijirri nyulu. Wilijirri wadukuu.
\sfx wilijirri nyulu wilijirri wadukuu.wav
\xe He's pulling it in (of fish). Pulling it in with a fishing line.
\rf RS2005-04
\rf Kakun nyulu wilijirri, nangkani burrurrii.
\sfx kakun nyulu wilijirri#nangkani burrurrii.wav
\xe This man's pulling in a fish.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Budangku ngawu na wilijirrinyi, jalwa nana. 
\xe I can't pull it as it's too heavy.
\rf GB
\xv Jalu-nanja nyulu marrijbi. Wilijirri nyulu kingkarri. Jalu-nanja nyulu wilijirri wanami-wunyi.
\xe She grabs him by the arm and drags him up, drags him by the arm, out of the water.
\rf RS
\xv Kujarra nyulu ngabaa. Wilijirri nyulu bulanya, kadimirra, bulungu-wiya.
\xe He's brought the two (babies). He has pushed the two little babies (in a pram or stroller).
\rf RS
\xv Wilijirri-wurru, kuna-najba ngawu. 
\xe I'm watching him pull it (fish) in.
\rf RS
\xv Wilijinmi!
\xe Pull (it)!
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Wilijirranyi ngawu nana kara.
\xe I'm going to pull that rock away.
\rf MF_GB76
\va
\sy
\cf kurrkulaba
\cf ngajikajba
\an mayangka
\nt MF+EM_CO also records {wilijini} 'drag (it)!'
\cp
\nq wilirrjirri in 2002-1 for pull out or wirlirrjirri; wirlijirri = pull.on in 2002-4 ; roll ; drag
\nq possibly {wilijirrmi} 'pull-IMP' in place of {wilijinmi}

\sfx windijbi-ngaan.wav

\xe We give the dogs the guts.

\xv Windijbi ja-nyulu ngaan kara-anyi. Ja-ngawu nanganja nayi barri narrunguja.
\xe He'll give me money so I can buy this truck.
\rf RS
\xv Kuluu ngaa windingi, daya-anyi ngawu jangun.
\xe Give me the axe so I can chop wood.
\rf GB

\xe He handed the man that stick.
\rf RS

\xe His mother gives (him) some milk.
\rf RS

\xe They are giving me cheek.

\xe I'll give you this bream (which is) good to eat.

\xe They supply that old man with meat and vegetables.
\rf RS

\xe I would give you some money, (but) I don't have any money.
\rf RS
\xv Mayi nyulu windijbi niyanya ngalyaa.
\xe It might make us sick (lit. give us sickness).
\rf RS
\xv Windi-kanyi ninya, manijaa, yanyi-yanyi kurrkamala-anyi.
\xe (I've) got to give you a lot more language next time.
\rf RS
\xv Windijbi ngawu ninya, ngakinkanyi jawaji-nganja-anyi. 
\xe I promise (give) you my daughter.
\rf RS
\xv Jawikajba ngawu ninya, windi-kanyi ninji ngaan jukuli-yanyi.
\xe I'm asking you to give me a boomerang.
\rf RS
\xv Wanami windijbi ngan wambukurru.
\xe Give me water as I'm sick.
\rf MF_EM_CO
\va
\sy
\cf
\nt The thing given is marked as either ergative or dative. The recipient is either accusative (pronoun) or unmarked (noun).
\cp
\nq

\lx wingki
\mr wingki
\sf wingki-unripeF.wav
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd food related
\lt of vegetable food that is immature
\ge green 
\ge not ripe
\ge raw
\ge unripe
\re 
\so EF_R299D3, RS, GB

\sfx wingki_nyulu_wingki.wav
\xe It's green (of fruit), unripe.
\rf RS2002-11
\xv Janybijbi ngawu nana wingki.Budangku ngawu jarrba.
\xe I throw that green (fruit) away. I don't eat it.
\rf RS
\xv Windijbi nyulu, ngalyaa, nanangkani mamaa. Lungkarraa. Darimaa. Budangku ngamba jarrba. Wingki nyulu. Duruu, rajba barri nana maman, darima. Nanganja ngamba. Jarrba barri ngamba, jangkaranyi.
\xe That bitter unripe plum makes (us) sick. We can't eat it. When the sun has ripened the plum fruit, we pick it and then we eat it, ripe.

\lx winjika
\mr winyjika
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt Used to question identity of human.
\ge who
\ge what
\ge which
\re
\so EF, GB, RS, MF_SK, MF+EM_CO
\xv Winjika burrurrin jilaba?
\sfx winyjika_burrurrin_jilaF.wav
\xe Which man is going?
\rf EF_R299EA1
\xv Winjika ninji niji?
\xe What's your name? (Lit. who you name)
\rf rs2003-01
\xv Winjikaa ninya burru-daba?
\xe Who knocked you down?
\rf RS
\xv Mudumbanyi ngawu, winjikaa ninya burru-daba.
\xe I don't know who knocked you down.
\rf RS
\xv Jawikajba ngawu, winjikaa ngaki ramijbi wadukun?
\xe I'm asking you, who broke my fishing line?
\rf RS
\xv Winjika nyulu wuluku?
\xe Who's the older one? (lit. who he big)
\rf RS
\xv Winjika ninji?
\xe Who are you?
\rf RS
\xv Winjika ninji makarraba?
\xe Who are you burying?
\rf RS
\xv Winjikanyi nana bajangun?
\xe Whose dog is that?
\rf MF_RS76
\xv Winjikaa ninya windijbi nangkanyi mama-anyi?
\xe Who gave you this money?
\rf RS
\xv Winjika nana kirriya?
\sfx
\xe Who is that woman?
\rf MF_SK
\xv Ngurruji ngan winjika ninji ngaraba.
\xe Tell me what you're drinking.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Winjika jila?
\xe Who is coming?
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Winjika ninji daba?
\xe Who did you hit?
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Winjikanyi nana waliji?
\xe Whose is that meat?
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Winjikadu nana wawurra jila?
\xe Who did that child go with?
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Winjikana nana wawurra jungku?
\xe Who does that child live with?
\rf MF+EM_CO 
\xv Winjika nganyi yanyi? Ngaki yanyi, Waanyi.
\xe What's your language? My language is Waanyi.
\rf RS2004.04-15
\va
\sy
\cf wanyi
\cf winja
\cf wunjuku
\nt

\lx winngil
\mr winngil
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd ELEMENTS
\sd water
\sd weather
\lt large quantity of rain
\ge big rain
\ge wet season
\ge monsoon
\re
\so RS, GB, JD93
\xv Winngil, jungku nyulu wuja. Wuja nyulu jungku, burrarrajini wanamin. Burra-daba wanamin, winjuraba ngambalanya. Mirramba nyulu dumularra, wulukun,
dumularra wanamin.
\xe The heavy rains stay in one place. The rain falls in one place. It makes the rain fall down on us with force. It makes the creeks and rivers flow with big torrents of water.
\rf RS
\xv Dumularra nana burrbijbi winngil-wunyi.
\xe The river has been running since the wet season.
\rf GB
\xv Kudaajba nyulu, wanamini, winngirrini.
\xe He died during the wet, in the rainy season.
\rf GB

\cf janja
\cf wanami

\xe Two brothers.
\rf GB

\xe I tie its two arms together.
\rf RS

\xe You are grandfather to us two little girls.
\rf RS
\xv Winjika-wiya?
\xe Which two (people)?
\rf GB
\xv Wanyi-wiya?
\xe What two?

\xe We are watching both children climbing, the two (of them).
\rf RS

\xe Waanyi and Garrwa are two languages.
\rf RS
\xv Dara-wiyaa, bijbi bulangka.
\xe The two dogs are fighting each other.
\rf RS
\xv Mambuka-wiya kujarra, julaki-anyi.
\xe The two 'bosses' for the aeroplane.
\rf RS
\xv Maku-nganja-wiya.
\xe Her two cousins.
\rf RS
\xv Ngaraba bula, wanami, kamukamu, nanangkujarraa burrurri-wiyaa.
\xe Those two men are drinking grog.
\rf RS

\lx wiyala
\mr wiyala
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd contact (impact and violence)
\lt Xerg make contact with Y by moving part of X or entity manipulated by X lengthwise on surface of Y
\ge grind
\ge rub
\re grind
\re rub
\so RS, CO
\xv Wumulu nyulu, dayi, mama-anyi buja-anyi. Niijbi yalu, niijbi yalu, bujaa. Wiyala barri yalu.
\xe He chops wood (to make) a coolimon for wild rice (to put it in). They fill it, fill it with wild rice. Then they grind it.
\rf rs2005-03
\xv Nganyi nana, nganyi ninji wiyalaa, nana wanu, wululuku.
\xe That yours, you rub that tobacco of yours, old man.
\rf RS
\xv Ngamijbi (~ namijbi) yalu manii, wiyala.
\xe They mix (ochre and bird down) by hand, rub it (together).
\rf RS
\xv Nangkani barri wuliwulii, wiyala ngawu. Yamarrina.
\xe With this round stone I'm grinding it on a flat rock.
\rf RS
\xv Wiyalama!
\xe Grind it!
\rf MF+EM_CO
\va
\sy
\cf ngukujaba
\nt
\cp Wambaya {wuyala}
\nq MF+EM_CO {wuyalama} 'bake (it)!'

\lx wububu

\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd motion
\lt X move rapidly
\ge move fast
\ge race
\ge rush
\ge speed
\ge come at great speed
\ge blow strongly (of wind)
\re
\so RS
\xv Wububu nyulu bikalini, narrunguja. Wububu nyulu mama-yudu, bikalini 
\xe The truck carrying (it) is coming at great speed. It's speeding with the food, carrying (it).
\rf RS
\xv Wububu nyulu nungkurrini.
\xe It's speeding roaring (as it goes).
\rf RS
\xv Wububu nyulu nana wanamin. Kuku-najba ngamba wububu-wurru.
\xe That water is rushing (past). We are watching it rush (past).
\rf RS
\xv Wububu nyulu wurrarra. Wurrarra nyulu nangkurru wububu, ngambalangi nangkurru. Mayi nyulu janybijbi ngambalangi barrawu, jalwaa wurrarraa.
\xe The wind is blowing strongly. The wind is rushing this way towards us. This strong wind might knock over our houses. 
\rf RS
\xv Diindi nyulu jilaba wububu. Kannga nyulu.
\xe He raced straight through. He went back.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf burrbijbi
\cf ngajangaja
\cf waku
\nt
\cp
\nq

\ge start fire
\ge set fire to
\re

\xe The sun is cooking us. We are getting hot.
\rf RS

\xe The flame, it burnt my foot.
\rf RS
\xv Wukarrijbi nyulu ngaan, danyali.  Nijbijbi ngawu.

\sn 2
\ps verb
\pc
\sd 
\lt Xerg cause Y to burn
\ge ignite
\ge start fire
\ge set fire to
\ge set alight
\re fire
\so RS
\xv Wukarrijbi nurri, jindal-anyi, jakaba nyulu wanangarrii.
\xe We set fire to it to (chase away) mosquitoes. The (burning) bee wax chases them.
\rf RS
\xv Jangu nyulu wukarrijbi.
\xe It (lightning) starts a fire.
\rf RS
\xv Rangkijbi nyulu, kanba, wukarrijbi.
\sfx
\xe It (lightning) strikes the grass and sets it alight.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt
\cp
\nq

\lx wuliwuli
\mr wuli-wuli
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc grindstone.jpg
\sd artifact
\lt round stone such as those used for grinding 
\ge round stone
\ge round rock
\ge round pebble
\ge grinding stone
\re
\so RS, GB, EK, JD93
\xv Kuujbu ngawu, nanganja ngawu, wuliwuli. Wiyala ngawu, wanu, nangkanyi buni-yanyi. Bunija, julwu-yudu. Nangkani barri wuliwulii, wiyala ngawu.
\xe I look for and find a round stone. I grind the tobacco in order to mix it. Mix it with ashes. Then with this round stone, I grind it.
\rf RS
\xv Daba nurri ramijbi, nangkani wuliwulii.
\xe We break it off by striking it with the small round rock.
\rf rs2002-04-13
\xv Jalwa nayi walijin. Nanjarrba nurri, nanjarr-nanjarrba nurri wuliwulii, yamarrina.
\xe This meat is tough. We soften it, we soften it by pounding it with a round stone, against a flat stone.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf BURULYA
\nt Dymock (1993) records BURULYA 'round pebble'
\cp
\nq

\lx wulu
\mr wulu
\hm 1
\sf wulunganyja.wav
\ps noun
\pc
\sd PEOPLE
\sd KIN
\lt speaker uses {wulu} to denote 'father' of another person
\ge father
\re 
\so RS, GB, JP_TT
\xv Nganyi wulu-nganja.
\xe Your father.
\rf GB
\xv Ngada-nganja yanyba: Ngabama nayi nganyi wulu-nganja-wurru.
\xe A mother says (to her child): Take this to your father.
\rf GB
\xv Yakujbu ngawu wawurra ngada-nganjana, wulu-nganjana.
\xe I left the children with their mother and father.
\rf GB
\xv Jawaji-nganja, wulu-nganja.
\xe Son and father.
\rf RS
\xv Kuujbu yalu wulu-nganja-anyi.
\xe They are looking for their father.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku ninji najba nganyi ngada-nganja, wulu-nganja.
\xe You won't see your mother and father.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf bana
\cf murriba
\nt Speaker uses {murriba} to refer to own father, but uses {wulu} to refer to father of another person.
\cp Mangala {wulu} 'father' (BAgnew)
\nq
\dt 29/Sep/2006

\lx wuluku
\mr wuluku
\sf wulugu-RS2003-12T03.wav
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd size
\lt relatively large in size
\ge big
\ge large
\re big
\so EF, RS, JD93, RC_SK, RC+MF_SK, MF+EM_CO, GB, AD
\xv Dungala, wuluku.
\xe Big hill.
\rf RS
\xv Wuluku dara.
\xe A big dog.
\rf MF_SK
\xv Bidirrika, wuluku; bungkinan, kadin
\xe The kangaroo is bigger than the wallaby.
\rf GB
\xv Ngakin bulungu wuluku barri, banyajba barri nyulu ngaa.
\xe My child is big now, he now surpasses me.
\rf GB
\xv Wuluku waliji, walanybirri.
\xe The pelican is a large animal.
\rf GB
\xv Wuluku wurrarran burrbijbi.
\xe A big wind is blowing.
\rf GB
\xv Banyajba ngambalanya wulukuu narrungujaa.
\xe The big truck overtook us.
\rf RS
\xv Nanajba ngamba nanangkanyi narrunguja-anyi, wuluku-wanyi.
\xe We are waiting for that truck, for the big one.
\rf RS
\xv  Makarraba ngambalanya rami jundurri, jambaa, wulukuu.
\xe A big cloud of dust and dirt gets into (covers) our eyes.
\rf RS
\xv Wuluku wanami.
\xe Big waterhole.
\rf JD93
\xv Najba ngawu nanganja-wurru wuluku-wurru kaku-wurru.
\xe I saw him catch a big fish.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\va
\sy
\cf jalwa
\an kadi
\an kadimirra
\nt Dymock (1993) also records {wulukuji}
\cp
\nq

\lx wuluku-dirri
\mr wuluku-dirri
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd size
\lt relatively large quantity or size
\ge bigger
\ge biggest
\ge really big 
\ge very big
\ge older
\re big
\so RS, JD, MB_LH12
\xv Nana wulukun, wuluku-dirri, kadimirra jukan. Kadimirra, ngila wadukarra. 
\xe That big one, the bigger (older) one, is a young boy. The little (younger) one is a young girl.
\rf RS2005-02
\xv Wuluku-dirri julaki.
\xe A really big aeroplane.
\rf RS2005-08a
\xv Nanajba ngamba nanangkanyi narrunguja-anyi, wuluku-dirri-yanyi.
\xe We waited for that really big truck.
\rf RS2004-07
\xv Wuluku-dirrii, jarrbalamba nyulu jamban, jundurr.
\xe That really big one (wind), it lifted up the soil and the dirt.
\rf RS2004-07
\xv Yakujbu nurri yaluyanya, walimbi nurri bayungu julakini barri, yingkanyini, wuluku-dirrini.
\xe We left them, we headed west in one very big aeroplane.
\rf RS
\xv Kadimirra nana wanami kala. Nana wuluku-dirri, kala wuluku-dirri, manangka.
\xe That river is a small one. That (other) one is bigger, it's a much bigger river.
\rf RS
\xv Wuluku-dirri, kanawa kanba nayi.
\xe This tall grass is too big (to be able to see the ground).
\rf RS
\xv Dinmanja kijibaji. Wuluku-dirri, biraki.
\xe Bullants are aggressive. They are really big ants.
\rf RS
\va
\sy wuluku-mirra
\cf
\an kadi-mirra
\nt This suffix only recorded on {wuluku} 'big'
\nt Recorded by Dymock (1993) in description of full moon (compared to crescent and half moon)
\cp
\nq
\dt 29/Sep/2006

\lx wululuku
\mr wululuku
\sf wululuku_RS.wav
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd PEOPLE
\lt used to address and refer to a middle-aged or elderly man
\ge old man
\ge elder
\ge mature man
\re old man
\re elder
\so EF, RS, MS_SK, RC+MF_SK, CO
\xv Nana wululuku.
\sfx nana wululuku.wav
\xe That old man.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Nanganja ngawu waliji nimbalangi wululuku-wiya.
\xe I'm fetching meat for you two old men.
\rf RS
\xv Wululuku ngawu.
\xe I'm an old man.
\rf RS
\xv Wululuku, ngabuji, nanganja ninji ngaki, wanamin.
\xe Old man, grandfather (FMB), fetch me some water.
\rf RS
\xv Kangku ninji ngaliyangi, kirriya-anyi, ngila-wiya-anyi. Wululuku.
\xe Old man, you are our grandfather (father's father), for us two little girls.
\rf RS
\xv Walimi nyulu, jilaba, wanu-wanyi, wululuku.
\xe The old man has gone out to get tobacco.
\rf RS
\xv Milirrimbi nyulu wululukuu.
\xe The old man is teaching him.
\rf RS
\xv Nanganja nyulu wululukuu,  wanamin ngajirri.
\xe The old man got some cold water.
\rf RS
\xv Ja-nyulu nanganja ngaki, nangkani wululukuu.
\xe This old man will get (it) for me.
\rf RS
\xv Kujarra jumbuuna-wuya, wululuku-wuya. Murrumurrula-wunyi nanangkujarra wululuku.
\xe Two old Yellow Goanna men (Dreaming ancestors). Those two old men went from Murrumurrula.
\rf RS
\xv Kuku-najba nungka, nayi wululuku, dabarra-kurru.
\xe We are looking at this old man cooking.
\rf RS
\xv Yakuu nana! Yakuu! Maninja, nanangi wululuku-wanyi. Mayi nyulu ninya dabaa.
\xe Leave that! Leave (it)! It belongs to that old man. He might hit you.
\rf RS
\xv Durramba nyulu ninya, kijibajii wululukuu.
\xe The cheeky old man will frighten you.
\rf RS
\xv Ngamuyu wululuku-waya nyulu jilaba nana kadimirra jukajuka.
\xe That little boy walks like an old man.
\rf RS
\xv Nayi nyulu wululuku, wankan jungku.
\xe He's old, (but) he's still alive.
\rf EF_R299EB1
\va wuluwuluku [IS_GB]
\sy
\cf badibadi
\cf burrurri
\cf malbu
\cf ngandaarra
\nt Dymock (1993) also records as 'big, important', used of 'station owner or manager
\nt Also applies to mature male animal, e.g., rooster, ram.
\cp
\nq
\dt 04/Sep/2006

\dt 19/Sep/2006


\lx wunanba
\mr wurna-n-ba
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd spatial
\lt long distance
\ge long way
\ge far
\re far
\re distant
\re long way
\so RS, JD93
\xv Wunanba ngawu jilaba. Wunanba. Bayungunu. Karurri.
\xe I've come a long way. A long way, from the west, to the east.
\rf rs2002-06
\xv Ngurujbu ngawu. Burrbijbi ngawu wunanba.
\xe I knocked up. I had run a long way.
\rf RS2005-01
\xv Bujada Jiranyku-mungkuji. "Jilaba ngawu Jiranyku-wunyi. Wunanba."
\xe The quiet snake (Dreaming ancestor) is from Jiranyku (Newcastle Waters). "I've come from Jiranyku (which is) a long way."
\rf rs2002-06
\xv Wunanba, burrbijbi nurri. Narrunguja-yudu.
\xe We've driven a long way, with the car.
\rf RS
\xv Wunanba ngawu jungku Kayawanana.
\xe I live a long way away at Kiana Station.
\rf RS
\xv Wunanba nana, kala yalungi, jujuu, karurri.
\xe That place of their is far away, a long way to the east.
\rf RS
\xv Jilaba nurri langini. Nangkurru. Kularra. Wunanba.
\xe We've come from the north to here. To the south. A long way.
\rf RS
\xv Wandajba nyulu. Wunanba.
\xe He took the long way around.
\rf RS
\va
\sy junii
\cf jujuu
\cf kanawa
\nt
\cp
\nq Dymock (1993) WUNAMBA
\dt 19/Sep/2006

\lx wundijbi
\mr wundi-j-bi
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd motion
\lt X change direction to retrace steps
\ge go back
\re return
\so RS
\xv Jilaba yalu, najba nurriyanya, wundijbi yalu.
\xe They've gone. They saw us and turned around and went back.
\rf RS
\va
\sy kannga
\cf
\nt
\cp
\nq 
\dt 18/Oct/2006

\lx wundunyuka
\mr
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd animal
\sd mammal
\la Dugong dugon
\lt
\ge dugong
\re
\so RS, GW
\xv Wundunyuka nana bulungu-yudu.
\xe That dugong has a baby (is pregnant).
\rf RS, GW
\va
\sy
\cf walya
\cf wiriji
\nt Roy Seccin describes {wundunyuka} as "girl dugong" as opposed to {wiriji} "male dugong"
\cp 
\nq check meaning
\dt 19/Sep/2006

\sn 2
\ps noun
\pc
\sd animal
\la Chelonia mydas
\lt
\ge Green Turtle
\re 
\so GB, GW
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\va
\sy walya
\cf
\an
\nt Recorded as "sea turtle" by Breen
\cp Bradley records Yanyuwa {wundunyuka} as 'sea turtle (generic)' and {walya} as 'dugong/sea turtle (generic)'
\cp Garrwa [SJ_SK]
\nq

\dt 24/Oct/2006


\lx wunjuku
\mr wunyjuku
\sf wunyjuku.wav
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd quantifier
\lt to what place
\lt in what direction
\ge where to
\re where
\so RS, EF, GB, EK
\xv Wunjuku nimba jilaba? 
\xe Where are you two going?
\rf RS
\xv Wunjuku nyulu jila?
\sfx wunyjuku_nyulu_jilaaF.wav
\xe Where has he gone?
\rf EF_R299EA1
\xv Wunjuku nayi jilaba nukamin?
\sfx wunjuku_nayi_jilaba_nukami_n_RS.wav
\xe Where do these footprints go?
\rf RS2005-01
\xv Wunjuku ngamba jilaba mudunama?
\sfx wunjuku=ngamba jilaba mudunama.wav
\xe Where are we going tomorrow?
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Wunjuku nyulu ngabaa?
\xe Where did he take him?
\rf RS
\xv Mudumbanyi ngali wunjuku ninji jilaba. Budangku ninji ngurrubu ngaliyanya.
\xe We didn't know where you had gone. You didn't tell us (where you were going).
\rf rs2000-09
\xv Junuu wunjuku ngamba jilaba mudunama.
\xe (We) don't know where we are going tomorrow.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku nyulu ngurrubu niyanya, wunjuku nyulu jilaba.
\xe He didn't tell us where he was going. 
\rf RS2003-02
\xv Jungku ninji wuja. Jila-kana wunjuku.
\sfx
\xe You stay put. Don't go anywhere.
\rf RS2005-05
\va
\sy
\cf winja
\cf winja-kurru
\nt Clause initial {wunjuku} is interpreted as 'to which place'. The clause it heads may be in the scope of a speech act or knowledge related verb or particle.
\nt In the scope of negation, {wunjuku} translates as 'to anywhere' or 'to nowhere'.
\cp
\nq
\dt 20/Sep/2006

\sn 2
\ps noun
\pc
\sd
\lt in what manner
\ge how
\re how
\so EF, GB, RS, JD93
\xv Wunjukuu ninji nana mirramba, mirramba mukuran?
\sfx wunyjuku_ninyji_mirrambaF.wav
\xe How did you make that, make that spear?
\rf EF_R299EA1
\xv Wunjukuu ninji nana mirramba?
\sfx
\xe How did you make that?
\rf RS
\xv Wunjukunyi nan kakun?
\xe How (big) is this fish?
\rf GB
\xv Wunjuku ninji jungku?
\sfx wunjuku-ninji-jungku_CO.wav
\xe How are you?
\rf OSBORNE_C02-000165B.TMP
\xv Wunjuku ninji?
\xe How are you?
\rf JD93
\xv Wunkuju ninji yanyba?
\sfx
\xe What did you say?
\rf EF_R299EA1
\xv Wunjuku ninji yanyba ngaki?
\sfx
\xe What did you say to me?
\rf EF_R299A4
\va
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt
\cp Wambaya
\nq
\dt

\sn 3
\ps noun
\pc
\sd
\lt what (as complement of) 'say'
\ge what (say)
\re
\so EF, MF+EM_CO
\xv Wunjuku ninji yanyba?
\sfx wunyjuku-ninyji-yanyba.wav
\xe What did you say?
\rf EF_R299EA1
\xv Ngurrubu ninji ngan wunjuku yanyba ninji.
\xe You tell me what you said.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\va
\sy
\cf wanyi
\cf winja
\an
\nt
\cp
\nq

\lf


\lx -wunyi
\mr -wunyi
\sf
\sn 1
\ps suffix
\pc
\sd space
\lt ablative
\ge away from
\ge from
\ge out of
\re from
\so RS, GB, CO
\xv Budangku ngali najba nana-waan. Jilaba yalu nana-wunyi.
\xe We didn't see anyone. They had gone from there.
\rf RS
\xv Bulubarrba nyulu kaku wanami-wunyi.
\xe The fish is jumping up out of the water.
\rf RS
\xv Jilaba ngawu Jiranyku-wunyi.
\xe I've come from Jiranyku.
\rf RS
\xv Jangu-wunyi ngawu wilijirri.
\xe I pulled it out of the fire.
\rf RS
\xv Mularrijbi yalu jamba-wunyi, janki-wurru barri.
\xe They lift it up off the ground and then onto their shoulders.
\rf RS
\xv Janybijbi nyulu nana-waan warrwarri-darra, narrunguja-wunyi. 
\xe He's dropping off the kids from the truck.
\rf RS
\xv Yingka-wunyi, kala-wunyi, nana burrurrin.
\xe That man's from another country.
\rf RS
\xv Nanganja yalu nguli bala wadaba-wunyi.
\xe They get the bone to make a (fish) hook out of a goanna.
\rf RS
\xv Dungkala ngawu bala kaku-wunyi janyi-wunyi.
\xe I'm removing the hook from the fish's mouth.
\rf RS
\xv Jilaba nyulu kirriya-wunyi.
\xe He's going away from the woman.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\va -bunyi
\va -winyi
\sy
\cf -nanja
\nt
\an -wurru
\nq
\dt 24/Oct/2006

\sn 2
\ps suffix
\pc
\sd time
\lt following a previous event or action
\ge after
\ge since
\re
\so RS
\xv Yurrukadi nyulu wanbana kalawunyi kirriya-darraa, nanganja-wunyi.
\sfx
\xe The women took him inside the building after picking him up.
\rf RS
\xv  Murrumurrula-wunyi nanangkujarra wululuku, warrakujbu bula.
\xe After (leaving) Murrumurrula those two old men got lost.
\rf RS
\xv Nginngi bulangka nanangkuya barri mungana-mungana-wunyi.
\sfx
\xe Those two have been arguing since sunset.
\rf GB
\va
\sy
\cf
\an 
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt

\sn 3
\ps suffix
\pc
\sd cause
\lt cause of some change of behaviour or state
\ge because of
\ge from
\ge as a ^result of
\re
\so RS, GB
\xv Nanjarrijbi nyulu, nana maman, wanami-wunyi, nanyalu-wunyi.
\xe That food gets soft from the water, and from the tea (it is dunked in).
\rf RS
\xv Wambu ngawu waliji-wunyi.
\xe I'm sick from (eating) the meat.
\rf GB
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\va
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt

\lx wurrali
\mr
\hm
\sv
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd plant related
\sd fire
\la
\lt small pieces of dry wood used to start a cooking fire
\ge firewood
\ge kindling
\re
\so EM+MF_EF, GB78, RS, EK20081127-06, CO
\xv Wunjukumba nungka jila jangu-anyi kujbu? Wurrali-anyi?
\sfx
\xe Where will we go to look for firewood? For kindling?
\rf EM+MF_EF(Tape R299A5)
\xv Ngila, jilaba! Jilaa ninji, nanganja jangu, Wurralin.
\xe Little girl, go! You go and fetch firewood, kindling.
\rf RS
\xv Nanganja wurrali, jangu niya!
\xe Get kindling and make (lit. put) a fire.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\va
\sy
\cf jangu
\an
\nt
\cp
\nq

\lx wurrarra
\mr wurrarra
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd ELEMENTS
\sd weather
\lt wind
\ge breeze
\ge wind
\re wind
\so EF, RS, GB, JD93, RC_SK, RC+MF_SK, JP_TT
\xv Wurrarra jalwa.
\xe Strong wind.
\rf RS
\xv Dajkanyi nyulu ngambalanya, kijibajii wurrarraa.
\xe The dangerous wind will strike us.
\rf RS
\xv Wandamba nangka, ngambalangi, wurrarraa barri.
\xe The wind is moving around us, changing direction.
\rf RS
\xv Wurrarra langini.
\sfx
\xe Wind from south.
\rf EF_R299D2
\va
\sy
\cf wirriwiji
\nt Also recorded by Dymock (1993) as 'cold weather'
\nt RC_SK & RC+MF_SK 'winter' as well as 'wind'
\cp
\nq often wurrara {need to check further}; transcribed by BS as wurrara
\dt 01/Oct/2006
\sn 2
\ps noun
\pc
\sd body related
\lt breath
\ge breath
\re
\so RS
\xv Wurrarra ngawu janybijbi janyini ngalu-nanja. Ngarrkudujbu ngawu ngalu.
\sfx
\xe I am breathing (lit. casting wind) through my mouth from my chest. I am short-winded.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf ngarrkudujbu
\cf ngurujbu
\an
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt

\lx wurrijbi

\hm
\sv
\sf
\sn
\ps verb
\pc

\la

\ge gang up on
\re
\so GB (grammar ch 6)
\xv Kaja-darraan ngan dara-darraa bijbi, wurriijini.
\sfx
\xe A big mob of dogs ganged up on me and bit me.
\rf GB (Grammar ch 6)
\va
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt
\cp
\nq GB records as wurriijbi

\lf wurriijini


\lx wurrimbi
\mr wurri-mbi
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd removal
\lt Xerg remove outer surface of Y
\ge scrape off
\ge scale (fish)
\ge skin
\ge strip
\re scrape off
\so RS, GB
\xv Wurrimbi nurri kakun, nyili.
\xe We scrape off the fish's scales.
\rf RS
\va wirrimbi
\sy
\cf bangkijbi
\nt
\cp
\nq also "scale" (v) ; wirrimbi in 2000-03
\dt 30/Sep/2006


\lx -wurru
\mr -wurru
\sf
\sn 1
\ps suffix
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt allative suffix
\ge onto
\ge to
\ge towards
\re to
\so RS, GB
\xv Jilaba nurri, Kudalku-wurru.
\xe We went to Kudalku.
\rf RS
\xv Kannga nurri jilana, raji-wurru barri.
\xe We are going back home now.
\rf RS
\xv Burrbijbi nyulu Dungkumini-wurru, bala-anyi.
\xe He drove to Dungkumini to (get) fish hooks.
\rf RS
\xv Kularra kiya nyulu jilaba Kayawana-wurru 
\xe He should have gone south to Kiana.
\rf RS
\xv Kannga ngali manangka-wurru wanami-anyi. 
\xe We went back to the river to get water.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku ngamba jilaba, nanangkurru raji-wurru.
\xe We won't to that camp.
\rf RS
\xv Mularrijbi, bikali-daba, janki-wurru.
\xe Pick it up, put it on (your) shoulder to carry.
\rf RS
\va -kurru
\va -ngkurru
\va -rru
\va -yurru
\sy
\cf
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt 29/Aug/2006

\sn 2
\ps suffix
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt suffixed to predicate that is concurrent with main predicate such that referent of Object of main predicate is coreferent with implicit referent of subject of predicate to which {-wurru} is suffixed.
\ge while
\re while
\so RS
\xv Kalijbi ngawu. Kudijbi-wurru.
\sfx
\xe I speared it as it lay (there).
\rf RS
\xv Kawa-najba ngawu, kunuma, baba-wurru.
\xe I spot honey bees flying (around).
\rf RS
\xv Najba yalu ngambalanya, jungku-wurru. 
\xe They see us sitting down.
\rf RS
\xv Lajikini ngamba jungku, ngindi-wurru.
\xe We are sitting listening to him crying.
\rf RS
\xv Manku ngawu kuwadaa, ngungkurru-wurru.
\xe I can hear it (=car motor) roaring.
\rf RS
\xv Najba ngawu ramii, ngira-wurru.
\xe I saw him steal it.
\rf RS
\xv Mama-wurru najba nga dabarra-kurru.
\xe He watched me cook damper.
\rf GB
\va -kurru
\va -ngkurru
\va -rru
\sy
\cf ngala
\an
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt


\lx wurrujbu
\mr wurru-j-bu
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd motion
\lt X move downwards in water and be unable to exit
\ge drown
\ge sink
\re drown
\re sink
\so RS
\xv Budangku nyulu bilikijaa, kadimirra wawurra. Wurrujbu nyulu wanamini.
\xe The little child can't swim. He's drowning in the water.
\rf RS
\va
\sy ngurralyijbi
\sy ngurrurijbi
\cf
\nt
\cp
\nq 
\dt 26/Oct/2006

\lx wurrumbu
\mr wurru-mbu
\hm
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd movement
\lt Xerg cause Y to move down in water
\ge sink
\ge drown
\re drown
\re sink
\so RS
\xv Wurrumbu ninya, kadimirra wawurra, wajka wanamini. Marijbi ninya kaburrukajaa.
\sfx
\xe He'll drown you, little boy, down in the water. The crocodile will grab you.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt
\cp Garrwa {ngurrumbu} 'sink'
\nq

\sv
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc MarchFly.jpg
\sd insect
\la Diptera
\la Tabanidae
\lt
\ge Marchfly
\re
\so RS, JD93, GW
\xv Kijibaji, wurumbumbu. Bijbi nyulu ngaan, wurumbumbuu. Dadajba ngawu, banyi.
\sfx
\xe The Marchfly is nasty. Marchflies bite me (and) my skin stings.
\rf RS2002-10
\va wurrumbumbu (?)
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt Dymock (1993) also records {WURRUMBUMBU, WURRUMALA, WURRUMULA} 'March Fly'.
\cp
\nq
\dt
\lf

\sn 2
\ps noun
\pc
\sd animal
\sd insect (and spider)
\la Odonata
\la Anisoptera
\lt flying insects; dragonflies (many taxa)
\ge Dragonfly
\re 
\so JD93, GW
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\va wurrumbumbu
\sy lunmuru
\cf jumbujumbu
\an
\nt Also recorded by Dymock (1993) as 'wasp','March fly', 'dragon fly', 'damsel fly' and 'moth'
\nt
\cp Wambaya {wurumbumbi} 'Dragonfly'
\nq
\dt
\lf
