\lx -wuya
\mr -wuya
\sf
\sn 1
\ps suffix
\pc
\sd quantity
\sd grammar
\lt dual suffix on nouns
\ge two
\re two
\so RS
\xv Kujarra mandaki-wuya.
\xe Two white men.
\rf RS
\xv Jungku bula nanangkujarra burrurri-wuya, wakalinyi ngandunu. 
\xe Those two men are sitting inside the shelter.
\rf RS
\xv Nangkujarra, ngila-wuya. Bankanya-wuya. Maku-nganja-wuya. Nangkujarraa ngila-wuyaa, nijbi bulangka mimi-kula.
\xe These two girls, they are two cousins, two cross cousins. These two girls, they call themselves cousins.
\rf rs2004-01
\xv Kujarra makulu-wuya nanangkujarra, nayi kingkarri balana.
\xe Those two 'eggs' (= Magellanic Clouds) are up here in the sky.
\rf RS
\xv Mudumbanyi bula nangkujarra, ngila-wuya, ngakinkanyi yanyi-anyi.
\xe These two girls don't know my language.
\rf RS
\xv Kujarra jumbuuna-wuya, wululuku-wuya.
\xe Two old Yellow Goanna men (ancestors).
\rf RS
\xv Marrijbi bulangka. Manangka-wuyaa.
\xe The two rivers join up.
\rf RS
\va -kiya
\va -kuya
\va -ngkuya
\va -wiya
\sy -ngkujarra
\cf kujarra
\nt
\cp
\nq 
\dt 20/Oct/2006
\lf -wuyaa

\lx wuyunbu

\sn 1

\xe The bird, the kookaburra, it might be laughing at us.

\xe He's laughing at us while we're talking.

\cf nguyulijbi

\lx -ya
\mr
\sf
\hm 2
\sn 1
\ps suffix
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt privative suffix
\ge without
\ge not having
\ge no
\re 
\so EF, GB, RS
\xv Waliji-yan nungka jungku, balika.
\sfx 
\xe We have no meat, and are hungry.
\rf EF_R299AE2
\xv Jungku nyulu nana wanami-yaa.
\sfx
\xe He's got no water.
\rf EF_R299AE2
\xv Wanamiya nana jungku nyulu.
\sfx
\xe He has no water.
\rf EF_R299EA2
\xv Ngarriyimbayan ngawu.
\xe I've got no mate.
\rf MF_GB76
\xv Kalijbi nyulu kudumanjaa, kuwada-yani burrurrii, winyakii, nyubanyubanyii.
\sfx
\xe That crazy man, wild bush man, kept on spearing him, all on his own.
\rf RS
\va -yaa
\va -yaan
\va -yan
\sy maku
\cf 
\nt Ergative form is {-yani}
\nt The vowel is often lengthened to {-yaa} and/or hosts final {-n}
\cp
\nq

\lx yababala
\mr yababala
\sf yababala_CO.wav
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd time
\lt time between daylight and night
\ge end of day
\ge evening
\ge late afternoon
\ge early evening
\ge sundown
\ge sunset
\ge sundown
\re
\so RS, EK, JD93, EM_SK, MB_LH12
\xv Yababalana.
\sfx yababalana-evening.wav
\sfx yababalana.wav
\xe At sundown.
\rf RS-RG1999
\xv Mudunama yababala.
\sfx mudunama-yababala_CO.wav
\xe Tomorrow evening.
\rf OSBORNE_C02-000165B.TMP
\xv Kannga nyulu jalanya. Yababalana.
\xe He'll come back directly, before sundown.
\rf RS
\xv Jungku nurri yingkanyini durunu, kannga nurri yababalana.
\xe We'll stay away for one day and return in the evening.
\rf RS
\xv Jilaba ngawu, kannga ngawu yababalana.
\xe I'm going and I'll come back late afternoon.
\rf RS
\xv Yababalana nurri kannga bayungu barri Mungkubayi-wunyi.
\xe We will come back west from Burketown in the late afternoon.
\rf EK (ML notes)
\va yabaabala [GB]
\va yabalabala [EM_SK]
\sy
\cf kamu
\cf munga
\cf ngabungabu
\nt

\lx yajanga
\mr yajanga
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd spatial
\lt anterior part of something or position ahead of something
\ge ahead
\ge front
\ge in front
\ge before
\re
\so RS, MB_LH13
\xv Jilaba ninji ngaki banjana. Jilaba ngawu yajanga.
\xe You come behind me. I'll go in front.
\rf RS
\xv Yurrukadi nyulu, janyini, mukurana, yajangana, kangkarinya, jimindi.
\xe He puts the knife, the stone tip on the front part of the spear.
\rf RS
\xv Karrinja nganyi yajangu, nganyinbuyangka dalu. Jungku ngamba, wakalinyi.
\xe It's standing in front of you, the shady tree is near you. We are sitting under it.
\rf RS2000-11
\xv Yajanga ninji yila, ngala ngawu banjana. 
\sfx
\xe You to ahead while I (go) behind.
\rf MB_LH13
\va yajana
\sy
\cf janyi
\an banjana
\nt
\cp
\nq check if yajana ~ yajanga

\lx yakujbu
\mr yaku-j-bu
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd motion
\lt Xerg move away from Y 
\ge abandon
\ge discard
\ge divorce
\ge leave
\re leave
\so RS, GB, EK, CO, MB
\xv Yakujbu yalu.
\sfx yakujbu_yalu.wav
\xe They leave it.
\rf RS-RG1999
\xv Balyanga nanganja. Yakujbu. Yingka-anyi, burrurri-anyi.
\xe Don't take it. Leave it. It belongs to another man.
\rf rs2000-08
\xv Yakujbu ninji banjana rajini.
\xe You left it behind at home.
\rf rs2004-04
\xv Budangku yalu kannga mukura-yudu. Yakujbu yalu. Ramiramba yalu, ramiramba mukuran. Bakarrijbi yalu, bakarrijbi yalu jangunu.
\xe They didn't go back with the spears (after a revenge party). They would leave them there. They would smash them up, smash up the spears. They would burn them, burn them in the fire.
\rf rs2002-03
\va
\xv Yakujbu bulangka.
\xe They left each other (i.e., they got divorced)
\rf rs2004untaped
\xv Dabarra-kana! Ngaki nana. Yakujbu! Yakujbuma!
\xe Don't cook (it). That's mine. Leave (it)! Leave it alone I say!
\rf RS2005-05
\xv Yakujbu nyulu niyanya daluu, nganduu.
\xe The shade is leaving us, the shade of the tree. (We are no longer in the shade.)
\rf RS2005-01
\xv Jarrba yalu dawurrumbu. Budangku yalu yakujbu, nana-waan-kanyi.
\sfx jarrba yalu dawurrumbu-they ate all.wav
\sfx budangku yalu yakujbu nana-waan-kanyi.wav
\xe They ate it all up. They didn't leave anything for others.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Yakujkanyi nimba ngaan. Kannga-anyi nimba, kala-wurru.
\xe You two have to leave me. You've got to go back to your home country.
\rf RS
\xv Mudamudajibi nurri kalawa jibana. Yakujbu nurri, kumayangunu. 
\sfx
\xe We wrapped up the bones (of the dead person) in sheets of paperbark and we left them in a cave. 
\rf RS2002-09
\xv Budangku ninji kirinji nanangkanyi. Yakujbu, maninja.
\xe Don't you try to take that. Leave it. It belongs to someone else.
\rf RS2004-04
\xv Mangkarri-nganja nyulu yakujbu, ngaba nyulu yingka-anyi.
\xe He left his (own) wife, and took another's.
\rf RS
\xv Yakujbu ngawu, narriyanya. Jungku narri. Ngawu, jilaba ngawu, kudijbi ngawu mukudarrana ngunyini.
\xe I'm leaving you mob. You stay here. I'm going out camping for a few days.
\rf RS
\xv Yaku!
\xe Leave (it)!
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Ngawuji yakujbu wabula.
\xe I left it a long time ago.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Yakujbu ngawu wawurra ngada-nganjana, wulu-nganjana.
\xe I left the child with her mother and father.
\rf GB
\va
\sy
\cf nijbi
\nt
\cp Kudanji {yakujbi}; Wambaya {yaku}
\nq 
\dt 29/Sep/2006
\lf yaku
\lf yakujkanyi
\lf yakukana
\sn 2
\ps verb
\pc
\sd negation
\lt Xerg not do something to Y 
\ge don't (do something to something)
\ge desist from doing
\ge keep from doing
\re desist
\so RS, GB
\xv Kalijkana yaku! Ngarrimba nganyi. Barrakalaba ngawu ninya. Mungkuji nganyi.
\xe Don't spear him. He's your mate. I'm stopping you (from hitting him). He's your countryman.
\rf rs2004-04
\xv Bulinja-kana wululuku! Yakujbu nana wanu. Mayi ninji warrawarraa. Mayi ninya burra-daba.
\sfx bulinja-kana wululuku.wav
\sfx yakujbu nana wanu.wav
\sfx mayi ninji warrawarraa.wav
\sfx mayi ninya burra-daba.wav
\xe Don't smoke, old man! Leave that tobacco alone. You might have a fit. It might knock you out.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Jarrkana nana maman, dawurrumbu ninji. Jarrkana yakujbu ngambalangi.
\xe Don't eat that food, you're eating it all up. Don't eat it (all) and leave some for all of us.
\rf RS2005-05
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\va
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt Used with transitive verb to express negation of action.
\cp
\nq

\lx yalu
\mr yalu
\sf yalu.wav
\sn 1
\ps pronoun
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt third person plural subject pronoun
\ge they
\re 
\so RS, GB, CO, MB
\xv Kuujbu yalu ngaki.
\sfx kuujbu yalu ngaki.wav
\xe They are looking for me.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Budangku yalu windijbi nurriyanya namirra-anyi.
\xe They don't give us any money.
\rf rs2003-01
\xv Mirramba yalu babakana. Daba yalu karaa. Ramijbi yalu. Ngukujaba yalu yamarrina barri.
\xe They used to make stone knives. They would strike them with a rock and break them (in two). They would sharpen it on a flat rock.
\rf rs2002-04
\xv Budangku yalu kannga mukura-yudu. Yakujbu yalu. Ramiramba yalu, ramiramba mukuran. Bakarrijbi yalu, bakarrijbi yalu jangunu.
\xe They didn't go back with the spears (after a revenge party). They would leave them there. They would smash them up, smash up the spears. They would burn them, burn them in the fire.
\rf rs2002-03
\xv Nana-waan kudaya-waan, jilaba yalu, bayinga. Wandajba yalu bayinga. Kannga yalu langkurri.
\xe Those others, they are going on the west side. They are travelling on the west side as they return north.
\rf rs2005-08b
\xv
\xe
\rf
\va
\sy
\cf
\nt
\cp

\lx yalungi
\mr yalu-ngi
\hm
\sf
\sn
\ps pronoun
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt dative form of third person plural pronoun
\ge their
\ge theirs
\ge for them
\ge belonging to them
\re
\so RS, GB, CO, MB_LH
\xv Junuu, mudumbanyi, budangkun lajibi, yanyi yalungi, Kudanji, banga Ambaya. Budangku ngamba lajibi nana yanyi yalungi. Mudumbanyi ngamba.
\xe Don't know, ignorant, can't understand their language, Kudanji and Wambaya, we don't understand that language of theirs. We don't know it.
\rf rs2004-05
\xv Budangku nayi jamba nganyi; yalungi nayi jamban. 
\xe This land is not yours, this land is theirs.
\xe RS2004-05
\xv Jalwa nana, yanyi yalungi. Budangku ngawu mankuu.
\sfx
\xe That language of theirs is hard. I can't understand it.
\rf RS2004-05
\xv Nanganja ngawu wanami yalungi.
\xe I get meat for them.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\va yaluwangi
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt
\lf yalu
\lf yalunginbunu
\lf yalunginburru

\lx yalunginbunu
\mr yalu-ngi-n.bu-nu
\hm
\sv
\sf
\sn 1
\ps pronoun
\pc
\sd grammar
\la
\lt third person plural locative pronoun
\ge with them
\re
\so CO
\xv Wawurra jungku yalunginbunu.
\sfx
\xe The child is living with them.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\va

\lf yalu
\lf yalungi
\lf yalunginbunu


\lx yalungka
\mr yalu-ngka
\hm
\sf
\sn
\ps pronoun
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt reflexive/reciprocal form of third person plural pronoun
\ge they themselves
\re
\so RS, GB, CO
\xv Daba yalungka mama-nanja.
\xe They are fighting over food.
\rf RS2005-02
\xv Kawa-najba yalungka.
\sfx
\xe They meet up.
\rf RS
\xv Madamba yalungka yanyii.
\xe The languages have mixed together.
\rf RS2004-05
\xv Daba yalungka nguwajini burrurrii.
\xe The men fight being jealous.
\rf RS
\xv Jurrangkimbi yalungka.
\xe They are playing around.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku yalungka kudumbu yalungi rami. Jalwa rami.
\xe They don't close their eyes. (They are) wide awake (Lit. eyes are strong).
\rf RS
\va yaluwangka
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt
\lf yalu
\lf yalungi
\lf yalunya
\lf yaluwanya

\lx yalunya
\mr yalu-nya
\hm
\sf
\sn
\ps pronoun
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt accusative form of third person plural pronoun
\ge them
\re
\so RS, GB, MF+EM_CO, MB_LH09
\xv Mirrirrimbi yalunya.
\sfx
\xe (They) teach them.
\rf RS
\va yaluwanya
\xv Daba yalunya narrungujaa.
\xe Cars hit them (animals).
\rf RS
\xv Najba ngawu yalunya. Jurrangkimbi yalungka.
\xe I can see them. They are playing.
\rf RS
\xv Najba nyulu yalunya mularri-kurru.
\xe He saw them lifting (it) up.
\rf RS
\xv Kuku-najba ngamba yalunya kajala-kurru.
\xe We are watching them climb.
\rf RS
\xv Lajibi ngawu yalunya.
\xe I can hear them.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku ngawu manku yalunya yanykurru.
\xe I can't understand them when they talk.
\rf RS
\xv Wanamii, ngunyimbi yalunya. Kudijbi barri yalu.
\xe That water has made them go to sleep. They are asleep now.
\rf RS
\xv Daraa bijbi yalunya.
\xe A dog bit them.
\ef MF+EM_CO
\va yaluwanya
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt
\lf yalu
\lf yalungi
\lf yalungka


\lx yaluwangi
\mr yalu-wa-ngi
\hm
\sf
\sn
\ps pronoun
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt dative third person plural pronoun
\ge theirs
\ge for them
\ge belonging to them
\re
\so RS
\xv Budangku yaluwangi, kannga ngamba. 
\xe (If) they are not (there), we (will) come back.
\sfx
\rf RS
\xv Najba ngamba, budangku nayi yaluwangi, budangkun, kannga ngamba. Budangku ngamba jungku nawunu. Budangku yaluwangi. Budangku yaluwangi nayi, raji yaluwangi. 
\xe We see that there's no one here, noone, so we'll go back. We won't stay here. They are not here. They are not here in their camp.
\rf RS
\va yalungi
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt Pronounced [yaluangi].
\cp
\nq
\dt


\lx yaluwangka
\mr yalu-wa-ngka
\hm
\sf
\sn
\ps pronoun
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt reflexive and reciprocal third person plural pronoun
\ge they [...] themselves
\ge they [...] each other
\re themselves
\so RS
\xv Yurru-yurru-kadi yaluwangka julakini.
\sfx
\xe They get themselves into the aeroplane.
\rf RS
\xv Mudamudajibi yaluwangka.
\xe They tie themselves in. (i.e., They put on their seatbelts.)
\rf RS
\xv Daba yaluwangka kundaa, wawurra-darraa kuwada-yani.
\xe Those silly kids are hitting each other with sticks.
\rf RS
\xv Kurrkamalaa dara-darraa, bijbi yaluwangka.
\xe A big mob of dogs are biting each other.
\rf RS
\xv Birajba yaluwangka yurrul. Jungku yalu birajini yurrulini nana-waan burrurri-darra.
\xe They're singing (themselves) a corroboree. Those men are sitting singing a corroboree song.
\rf rs2004-01
\xv Budangku yalu ngunyijbi, jalwa rami. Budangku yaluwangka kudumbu ramin.
\xe They don't nod off as their eyes are strong (i.e., they can stay awake). They don't close their eyes.
\rf RS2004-08
\va yalungka
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt Pronounced [yaluangka].
\cp
\nq
\dt


\lx yaluwanya
\mr yalu-wa-nya
\hm
\sf
\sn
\ps pronoun
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt accusative third person plural pronoun
\ge them
\re
\so RS
\xv Durramba yaluwanya, nana kadimirra, jukajuka.
\xe They frighten them, those young boys.
\rf RS
\xv Yanyba ngamba yalungi, kuwada-yaan. Ngurrubu ngamba yaluwanya, budangku yalu lajibi ngambalanya.
\xe We talk to them who take no notice (lit. earless). We tell them, (but) they don't listen to us.
\rf RS
\xv Kuku-najba nyulu yaluwanya, nana-waan, wakubaku-darra kadimirra.
\xe He's watching them, those little boys.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku nurri najba yaluwanya.
\sfx
\xe We didn't see them. OR We didn't see anyone.
\rf RS
\xv Windijbi nurri yaluwanya kajaa yanyii.
\xe We gave them a lot of stories.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku yalu windijbi yaluwanya burrurri-darra, namirra-anyi.
\xe They didn't give the men any money.
\rf RS
\xv Yakujbu nurri yaluwanya, walimbi nurri bayungu julakini barri, yingkanyini, wulukudirrini.
\xe We left them, we headed west in one very big aeroplane.
\rf RS
\xv Mayi yaluwanya jarriyamba, warrakumbu. 
\xe He might carry them off and make them go mad.
\rf RS
\xv Windijbi nurri yaluwanya kajaa yanyii.
\xe We supplied them with a lot of information.
\rf RS
\va yalunya
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt Pronounced [yaluanya].
\cp
\nq
\dt

\lx yama

\sf

\pc

\xe Let him wake up by himself. (OR 'He wants/has to wake up by himself.')

\xv Budangku ngawu bawa-nganja-anyi, ngawu yama.
\xe I have no brothers, (there's) only me.
\rf GB
\xv Nyulu yama lalujkanyi.
\xe He will wake up by himself.
\rf GB
\xv Budangku ngawu bawa ngakinkanyi, ngawu yama.
\sfx
\xe I don't have any brothers, there's just me.

\lx yamarr
\mr yamarr
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd manufacture
\lt flat rock used for grinding, or smooth stone
\ge flat rock
\ge flat stone
\re grinding stone (base)
\so RS, JD93
\xv Mirramba yalu babakana. Daba yalu karaa. Ramijbi yalu. Ngukujaba yalu yamarrina barri.
\xe They used to make stone knives. They would strike them with a rock and break them (in two). They would then sharpen it on a flat rock.
\rf rs2002-04
\xv Nanganja ngawu yamarr.
\xe I'm fetching a grinding stone.
\rf RS
\xv Nanjarr-nanjarrba nurri wuliwulii, yamarrina.
\xe We used to soften it by (striking it) with a round rock on a flat grinding stone.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf wuliwuli
\cf birrara
\nt Used of flat stone on which seeds were ground up.
\nt Also recorded as 'pebble' by Dymock (1993)
\cp
\nq
\dt 12/Sep/2006

\lx yandujbu
\mr yandu-j-bu
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd hold (holding and transfer)
\lt Xerg be in possession of Y
\ge have
\ge hold
\ge keep
\ge touch
\re 
\so RS, GB, EK, MB_LH
\xv Yandujbu nyulu ngaki namirra. Nanajba nyulu ngaki namirra-yudu.
\xe She's keeping my money. She's waiting for me with the money.
\rf rs2004
\xv Waliji nungka yandujbu kujarrana ngunyini.
\xe Let's hold onto the meat for two days.
\rf GB
\xv Yandujbu nana yanyin. Budangku ninji mamanumbu.
\xe Hold onto that language. Don't you forget it.
\rf RS
\xv Yandujbu ngawu yanyi kurrkamala, nganyi.
\xe I've got many words of your language.
\rf RS
\xv Yandujbu ninji yanyi kurrkamala ngaki.
\xe You still have all my words.
\rf RS
\xv Yandujbu ngamba, munji-munji.
\xe We'll keep him a long way away (out in the bush).
\rf RS
\xv Yandujbu nyulu ngaki namirra.
\xe He's got my money.
\rf EK
\va
\sy
\cf marrijbi
\cf namanyba
\nt
\cp
\nq

\lx -yangkurru
\mr
\hm
\sf
\sn 1
\ps suffix
\pc
\sd human
\lt sympathetic: added to human-referring term to indicate referent is deceased
\ge deceased
\ge late
\re
\so GB
\xv Ngada-yangkurru
\sfx
\xe Deceased mother.
\rf GB
\xv Murriba-yangkurru
\xe Deceased father.
\rf GB
\xv Badada-yangkurru.
\xe Deceased child.
\rf GB
\xv Bawa-yangkurru.
\xe (My) late elder brother.
\rf GB
\xv Badibadi-yangkurru.
\xe An old woman who has passed away.
\rf GB
\va 
\sy -yurru
\cf bibi-yurru
\an
\nt Also recorded by Breen as {-yankurru}.
\cp
\nq

\lx yangulu
\mr yangulu
\sf yangulu_CO.wav
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd particle
\lt
\ge when
\ge for how long
\re 
\so RS, GB, EK, MB_LH13

\xe When will you come back here?
\rf RS2004-08a
\xv Yangulu ninji ngabaa ngaan kularra wanba-wurru?
\xe When will you take me back south to the station?
\rf RS
\xv Yangulu ninyji jungku? Murrku-darrana ngawu kudijbi ngunyini.
\xe For how long are you staying (away)? I'll be camping away for four nights.
\rf RS
\xv Yangulu ninji najba?
\xe When did you see him?

\lf yanyba

\lx yanja
\mr yanyja
\hm 2
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd land
\lt large body of water
\ge big water hole
\ge river
\re water
\so RS, EK
\xv Jungku nurri yanjini yanjana. Langkurri nyulu burrbijbi wanamin, dumularra, malu-wurru barri.
\xe We are sitting talking at the big water hole. The water current runs north towards the sea.
\rf RS
\xv Makaramba nyulu, ngambalanya. Wurrarraa, yanja-wunyi.
\xe The wind is blowing cool air on us, off the water.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf dumularra
\cf kala
\cf manangka
\cf wanami
\cf wirringayi
\cf wirriwudirri
\nt Used by Doomadgee men to refer to Gregory River.
\cp
\nq

\lx yanyba
\mr yany-ba
\sf yanyba.wav
\sf yanba.wav
\sf yanba02.wav
\sf yanba03.wav
\sf yanba04.wav
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd sound
\lt X produce sound characteristic of X (to communicate to Ydat)
\ge say
\ge speak
\ge talk
\ge tell
\re 
\so EF, RS, GB, EK, MF_EM_CO, MB_LH13
\xv Wanyi nana yanyin? Yanyba ngawu nganyi, Layadila nana.
\sfx wanyi nana yanyin.wav
\sfx yanyba ngawu nganyi Layadila nana.wav
\xe What's that language? I say to you, that's Laardil.
\rf RS2004-05
\xv Mankuu nyulu niyanya yanykurru.
\xe He's listening to us talking.
\rf RS2005-02
\xv Lajibi nyulu niyanya, yanyba nungka.
\xe He's listening to us, (while) we are talking.
\rf RS2005-02
\xv Lajibi nyulu ninya Waanyi-wurru yanykurru.
\xe He's listening to you talking Wanyi.
\rf RS
\xv Balyanga yanja!
\xe Don't talk.
\rf GB (PC)
\xv Warawara yanja!
\xe Keep on talking!
\rf GB (PC)
\xv Jila ngamba yanyjudu yanyi-yanyi.
\xe We are going to talk language.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Jila ngamba yanjini yanyini.
\xe We are going along talking language.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Wayi ninji lajibi yanykurru?
\xe Did you hear him talking?
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Yanja nungka.
\sfx
\xe Let's talk.
\rf IS_GB
\xv Yanykana jilanji.
\xe Go in silence (lit. not talking).
\rf IS_GB78
\xv Yanyba ninji ngaki.
\sfx
\xe You talk to me.
\rf EF_R299A4
\va
\sy jangkurr
\cf karubu-yanyba
\cf baraku-yanyba
\nt
\cp Garrwa; Wambaya {yanybi} 'get, pick up' 
\nq

\lx Yanyula

\sf
\sn 1

\pc

\ge Yanyula
\ge Yanyuwa
\re

\sfx budangku_ngawu_mankuu_yanyula_RS.wav

\xv Langkurrinyi, Marra, Yanyula. Yanyi yingka nana yanyi yalungi.
\sfx
\xe The Marra and Yanyula people are northerners. Their language is different.
\rf RS
\xv Kiyiwurrunu yalu jungku. Yanyula-anyi yaji.
\xe They live on Kiyiwurru. That's a Yanyula place.
\rf RS2004-03
\xv Maninja nayi jamba. Yanyula-anyi. Yanyula-anyi nayi jamba. Budangkun Waanyi-anyi.
\xe This country (i.e. Borroloola, NT) belongs to other people. To Yanyula people. This land is for the Yanyula. It doesn't belong to Waanyi people.
\rf RS2002-04
\xv Budangku nurri Waanyii mankuu, yanyi Yanyula. Miyarrka nurri.
\xe We Waanyi don't understand the Yanyula language. We don't know (it).
\rf RS

\sy
\cf
\nt
\cp
\nq

\ge debris carried and deposited by strong river currents

\sfx Yimbirra-nyulu-bikali wanamii dumularraa-RS2003-12T03.wav
\xe The floodwaters carry the loose vegetation along with them. The strong current discarded it along the way.
\rf rs2005-02

\xe I saw that debris hanging up (there).

\lx yingamali
\mr yinga-mali
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc

\lt single entity
\ge alone
\ge one
\ge same
\re one

\xe He's got only one daughter. My granddaughter, one little one.

\sy yingkanyi

\lx yingka
\mr yingka
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd quantity
\lt
\ge different
\ge other
\ge another
\ge others
\re other
\so RS, GB, MB_LH87
\xv Yingka-wiya.
\xe Other two.
\rf GB
\xv Yingka nyulu banyajba.
\xe He passed the other one.
\rf GB
\xv Yakujbu. Yingka-anyi, burrurri-anyi.
\xe Leave it. It belongs to another man.
\rf rs2000-08
\xv Jujuu nyulu jungku bayungu, yingkana barruwunu.
\xe He's living far away to the west, in another town.
\rf rs2003-02
\xv Langkurrinyi, Marra, Yanyula. Yanyi yingka nana yanyi yalungi.
\sfx
\xe The Marra and Yanyula people are northerners. Their language is different.
\rf RS
\xv Malijibi ninji yingka-anyi wululuku-anyi.
\xe You were behind that other old man.
\rf RS
\xv Nawunu ngamba jungku, yingkana yajini.
\xe We are here in another place (not our own home town).
\rf RS
\xv Mangkarri-nganja nyulu yakujbu, ngaba nyulu yingka-anyi.
\xe He left his (own) wife, and took another's.
\rf RS
\xv Daba nyulu yingkan.
\sfx
\xe He hit the other one.
\rf IS_GB78
\xv Nana yingkan ngudin; nana yingka yarramba.
\sfx
\xe That one is narrow; that other one is wide.
\rf IS_GB78
\xv Yingka-darra.
\sfx
\xe Others.
\rf MB_LH13
\va
\sy
\cf yingamali
\cf yingkanyi
\nt
\cp
\nq or 'other'? 'another'
\dt 28/Oct/2006

\lx yingkanyi
\mr yingkanyi
\sf yingkanyi_CO.wav
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd quantity
\lt single entity
\ge one
\ge alone
\ge same
\re one
\so EF_R299EA1, RS, GB, JD93, SC_BB, JP_TT
\xv Yingkanyi burrurri
\sfx yingkanyi_burrurri.wav
\xe One man.
\rf RS-RG1999
\xv Yingakanyi ngawu.
\sfx yingkanyi_ngawu.wav
\xe I'm alone.
\rf RS-RG1999
\xv Wadabaku yingkanyi.
\xe One boy.
\rf RS
\xv Yakujbu nurri yaluwanya, walimbi nurri bayungu julakini barri, yingkanyini, wulukudirrini.
\xe We left them, we headed west in one very big aeroplane.
\rf RS
\xv Yingkanyi mangala.
\xe Same design.
\rf RS
\xv Jungku nurri yingkanyini durunu, kannga nurri yababalana.
\xe We'll stay away during the day and return in the evening.
\rf RS
\xv Kananganja yingkanyi, Yakimarri-yanyi, Kangala-anyi.
\xe One Emu (Dreaming) belongs to the Yakimarri-Kangala patricouple.
\rf RS
\xv Yingkanyii ngaan daba, kundaa. 
\xe One (man) hit me with a stick.
\rf RS
\xv Jilaba barri ninji, kujbu ninji, yingkanyi-anyi barri nawi-nganja-anyi.
\xe You go and look for one other husband after that (i.e., after becoming a widow).
\rf RS
\xv Yingkanyii burrurrii, nanganja nyulu mukuran, nangangi.
\xe One man got his spear.
\rf RS
\xv Bajawaja nyulu, yingkanyi wawurra, ngindini.
\xe One child is thrashing around, crying.
\rf RS
\va
\sy yingamali
\cf yingka
\an 
\nt

\nq

\xe Those ones are another mob. Those ones are different.

\xv Dajaya yalu niyanya. Yingka-yingka-darra burrurri. Budangku nungka lajibi yanyin yalungi.
\xe You and I can't go any further. They are different people (from us). We don't understand their language.

\lx yinini
\mr yinini
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd
\lt not like object of comparison
\ge different
\ge distinct
\ge other
\ge other type of
\ge particular
\re different
\so RS, EK
\xv Jingili-anyi, yinini yanyi, budangku ngawu jirringkijbi.
\xe The Jingili people's language is different, I can't understand it.
\rf RS
\xv Yinini mulu yalungi julaki-yanyi.
\sfx
\xe Birds have all distinct beaks.
\rf RS
\xv Waanyi nungka burrurrin. Yinini nayi, yingka-anyi nayi jamba, yanyi.
\xe We are Waanyi men. This is different, this land and language belongs to other people.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku ngamba ngaraba, yinini nana wanamin. Ngarrawa-yudu.
\xe We don't drink it, that water is different. It's salty.
\xv Yinini, yinini, nana-waan kaku-darra. Mujudi yinini. Wirrikajikaji, yinini kaku. Mujularri, yinini. Bununganyi, yinini.
\xe Those fish are all different (from each other). The black bream is distinct. The spotted catfish is a different fish. The rockcod is different (again). The spotted bream is another type (of fish).
\rf RS
\xv Yinini nana-waan, kundan. 
\xe Those trees are (all) different.
\rf RS
\xv Yinini nukami yalungi julaki-anyi.
\xe Birds all have different feet (tracks).
\rf RS
\va yiniyini
\sy yingka-yingka
\cf kudaya
\an yingkanyi
\nt
\cp
\nq 
\dt 26/Oct/2006



\lx yiniyini
\mr yiniyini
\hm 1
\sf
\sn
\ps noun
\pc
\sd quantity
\lt emphasizes distinctness or individuality of something
\ge distinct
\ge individual
\ge self
\re distinct
\so GB
\xv Ninji nukami-yudi jilanji yiniyini nanganjana.
\xe You've got feet (so) go and get it yourself.
\rf GB
\xv Jungkumu yiniyini.
\sfx
\xe Sit by yourself (keep away from another).
\rf GB
\xv Wadaba yiniyini, jumbuuna yiniyini, wabinbarran yiniyini.
\xe The sand monitor is different (itself), yellow goanna is distinct, the snapping turtle is itself (different again).
\rf GB
\xv Ngawu yiniyini mirramba.
\sfx
\xe I'll do it myself. (Don't you do it!)
\rf GB_IS
\va yinini
\sy
\cf nyubana
\cf yama
\an
\nt
\cp

\lx yirrba
\mr yirr-ba
\hm 1
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd movement
\lt X fall
\ge fall
\ge go down
\ge set (of sun)
\ge descend
\re
\so GB, EK
\xv Wajka barri nayi. Yirrba nyulu nana ngadara ngambalangi. Kudijbi barri nungka mudunama-anyi.
\sfx
\xe It's low now. That sun is setting on us. Let's go to sleep ready for tomorrow.
\rf EK (ML notes)
\va
\sy yirrbinkijbi
\cf
\an
\nt Pronounced [yidba]
\nt 
\cp Garrwa {yirrba} 'fall'
\nq
\dt

\sn 2
\ps verb
\pc
\sd Used figuratively to mean 'die'
\lt X die
\ge die
\ge pass away
\re
\so EK
\xv Mangkarri-nganja, yirrba nyulu nayi mudunyi. Ngindu barri nyulu mirraji mudunyi-anyi.
\xe His wife, when he has died (=fallen), the widow cries over the dead man.
\rf ek
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\va
\sy
\cf kudajba
\an
\nt Respectful euphemistic way of referring to death of a person.
\cp
\nq
\dt

\lx yirrbinkijbi
\mr yirrbinki-j-bi
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd motion
\lt
\ge descend
\ge fall
\ge stagger
\ge trip over
\re fall
\so RS, GB, EF, JD, MF+EM_CO
\xv Yirrbinkijbi ngawu karana.
\xe I tripped over a stone.
\rf GB
\xv Burra-daba nyulu. Yirrbinkijbi nyulu mani-wunyi, ngada-nganja-wunyi.
\xe She dropped him. He fell from his mother's hand.
\rf RS
\xv Mama nan diba-diba kunda-nanja. Yirrbinkijbi kunda-wunyi, langankini, jamba-wurru.
\xe The fruit was struck down from the tree. It fell from the tree where it was hanging, to the ground.
\rf GB
\xv Yangku nani yirrbinkijbi.
\xe He's always falling over.
\rf GB
\xv Duru yirrbinkijbi.
\xe The sun is setting.
\rf GB
\xv Kajalijini kundana ngawu yirrbinkijbi.
\xe While climbing a tree I fell down.
\rf GB
\xv Jalu-kiya ngawu yirrbinkijbi.
\xe I almost fell down.
\rf GB
\xv Yirrbinkijbi nyulu nana wanami.
\xe That rain is falling.
\rf GB
\xv Dadarrba ninji yirrbinkijini.
\xe You are sore because you fell.
\rf MF_EM_CO
\xv Najba ngawu ninya yirrbinkikurru.
\xe I saw you fall.
\rf MF_EM_CO
\xv Yirrbinkijbi wawurra.
\sfx
\xe The child fell.
\rf EF_R299B1
\va yirrbingkijbi
\sy yirrba
\cf burra-daba
\cf kulikulijibi
\nt Pronounced [yidbinkijbi]
\cp Garrwa {yirrba}
\nq Dymock (1993) records YIRRBINKI 'water', probably for 'falling (water)'
\dt 17/Oct/2006

\lx yirrkuu
\mr yirrkuwu
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd spatial
\lt be relatively short distance from
\ge close
\ge near
\re near
\so RS, CO, GB
\xv Wanamini yirrkuu.
\sfx wanamini-yirrku_CO.wav
\xe Near the water.
\rg OSBORNE_C02-000165B.TMP
\xv Ninji, jilaba ninji! Yirrkuu! Wirrkirrbi ninji! Ngakinburru.
\xe You, you come (here)! Close! Move closer! Towards me.
\rf RS
\xv Najba-nurri. Yirrkuu barri nana wanba, barrawu.
\xe We can see it. That town, settlement, is close now.
\rf rs2005-06
\xv Karrinja ngawu yirrkuu jangunu.
\xe I was standing close to the fire.
\rf RS
\xv Kanungku barri yirrkuu.
\xe It's getting closer.
\rf RS

\xe That road is nearby.

\lx yubal
\mr 
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc road.jpg
\sd spatial
\lt
\ge path
\ge road
\ge track
\re path
\so RS, GB
\xv Jilaba ngawu nukamini, yubalina barri, yuwarrana.
\xe I'm walking along the track, on the path, on the road.
\rf RS
\xv Nanajba ngamba, kadimirrana, yubalini.
\xe We waited on the little track.
\rf RS
\xv Kudanba yalu kurrkamala barri, walijin, nangulbuwarra, yubalina.
\xe There are lots of dead animals including big kangaroos on the road.
\rf RS
\xv Barulajba, jilaba yalu yubalina barri.
\xe They then go by along the road.
\rf RS
\xv Najba nurri kurrkamala kananganja, yubalina.
\xe We saw lots of emus along the road.
\rf RS
\xv Wanamii, barimbi nyulu yubal. Wanamiin, dumularraa.
\xe The rain, it wrecked the road. The water, the flowing water (did).
\rf rs
\xv Barijbi nayi yubal. Karalbanja nyulu nayi. Kurrkamala-yudu nayi karalbanja.
\xe This road is bad. It's a rocky surface. This stony ridge has a lot of small stones.
\rf RS
\xv Nanajba nungka narrunguja-anyi. Wajamba nungka yubal, wululuku-anyi.
\xe We waited for the car (to come). We were watching the road looking out for the old man.
\rf RS
\xv Mandakii, mirramba nayi yubal, yalungi.
\xe A Whitefella, he made this road for them.
\rf RS
\va yubal
\sy yiwarra
\sy yuwarra
\cf jiwarra
\nt
\cp Garrwa
\nq 
\dt 30/Apr/2009

\lx YUBURAJI
\mr
\hm
\sv
\sf
\sn 1
\ps noun
\pc
\sd animal
\sd bird

\lt
\ge Australian Magpie
\re

\xv

\sy murrarawarru
\sy ngayukudu
\cf jalburrurru
\an
\nt
\cp
\nq
\dt
\lf

\lx -yudu
\mr -yurdu
\sf
\sn 1
\ps suffix
\pc
\sd grammar
\lt comitative
\ge with
\ge having
\re with
\so RS, GB, CO
\xv Walijin kunyba. Barrulki-yudu.
\xe It is good meat, with fat.
\rf rs2003-01
\xv Bambularra-yudu, nana baribari.
\xe That comet had a tail.
\rf rs2004-07
\xv Balungka-yudu ngawu kuyi. 
\xe My head is all bloodied.
\rf rs2002-03
\xv Nana-waan, banjana yalu jilaba, ngambalangi, jalanya. Narrunguja-yudu.
\xe Those people, they are coming right behind us, with a truck.
\rf rs2002-13
\xv Barijbi ngawu, ngalya-yudu.
\xe I'm (feeling) bad with sickness.
\rf rs2005-02
\xv Kannga ngawu wanami-yudu. Ngabaa ngawu nayi bujilii. Bujili-yudu ngawu jilaba.
\xe I've come back with water. I'm bringing it in a billycan. I've come with a billycan.
\rf rs2000-08
\xv Kulu-nganja-yudu.
\xe With (my) child.
\rf RS
\xv Dara-adu ngawu.
\xe I have a dog.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Wanami-yudu ngawu.
\xe I've got some water.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Dara jila burrurri-yudu.
\xe The dog went with the man.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\va -adu
\va -du
\va -udu
\va -wudu
\sy
\cf
\nt Following a word ending in 'a' {-yudu} is pronounced as [adu] or [du] as in [mamaadu] 'with food'; following a word ending in 'u' {-yudu} is pronounced [-udu], following word ending in 'i' it is pronounced [-yudu]. Suffixed to words of more than two syllables it is reduced to [-du].
\nt Some speakers recorded by Elwyn Flint express an instrument phrase by adding {-yudu} to the instrument word plus an ergative suffix {-ni} as in {ngalika-du-ni} 'with a spearthrower'.
\cp
\nq 
\dt 26/Sep/2006

\sn 2
\ps verbal suffix
\pc
\sd grammar
\la
\lt Purposive
\ge to (do)
\ge in order to
\re
\so GB, CO
\xv Ngurrubu ngawu nan burrbijudu.
\xe I told him to run.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Budangku wanami-yanyi wakadajudu ngakaadu.
\sfx
\xe There's no water to wash myself.
\rf GB
\xv Balyanga nganyingka mani niya! Ngarajudukanyi nana wanami.
\xe Don't put your hand (into it). That water is for drinking.
\rf IS_GB78
\xv Ngurrubu ngawu nan mirrambajudu.
\xe I told him to do it.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Kannga ngamba wawurranyi yandujudu.
\sfx
\xe We went back to look after the children.
\rf MF_EM_CO
\va
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt The suffix {-udu} is attached to verb final {j} to create a purposive verb.
\cp
\nq
\dt
\lf


\lx yujurru
\mr yujurru

\sf yujurru02.wav
\ps verb
\pc
\sd body
\sd bodily product
\lt
\ge vomit
\re 
\so RS, GB, EF, JD93, CO, MB_LH12
\xv Walijbi ngawu janyi-wunyi barri, muwa-nanja. Balunbu ngawu. Balunbu ngawu, yujurru.
\xe It comes out from my mouth, from the stomach. I'm vomiting, I'm vomiting, chucking up.
\rf rs2002-04
\xv Balunbu ngawu, yujurru. Maman, muwa-nanja.
\xe I'm vomiting, chucking up. It's food from the stomach.
\rf rs2002-04
\xv Winjika yujurru nawunu?

\va

\dt 17/Oct/2006

\lx yulurri
\mr
\hm
\sf
\sn
\ps noun
\pc
\sd PEOPLE
\lt capable of inflicting damage
\ge aggressive
\ge angry
\ge dangerous
\ge fierce
\ge hot tempered
\ge murderer
\ge wild
\re aggressive
\so RS
\xv Yulurri, yulurri burrurri.
\xe He's bad tempered, he's a bad tempered man.
\rf RS2000-04
\xv Daba bulangka, yulurrii muwaa.
\xe They fought in anger.
\rf RS2002-03
\xv Mijbi nyulu ngaan, yulurrii muwaa.
\xe He swore at me in anger.
\rf RS2002-04
\xv Wurrarra yulurri.
\xe Fierce wind.
\rf RS2000-07b
\xv Jarrba niyanya, yulurrii muwaa.
\xe That dangerous one (saltwater crocodile) can eat us.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf kijibaji
\nt Idiom {yulurri muwa} 'anger belly' is used to mean 'bad tempered' or 'full of aggression and anger' as well as 'with dangerous intent'.
\cp Garrwa {yulurr}
\nq also bad tempered, angry
\dt 21/Sep/2006

\lx yunngu
\mr yunngu
\sf yunngu.wav
\sn
\ps verb
\pc
\sd time
\lt X engage in activity or be in state for a relatively long time
\ge go away for good
\ge do something permanently
\re
\so RS, GB, EF
\xv Barranyi ninji jilaba, yunngumu ninji. Budangku ninji kannga.
\xe You go away and stay away for good. Don't you return.
\rf rs2002-07
\xv Yunngu ngakinbiyangka wikijbi. Ngawu barri durrajba, ngamuyu nanangkani kiya ngaan bijbi.
\xe It (snake) kept crawling towards me. So I was afraid thinking it was going to bite me.
\rf GB(IG)
\xv Kuwini ninji jilaba, yunngu barri.
\xe You're going for good now.
\rf RS
\va
\sy
\cf dawurrumbu
\cf yanngu
\nt Sometimes translated as 'altogether' in local English.

\nq

\lx yunngujbu
\mr yunngu-j-bu
\sf
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd time
\lt X engage in activity or be in state for a relatively long time
\ge remain
\ge for good
\ge permanently
\re remain
\so RS
\xv Jilaba ninji yunngujbu. Yunngumbu ninji jilaa. Budangku ninji nangkurru kannga.
\xe You'll go for good. You go and don't come back. You won't come back here.
\rf RS2005-01
\va
\sy
\cf
\nt Combines with another verb to express long term or permanent result of verb's action.

\lf yunngu


\lx yunngumbu
\mr yunngu-mbu
\sf
\sn
\ps verb
\pc
\sd time
\lt X VERB for long time
\ge all the time
\ge for good
\ge forever
\ge keep on
\ge permanently
\ge remain
\ge stay
\re remain
\so RS, GB, EM_SK, CO, MB_LH13, MB_LH17
\xv Burrbijbi nyulu, yunngumbu.
\xe He ran off and kept away.
\rf rs2005-01
\xv Kudijbi nyulu yunngumbu.
\xe He sleeps all the time.
\rf IS_GB78
\xv Jarrba ninji, yunngumbu. Yaku ninji jarrba.
\xe You eat all the time. Stop eating.
\rf GB(IV)
\xv Wanduraba nanangkani yunngumbu, warrakujini.
\xe That one barks all the time. It's mad.
\rf GB(IG)
\xv Jarrarra ngawu yunngumbu.
\xe I keep on yawning.
\rf GB(IG)
\xv Daba bulangka yunngumbu.
\xe They fight the whole time.
\rf GB(IG)
\xv Jilaba nana wanamin. Jila nyulu yunngumbu barri. 
\xe Those clouds have gone. They've gone for good now.
\rf GB(IG)
\xv Jilaba barri nurri, yanngu. Yunngumbu. Budangku nurri kanngaa.
\xe We are going away now, for good. We are staying away. We are not coming back.
\rf RS
\xv Yunngumbu nyulu burrbijbi.
\xe He ran away for good.
\rf RS
\xv Budangku nyulu kannga ngambalangi. Yakujbu ngambalanya. Yunngumbu. Kudajba.
\xe He won't come back to us. He's left us for good. He has died.
\rf RS
\xv Yunngumbu ngamba yanyba Waanyi. 
\xe We are still speaking Waanyi.
\rf C02-000165B.TMP
\xv Dara nyulu nana wanduraba yunngumbu.
\sfx
\xe That dog was barking for a long time.
\rf EM_SK
\xv Jungku ngawu yunngumbu.
\xe I stayed a long time.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\xv Dabarraba ngawu waliji yunngumbu.
\xe I cooked the meat for a long time.
\rf MF+EM_CO
\va yurrngumbu (?)
\sy
\cf dawurrumbu
\cf yanngu
\nt Combines with another verb to express long term or permanent action.
\cp
\nq gather? Breen ex 17 2000
\dt 17/Oct/2006

\lx -yurru

\lt Allative suffix
\ge into
\ge to
\ge towards
\re
\so RS, GB

\xe They are now jumping into the water.

\xe To home now.
\rf RS
\va -kurru
\va -ngkurru
\va -wurru
\sy
\cf
\an
\nt {-yurru} is added to words ending in vowel {i}.

\sfx

\rf IS_GB

\lx yurru-kadi
\mr yurru-kadi-j-bi
\sf yurru-kadi.wav
\sn 1
\ps verb
\pc
\sd hold (holding and transfer)
\lt Xerg cause Y to be inside or under something
\ge put into
\ge put under
\ge swallow
\re
\so RS, JD, GB
\xv Yurru-kadi ngaka wanamini.
\sfx yurrukadi ngaka wanamini.aif
\xe I'm getting into the water.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Yurru-kadi wanami-wurru.
\sfx yurrukadi wanami-wurru.wav
\xe Put into water.
\rf RS2005-04
\xv Yurru-kadi nyulu kala-wunyi barrawunu lungkajii kijibajii.
\xe The cheeky policeman took him from his place and put him into a jail cell.
\rf RS
\xv Yurru-kadi nurri dandi, kara, muwana.
\xe We put hot stones, rocks, in the belly (of animal being cooked in earth oven).
\rf RS
\xv Kirriya-darraa, mularrijbi yalu. Yurru-kadi yalu, narrungujana. 
\xe The women, they lifted him up. They put him into the car.
\rf RS2005-08a
\xv Yurru-kadi ngawu, ngadijbi ngawu, ngakinkanyini. Kalawunyi, bindawarrana. 
\xe I'll put it inside, I'll hide it in mine. Inside the bag.
\rf rs2005-05
\xv Yurru-kadi yalu bala janyini, kakunu.
\xe They put the hook in the fish's mouth.
\rf RS
\xv Yurru-kadi yalu ngadarru banmarrana.
\xe They stick the bunch of feathers into the headdress (for ceremony).
\rf RS
\xv Yurru-kadi yalu kumayangunu.
\xe They put him (deceased) into a cave.
\rf JD93
\va yurru-kadijbi
\sy
\cf buju-kadi
\cf burru-kadi
\cf jarrkarra
\cf nijbi
\nt {Yurru-kadi} is used with reflexive pronoun to mean 'enter' or 'go into'.
\cp
\nq to come to be inside something ; swallowing ; yurrukadi, trans
\dt
\lf yurru-kadijbi
\lf yurru-kadikanyi
\lf yurru-yurru-kadi
